Around 1 September 2018 (as reported), Chinese authorities had issued orders that small religious gatherings of less than three participants could also be subjected to persecution and were to be reported by locals. This new order would impact house churches in particular.

On 2 September 2018, around 100 police officers stormed into a Christian meeting venue during gathering in Luohe (Henan), and shut down the church as part of a region-wide campaign to crack down on churches and suppress religious belief. The police instructed the director of the neighborhood committee to change the locks of the venue, and arranged for local thugs to intimidate believers of the church.

On 2 September 2018, local government employees officiated the opening of the ''Gaozhuang village People's Activity Centre'' in Zhanglin town, Zhenping County (Nanyang, Henan) with a celebration attended by over 100 people. The ''activity centre'' was previously a Three-Self Church which has been taken over by the government. All religious symbols have been removed and replace with recreational facilities.

On 2 September 2018, nearly 100 government forces from multiple authorities sealed off a church in Panyu, Guangzhou and arrested 7 people during the raid. Believers who tried to photograph the scene also got their phones confiscated during the incident.

On 5 September 2018, more than 30 people from the police and urban management bureau forcibly demolished a shop owned by a human rights activist located in Yangpu District, Shanghai. The authorities claimed that the shop was ''illegal''.

On 5 September 2018, local authorities confiscated religious books, equipment and all valuables totaling about 100,000 RMB at a meeting venue of the Great Praise house church in Nanyang city (Henan) after the church's leader refused to join Three-Self Patriotic Movement. They tore down pictures and crosses from the wall, then sealed off the venue.

On 5 September 2018, the local government demolished the Enfu Church in Huixiaoying village (Nanyang, Henan) in retaliation of believers of the house church posting videos of the government tearing up a painting of the cross inside the church.

On 5 September 2018, between dozens to hundreds of police and government employees raided Huixiaoying Church in Tongzhaipu Town, Tanghe county (Nanyang, Henan) as part of a fresh campaign to remove crosses from churches. This was one of a few churches targeted by authorities on this day, where authorities were reported to have forcibly removed the cross, cleared out the church, and set fire to bibles and the cross. It was also reported that believers who tried to stop the damage were either arrested or dragged away.

On 5 September 2018, hundreds of police and government employees raided Guangcai Church in Wolong district (Nanyang, Henan). They smashed the cross of the church, cleared out everything from the church, and then set fire to the cross, bibles, and hymn books. Churchgoers who heard about the incident rushed to the scene to try to prevent it, but were forcibly dragged away by the police or government employees. As a result, they sustained soft tissue injuries all over their bodies. On the same day, several other churches in Nanyang city were targeted in a similar manner as part of a fresh campaign to remove crosses from churches.

On 5 September 2018, between dozens to hundreds of police and government employees raided Jinglou Church in Tanghe county (Nanyang, Henan) as part of a fresh campaign to remove crosses from churches. This was one of a few churches targeted by authorities on this day, where authorities were reported to have forcibly removed the cross, cleared out the church, and set fire to bibles and the cross. It was also reported that believers who tried to stop the damage were either arrested or dragged away.

On 5 September 2018, between dozens to hundreds of police and government employees raided Qiupo Church at Dongwangji Town, Tanghe county (Nanyang, Henan) as part of a fresh campaign to remove crosses from churches. This was one of a few churches targeted by authorities on this day, where authorities were reported to have forcibly removed the cross, cleared out the church, and set fire to bibles and the cross. It was also reported that believers who tried to stop the damage were either arrested or dragged away.
Around 7 September 2018 (as reported), local authorities forcibly shut down two mosques in Liugong Village (Shihezi, Xinjiang), removing its crescent and star symbols and blocking its entrance.

On 7 September 2018, the Caodian Three-Self Church in Lushan county (Pingdingshan, Henan) was demolished by local authorities despite being promised that gatherings could be held after paying a fine last month. This was related to a series of harassment and demolition of Three-Self Churches in the Henan Province.

On 7 September 2018, local town authorities demolished Xilin Temple in Linan town (Putian, Fujian) to take the land for a real estate development with private companies. The government had not discussed this with the temple administration and the public, and claimed that ''the government was more important than Bodhisattva, so, the temple must be demolished if authorities want to use the land.''
On 7 September 2018, nearly one hundred government personnel sealed off a Three-Self church in Miaonan village of Mangshan town (Luoyang, Henan), and seized about 100,000 RMB in donation money.

On 8 September 2018, a newly-built church in Pingdingshan (Henan) was demolished by the local authority. Over 50 police officers, two excavators, two ambulances, and over a dozen other vehicles were deployed, and the church was demolished as part of a governmental campaign to suppress religious belief in the region.

On 9 September 2018, the Bureau of Civil Affairs of Beijing Chaoyang District closed down Zion Church in Chaoyang District (Beijing), and released official announcement to outlaw the house church, and 20 to 30 vehicles including fire engines and ambulances were deployed. Evicted church followers were transferred to a hotel. The priest of the church was taken into custody by the personnel from several governmental departments, and four followers of the church were taken into the bus used to carry the evicted followers.

On 10 September 2018, around 70 local officials forcefully shut down an underground Protestant church located in Chaoyang District, Beijing, confiscating all properties of the church and sealed off the church itself. There were no reports of injuries.
On 10 September 2018, a Three-Self Patriotic church in Fuyang (Anhui) was demolished by the local authorities as a part of campaign in Anhui to crack down religious belief.

On 12 September 2018, in the morning, more than 30 rights protection-seeking citizens were arrested by the local police when they lit firecrackers to celebrate the release of a prisoner at the First Detention Center of Fuzhou located in Jin'an District (Fuzhou, Fujian). After a month, police released most of them from custody, except making charges for four people for 'picking quarrels and provoking trouble.'

On 13 September 2018, more than 50 vehicles and about 800 police officers were dispatched by the Religious Affairs Bureau, Public Security Bureau, and local government of Yanshi city, Henan to demolish the government-approved Protestant church Dongcun Church in Dakou town (Luoyang, Henan). Before the demolition, police had detained the person in charge of the church and upon hearing this news, more than 20 believers knelt at the church entrance, crying and praying to protect the church from being demolished. They were removed by the police officers and detained in a nearby factory until the demolition was complete, 17 hours later. In April, the government had ordered that the church be demolished because the members of the church refused to raise the Chinese national flag and sing the national anthem, and congregants had opposed multiple attempts to demolish the church since then.

On 14 September 2018, more than 100 police and officials of the local Administration of Religious Affairs broke into a Protestant Church located in Zhengzhou, Henan, smashing the facilities inside the church, confiscating Bibles, chorus books and the offering box. The Police eventually banned the church by accusing the church of conducting religious activities in unreligious regions.

Around 15 September 2018 (month of), a local government official ordered the head priests of a Daoist Temple to hand over the keys to their temples in Cijian Town (Luoyang City, Henan Province) within three days. It was further reported that after the head priests had handed over the keys, they were coerced to take down the temple signboards and Daoist flags, destroy the incense burners, and erect the national flag.

Around 15 September 2018 (month of), the Jinzhou authorities ordered Qingyan Temple in Changxingdian town, Beizhen City (Jinzhou City, Liaoning Province) to remove all of its 800 white marble Arhat statues. The destruction lasted for over a month and cost the temple more than 500,000 RMB. The inscriptions on the statue's bases were also scrapped off. This was part of a broader campaign to remove large outdoor religious symbols across China.

Around 15 September 2018 (month of), a 24-meter-tall reclining Shakyamuni Buddha statue in Lingbao Temple in Hunchun city (Yanbian Korean Autonomous, Jilin Province) was removed by the authorities because ''open-air Buddhist statues are exposed to the wind and rain, which is disrespectful to Buddha.''

Around 15 September 2018 (month of), 508 white jade Arhat statues in Ganjingzi District of Dalian City, Liaoning Province were removed by the local authorities because ''they were deemed illegal''. This was part of a broader campaign to remove large outdoor religious symbols across China.

Around 15 September 2018 (month of), more than 138 churches in 6 districts across 9 counties of Luoyang City (Henan) were taken over by the government and repurposed for the government's ''alleged need'' for communist party schools, cultural centres, and activity hubs.

Around 15 September 2018 (month of), the Xiuyan County Ethnic and Religious Affairs Bureau ordered workers to destroy the statues of Lord Guan and Guanyin at the thousand-year-old Buddhist Guanyin'gou Temple at Longquan Lake in Xiuyan Manchu Autonomous County (Liaoning). Workers toppled down the statues and used sledgehammers to destroy them. Based on claims that the statues were illegal and too large, the act reflected ''an escalation'' in religious persecution by regional CCP authorities. Six resident monks and three nuns were expelled.

Around 15 September 2018 (month of), at least 20 churches in Dengzhou City (Nanyang, Henan) were taken over by the government and repurposed for the government's ''alleged need'' for communist party schools, cultural centres, and activity hubs.

Around 15 September 2018 (month of), a house church meeting venue in Tongjiang City (Jiamusi, Heilongjiang), which was purchased with funds raised by the believers, was converted into a senior activity centre. Although the believers retain ownership of the meeting venue, they're prohibited from holding religious services there. This is part of a state-led campaign to convert houses of worship into non-religious government-sanctioned activity centres.

Around 15 September 2018 (month of), a 37-metre Guanyin statue in the Niuwangzhai scenic area in Xingtang County (Shijiazhuang City, Hebei Province) was forcibly demolished on orders of the local government. It was reported that provincial Party secretary of Xingtang County personally inspected the demolition, as the Party secretary and the county mayor would both be dismissed from their respective positions if the statue was not completely taken down. This was part of a broader campaign to demolish all large outdoor religious statues.

Around 15 September 2018 (month of), a Buddhist temple in Xinzheng city (Zhengzhou, Henan) was sealed off by the local authority. The local authority claims that the temple has no permit to operate, while it might be related to the crackdown of religious venues throughout China.

Around 15 September 2018 (month of), the Buddha statue in Jiushan Buddhist temple in Huixian (Xinxiang, Henan) was demolished within two weeks under the order of the local government as part of a campaign to demolish religious symbols.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of China (2012-) People's Armed Police
NOTES: Around 15 September 2018 (month of), thousands of Muslims held in the re-education camps in Kashi prefecture (Xinjiang) were transferred to other provinces by the People's Armed Police from outside of Xinjiang. The transfer was intended to hide the large number of Muslim populations in Xinjiang re-education camps from international attention.

Around 15 September 2018 (month of), the cross from a Three-Self Church in Huangzhuang Village (Puyang City, Henan Province) was removed by government personnel, on the grounds that the cross must be dismantled in order to create a ''civilised county''.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of China (2012-) People's Armed Police
NOTES: Around 15 September 2018 (month of), an 18-metre Buddha statue of Shakyamuni in Anning City (Kunming City, Yunnan Province) was forcibly demolished by more than 70 personnel from the city's Ethnic and Religious Affairs Bureau, United Front Work Department, armed police force and other departments. This was part of a broader campaign to demolish all large outdoor religious statues.

Around 15 September 2018 (month of), two Catholic churches in Qishan County (Baoji City, Shaanxi Province) were repurposed into ''Cultural Activity Centres'' by the county authorities. The authorities claimed that the church did not receive the formal approval from authorities and were ''illegal buildings''. Instead of being demolished, the crosses from the churches were removed and the words ''Catholic Church'' were replaced with signs stating that it was a ''Cultural Activity Centre''.
On 16 September 2018, local authorities removed the cross from a church in Erqi District (Zhengzhou, Henan) and then completely destroyed it.

On 20 September 2018, the cross of a Three-Self church in Luji Village (Puyang City, Henan Province) was dismantled by personnel from various departments, including the city's Ethnic and Religious Affairs Committee and the county's Religious Affairs Bureau. The removal of the cross happened after a stand-off between the church members and the government personnel, which started on the evening of 19 September 2018. During the stand-off, church members gathered at the road in front of the church to block the demolition, and sang hymns when the cross was dismantled.

On 21 September 2018, the Guanyin Statue in Jiuding Lotus Mountain in Yiyuan (Zibo, Shandong) was demolished by the local government after the Religious Affairs Bureau took the ownership of the statue from the funder. This is a part of nationwide crackdown on large open-air religious statues.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of China (2012-) People's Armed Police
NOTES: On 22 September 2018, officials from the Public Security Bureau, United Front Work Department, Religious Affairs Bureau, special police force, and other departments sealed off a house church in Tongjiang City (Jiamusi, Heilongjiang) and forcibly cut and destroyed the cross on the church. The pastors of the church were also prohibited from preaching by the Religious Affairs Bureau after they were accused by the administration of having ''foreign affiliation'' because the officials from the city's Religious Affairs Bureau and Public Security Bureau found religious books from South Korea during a search in the church. More than 300 believers were forced to disperse after losing their meeting venue.

On 23 September 2018, 5 government employees from the national United Front Work Department forced a church in Shandong to hang national flag and sing the national anthem during the sermon. Because the pastor refused to comply, the church was shut down.

ACTOR1: Government of China (2017-) Hong Kong Special Administrative Region
SOURCE: South China Morning Post; Wen Wei Po; Radio Free Asia
NOTES: On 24 September 2018, the Hong Kong Government officially banned the pro-independence Hong Kong National Party (HKNP) on the basis that it posed a threat to national security and public order. The ban is the first of its kind in Hong Kong. On 26 Feb 2019, the Hong Kong Government announced that the party's appeal had been rejected, that the ban was final, and that the central government had expressed its support for the ban and requested that the Chief Executive send them a report on the matter.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Former Police Forces of China (2012-); INTERPOL: International Criminal Police Organization
NOTES: Arrests: On 25 September 2018, the former chief of Interpol and China's former vice-minister of Public Security Meng Hongwei went missing after returning to China from Interpol's headquarters in France and was suspected to have been forcibly disappeared. Two weeks later, the National Supervisory Commission acknowledged that they had detained him for a criminal investigation.
On 26 September 2018, the Sui'an Temple in Baizi (Tongnan, Chongqing), a Buddhist temple, was destroyed by local officials with the intent to suppress religious beliefs.
On 27 September 2018, the Longwang Temple and the Baique Temple in Baizi (Tongnan, Chongqing), two Buddhist temples, were destroyed by local officials with the intent to suppress religious beliefs.

On 27 September 2018, the local authority tore down the cross of the Christian church on West Street in Chengguan Town (Kaifeng, Henan). It is a part of a campaign in Henan Province to suppress Christian churches.
On 30 September 2018, around 200 Christian groups at Xujixiang (Xinyang, Henan) were closed by the government in the campaign to suppress christian groups.
On 30 September 2018, the Renai Guizheng Christian groups in Guiyang (Guizhou) were closed by the department on religious affairs of the government in the campaign to suppress christian groups.

Around 30 September 2018 (end of month), the Maitreya Buddha statue in Ruzhou (Pingdingshan, Henan) was demolished under the order of the local United Front Work Department as part of a campaign to demolish religious symbols.
On 1 October 2018, the government in Pingdingshan city (Henan) assigned people to take down the cross and demolish some houses of the church in the campaign of suppress Christian groups.

Around 2 October 2018, ten days after the signing of the Vatican-China deal around 22 September 2018, local officials from the United Front Work Department ordered believers to hire a crane to remove the statues of at least three Chinese martyred saints from a Catholic church in Dongxihetou village (Hengshui, Hebei). They threatened to seize assets from the church if the church refused.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of China (2012-) People's Armed Police
NOTES: On 5 October 2018, a Lao-Tzu statue in Laojuntang in Xingyang county (Henan) was demolished by the Special Weapons and Tactics Unit police as part of a campaign to demolish religious symbols ordered by the local Ethnic and Religious Affairs Committee.

On 7 October 2018, a Christian church in Shangqiu City (Henan) was converted into a cultural practice and service centre for the local community. The week before, the local authorities had forcibly closed down the church and sealed and locked the door. It was a part of a campaign in Henan Province to suppress Christian churches.

On 10 October 2018, several Buddhist statues and a Buddhist temple in Baizi (Tongnan, Chongqing), including two Buddhist statues in Bajiao Temple in Shuangmen Village, a number of Buddhist statues in a Buddhist temple in Donglin village, and the Ma'ansan Temple, were destroyed by the local government. The demolitions of religious venues and symbols were intended to curb the religious beliefs in the region.

On 10 October 2018, the CCP enacted a new Amended Anti-Extremism Regulation, which legalized and standardized the transformation through education camps for ''people who have been affected by extremist thoughts'' in the Xinjiang Autonomous Region. The regulation legitimizes camps in Xinjiang, which reportedly could apply to members of all religions not approved and controlled by CCP, where they can be detained in the camps or even given ''harsher'' punishments.

On 12 October 2018, a provincial inspection team conducted an inspection of a government-controlled Catholic church in Yuzhou city. Inspectors ordered officials from the Religious Affairs Bureau to remove the church's cross and sign and replace them with the national flag and political slogans. The church had been complying with the government's other orders of ''sinicisation'' since July 2018.

On 12 October 2018, a Buddhist temple in Huludao City, Liaoning Province had all its doors and windows sealed off with plasterboard by personnel on orders of government officials. All Buddhist items inside the temple were also seized. The entrace was completely sealed off with bricks. This was part of a broader campaign to crack down on religious venues, on the grounds that they did not possess the relevant permits and were forcibly shut down or demolished.

On 12 October 2018, Religious Affairs Bureau officials sealed off the Linggan Temple in Yitang town of Yunmeng county (Xiaogan, Hubei) on the grounds that it did not have a relgious activity venue registration certificate.

On 14 October 2018, officers from the Urban Administrative and Law Enforcement Bureau broke into the house of a female petitioner in Yangjiang town (Wuxi, Jiangsu) through the window, tore down banners with President Xi's sayings and stole 2,300 RMB in cash as a ''punishment'' for her petitioning efforts against forced evictions.
On 14 October 2018, the Ronggui Lane Church which is a house church in Guangzhou (Guangdong) was shut down by the local government as a strategy of religious persecution.

Around 15 October 2018 (week of), several underground church meeting venues in Dingzhou city (Hebei) were forcibly shut down by the authorities. Church members were also required to have sermons by government-assigned priests, and will be arrested if they did not comply.

Around 15 October 2018 (week of), an underground Catholic church in Qiaoxi district (Xingtai, Hebei) was sealed off by the authorities on the grounds that the relevant procedures had not been completed. The authorities also arranged for personnel to arrest the priest once he enters the church.

Around 16 October 2018 (month of), a sign reading ''Zhangjin Village Cultural Activity Centre'' was posted on the entrance to the Three-Self Church of Zhangjin Village/Zhangjincun in Zhicheng Town (Jiyuan, Henan) as part of a state-led province-wide campaign to convert houses of worship into non-religious government-sanctioned activity centres.
Around 16 October 2018 (month of), the meeting venue of a Catholic church in Taiyuan City, Shanxi Province was shut down, after the church refused to join the Chinese Patriotic Catholic Association.

Around 16 October 2018 (month of), a house church's meeting venue located near the Fuzhou University district in Gulou District (Fuzhou City, Fujian Province) was raided and shut down by more than a dozen police officers from the local police station. During the raid, they also took photos and registered the information of each of the 60 to 70 students present at the venue.
Around 16 October 2018 (month of), a Taoist statue of Laozi in Xingyang City (Zhengzhou City, Henan Province) was demolished by authorities, on the grounds that it was an ''illegal construction''.

Around 16 October 2018 (month of), a Buddhist temple on Bijia Mountain in Zunhua City (Tangshan City, Hebei Province) was forcibly shut down by the authorities. It was reported that after shutting down the temple, the authorities continued to monitor the temple using an aerial drone.

Around 16 October 2018 (month of), a house church in Jintai district (Baoji, Shaanxi) was pressured by authorities to raise the national flag, put up a portrait of Mao Zedong, and post up slogans of the core socialist values. To remain open, the congregation also had to stop singing hymns after personnel from the Religious Affairs Bureau arrived during their worship sessions, as they were ordered to only sing songs praising the Party. This is part of the ''red revolution'' (sinicisation) campaign launched against churches in Baoji city.

Around 16 October 2018 (month of), a kindergarten established by a Catholic church in Cangzhou City, Hebei Province was shut down by the government on the grounds that it was ''unlicensed''. It was part of a broader campaign by the government to crack down on church-established schools, in order to prevent access to religious education for minors.
Around 16 October 2018 (month of), a Christian Three-Self church in Zibo (Shandong) was demolished by the local authorities as a part of campaign in Shandong to crack down religious belief.

Around 16 October 2018 (month of), the head of a Daoist Temple in Gaolan County (Lanzhou City, Gansu Province) was forced to lock up the main hall of the temple and hand over the keys to the authorities, under the pretext of ''eliminating of outmoded conventions''. A pole for the national flag and a bulletin board with the ''four requirements'' were placed outside the temple.

Around 16 October 2018 (month of), the statue of the Holy Virgin was removed from the courtyard of an underground Catholic church in Gucheng County (Hengshui City, Hebei Province) by the local government. The church's cross was also dismantled, and the venue was sealed off on the grounds that the gathering venue ''was unlicensed and thus illegal''.

Around 16 October 2018 (middle of month), the Taiwang Temple in Yangxin County (Huangshi, Hubei) was sealed off by the local government. It was among many cases of closing down and demolishing religious venues throughout China, which were intended to suppress religious belief.

Around 16 October 2018 (month of), the Buddhist Xiuling Temple in Tieshan District (Huangshi City, Province) was closed down by the authorities, on the grounds that there were ''unlicensed'' religious venues.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of China (2012-) People's Armed Police
NOTES: Around 16 October 2018 (middle of month), Machi Church, the largest underground Catholic Church in Baotou city, was raided by authorities. Later the same day, over 300 special and armed police surrounded the church to force members to accept a government-assigned priest from the Chinese Patriotic Catholic Association (CPCA) of Qingshan District (Baotou, Inner Mongolia).

Around 16 October 2018 (month of), a house church meeting venue in Bazhou City (Langfang, Hebei) was shut down due to its proximity to a kindergarten. This is part of a government crackdown on religious facilities near schools, which is linked to the revised Regulations on Religious Affairs that came into forced on 1 February 2018.

Around 16 October 2018 (month of), the congregation venue of the Maoling Church in Potou town (Jiyuan, Henan) was cleared out and converted into a ''Wedding and Funeral Council'' as part of a state-led province-wide campaign to convert houses of worship into non-religious government-sanctioned activity centres.

Around 16 October 2018 (month of), two government officials and the village secretary bricked up the entrance and windows of Zushi Temple in Huangshi prefecture (Hubei), then evicted a Buddhist resident and ordered her to move into a crude building where the deceased would be housed before burial.

Around 16 October 2018 (month of), the Three-Self Church of Jianmiaocun/Jianmiao village in Ningling County (Shangqiu, Henan) was cleared out by the CCP on the grounds that it was ''too close to the village committee,'' and was converted into a ''villagers' recreational activity centre.'' This is part of a state-led province-wide campaign to convert houses of worship into non-religious government-sanctioned activity centres.

Around 16 October 2018 (month of), the Three-Self Church of Huacunpu Village in Weishi County (Kaifeng, Henan) was converted into a ''cultural activity venue'' as part of a state-led province-wide campaign to convert houses of worship into non-religious government-sanctioned activity centres.

Around 16 October 2018 (month of), religious paintings and crosses were removed from a Three-Self Church in Changchun City, Jilin Province by the government. A ''Culture Book House'' was also set up in the church, and filled with propaganda materials promoting Xi Jinping's thought and Maoism.
Around 16 October 2018 (month of), a Buddhist temple was shut down by authorities in Qianxi county (Tangshan, Hebei).

Around 16 October 2018 (month of), religious and education officials from central, provincial, and municipal governments ordered the principal of a Catholic school with 300 students in Handan City (Hebei) to shut down the school on the basis that ''churches were not allowed to participate in education''.

Around 16 October 2018 (month of), the exterior walls of a Buddhist temple in Guichi District (Chizhou City, Anhui Province) were painted white on orders of government officials, and its incense burners were destroyed. This is reportedly part of a government campaign to crackdown on colours it deems too religious, like the yellow and dark red that have come to symbolize Buddhist temples.

Around 16 October 2018 (month of), a massive removal of Arabic symbols took place in Mengcun Hui Autonomous County (Cangzhou, Hebei), which has a high Hui Muslim population. Arabic signs and symbols were removed from all restaurants, grocery stores and shops. This was undertaken as part of a campaign launched by Hebei authorities last year to remove Arabic symbols.

Around 16 October 2018 (month of), the yellow walls of a Buddhist temple in Huangshi City, Hubei Province were painted white, with the Chinese characters for ''Amitabha'' on the wall replaced with a phrase ''the country flourishes and the people live in peace''. The name of the temple was also changed. This is reportedly part of a government campaign to crackdown on colours it deems too religious, like the yellow and dark red that have come to symbolize Buddhist temples.

Around 16 October 2018 (month of), Chinese authorities in Xinjiang had begun covertly sending detainees to prisons in Heilongjiang province and other parts of China to address an ''overflow'' in overcrowded camps.

Around 16 October 2018 (month of), the authorities in Xinjiang transferred up to 1 million Chinese Muslims in its re-education camps to other provinces in China, and released hundreds of Muslim detainees from the re-education camps in Ili prefecture.

On 18 October 2018, a Buddhist temple in Shenzhou City (Hengshui City, Hebei Province) was demolished by about 30 demolition workers under the orders of the local authorities, on the grounds that it was an ''illegal building''. 12 Bodhisattva statues were also destroyed.

On 19 October 2018, a house church in Yaopu Town, Tieling City (Liaoning) was shut down by local government officials after it refused to join the state-sanctioned Protestant Three-Self Church. This closure follows a meeting of neighbourhood committee employees convened by the United Front Work Department to launch a crackdown on religious home gatherings.

On 19 October 2018, the memorial archway at the entrance of Mount Jiuhua, one of the four sacred mountains of Chinese Buddhism, in Qingyang County (Chizhou, Anhui) was demolished by the local bureaus of Public Security and Urban Management under the ''sinicization'' policy. It was reported that the Dabeilou Temple guesthouse and a Buddha statue carved in a cave at Mount Jiuhua were also destroyed by authorites as part of the same campaign.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of China (2012-) People's Armed Police
NOTES: On 20 October 2018, a Maitreya statue in the Dongwo Scenic Area of Longmatan District (Luzhou City, Sichuan Province) was demolished by over 200 individuals made up of traffic police, special police and migrant workers. It was reported that on the day before the demolition, the local Ethnic and Religious Affairs Bureau issued a notice stating that the statue violated a provision of the new Regulations on Religious Affairs which prohibits ''the construction of large outdoor religious statues outside of temples and churches''.

On 22 October 2018, officials from the Religious Affairs Bureau of Ningjin county (Xingtai, Hebei) stormed into a local underground Catholic church and forced believers to religious symbols. The officials then sealed off the church with barricade tape on the basis that it was unlicensed and that its priest was not recognised by the government.

On 22 October 2018, four Buddhist temples in Guichi District (Chizhou City, Anhui Province) were shut down by the local government. All of the temples were also painted white, and a number of the temples had their Buddhist-related symbols and incense burners destroyed.

LOCATION: Minhe Hui and Tu Autonomous County
NOTES: On 23 October 2018, a Taoist temple in Minhe Hui and Tu Autonomous County (Haidong City, Qinghai Province) was forcibly demolished by the government, on the grounds that it was an ''illegal construction''. This was part of a broader campaign on religious activities following the introduction of the new Regulations on Religious Affairs, requiring religious venues to be approved and issued a registration certificate by the local government.

On 24 October 2018, the local authorities tore down the angel statue and the cross in front of the Qikushan Cathedral at the top of a mountain in Dong'ergou Village (Taiyuan, Shanxi), on the grounds that ''there was a large amount of holy statues and crosses in Qiku mountain, which violated the regulations''.

On 24 October 2018, the local authorities tore down a Catholic church in Anlong County (Qianxinan, Guizhou) with large-sized mechanical equipment, jackhammer, and other equipment. Previously, the cathedral received warning from the Urban Management And Law Enforcement Department that the building was ''illegal'' and should be torn down by the church itself by 20 October 2018, or the government would forcibly tear it down if the church failed to do so.

On 24 October 2018, the gathering of about ten members of the Guang Zhou Gengxin Christian group was forcibly dispersed in Xiashan district (Zhanjiang, Guangdong) by police officers, the officials from administration of religious affairs, and sub-district officers. The officers demanded that the group stop their gatherings and also ordered the landlord to withdraw the rental contract with the Christian group.

On 25 October 2018, government employees dismantled the cross and signs of a government-approved Protestant church in Shangrao city (Jiangxi) and converted it into an ''activity centre.'' This is part of a state-led campaign to convert houses of worship into non-religious government-sanctioned activity centres.

On 25 October 2018, the local government of Luoyang City, accompanied by the local sub-district office, closed down a church in Jianxi District (Luoyang, Henan), sealed the door, and loaded all church properties to a lorry and took them away for the reason that the church was not registered, and the church will be forcibly torn down. It is a part of the campaign in Henan Province to suppress Christian churches.

On 26 October 2018, the Religious Affairs Bureau in Donggang City (Dandong, Liaoning) hired ''local ruffians'' to destroy 34 statues in a Daoist temple after the temple manager refused to destroy them himself. This is part of a nationwide campaign to ''sinicise'' religion.

On 27 October 2018, the cross on the top of a local church in Huijiabao in Matou town (Langfang, Hebei) was demolished by the local authorities. It was reported that the demolition continued until 28 October 2018.

On 28 October 2018, the Living Springs Church in Xiamen (Fujian) had to shut down due to the pressure from the local officials on the landlady to end the rental contract with the church. It is a part of a nationwide campaign to shut down house churches.

On 28 October 2018, the police and more than 20 government officials went to stop the gathering of Changsha Mars Church Group, and when the followers came back, the door plate was demolished and the locker was smashed. Authorities asked the group to register as a ''Three-self'' Church recognized by the Chinese government.
On 28 October 2018, the gathering of Christian group was disrupted in Lanxi (Jinhua, Zhejiang) by the local authority and were forbidden from holding religious gatherins of more than 5 people.
On 28 October 2018, two Christian house churchs in Jiangxia district (Wuhan, Hubei) was banned in Jiangxia by the local administration of religious affairs.

On 28 October 2018, the gathering of Guang Zhou Taojin Christian group was disrupted in Guangzhou (Guangdong) by five police officers and sub-district officers. The police put iron fences to keep the followers away from the house.

On 29 October 2018, a Three-Self church in Zhaochang village (Xinxiang, Henan) was demolished by the authorities without credible explanation. Members of the congregation who rushed to the church to prevent the demolition were stopped by police who cordoned off the area. Ealier, in August 2018, the church had been sealed off and emptied by the local authorities as well.

SOURCE: Bitter Winter; South China Morning Post
NOTES: Around 30 October 2018 (between 28 Oct to 1 Nov 2018), 35 memorial temples (places of worship commemorating prominent people) and Buddhist temples in Xinmi City (Zhengzhou, Henan), including one that was built centuries ago, were shut down or sealed off and had their banners removed as part of a county-wide operation to implement government policies cracking down on religion.

On 30 October 2018, the walls of a Buddhist temple in Ruichang City (Jiujiang City, Jiangxi Province) were painted white, on orders of the municipal government. According to one of the monks of the temple, the government said the yellow colour of the outer walls of the temple were too ''conspicuous'', and that the temple would be shut down or demolished if it wasn't repainted. This is reportedly part of a government campaign to crackdown on colours it deems too religious, like the yellow and dark red that have come to symbolize Buddhist temples.

Around 31 October 2018 (end of month), a house church in Yanshou County (Harbin, Heilongjiang) was forced to stop holding gatherings on pain of being fined or arrested after receiving a notice from the county's Bureau of Ethnic and Religious Affairs. The believers consequently broke up into smaller groups and convened in secret elsewhere.

Around 31 October 2018 (end of month), a Christian's home in Liaoning Province being used as a religious meeting place was closed down by police officers from the Liaoyang City Public Security Bureau. Police searched her home, tore down the cross in her home, confiscated bibles, a donation box, and other items.

Around 31 October 2018 (end of month), a Three-Self Church in Nanyang City, Henan Province was raided and shut down by local authorities. This was part of a broader campaign to crack down on both house churches and Three-Self churches in the country.

Around 31 October 2018 (end of month), Religious Affairs Bureau officials ordered church members to remove the statues of two French Jesuit priests from a Catholic Patriotic Association Church in Wuyi county (Hengshui, Hebei). They threatened to excavate the statues and the pavilions in the courtyard if the church refused.

Around 1 November 2018 (beginning of month), urban management officers removed halal signage and Arabic symbols from restaurants, shops and market places on Zijincheng Street and Jiefang Road in Kongtong district (Pingliang, Gansu). This was part of a campaign to crackdown on the ''spread of halal'' in areas inhabited by Hui Muslims.

Around 1 November 2018 (beginning of month), the local government started the demolition of two large outdoor Guanyin statues from a temple in Xixiang County (Hanzhong City, Shaanxi Province). The complete demolition of the statues took two months, with the demolition of the second statue beginning on 28 December 2018.

On 1 November 2018, village and county government authorities began to dismantle religious portraits at an underground Catholic church in Baizhuang Village (Pingdingshan, Henan), as ''a punishment for the church's refusal to join the Chinese Patriotic Catholic Association.'' They forbade worship activities to take place, eventually destroying all religious symbols and furnishings over the course of 12 days.

Around 2 November 2018, a month after 2 October, local village officers forced members of the Catholic Dechao Church in Shenzhou county (Hebei) to dismantle their statues of Jesus and a Chinese martyred saint in order prevent their church from being demolished. The entrance of Dechao church was also blocked.

On 4 November 2018, a 23 years old Tibetan, who was a resident of Choeje-Ma Township Jhakorma village-level division, committed self-immolation and died in Ngawa County (Ngawa, Sichuan) in support of Dalai Lama. During the self-immolation, he shouted prayers of long life for Dalai Lama and his right to return to Tibet.

On 9 November 2018, a family of four people were taken away from their home in Jiulongpo District (Chongqing Municipality) by Chongqing police. Their house was also demolished. They were not officially charged at the time of arrest. They were suspected to be arrested because a friend, who was a petitioner, stayed with their family.

On 9 November 2018, the four-faced Guanyin statue, located outside the Eastern Buddhist Temple in the village of Xinyi, Shibantan town, Xindu district (Chengdu city, Sichuan Province) was demolished by around 300 officials from the Public Security Bureau, Urban Management Bureau, and Fire Prevention Bureau to advance the CCP's nationwide campaign to eliminate all open-air religious symbols.

On 9 November 2018, six villagers under the order of two government officials and one police officer destroyed a deity statue in a Taoist temple in Shaogang Town (Shangqiu City, Henan Province). The temple was subsequently repurposed into an elderly activity centre.

On 11 November 2018, a demolition team led by the secretary-general of the local government tore down most of the buildings of the abbey of Chaocheng Catholic Church in Shen County (Liaocheng, Shandong). Only the main hall of the church remained due to obstruction by banners hung by believers on the vehicles of the demolition team and on the wall of the church. It was reported that believers were guarding the site to prevent the demolition.

On 11 November 2018, staff from Religious Affairs Bureau and policemen broke into the gathering of a family church in Huozhou (Linfen, Shanxi), and shut it down for exceeding the legally permitted size of gatherings.

Around 13 November 2018 (as reported), the demolition of Giant Buddha statue at Jingniang Lake in Wu'an (Handan, Hebei) was in progress under the orders of the local authority to demolish all religious statues in the region.
On 13 November 2018, the Xishan Temple in Huangshi (Hubei) was demolished by the local government. The government claimed that the temple was illegal because it had no permit.

On 13 November 2018, authorities demolished a house church congregation site in Jiangjia village of Shuixi town (Xinyu, Jiangxi) after claiming it was structurally compromised, while church members claimed differently, saying that the site was structurally stable. The government had banned congregations at the site four months ago.

On 14 November 2018, the Gaoshan Buddhist Temple in Jiujiang (Jiangxi) was destroyed by the local authorities to build a highway. The local authorities forced the abbot to sign the agreement by threatening and detaining him, and paid a portion of promised compensation for the demolished temple.

Around 15 November 2018 (month of), the house of a member of the Church of Almigty God in Zibo City, Shandong Province was raided by several public security officers. They rummaged through their belongings and confiscated their life savings worth 145,000 RMB, on the grounds that the money belonged to the Church and was illegal. This was part of an ongoing campaign to crack down on the members of the Church of Almighty God.

Around 15 November 2018 (month of), a 13-metre-tall outdoor Guanyin statue of a Buddhist temple was demolished by the local government in Nanchong City, Sichuan Province. This was part of a broader campaign undertaken by the CCP to crack down on religious activities.

Around 15 November 2018 (month of), the local government of Jiamusi prefecture-level city in Heilongjiang Province demolished a 27-meter-high Guanyin statue outside the Qingyun Temple in the city to advance the CCP's nationwide campaign to eliminate all open-air religious symbols. The demolition lasted for two months.

Around 15 November 2018 (month of), a house church meeting venue in Dezhou City, Shandong Province was repeatedly raided by the police and forced to shut down. When the person in charge attempted to apply for the permits to reopen the church, she was told that in addition to the standard procedures, the venue will need to display the new Regulations on Religious Affairs and a portrait of Mao Zedong. The congregation would also be prohibited from celebrating Christmas, and would have to observe the Great Man's Day instead.

Around 15 November 2018 (month of), a Buddhist temple in Huangshi City, Hubei Province was painted white by government personnel, on the grounds that they were creating ''a civilised city'' and the red pillars and Buddhist symbols of the temple affected the appearance of the city. This is reportedly part of a government campaign to crackdown on colours it deems too religious, like the yellow and dark red that have come to symbolize Buddhist temples.

Around 15 November 2018 (month of), more than a dozen personnel from the local Land Management Bureau aggressively smashed things and forcibly halted the reconstruction of a Buddhist temple in Xianyou County (Putian City, Fujian Province). It was reported that the head of the temple had already obtained the approval from the local village committee to reconstruct the temple.

Around 15 November 2018 (month of), at least three house churches in Lindian County (Daqing City, Heilongjiang Province) were shut down by the authorities. This was part of a broader campaign to crack down on non-approved religious venues, for the fear of foreign infiltration through religion.

Property destruction: Around 15 November 2018 (middle of month), a church in Duqu Town (Luohe City, Henan Province) was forcibly shut down by local authorities. The town's CCP secretary also ordered personnel to burn and destroy all of the church's gospel materials, Christian couplets and stools. The church's electronic organs, speakers, quilts, and other items were emptied out.

Around 15 November 2018 (month of), town government officials ordered the dismantling of a 18-metre-tall outdoor Guanyin statue erected at Doushuai Buddhist Temple in Xiushui county (Jiujiang, Jiangxi). The temple had spent more than one million RMB on the statue.

Around 15 November 2018 (month of), government authorities forcibly dismantled all of the Islamic symbols from a mosque in Zhoukou, Henan. Afterward, the mosque was converted into an activity centre for seniors. This is part of a five-year plan to ''sinicize'' all Chinese Muslims outside of Xinjiang.

Around 15 November 2018 (month of), state authorities had been checking and removing Arabic symbols and prohibiting their use in public places in two Muslim Hui communities, Huixin and Huihui, in Sanya prefecture (Hainan). Authoirities have identified 50 violations, including elements of menus, advertising boards, supermarkets and kindergartens. The government believes that ''pan-Arabization'' can be restrained through this action.

Arrests: Around 15 November 2018 (month of), large numbers of police officials broke into the homes of villagers of Sanhongqicun in Shunde, Foshan late in the night to arrest them. This was in retaliation to the villagers' large-scale protest against the unauthorised selling of land by village officials.

Around 16 November 2018 (as reported), the government of Gongliu county reverted the re-education camp site at No.2 Secondary School of Gongliu County (Ili, Xinjiang) back to a regular school, and started to release Kazakhs detained in the camp.

Around 20 November 2018 (as reported), the satellite images from Asia Maritime Transparency Initiative showed that Chinese military forces had constructed new facilities which could be used as military facilities on Bombay Reef in the Paracel Islands (Hainan).

On 22 November 2018, the Zion Church, a government-approved Protestant Three-Self church on Zhujiang Road in Jianxi district (Luoyang, Henan), was demolished by the local authority. The church had started being physically attacked since October because it sat on the Zhujiang Road which the local government intended to reconstruct.

Around 24 November 2018 (as reported), the Taoist Yaochi Palace Temple located on Qingliang Mountain in Huyi district (Xi'an, Shaanxi) was demolished by the Shaanxi provincial authorities, while only the main hall remained. The demolition was due to the control and suppression of religious belief imposed by the authorities in Shaanxi.

On 27 November 2018, a house church meeting venue in Sartu District (Daqing City, Heilongjiang Province) was shut down by officials from the Religious Affairs Bureau. The congregation was also ordered to cease gatherings, remove the cross, clear out all tables and chairs. This was part of a broader campaign to crack down on non-approved religious venues, for the fear of foreign infiltration through religion.

On 28 November 2018, a Buddhist temple in Dingzhai Village (Xinxiang City, Henan Province) was demolished by the local government, on the grounds that ''a civilised village cannot have temple''. This followed after the village was selected as a ''civilised village'' by the state, and that the village would only be granted a cash reward of one million RMB after the temple was demolished.

On 29 November 2018, the Buddhist Guangyan Temple was vandalised by three village officials in Chengbo town of Mengzhou county (Jiaozuo, Henan) prior to being blocked and sealed off on the grounds of being ''unlicensed.'' The officials knocked over the incense burner, scraped off patterns engraved on the pillars, and tore down the plaque on the temple's gate.

Around 30 November 2018 (end of month), a house church in Jinxian County (Nanchang City, Jiangxi Province) was raided and forcibly locked by local officials. The officials also ordered the church leader to join the state-run Three-Self Church. They shredded the couplet banners and scripture extracts, and confiscated Bibles and book of hymns. Propaganda posters with information on the new Regulations on Religious Affairs and the core socialist values were hung up. This was part of a broader campaign to forcing church leaders to join the state-run Three-Self Church.

On 30 November 2018, officers from the Urban Administrative and Law Enforcement Bureau tore down banners with President Xi's sayings and destroyed a security camera installed in front of a female petitioner's house in Yangjian town (Wuxi, Jiangsu) as a ''punishment'' for her petitioning efforts against forced evictions. She installed the camera after past episodes of these officers breaking into her house, and the police station's refusal to file her case or release security footage (she lived in front of the police station, so the station's security camera would have covered the incident that day.)

On 1 December 2018, the house of a local church leader located in the High-Tech Development Zone in Xian'an District (Xianning City, Hubei Province) was raided by more than a dozen town government officials and police officers. More than 100 believers were gathered at the house for a rehearsal of a Christmas performance. The government officials and police officers seized at least 200 bed quilts, more than 60 benches, significant quantities of food, and all of the church's valuables, amounting to a total loss of at least RMB 31,500 for the believers.

On 1 December 2018, a palace hall at a Buddhist monastery in Chang'an District (Xi'an City, Shaanxi Province) was completely destroyed by government officials, on the grounds that it was an ''illegal building''. It was also reported that the head of the temple was placed under house arrest when he attempted to appeal against the order to demolish the palace hall.
Arrests: Around 1 December 2018 (beginning of month), police detained 50 members of the Early Rain Covenant Church in Sichuan as part of a nationwide crackdown on churches.

On 3 December 2018, the house of a local church leader located in the High-Tech Development Zone in Xian'an District (Xianning City, Hubei Province) was raided by the authorities. Believers gathered at the house were driven away, while government personnel confiscated Bibles and sermon materials, food supplies and more than 20 bed quilts, and some of the believers' handbags, amounting to a total loss of RMB 10,000 for the believers. The church leader and two believers were taken away to the police station for interrogation. The leader was subsequently detained for one month, on the grounds of ''disturbing public order''. This was a series of raids and acts of intimidation carried out by the authorities against the same church since 1 December 2018.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of China (2012-) People's Armed Police
NOTES: On 4 December 2018, a makeshift house of a local church leader located in the High-Tech Development Zone in Xian'an District (Xianning City, Hubei Province) was demolished by the authorities. The Xianning City Special Police Unit and town government officials brought in six buses and brought more than 100 believers to a detention house. At the detention house, the believers were interrogated, with their ID information registered, before being sent back to their hometowns. This was a series of actions and acts of intimidation carried out by the authorities against the same church since 1 December 2018.

Arrests: Around 4 December 2018 (as reported), more than 300 Kyrgyz people from Payiz village in Akto county (Kizilsu Kirghiz, Xinjiang) were arrested and detained in re-education camps for possession of inappropriate content on their phones and involvement in minor demeanors. They were accused by local authorities of having ''strong religious views'' and ''politically incorrect ideas.''

On 5 December 2018, about 40 police officers were dispatched to arrest 13 Christians gathered at the Word of Life house church in Shangzhi City (Harbin, Heilongjiang). Police raided the home and confiscated all bibles, hymnbooks, and sermon CDs.

Around 5 December 2018 (as reported), a private Arabic language school in Kongtong district (Pingliang, Gansu) was shut down by local authorities after the Gansu government ordered to shut down local private schools with a religious undertone.

On 6 December 2018, police summoned more than 30 believers, including 13 who had been arrested the day before, from the Word of Life house church in Sangzhi City (Heilongjiang) to the village security director's home. They were ordered to sign a guarantee that they would not attend gatherings again and to join the state-approved Three-Self Church, while their own church was closed.

SOURCE: South China Morning Post; Bitter Winter
NOTES: Around 7 December 2018 (as reported), city education officials ordered a 34-year-old a Arabic language school and charity institution catering underprivileged students in Pingliang prefecture (Gansu) to close by 17 Dec.

On 8 December 2018, a 22 years old Tibetan committed self-immolation outside the Ngaba County Public Security Bureau in Ngaba (Ngawa County) (Ngawa, Sichuan) to call for religious and political freedom in Tibet.

On 9 December 2018, two Tibetan monks around 16 years old committed self-immolation in Ngawa County (Ngawa, Sichuan) and shouted slogans calling for political and religious freedom in Tibet. Two monks were sent to the hospital in Khyungchu County hospital and Barkham County hospital.

SOURCE: DW; Radio Free Asia; South China Morning Post; AFP
NOTES: Arrests: On 10 December 2018, Michael Kovrig, a former Canadian diplomat and senior adviser of International Crisis Group, were ''arbitrarily detained'' in Beijing by national security officers. Chinese authorities stated that Kovrig had conducted ''relevant work'' for International Crisis Group without an official registration, and might have breached the Law on Administration of Activities of Overseas Nongovernmental Organizations. However, it is suspected that it is a retaliation by the Chinese government against the arrest of Meng Wanzhou, Huawei Chief Financial Officer accused of violating Iran sanctions, by the Canadian government. On 16 May 2019, the Chinese Ministry of Foreign Affairs announced the ''recent'' formal arrests of Kovrig and China-based businessman Michael Spavor, during a press conference in Beijing, on the grounds that they were ''endangering China's security'' in relation to gathering state secrets and providing them to overseas forces. The state spokesperson did not announce the whereabouts of the two arrestees.

SOURCE: AFP; South China Morning Post; Radio Free Asia; DW
NOTES: Arrests: On 10 December 2018, Michael Spavor, a Canadian businessman, were ''arbitrarily detained'' in Dandong (Liaoning) by the Liaoning National Security Bureau. However, it is suspected that it is a retaliation by the Chinese government against the arrest of Meng Wanzhou, Huawei Chief Financial Officer accused of violating Iran sanctions, by the Canadian government. On 16 May 2019, the Chinese Ministry of Foreign Affairs announced the ''recent'' formal arrests of Kovrig and China-based businessman Michael Spavor, during a press conference in Beijing, on the grounds that they were ''endangering China's security'' in relation to gathering state secrets and providing them to overseas forces. The state spokesperson did not announce the whereabouts of the two arrestees.

Around 11 December 2018 (week of), eight people (including village officials and urban management officers) tore down the kitchen of the house of a local church leader in the High-Tech Development Zone in Xian'an District (Xianning City, Hubei Province). Another makeshift house built in front of her home was also demolished. This was a series of actions and acts of intimidation carried out by the authorities against the same church leader since 1 December 2018.

On 14 December 2018, Armed Forces Department officials removed and destroyed all faith-related symbols at the Three-Self church in Yanwangmiao village, Wulihe town of Qi county (Kaifeng, Henan), confiscated religious texts, and the Religious Affairs Bueau collected 95,000 RMB in donation money. Two days later, the church was demolished.

On 14 December 2018, an underground Catholic church in Xintaizi Town (Tieling City, Liaoning Province) was sealed off by the local town government. This was part of a broader campaign to persecute underground churches which had intensified following the signing of the Vatican-China Deal of 2018, in an attempt to force the underground churches to join the state-run Chinese Patriotic Catholic Association.

SOURCE: South China Morning Post; Radio Free Asia
NOTES: On 15 December 2018, more than 60 police officers and government officials cracked down on the Rongguili Church in Yuexiu District (Guangzhou, Guangdong), forbade all future activities after accusing it of violating regulations on religious affairs. More than 4000 books were confiscated, and the area was sealed off by the police during the crackdown.

On 16 December 2018, about 30 people from the local Religious Affairs Department and Gulou Police Station charged into a church in Lu'an City (Anhui) and took away electronic devices and furniture by force.

On 16 December 2018, the Taiyuan Cornerstone Church was banned by the Xiaodian District Bureau of Ethnic and Religious Affairs (Taiyuan, Shanxi) on the basis that it was carrying out religious activities without official approval.

Around 16 December 2018 (month of), a church meeting venue in Fuzhou prefecture-level City in Jiangxi Province was raided by local National Security Brigade and police officers allegedly because the congregation had been in contact with a South Korean church and received donations of 380,000 RMB (about $ 55,000) from it. They meeting venue was taken over by the state and transferred to the Three-Self Church. The police confiscated the money, threatening to imprison believers and suspend the church's bank account if the congregation attempted to protest.

Around 16 December 2018 (month of), crosses, religious paintings and Bible verses were removed from a Three-Self Church in Tongdi Village (Weinan City, Shaanxi). This was part a broader campaign to ''sinicize'' religion in the country.

Around 16 December 2018 (month of), a Catholic church in Dayangshu township, Oroqen Autonomous Banner (Hulunbuir, Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region) was closed down by the authorities, because it refused to join the Chinese Patriotic Catholic Association (CPCA).

Around 16 December 2018 (month of), a Three-Self Church in Lihe Township (Nanyang City, Henan Province) was shut down by the local government, forcing its members to congregate at the house of a fellow believer adjacent to the church. It was reported that officials installed a surveillance camera on 8 March 2019 to monitor their activities at the new temporary venue. Believers were then threatened to stop gathering or face arrest.
Around 16 December 2018 (month of), Religious Affairs Bureau officials ordered the demolition of Baima Temple in Chenhe town (Yingcheng, Hubei), and moved away five large Bodhisattva statues.

Around 16 December 2018 (middle of month), the head of the local Township Armed Forces Department directed a demolition crew to remove about 260 Buddhist statues from the Qibugou Scenic Area in Wu'an City (Handan, Hebei). Locals had previously tried to cover the statues with billboards an cloths to prevent their removal.

On 18 December 2018, a church in Ningxi Town (Taizhou City, Zhejiang Province) was demolished by the local authorities, on the grounds that it was ''too close to the reservoir and will pollute the water source''.

On 18 December 2018, the Home of God's Love Christian Church in Xiamen City (Fujian) was closed down. Since September 2018, the local Fire Prevention Bureau had been increasing its requirements for the church to remain open. Finally, the property management company of the building ordered the church to move out on the basis that the location could only be used for factories.

On 19 December 2018, law enforcement officers forcibly evicted a convent in Qiqihar City (Heilongjiang). The convent had one hour to move their belongings after officers showed up with an eviction notice.

On 22 December 2018, a house church in Pingdingshan City (Henan) was closed down by more than a dozen officials following a tip-off that believers were gathered there for an ''illegal'' Christmas celebration. Officials barged into the place and ''tore up'' the place, destroying the cross and a plaque of Christian doctrine.

On 24 December 2018, Christmas Eve, more than 10 police officers raided a gospel church affiliated to the Early Rain Covenant Church in Chengdu City (Sichuan), taking away all the book, bibles, and computers. Police also changed the locks to the building to prevent members from having a Christmas gathering.

On 24 December 2018, Christmas Eve, the Early Rain Covenant Church in Qingyang District (Chengdu, Sichuan) was taken over by government authorities and turned into a Community Office where all community employees will be stationed. This is part of an ongoing crackdown by the authorities on the Early Rain Covenant Church.

On 26 December 2018, around 200 personnel, including town and village officials, demolished a Three-Self church in Miaonan village of Mangshan town (Luoyang, Henan). The director of the church was forced to sign a document claiming that the demolition was of the believers' own volition.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of China (2012-) People's Armed Police
NOTES: Property destruction: On 28 December 2018, the Wanning City government dispatched nearly 200 personnel, including SWAT police, to forcibly demolish a Three-Self church in Qinsai Village, Helezhen Town (Wanning, Hainan) on the basis that it was illegally constructed. About 50 believers had a standoff with the authorities for over an hour before they were forced to leave the church, which was demolished shortly after.

Around 30 December 2018, state authorities started checking and removing Arabic symbols and prohibiting their use in public places in in Huangliangmeng township (Handan, Hebei), changing the menu and advertising board of a Lanzhou beef noodle restaurant. The government believes that ''pan-Arabization'' can be restrained in Hui Muslim-populated areas through this action.

On 31 December 2018, 3 mosques established by the Hui Muslim ethnic minority in Yunnan Province were shut down by local authorities on the basis that they were providing ''illegal religious education'' to local believers.

Around 1 January 2019 (beginning of month), a 28-metre-tall bronze Guanyin statue inside a Buddhist temple in Taizhou City, Zhejiang Province was demolished by the authorities, on the grounds that the statue was 'too tall'. The authorities also threatened that they would tear down the temple should the statue not be demolished.

On 2 January 2019, small fires broke out in four different areas at the Macau checkpoint building and cross-border bus stop for the Hong Kong-Zhuhai-Macau Bridge. The police suspected alleged arson by a Hong Kong man. No injuries reported.

On 3 January 2019, the Canadian government reported that 13 Canadians had been detained in China since the arrest of a senior executive from Chinese telecoms equipment giant Huawei on 1 December 2018. Eight of them had been released.

On 4 January 2019, more than 10 law enforcement officers stormed into a Buddhist temple in Guangshui City (Suizhou City, Hubei Province) and smashed the statues inside the temple with sledgehammers. During the raid, they also threatened to arrest the person in charge if he interfered.

On 4 January 2019, the local government dispatched more than 100 persons to forcibly remove the cross from a Three-Self Church in Xiayi County (Shangqiu City, Henan Province). They dismantled three loudspeakers, two small crosses on the left and right side of the church roof, and twelve other small crosses on the perimeter wall. The donation box of the church, pictures of the cross, among other items, were taken away. Demolition personnel also tore down sections of the perimeter wall.
Property destruction: On 6 January 2019, a 30-meter-tall Guanyin statue in Zhujia Villa of Zaozhuang prefecture (Shandong) (location coded as Xuecheng) was demolished by authorities.

Arrests: On 7 January 2019, more than 20 police officers stormed into a restaurant in Chengdu (Sichuan) and took away more than 34 students who just attended a class by the Early Rain Covenant Church. Police confiscated the phones and ID cards of all students. Many of the students were released before midnight, while some were detained for 48 hours before their release.

As reported on 9 January 2019, China agreed to let over two thousand ethnic Kazakhs abandon their Chinese citizenship and leave China, which was widely believed to be a response to the backlash against the country's crackdown on Uyghur Muslims in Xinjiang.

On 10 January 2019, a Bible study group was studying the Bible in a church in Chengdu City, Sichuan Province, when the local police and Department of Civil Affairs raided the church, announced that the gathering was illegal, and that the church would be shut down. They warned the congregation that 'religious activities cannot be organised illegally'. Some books were taken away from the church.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of China (2012-) People's Armed Police
NOTES: On 14 January 2019, a church-run kindergarten in Xinglin District (Xiamen City, Fujian Province) was demolished by a large number of heavily armed police officers in anti-riot gear and personnel from the district's urban management bureau. It was reported that parents and teachers were blocked in their own homes, with each household guarded by 5 to 6 personnel to prevent them from going out during the demolition.

Around 15 January 2019 (month of), a house church in Kunming City, Yunnan Province was shut down by the officials, on the grounds that it was 'dangerous' as 'the church was on too high a floor'. It was reported that the church was shut down for refusing to join the state-run Three-Self church.

On 15 January 2019, a Three-Self Church meeting venue housed in a relatively concealed basement of a residential building in Dapan Village, Zhongmu County (Zhengzhou City, Henan Province) was discovered and shut down by local authorities. The furnishings at the venue were also cleared out.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of China (2012-) People's Armed Police
NOTES: On 15 January 2019, special police officers raided a hotel in Wancheng District (Nanyang City, Henan Province) and arrested 150 pastors, elders and leaders of the Henan Province's China Gospel Fellowship, who were attended their year-end gathering. All of their mobile phones were confiscated. It was also reported that the deputy minister of Henan's Province United Front Work Department and more than 150 police officers were mobilised for the raid.

In January 2019, a big Buddha statue and 11 small Buddha statues of a Buddhist temple in Anning City (Kunming City, Yunnan Province) were demolished by the local authorities. It followed the demolition of a 18-metre Buddha statue of Shakyamuni at the same temple in September 2018, as part of a broader campaign to demolish all large outdoor religious statues.
In January 2019, Beifudian Three-Self Church in Yichuan county (Luoyang City, Henan Province) was taken over by the government and repurposed into an elderly activity centre.

On 17 January 2019, on the death day of the former Premier of the PRC Zhao Ziyang, his residence was heavily securitised and many dissidents were prevented from paying their respects to him. They reported having been 'taken away' temporarily by the state police.

On 17 January 2019, five houses in Dongyangcun (Luoyang City, Henan Province) were forcibly demolished by a forced demolition team made up of more than 100 personnel (including representatives from the Urban and Rural Planning Bureau, public security, subdistrict office). The people whose houses were demolished believed that their properties were legal, and that the administrative agencies had no legal right to forcibly demolish them.

As reported on 19 Jan 2019, the Chinese government recently issued a notice prohibiting Tibetan party members and government officials from taking part in any religious activities on pain of permanently losing their ID cards and all rights that come with their job. Authorities have also installed additional surveillance mechanisms around temples and circumambulation routes to gather information on this matter.
On 21 January 2019, government authorities sealed off a Buddhist temple in Shisi town of Xin'an county (Luoyang, Henan) based on claims that 'the land had been taken illegally.'

ACTOR1: Government of China (2019-) Macau Special Administrative Region
NOTES: On 24 January 2019, the Legislative Assembly of Macau passed a bill amending the National Anthem Law. The amendments include prohibitions on disrespect of the national anthem, flag, and anthem. The bill is a result of the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress' 4 November 2017 decision to apply the National Anthem Law in Hong Kong and Macau. A similar bill in Hong Kong sparked protests.

On 26 January 2019, a Three-Self Church in Yiyang County (Luoyang City, Henan Province) was 'transformed' on orders of officials from the county's Religious Affairs Bureau, with the original Western-style steeple and cross dismantled, and the building converted into a 'Chinese-style private house'. This was part of an ongoing campaign to 'sinicize' places of worship.

Arrests: Around 27 January 2019 (as reported), 31 Kazakh writers were arrested in Xinjiang and sentenced to 15 years in prison. This is part of an ongoing campaign to suppress Muslim Kazakh cultural figures.

As reported on 29 January 2019, a Kazakh woman was arrested with 30 other colleagues and sentenced to 15 years in re-education camp. Location coded as Tacheng city, Xinjiang at GP3 based on the location in the report's dateline.

LOCATION: Minhe Hui and Tu Autonomous County
NOTES: On 1 February 2019, a mosque in the Minhe Hui and Tu Autonomous County (Haidong, Qinghai) was forcibly demolished by police as part of a five-year plan to 'sinicize' all Chinese Muslims outside of Xinjiang.

On 2 February 2019, a 57.9-metre-tall Guanyin statue in Pingshan County (Shijiazhuang City, Hebei Province) was detonated and destroyed by local government officials. This was part of the broader campaign to stop the 'commercialisation of Buddhism' through the crackdown on religious venues and open-air religious statues through China.
On 3 February 2019, the local government of Dianzhuangzhen, Luoyang, Henan blocked the entrance of a church in Dianzhuangzhen with two trucks to prevent church goers from entering the church.

On 3 February 2019, police stormed into a house church in Yanghezhen, Pingqiao (Xinyang, Henan) and looted the cross, speakers, projectors, carpet. When the church goers insisted on gathering, police stormed into the house church again and demanded that they stop gathering. Police also took away a preacher and detained the preacher for 15 days.

On 11 February 2019, state authorities prohibited incense burning and donation collection at the five-hundred-year-old Ruifeng Taoist Temple on Longfeng Mountain in Xiuyan Manchu Autonomous County (Liaoning). The Temple was located in a provincial-level historical and cultural site, and the act reflected 'an escalation' in religious persecution by regional CCP authorities.

On 12 February 2019, some ethnic Uyghurs launched a global social media campaign under the hashtag #MeTooUyghur to press China for video proof that their missing relatives are alive, after China released a video of a Uyghur man saying he was alive and well.

ACTOR1: Government of China (2017-) Hong Kong Special Administrative Region
ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Government of China (2017-) Hong Kong Special Administrative Region
SOURCE: Wen Wei Po; Radio Free Asia
NOTES: On 12 February, the Security Bureau of Hong Kong submitted a proposal to the Panel on Security of the Legislative Council in Central and Western District to ammend the Fugitive Offenders Ordinance and the Mutual Legal Assistance in Criminal Matters Ordinance in order that authorities of the mainland, Hong Kong, and Taiwan could provide each other with legal assistance and carry out extraditions on a case-by-case basis for criminal offences. The proposal (known as the 'Extradition Bill' in most media reports) was sparked by the lack of legal recourse available to prosecute a Hong Konger who had committed a murder in Taiwan last March. It has since led to significant demonstrations across Hong Kong.
In February 2019, government authorities sealed off a Buddhist temple in Yicheng district (Zaozhuang, Shandong) to prevent believers from offering and burning incense.

In February 2019, authorities surrounded the Taoist Taizi Temple in Leijiagou village of Shaolin sub-district, Dengfeng (Zhengzhou, Henan) with barbed wire, claiming that it was 'Closed for Rectification.' This came after authorities from the Cultural Relics Management Bureau claimed that incense burning was prohibited. Back in November 2018, the owner of the temple was warned to leave the premise after clearing out the statues of deities, an incense burner and a donation box within three days.

In February 2019, authorities in Datianzhuang township (Feixian, Shandong) forcibly repurposed Guanyin Temple to turn it into the 'Yuhuangtai Academy of Painting and Calligraphy' on the grounds that private construction of temples is not allowed. An eight-meter-tall outdoor Guanyin statue in the temple's courtyard was completely covered with marble slabs. All other statues inside the temple were barricaded with steel pipes and plywood, and the authorities prohibited people from entering the temple to worship and make offerings.

In February 2019, a Catholic church in Yugan County (Shangrao City, Jiangxi Province) had its cross forcibly removed by local officials, which was replaced by the Chinese national flag. Other religious symbols outside the church were also removed.

In February 2019, the Three-Self Church located in Longdong village, Longdong subdistrict of Zhongzhan district (Jiaozuo, Henan) was forced to be 'donated' to the authorities and converted into a cultural centre. It was part of a campaign for the purpose of limiting the number of Three-Self Churches.

As reported on 18 February 2019 by The Guardian, a Chinese surveillance company has been tracking the movements of at least 2.5 million residents in Xinjiang. The database contained the name, sex, ethnicity, ID number, birth date and employer of residents in Xinjiang and included 6.7m location points of 'trackers' that residents had passed in the past 24 hours.

On 19 February 2019, a Three-self Protestant church in Fucheng town in Funing county (Yancheng, Jiangsu) was raided by police and the cross was forcibly removed. This is part of an ongoing campaign to crack down on Protestant churches in China.

On 19 February 2019, two police officers from the local police station stormed into the house of a house church Christian in Wufeng Tujia (Yichang City, Hubei Province). The believer was forced to hand over his Bible and MP5 player. He was also forced to burn numerous crosses which he used for sharing the gospel. It was reported that the believer ingested pesticide and killed himself the next morning following the raid.

On 24 February 2019, a house church in Xincheng Sub-district (Shangqiu City, Henan Province) was raided by several government officials, and ordered the church's preacher and more than a dozen believers to end their gathering. During the raid, they destroyed all religious symbols in the home and confiscated Bibles, hymnbooks and other religious books. The officials also forced the landlord to terminate the lease contract with the pastor.

On 25 February 2019, government authorities sealed off Chaoyin, Chaoyang and Sengcha temples at Bodhi Island Scenic Area (also known as Putidao, near Laoyujian village in the Bohai Bay area) in Laoting County (Tangshan city, Hebei) and ordered monks to leave the premises within a week.

On 26 February 2019, the government authorities removed a nearly 18-meter-tall bronze statue of sitting Maitreya, the 'future Buddha', in the Longfeng cemetery in Xinhua (Shijiazhuang City, Hebei Province). It was part of a campaign by CCP to crackdown on Buddhism.
