On 1 March 2019, Hongshan Temple in Leigong town, Anlu County (Xiaogan City, Hubei Province) was razed to the ground by the authorities, leaving the old female temple owner homeless. It was reported that the incident was part of an intensified campaign launched by the Hubei authorities to crack down on Buddhism.

On 3 March 2019, the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference (CPPCC) began in Beijing, signifying the official start of the 'liang hui' period, which is the collective term for the annual meetings of the CPPCC and the National People's Congress (NPC), the latter of which began on 5 March 2019. This is a 'sensitive period' for the government and many arrests, abductions, and forced disappearances of human rights defenders and petitioners are carried out in the lead up to it as part of an effort to 'maintain stability'.
As reported on 4 March 2019, police officers shut down a shop owned by Christian house church believers in Chengdu. The act was part of a regional crackdown on Christian house church believers.

On 6 March 2019, officials from the Jinshui District Bureau of Religious Affairs sealed off Panshi Church in Erqi district (Zhengzhou, Henan) after claims about regulation violations, and forbade them from organising religious activities in the future. Slogans were removed, and electricity supply was cut off.

On 6 March 2019, local government officials pried open the gate to a church in Erqi District (Zhengzhou City, Henan Province) and vandalized the venue. The officials also looted RMB 70,000 worth of church items, and sealed off the venue with barricade tape.

On 6 March 2019, local police raided six Buddhist statue factories in Zhuanlu Town (Baoding City, Hebei Province) and destroyed the casting kilns in one of the factories and smashed statue moulds in another factory. It was reported that the owners of these two factories incurred losses of ten of thousands of RMB. In the other four factories, Buddhist statues were confiscated. It was part of an extended campaign to crack down on Buddhist statues at the source, by cracking down on factories that produce the statues.

On 9 March 2019, the one-month baby shower of the daughter of a poet in Guangzhou (Guangdong) had to ultimately be cancelled after police authorities sent troops to the homes of multiple invited guests and trapped them from morning till 8 o'clock that evening. In hopes of preventing police intervention, the hosts changed their venue multiple times ahead of the day, but were ultimately discovered. The poet was arrested at his party, and taken away for interrogations overnight. He was previously detained in July 2017 for commemorating the death of Liu Xiaobo, and in Aug 2017 for editing books related to Liu.

On 11 March 2019, more than a dozen officials stormed into the home of a believer of a Three-Self Church in Zhoukou City, Henan Province. They took away religious paintings and books from his home and burned them outside. The officials also ordered the family to get rid of the remaining religious items at home.

Around 11 March 2019 (between 2 and 21 March 2019), 32 folk temples and at least 164 other faith-related buildings in Yi Country (Baoding, Henan) were demolished by local government personnel as part of the wider plan to crack down on religious activities in the country. The demolition was supervised by Baoding city's United Front Work Department.

On 14 March 2019, about 100 government officials and police officers, led by the Town Secretary, demolished a Three-Self church in Xianglushan town of Yiyang county (Luoyang, Henan). The church was state-approved with a property certificate, but authorities now claimed that it had 'violated building laws,' resulting in the joint operation led by the Yiyang County Government, State Land Management Bureau and Planning Bureau.

In March 2019, a Catholic church in Nanyang City, Henan Province was raided by seven local government officials for being 'unlicensed'. It was reported that the officials smashed tables, chairs, and the podium in the church, and ransacked the residence of the priest. The officials also confiscated more than 400 Bibles, loudspeakers and other valuables.

In March 2019, local authorities dispatched personnel to demolish all the remaining Buddhist statue factories in Yueling Village (Baoding City, Hebei Province), on the grounds that it 'polluted the environment'. It was part of an extended campaign to crack down on Buddhist statues at the source, by cracking down on factories that produce the statues.

Around 15 March 2019 (month of), a Catholic church in Ji'an City, Jiangxi Province was shut down by the local government, on the grounds that it was an 'unlicensed venue'. The officials also threatened to impose a fine on the congregation if they were to gather again. Following the shutdown of the church, government employees continued to visit the venue to ensure that no meetings were held there. It was reported that the government employees also visited the homes of believers, ordering them to believe in the CCP, and threatened to send them to jail if they continued to express their religious beliefs.

In March 2019, 5911 local Tudi temples (temples dedicated to the local god of land) were demolished in Gaoyou (Yangzhou, Jiangsu) within 26 days on the grounds that they were illegal and they occupied large areas of rural arable land and urban public facilities and places. This is part of the wider plan to crack down on the country's religious activities.

In March 2019, a Catholic Church in Bixi Town, Taihe County (Ji'an City, Jiangxi Province) was taken over by the government and repurposed into a cultural activity centre. Religious paintings and the crucifix were taken over, and replaced by CCP's propaganda slogans and Xi Jinping's quotes. After the church was repurposed, government officials also visited the homes of congregations members to force them to sign statements renouncing their faith. The incident was part of a broader campaign to persecute congregations and churches that declined to join the Chinese Patriotic Catholic Association.

On 15 March 2019, more than 10 police officers stormed into a house church in Yanghezhen, Pingqiao (Xinyang, Henan) and demanded the worshippers to stop the gathering on the grounds that such gatherings were illegal. Police confiscated hymn books, Bibles, computers, tables and chairs and 1095 RMB. The house church was then sealed off. 4 people were taken away but released on the same day.

In March 2019, Huangdiling Church in Baizhai town, Xinmi (Zhengzhou City, Henan Province) was taken over by the government and repurposed into a village warehouse. A placard with political slogans was posted on the church.

In March 2019, 14 meeting venues established by a Three-Self church in Xiongguantun Township, Tieling county (Tieling City, Liaoning Province) were shut down by the authorities. The government proclaimed that it had to be done to 'prevent external infiltration' and because 'too many meeting venues cause trouble for management'.

In March 2019, authorities in Tongcheng county (Xianning City, Hubei Province) repurposed the Ding family ancestral hall (part of China's folk religions) into a cultural auditorium by putting up spiritual maxims signboards promoting the core socialist values on top of the building. The act was taken to advance a coordinated crackdown against folk religions and family clans. In this campaign, it was reported that 24 ancestral clan halls in the Tongcheng county were converted into cultural auditoriums.

In March 2019, the newly-built Protestant Liandong Church in Youdunjie town, Poyang county (Shangrao City, Jiangxi Province) was forcibly transferred to the village committee because the local officials threaten to demolish the building if the order was rejected. The newly-built church building was converted into a village committee office, while the next-door old church building was sealed at the front door. The act was taken to advance the CCP's policy to reduce the number of Three-Self Churches nationwide.

Around 15 March 2019 (month of), a 30-odd-meter-high Guanyin statue in Nan'an county-level city, Fujian Province, was concealed soon after it was unveiled in March due to government orders to implement the CCP's nationwide campaign to eliminate all open-air religious symbols.

On 16 March 2019, more than 30 government officials besieged a house church in Poyang County, Shangrao, Jiangxi province and robbed the church, confiscating things including piano, blankets, etc. They looked up the church's financial records and announced that the church would be closed because it was illegally built.

On 16 March 2019, officials from Ju County's United Front Work Department, Religious Affairs Bureau and other institutions ordered a folk tourism holiday resort in Ju County (Rizhao City, Shandong Province) to demolish its Guanyin statue for 'being outdoors and too tall'. The director of the resort eventually covered the icon with socialist propaganda posters, due to high cost of demolishing the statue. A temple in the resort was also shut down by the authorities.

Property destruction: Around 16 March 2019 (month of), officials destroyed a Three-Self Church in Heze prefecture (Shandong) (coded to Mudan) on the pretext of building a high-speed railway. They promised to approve the building of a new church before admitting that it was a false excuse to gain the congregation's support.

Around 19 March 2019 (a week after 12 March 2019), Sola Fide house church in Chumen town of Yuhuan county (Taizhou City, Zhejiang Province) was demolished by the United Front Work Department officials on the grounds that the church was an illegal building. The church's head was sent to the police station, extracted blood for the biodata database, and forced to sign a statement of guarantee, promising not to convene gatherings of believers again.

On 20 March 2019, several dozens of people demolished the ancestral home of a human rights artist in Shangzhai village of Pingdu district (Beijing). They did not present any documentation or follow any official procedures, but claimed the house had to be demolished to build a road to fulfill President Xi Jinping's political vision of the 'new village.'

On 24 March 2019, police deputies stormed into a Protestant church in Haidian District (Beijing), banned it, and shut it down because it was a 'privately-established meeting venue'. All church goers who were attending a gathering there were taken away by police for investigation. Church belongings were confiscated. This happened a day after Beijing Municipal Government announced the decision to shut down house churches in Beijing, which is part of an ongoing campaign to crack down on house churches in China.

ACTOR1: Government of China (2017-) Hong Kong Special Administrative Region
NOTES: On 26 March 2019, high officials of the Hong Kong government, including Chief Executive Carrie Lam and officials from the Security Bureau, announced that they would remove 9 'white collar' offences from the 47 offenses included in the proposed Extradition Bill, which will be tabled at the Legislative Council on 3 April 2019. This revision is a response to the business community's concerns over the bill and their outcry over it. The proposed bill also sparked mass demonstrations across the country that lasted for months.

On 28 March 2019, government officials sealed off the Buddhist Fojing Temple in Jindegu township of Nanle county (Puyang, Henan) after burying religious statues that were previously erected. The temple did not manage to receive state approval despite repeated applications in the past three years.
As reported on 28 March 2019, the signboard of a Hui Muslim restaurant in Taipingdian township (Baiyin, Gansu) was covered up.

Around 31 March 2019 (end of month), the cross of a Three-Self Church in Xiangshuitian (Shangrao City, Jiangxi Province) was removed by local officials, on the grounds that 'the church had a bad influence because it was near a highway'. The name of the church on the outside wall was also removed and replaced with ceramic tiles. In late November 2019, a painting depicting Jesus, a plaque, and religious couplets were removed from the walls inside the church. This was part of a broader campaign to remove religious symbols from churches and other structures.

On 31 March 2019, about 12 Tibetan families were evicted from their homes in resource-rich Gonjo County (Chamdo, Tibet) by police. The families, who were moved to Kongpo prefecture, had resisted orders to relocate from their ancestral land by Chinese authorities for months, despite promises that new land and housing would be provided for them.

Around 31 March 2019 (end of month), a Three-Self Church in Jincheng City, Shanxi Province was demolished by local authorities. It was reported that the church was first designated for relocation as part of a redevelopment plan, but the construction of a new church never materialised.

Around 31 March 2019 (end of month), a Protestant house church venue in Wuchang District (Wuhan City, Hubei Province) was raided by government officials and the police. A congregation member later reported that broken glass were everywhere in the venue after the raid, with the air conditioner and projector taken, a hole in the roof, and the signboards of the church were smashed. This was part of a broader campaign undertaken by the CCP to crack down on religious activities.

On 1 April 2019, the cross of a Three-Self Church in Shengli Town (Linyi City, Shandong Province) was removed by workers dispatched by a village official. It was reported that the village official received orders from his superiors that village officials would be held accountable if any crosses remain in their jurisdiction.

On 1 April 2019, about 50 personnel from the local government stormed into a Protestan church in Zhangjiajie, Hunan and tore down all symbols of faith and confiscated 100 copies of the Bible and more than 70 hymnbooks. Equipment worthy of 50,000 RMB were looted during the raid. The church was repeatedly harassed by government personnel in late-March.

Around 1 April 2019 (beginning of month), four local police officers stormed into the house of a member of the Church of Almighty God in Puyang City, Henan Province. They confiscated her savings of 100,000 RMB, on the grounds that it belonged to the Church. This was part of an ongoing campaign to crack down on the members of the Church of Almighty God.

Around 1 April 2019 (beginning of month), a Catholic church in Raozhou Subdistrict, Poyang county (Shangrao City, Jiangxi Province) was raided by more than 30 officials from the subdistrict office and ordered to shut down because it was 'unlicensed' and a 'privately-established meeting venue'. This was reportedly a broader campaign to force all Catholic churches to join the state-controlled Chinese Patriotic Catholic Association (CPCA).

Around 1 April 2019 (beginning of month), a Protestant house church meeting venue in Tangxia town in Rui'an County (Wenzhou City, Zhejiang Province) was demolished by the authorities because the land was claimed for the construction of an industrial development zone. It was reported that the authorities had been using the pretext that the land was needed in order to crack down on religious activities.

ACTOR1: Government of China (2017-) Hong Kong Special Administrative Region
NOTES: On 2 April 2019, the Department of Justice of Hong Kong and the Supreme People's Court of China signed an agreement that allowed the courts of both parties to provide assistance to each other in their arbitration procedures, making Hong Kong the first jurisdiction to sign arbitration procedural safeguards with the Mainland. Specifically, it would allow arbitration results of either party to be enforced in the jurisdiction of the other party. This agreement comes amidst widespread opposition to the Extradition Bill in Hong Kong.

ACTOR1: Government of China (2017-) Hong Kong Special Administrative Region
SOURCE: Radio Free Asia; The Stand News
NOTES: On 3 April 2019, the highly controversial Extradition Bill was tabled for its first and second readings at the Legislative Council in Central District (Hong Kong). After the first reading, legislators opposed to the bill repeatedly disrupted the second reading, resulting in its adjournment to a later date, before which a committee is expected to be set up to scrutinize the bill. The proposed bill sparked mass demonstrations across the country that lasted for months.

Around 3 April 2019 (in the 26 days before 16 April 2019), city officials from the Ministry of Land and Resources had demolished 5,911 Taoist Tudigong temples in Gaoyou city (Jiangsu) in the past 26 days (coded on April 3 due to aggregation). Officials claimed that the temples were constructed illegally, and carried out restoration and re-forestation projects on the lands reclaimed.
On 4 April 2019, a Catholic church in Qianyang County (Baoji, Shaanxi) was demolished by police. According to the report, the reason for the demolition was unclear.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: The Alliance: Hong Kong Alliance in Support of Patriotic Democratic Movements of China
NOTES: On 7 April 2019, a museum set up in the Mong Kok area in Yau Tsim Mong District (Hong Kong) by the Hong Kong Alliance in Support of Patriotic Democratic Movements of China to commemorate the Tiananmen Massacre was vandalised by unknown individuals who damaged electric outlets and appliances, and furniture. The museum had been under renovation and was due to be reopened on 26 April ahead of the 30th anniversary of the massacre.

On 8 April 2019, more than 50 police officers stormed into a house church in Houlongzhen, Quangang (Quanzhou, Fujian) and looted items worth of around 80,000 RMB inside the church, including Bibles, desks, printers, speakers, computers, cross, and hymn books. This is a retaliation move after the house church refused to join the three-self church in 2018.

On 11 April 2019, authorities demolished part of a mosque in Gazhuang village of Zheqiao town (Linxia Hui Autonomous Prefecture, Gansu) for having strong Arabic architectural influences. Many Hui people were spotted laying on the ground, with blood on their bodies or knees. The reason for their injuries was unknown.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of China (2012-) People's Armed Police
NOTES: On 11 April 2019, the Guanyin Hall of a temple in Xingguo town, Yangxin County (Huangshi City, Hubei Province) owned by a female owner was razed to the ground under the reason that the land was claimed for the development of roads. More than 100 special police cordoned off the area, and two excavators were directed to demolish the hall. It was reported that the authorities had been using the pretext that the land was needed in order to crack down on religious activities.

On 11 April 2019, a Buddhist temple in Guodian town, Xinzheng (Zhengzhou, Henan) was sealed off by government authorities as part of the campaign to suppress religious activities in the country. They covered with a red cloth the three Chinese characters for the temple on the gate and the Buddhist statues inside the hall, destroyed the incense burner and used iron sheets to obscure the doors and a large bell.

On 11 April 2019, the Gazhuang Mosque in Zheqiaozhen Town, Linxia City (Linxia Hui Autonomous Prefecture, Gansu) was demolished without warning by dozens of government personnel just a month after it was built, on the basis that it was 'too Arabic'. Muslims at the scene who recorded the incident were arrested.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of China (2012-) People's Armed Police
ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Government of China (2012-); Unidentified Armed Group (China)
NOTES: On 12 April 2019, Pure Land Temple in Fuchang town, Honghu County (Jingzhou City, Hubei Province) was demolished entirely because the government had already sold the temple's land. More than 10 government officials, armed police officers and thugs cordoned off the temple and destroyed the premise.
On 12 April 2019, a Christian church in Jinan, Shandong was sealed off by the police on the grounds that it was unlicensed.

On 14 April 2019, 33 Guanyin statues on the Guanyin Island, Zhanghe New Area (Jingmen City, Hubei Province) were demolished by the authorities to 'stop the commercialization of Buddhism and Taoism'. The demolition work lasted for half a month and was a part of the CCP's policy to destroy all outdoor religious statues in the country.

On 14 April 2019, two Protestant house churches in Jiang'an (Wuhan, Hebei) were forcibly shut down by about 20 government personnel. Church properties including the donation box, hundreds of books, including Bibles and hymnbooks were confiscated from one church, while the donation box, as well as over 100 Bibles and hymnbooks were confiscated from another house church. This was part of a broader campaign to exterminate house churches that refused to join the state-controlled Three-Self church.

Property destruction: Around 15 April 2019 (month of), the local government closed a Three-Self Church in Shuyang county (Suqian, Jiangsu) and tore down the two top floors it occupied, on the grounds that the building was higher than the county committee office.

On 15 April 2019, police demolished a Protestant house church in Zhejiang province. It was reported that the government would have permitted them to continue their operation if they had agreed to join the state-run Three-Self church.

Around 15 April 2019 (month of), a Taoist temple in Baofeng County (Pingdingshan City, Henan Province) was shut down by government officials, on the grounds that it was 'set up illegally, and religious activities were conducted without permission'.

In April 2019, a non-approved Catholic church in Shenzhou City (Hengshui City, Hebei Province) was raided by the police. The police ordered the congregation to stop assembling and clear up the church as it was holding 'illegal gatherings'. They also warned the believers that the church property would be confiscated, with a fine of 20,000 RMB imposed if they failed to act upon their orders. Following the raid, the believers moved all the religious symbols and images and closed the church.

In April 2019, a mosque on Beibinhe West Road in Linxia city (Linxia Hui Autonomous Prefecture, Gansu Province) was remodelled by the government to look 'more Chinese'. The act was taken as a part of a national campaign to 'sinicize' the Muslim faith and replace it with the CCP's ideology. It was reported that numerous mosques in Linxia had been remodelled by 2019 to look 'more Chinese' with their traditional Islamic-style elements removed and replaced with the ones reflecting traditional Chinese architecture. No further details were reported on this event.

In April 2019, a Three-Self Church meeting venue in Foshan City, Guangdong Province was ordered to cease worship services, on the grounds that it was 'unlicensed' and 'its fire control measures were substandard', despite the church being well-equipped with fire extinguishers, emergency lights, and other devices that met the government's requirements. The venue was shut down and the congregation had since gathered at a new location in secret.

As reported on 15 April 2019, Islam-related and Arabic symbols were removed from an estimate of almost 150 Hui-owned stores across three streets in Chengde prefecture (Hebei), known for a high Hui Muslim population. This was done on orders from the United Front Work Department.

As reported on 15 April 2019, Arabic symbols on signboards at halal restaurants in Shanghaiguan district (Qinhuangdao, Hebei) were recently removed or covered up following a notice issued by municipal government authorities calling for investigation and regulation of Arabic symbols and control over the generalization of halal practices. The province is known to have a high Hui Muslim population.

In April 2019, a Three-Self church meeting venue in Guozhai village in Fuzhou City (Fujian Province) was demolished by the authorities. The act was taken in the context of alleged increasing suppressions on state-controlled worship places.

In April 2019, A Sola Fide house church meeting venue in Zhangjiajie city (Hunan Province) was shut down by the authorities and all its assets were confiscated because the church refused to join the state-sanctioned Three-Self Church.

In April 2019, 36 meeting venues established by Trinity Church, a Three-Self church in Xi'an City (Shaanxi Province) were closed down by the authorities. The government proclaimed that it had to be done to 'prevent external infiltration' and because 'too many meeting venues cause trouble for management'.

Around 15 April 2019 (between 10 to 20 April 2019), government personnel forcibly demolished 21 Buddhist temples in Xianju (Taizhou, Zhejiang). This is part of the campaign to crack down on the country's religious activities.

In April 2019, a 10-meter-tall Shakyamuni Buddha statue from Yongning Temple in Wensheng district of Liaoning city, Liaoyang Province was ordered to be removed by the authorities. The person in charge of the temple had to hire a crane to take it down. This was part of a broader campaign to remove large outdoor religious symbols across China.

In April 2019, several hundred outdoor Buddha statues in the Thousand Buddhist Square of Yuhua Palace Scenic Area in Yintai District (Tongchuan City, Shaanxi Province) were destroyed on orders from the government. This was part of a broader campaign to crack down on places of worship and outdoor worship areas across China, and destroy statues of deities and religious symbols.

In April 2019, nearly 600 Arhat statues of a Buddhist site in Qixingyan Scenic Spot in Fengkai County (Zhaoqing City, Guangdong Province) were covered with cement to make them look like stones. This was part of a broader campaign undertaken by the CCP to crack down on religious activities.

As reported on 15 April 2019, Arabic symbols had been painted over or covered up on all halal restaurants along a street populated by Hui Muslims in Yuanjia village (located in the hinterland of Guanzhong Plain) Liquan County (Xianyang, Shaanxi).

In April 2019, government personnel forced their way into the Site of Kaifeng Synagogue in Shunhe (Kaifeng, Henan) and removed all Jewish signs such as signs mentioning that this was indeed the Site of Kaifeng Synagogue and flag of Israel from the doors and windows. They put up signs promoting the government's attacks and repression against Judaism.

Around 15 April 2019 (month of), local town government authorities shut down Qinfo Temple (used to be called Shuiye Temple) in Hejiang town of Hejiang county (Luzhou, Sichuan). At least 160 Buddhist and Taoist activity venues were reportedly shut down in Luzhou prefecture between February 2018 and September 2019, which was immediately after the Regulations on Religious Affairs was signed into effect.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of China (2012-) People's Armed Police
NOTES: Around 15 April 2019 (middle of month), a millennium-old Guanyin statue at Jishan Temple, Shayang county (Jingmen City, Hubei Province) was demolished by more than 100 government officials and policemen, including the special police. The temple was sealed off and the demolishing took 4 days to finish. The act was taken as part of the CCP's policy to destroy all outdoor religious statues in the country.
On 16 April 2019, police demolished the cross of a Catholic church in Xinzhou District (Wuhan, Hubei). This was part of an ongoing campaign to crack down on churches in China.

Within four days after 17 April 2019, four temples in Baisha village of Zhongmu County (Zhengzhou city, Henan Province) were demolished by the government authorities on the grounds that it was 'illegal religious activity venue with substandard fire control measures'. It was part of a greater campaign by the CCP to suppress Buddhism.

As reported on 19 April 2019, the Religious Affairs Bureau shut down a temple in Beigongzhuang village, Feicheng town of Fei county (Shandong) and destroyed a large incense burner at its entrance. They hung up a banner that said 'Resolutely resist xie jiao, guided by Xi Jinping thought on socialism for a new era.'

On 19 April 2019, more than 10 personnel from the United Front Work Department shut down a Buddhist temple in Honghu (Jingzhou, Hubei) and ordered the owner of the temple to move out the Bodhisattva statues and to remove the religious symbols outside the temple, and to post political slogans above the temple's entrance. To avoid the temple being demolished, the temple's owner was forced to spend 6,000 RMB to convert the temple into a casino.

On 19 April 2019, the local authorities dismantled the East Street Church, a legal Three-Self Church, in Sunfuji township, Liangyuan district (Shangqiu City, Henan Province). The authorities looted all valuables, ripped up the floors, dismantled the wooden planks and tore apart the podium of the church.

As reported on 19 April 2019, Sichuan authorities had declared that no new residents will be allowed to reside or study at the state-backed, full-time religious institute Larung Gar Buddhist Academy in Laronggou, Luoruo town (Larung Gar) of Serthar county (Ganzi Tibetan Autonomous Prefecture, Sichuan). Walls were built and checkpoints were set up.

On 20 April 2019, a Three-Self Church in Lugou village, Yuecun town of Xinmi City (Zhengzhou City, Henan Province) was taken over by the government and repurposed into an activity centre. The village officials set up a stage and hung up the national flag inside the meeting venue.

On 20 April 2019, government personnel shut down a Sanguan Temple in Chahe, Honghu (Jingzhou, Hubei) and ordered the temple's owner to remove statues of deities, under threat of demolishing the temple. The officials also sealed off the entrance to the temple and demanded that the Eight Trigrams on either side of the entrance be removed.

On 20 April 2019, a few hundred police officers demolished a church in Guojiaying Village in Yuquan district (Hohhot, Inner Mongolia) and took away believers who resisted the demolition. A few hundred believers sang hymns and prayed during the demolition.
On 21 April 2019, police demolished the cross of a church in Zhengwang Town in Hedong District (Linyi, Shandong). This was part of an ongoing campaign to crack down on churches in China.

Arrests: On 21 April 2019, around 60 petitioners from Shanghai who were on their way to petition in Beijing were besieged by police at Beijing South Railway Station in Fengtai district (Beijing), most of which were arrested. This took place before the Belt and Road Forum which was due to commence in Beijing on 25 April 2019.

On 21 April 2019, more than 30 police officers, the district mayor, and government officials stormed into a Catholic house church in Binzhou high tech Industrial Development Zone in Bincheng district, Binzhou City of Shandong Province. The authorities confiscated everything and demolished the venue by removing the roofs, doors and windows. The police dispersed more than 100 believers and arrested 3 male believers. It was part of an ongoing campaign to crack down on religious activities.

Around 23 April 2019 (as reported), authorities prevented eight Christian churches in Beijing from organising gatherings and activities during Easter, allegedly as part of an effort to 'Sinicise' Christianity and prevent worshippers from celebrating Western festivities.

On 23 April 2019, more than a dozen government officials stormed into a house church in Huaining, Anqing in Anhui province to halt a church gathering. The police cut off electricity supply, burned the Bibles and other books and confisticated equipment worth about 10,000 RMB on the grounds that they constituted illegal promotional tools and materials.

On 23 April 2019, government personnel closed a Buddhist temple in Pingdu (Qingdao, Shandong) as a means to rectify Taoism and Buddhism. A statue of a Buddhist deity and the incense burner inside the temple were covered with red galvanized-iron sheets. The monks who lived at the temple year-round were driven out, forced to return to secular life.

Around 23 April 2019 (as reported), a Christian church in Guojiaying village, Taohua township of Yuquan district (Hohhot, Inner Mongolia) was demolished by local authorities during Easter on the grounds of being illegally constructed and not registered with state authorities. Close to 100 worshippers surrounded the church to prevent the demolition, but they were dispersed by the police without reported injuries or violence. This was a part of an organized effort to 'Sinicise' all religions.

On 25 April 2019, the government occupied a Three-Self Church that could host 1,500 people in Longdong township - now defunct and part of Longdong subdistrict - of Zhongzhan district (Jiaozuo, Henan) and stored entertainment equipment inside the church.

On 28 April 2019, two crosses of a Catholic church in Anyang City, Henan Province were forcibly demolished by police. This is part of an ongoing countrywide campaign to crack down on churches in China.

On 29 April 2019, an unreported number of Buddhist temples in Neijiang City, Sichuan Province were shut down by the government of Neijiang City. It was reported that this was part of a broader campaign launched by the local government to shut down Buddhist and Taoist temples on a large scale since March 2019, where more than 330 venues had been closed up until the time of reporting on 21 April 2020.

Around 30 April 2019 (end of month), the Jinshitan Tourist Resort's management company in Jinzhou District (Dalian City, Liaoning Province) began to dismantle a thousand-hand Guanyin statue and other Buddhist statues in the park because the government ordered that 'they were unapproved'. The demolition work was still ongoing when Bitter Winter visited the site in autumn. The act was taken as part of the CCP's campaign to eliminate all large open-air religious symbols.

Around 30 April 2019 (end of month), two large statues of the Medicine Buddha and Nanhai Guanyin in Chinese Buddhism in the Yaowang Valley Scenic Spot in Beichuan county (Mianyang City, Sichuan Province) were demolished according to the orders from Sichuan provincial government to advance the CCP's nationwide campaign to eliminate all open-air religious symbols.

On 30 April 2019, a house church in Mawei (Fuzhou, Fujian) was shut down by police as authorities deemed the building dangerous for congregating. This was part of a broader campaign to exterminate house churches that refused to join the state-controlled Three-Self church.

Around 1 May 2019 (beginning of month), a Catholic venue in Poyang county (Shangrao City, Jiangxi Province) was shut down on the grounds that 'any church refusing to join the Chinese Patriotic Catholic Association is a xie jiao ('illegal religion')'.

Around 1 May 2019 (start of month), a Catholic Church in Linchuan District (Fuzhou City, Jiangxi Province) was shut down, on the grounds that 'the congregation was too large'. The government also posted a slogan promoting the core socialist values at the entrance of the church. The incident was part of a broader campaign to persecute congregations and churches that declined to join the Chinese Patriotic Catholic Association.

Around 1 May 2019 (beginning of month), government officials led more than 10 villagers to smash and destroy all of the Buddhist statues of Shiyu Temple in Zhangqiu (Jinan, Shandong). The remains of the statues were buried in dug-out pits. This is part of a plan to crackdown on temples and outdoor religious venues as local officials prepared for a visit by the central government.

Around 1 May 2019 (beginning of month), a temple in Pinglu (Shuozhou, Shanxi) was sealed off by government authorities on the grounds that it was unlicensed. The officials also drove out all the monks from the temple and prohibited anyone from entering it. This is part of the campaign to suppress religious activities in the country.

On 2 May 2019, government officials forcibly removed the signboard (which contained crescent moon and Islamic minaret symbols) above the door of Hui restaurant 'Yang's Beef Stretched Noodles' in Zhongyuan (Zhengzhou, Henan) as part of a five-year plan to 'sinicize' all Chinese Muslims outside of Xinjiang.

On 4 May 2019, the Puyang County government forcibly dismantled the domes and star-and-crescent symbols of a mosque in Puyang County, Henan Province, which was the largest Islamic symbol in the local Hui area. The demolition work lasted for six days. It was part of the national five-year sinicization campaign targetting Muslims outside Xinjiang.

On 5 May 2019, more than 20 workers hired by local government officials forcibly dismantled 6 round Islamic structures at the top of a residential building in an ethnic Hui community in Liangyuan District (Shangqiu City, Henan Province). It was part of the national five-year sinicization campaign targetting Muslims outside of Xinjiang.
On 6 May 2019, the cross outside a Catholic church in Handan City, Hebei Province was demolished by government officials.

On 9 May 2019, more than 20 police demolished the office of a petitioner in Xiling District (Yichang City, Hubei City) on the ground of 'illegal structure'. The authorities arranged a TV team and a camera drone to film the demolition process.

On 10 May 2019, a Three-Self church venue in Yanwo Town (Jingzhou City, Hubei Province) was demolished by local authorities, claiming that the building had to be torn down to 'implement the state's policies'. The person-in-charge of the venue was made to sign the demolition agreement, and promised a compensation for the demolition. The government compensation never materialized. This was part of a broader campaign undertaken by the CCP to crack down on religious activities.

On 12 May 2019, the Jinxiangtan Church in Xiangtan City, Hunan Province was shut down by the police. At least 15 other house churches were sealed off over the weekend. It was reported that it might be part of a national campaign by the authorities to silence dissent and religious individuals before the 30th anniversary of Tiananmen Square protests.

On 12 May 2019, the Fuzhou Reformed House Church in Gulou (Fuzhou City, Fujian Province) was shut down by the police for refusing to join the Three-Self Church. Over 20 police officers stormed into the meeting venue, dismissed all the believers and seized over 200 books, including Bibles and hymnbooks. The police also arrested the church's elders and a few co-workers. At least 15 other house churches were sealed off over the weekend. It was reported that it might be part of a national campaign by the authorities to silence dissent and religious individuals before the 30th anniversary of Tiananmen Square protests.

On 12 May 2019, the Ren'ai Reformed Church in Guiyang city, Guizhou Province was shut down by the police. At least 15 other house churches were sealed off over the weekend. It was reported that it might be part of a national campaign by the authorities to silence dissent and religious individuals before the 30th anniversary of Tiananmen Square protests.

On 12 May 2019, more than 100 police officers demolished all the buildings inside a 'Chairman Mao Buddha Temple' in Ruzhou (Pingdingshan, Henan). The temple was a place of worship whose owner was unable to get a permit and, thus, came with an idea to turn it into a temple worshiping China's revolutionary leaders. They also sealed off the entrance to the courtyard with a mound of dirt and sheets of galvanized iron.

On 12 May 2019, protestant home churches were taken over by the authorities in Nanchang City of Jiangxi Province. In addition to three other cities, a total of more than 10 house churches were sealed off on the same day as part of a national campaign to crack down on home churches.

On 12 May 2019, protestant home churches were taken over by the authorities in Pidu District (Chengdu City, Sichuan Province). In addition to three other cities, a total of more than 10 house churches were sealed off on the same day as part of a national campaign to crack down on home churches.

On 12 May 2019, protestant home churches were taken over by the authorities in Xiamen city of Fujian Province. In addition to three other cities, a total of more than 10 house churches were sealed off on the same day as part of a national campaign to crack down on home churches.

On 12 May 2019, protestant home churches were taken over by the authorities in Shanghai (Shanghai Municipality). In addition to three other cities, a total of more than 10 house churches were sealed off on the same day as part of a national campaign to crack down on home churches.

On 12 May 2019, a Three-Self church in Hangzhou (Zhejiang Province) was demolished by the local authorities. This is reported to be part of a wider campaign by the CCP to force churches to 'donate' their meeting venues.

Around 13 May 2019 (between 12 May - 14 May), government personnel sealed off 18 temples in 14 villages in Guangwu town, Xingyang (Zhengzhou, Henan) as part of the campaign to crack down on the country's religious activities.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of China (2012-) People's Armed Police
NOTES: On 14 May 2019, the Dianjiang county government sent 500 people, including special police officers and officials from the Public Security Bureau and Environmental Protection Bureau, to demolish an 18-meter-tall sculpture of Buddha's head at Dafo Temple at Baijia town (Dianjing, Chongqing). The act was taken in the context of a nationwide crackdown on outdoor religious statues initiated by Chinese central government.

In May 2019, two white Tibetan towers in a Tibetan Buddhist temple in Jintai (Baoji City, Shaanxi Province) were painted grey on the orders of the government. Other Buddhist symbols in the temple were replaced with slogans promoting the new 'Regulations on Religious Affairs' and core socialist values.

Around 15 May 2019 (month of), the Cangzhou city government ordered the director of a Catholic orphanage for disabled children in Cangzhou City, Hebei Province to remove paintings of the Virgin Mary, liturgical calendars, and all other religious symbols from a small church on site, on the grounds that 'charitable institutions are not allowed to have religious overtones'. Religious symbols had since been removed from the church. The director was demanded to sign an agreement to stop using the church.

In May 2019, a famous ancient Buddhist temple on Mount Wutai had nearly 180 Buddhist icons demolished in three rounds by local authorities, on the grounds that these statues were 'too tall'. This was part of a greater campaign by the CCP to remove all outdoor Buddhist statues.
In May 2019, A Sola Fide meeting venue in Weihai (Shandong Province) was shut down by the authority. This is reportedly because the church refused to join the state-sanctioned Three-Self Church.

In May 2019, a Sunday school of a Catholic Church in Pingtan County (Fuzhou City, Fujian Province) was forced to shut down by government officials. This was part of a broader campaign to prohibit all religious activities for minors, since the introduction of the new Regulations on Religious Affairs in February 2018.

In May 2019, the cross of a Three-Self church in Tantou Town (Ganzhou City, Jiangxi Province) was demolished by the county's government officials, due to the proximity of the church to the highway. This was part of a broader campaign to remove religious symbols from churches and other structures.

In May 2019, a statue of Guanyin, Buddhist Goddess of Mercy, in Holy Water Pond Folk Culture Park of Chengdongbu village, Pingdu district (Qingdao, Shandong) was dismantled by the local authority according to the CCP's policy to prohibit the spread of 'feudal and superstitious' activities and reduce outdoor religious objects. The local authority was notified with CCP policy in the autumn of 2018 and tried to alter the Guanyin statue by replacing the head with that of Confucius in an effort to save it. However, the hybrid provoked more controversy even abroad. The authority had to demolish it in May 2019.

In May 2019, a Buddhist Temple in Tai'an City, Shandong was shut down by the local Religious Affairs Bureau, on the grounds that it did not have the religious activity venue registration certificate. All the monks living on the premises were also driven away.

In May 2019, three temples were shut down in Pingdu (Qingdao, Shandong) as a means to rectify Taoism and Buddhism. Yunshan Temple - a Taoist place of worship was closed on the grounds that it was unlicensed. Two Buddhist temples - Gaofu Temple and Cihang Temple - were sealed off because they allegedly 'violated building laws'. A Bodhisattva statue was covered after the closure.
In May 2019, local government ordered the removal of 13 Buddhist statues from a tourist site in Maguan County (Wenshan Zhuang and Miao Autonomous, Yunnan), which were buried in a pit.

Around 15 May 2019 (month of), a Catholic church Sunday school in Pingtan County (Fuzhou City, Fujian Province) was forced to close by the authorities. It was part of a broader campaign to crack down on religious activities for Catholic youth.

Around 15 May 2019 (month of), a 5-meter-high Guanyin statue in Jiaohe city, Jilin province, was demolished on orders from the government because it was deemed too high. The act was taken to advance the CCP's nationwide campaign to eliminate all open-air religious symbols.

In May 2019, a Taoist Sanguan Temple in Chahe town in Honghu City (Jingzhou City, Hubei Province) was rectified into a 'cultural activity centre' by the temple manager in order to save the temple. Signboards promoting the core socialist values were posted, with a large Xi Jinping banner posted in the middle of a hall. It was an attempt to save the temple from being demolished by the authorities, after it was sealed off and marked for demolition by the authorities in the previous month, as part of the CCP policy to demolish temples nationwide.

In May 2019, a House Church in Chengdu, Sichuan was shut down for refusing to submit to the government's control. More than 20 government personnel broke into the meeting venue and ordered believers to end their gathering. Police officers registered the IDs of all believers who were present and drove them out of the church. All church's belongings, including Bibles, podium, sound equipment, and over 100 chairs, were forcibly removed.

In May 2019, the cross of a Three-Self Church in Junan County (Linyi City, Shandong Province) was dismantled by workers, on orders of a local official. The Chinese national flag was also erected in front of the building.

Around 15 May 2019 (month of), the local Religious Affairs Bureau ordered a temple in Mianyang City, Sichuan Province, to remove the 500 Arhat statues at the temple's expense and build a cover to conceal a large reclining Buddha to advance the CCP's nationwide campaign to eliminate all open-air religious symbols. Moreover, 330 1.8-meter-tall statues of Shakyamuni Buddha and 88 additional religious figures outside the Arhat Temple were also covered with a specially-built glass structure. Also, over 1,200 other outdoor religious symbols were concealed.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Buddhist Group (China); Daoist Group (China); Confucian Group (China)
NOTES: In May 2019, 500 Arhat statues in the Arhat (or Luohan) Mountain Scenic Area in Lianhua town, Tong'an District (Xiamen city, Fujian Province) were covered with camouflage cloths, following an order from the central government claiming that they were 'unauthorized' and that no more than ten religious icons are allowed in one place. The statues of Buddhas were either concealed or demolished by the resort management company. Signs with religious content were also modified. The Arhat (or Luohan) Mountain Scenic Area is a large cultural and tourist resort previously approved by the government and built with private funds to pay tribute to Confucianism, Buddhism, and Taoism.

In May 2019, a 20 meters tall Buddhist Goddess Guanyin statue in Dahebei Ecological Garden Cemetery in Tieling county (Tieling City, Liaoning Province) was altered by the local authorities to save it from being demolished according to the CCP's policy to prohibit the spread of 'feudal and superstitious' activities and reduce outdoor religious objects. The statue's head was re-decorated in the shape of a lotus flower and the renovation took around three months. In the same county, another over-10-meter-tall statue of the Ksitigarbha Bodhisattva in the Junlongquan Cemetery was also covered twice to prevent it from being demolished due to the same campaign.

On 16 May 2019, the cross of a Three-Self Church in Lanling County (Linyi City, Shandong Province) was removed by workers dispatched by a local official, on the grounds that 'no crosses could be near national highways'.

On 16 May 2019, the provincial government sent its personnel to demolish a house church in Qiupo Village, Tanghe County (Nanyang, Henan), citing illegal occupation of farmland. The manager of the church was fined 50k RMB as the demolition cost. This is part of an ongoing countrywide campaign to crack down on house churches in China.

Around 16 May 2019 (month of), government officials from Datong city rectified the Tibetan Buddhist Huiquan Temple in Xisi village (Datong, Shanxi), converting the stupa (a shrine that housed sacred relics) into a Chinese-style pavilion with gray bricks and black tiles. Traditional bronze pillars at the entrance were also demolished.

On 16 May 2019, a Catholic meeting venue in Dongjiekou, Fuzhou in Fujian province was 'taken over' by over 100 personnel from the local government, who intercepted and photographed every person why came to the venue on the grounds that such gathering was unapproved.

On 16 May 2019, Buddhist statues in Shengquan Temple in Xianggongzhuang, Zhangqiu (Jinan, Shandong) were removed and smashed into pieces by local officials. This is part of a plan to crackdown on temples and outdoor religious venues as local officials prepared for a visit by the central government.

As reported on 16 May 2019, the government authorities seized the land of as many as 40 Tibetan families in Chunga village, near Qabqa City (Hainan Tibetan Autonomous, Qinghai) in order to make way for airport construction.
Around 16 May 2019 (middle of month), a Sola Fide house church meeting venue in Chenzhou City (Hunan Province) was shut down by the authority for refusing to join the Three-Self Church.

On 18 May 2019, Xunsiding Church in Xiamen city of Fujian Province was shut down by the local Ethnic and Religious Affairs Bureau. This was part of a broader campaign to crack down on places of worship across China.

On 19 May 2019, almost 40 personnel from the local government of Dianzhuangzhen surrounded a church in Dianzhuangzhen, Luoyang, Henan in an attempt to prevent the church goers from getting close when they forcefully changed the use of the church to an elderly activity centre. While arguing with the personnel, two people associated with the church fainted and were sent to a hospital. The reason for changing the use of the church was believed to be 1) limiting the development of Christianity in the locality and 2) the church was too close to the cultural centre and bad influence on the people. A personnel from the church was detained and released on the same day for tearing off a poster saying 'follow the Communist Party' which replaced the original Christian logo and paintings.

On 19 May 2019, almost 70 police officers and deputies stormed in to a Protestant house church in Siming (Xiamen, Fujian) and demanded a stop to the gathering immediately and took photos around the venue. Since 19 May, the government guarded the venue and prevented any believers from entering.

On 20 May 2019, a Wuzhuang church in Mawei (Fuzhou, Fujian) was shut down by police after police repeatedly threatened to cut off electricity and water supply if the church didn't register to join the Three-Self Church for years.

On 21 May 2019, over 20 personnel from the local government demolished some walls of a Catholic meeting venue in Dongjiekou, Fuzhou in Fujian province, claiming that they were obstructing the fire escape passage. Doors, parts of the ceiling, wall cabinets, and walls of the suite where nuns resided have been destroyed. The church's belongings were taken away. The police threatened demolition of the church.

On 21 May 2019, a Buddhist temple in Shishou (Jingzhou City, Hubei Province) was raided by officials from the United Front Work Department, Public Security Bureau, and other government institutions. They took away all the religious texts by a prominent Buddhist monk, and ordered to have them burned. This was part of a broader effort to confiscate books by a prominent Buddhist monk, whose teachings have been banned by the CCP.

On 22 May 2019, a Buddhist temple in Wu'an, Handan, Hebei province was forcefully demolished by local authority for occupying farmland and being an undocumented piece of land. Officers forced the nuns out of the temple, who knelt down to beg them not to demolish the temple. Two people were taken away for obstructing the demolition.

On 22 May 2019, a Catholic meeting venue in Pingtan County (Fuzhou, Fujian) province was raided and shut down by the local police, one day after another similar venue was torn down in Dongjiekou, Fuzhou.

On 24 May 2019, five domes of a century-old mosque in Pingdingshan city, Henan Province were removed and smashed into pieces by the authorities, due to a provincial campaign to expel Saudi and Arabic influence in the province, which is home to a large number of Hui Muslims. This was part of a broader campaign to 'sinicize' Islam in China, where all traditional Islamic symbols and characters are prohibited from being publicly displayed.

On 24 May 2019, more than 20 people were dispatched by the government to demolish parts of a church in Gulou, Fuzhou, Fujian province, on the grounds that the church's gatherings blocked fire exits. This follows officials' visit to the on 19 May, during which they questioned every person who showed up at the site.

On 26 May 2019, 5 police officers stormed into a house church in Lushan County (Pingdingshan, Henan), tore down and destroyed the picture of the cross, confiscated Bibles, hymnbooks, and other items. The owner of the meeting venue was taken to the police station and asked not to believe in God anymore and to host gatherings, otherwise, threatening with arrest.

On 26 May 2019, police stormed into a house church in Anyuan county, Ganzhou in Jiangxi province and looted it, taking away Bibles, poetries, tables and chairs. Four believers were taken away for investigation.

On 27 May 2019, a church in Huanggu (Shenyang, Liaoning) was shut down by the Religious Affairs Bureau. This was part of a broader campaign to exterminate house churches that refused to join the state-controlled Three-Self church.

On 28 May 2019, a Three-Self church in Wuzhi county (Jiaozuo City, Henan Province) was demolished by local authorities because the person in charge of the church refused to 'donate' the church land to the government.

Around 31 May 2019 (end of month), a unregistered Catholic church in Gaoyang County (Baoding City, Hebei Province) was shut down by over 20 personnel from the county government and the police. The priest who used to live on the premises was also expelled. It was reported that the authorities also visited over 80 congregation members at their homes, to force them to sign an application to join the state-run Chinese Patriotic Catholic Association.

Within less than a month from early June 2019, the crosses from 14 Christian meeting venues in the Gaoxin District (Linyi National Hi-Tech lndustrial Development Zone) within Luozhuang District (Linyi City, Shandong Province) were removed on orders of the Gaoxin District government.

Around 1 June 2019 (beginning of month), a white marble Guanyin statue at a residential community plaza in Lanshan District (Linyi City, Shandong Province) was concealed in a large fiberglass vase. Slogans promoting the core socialist values, such as 'prosperity' and 'democracy' were painted at the bottom of the statue. The act was taken as part of the CCP's policy to destroy all outdoor religious statues in the country.

On 2 June 2019, four meeting venues of an All Sphere Church in Jianshui County (Honghe Hani and Yi Autonomous Prefecture, Yunnan Province) were raided by the police. Over 100 believers were taken away to the police stations for questioning. Bibles and hymnbooks were also confiscated from the venues. The houses of believers were raided, and believers were threatened by the police that they would be sentenced to prison should they continue practising their faith.

On 6 June 2019, more than 100 government personnel forcibly demolished a Taoist temple in Shuangyashan city in Heilongjiang province without the person in charge ahead of the decision. Statues and other belongings in the temple were destroyed, causing up to 200,000 RMB worth of loss to the temple.

On 8 June 2019, six outdoor statues of a Buddhist temple in Mile City (Yunnan Province) were demolished and the temple was later shut down. This was part of a broader campaign undertaken by the CCP to crack down on religious activities.

On 9 June 2019, a Three-Self Church in Huangpi District (Wuhan City, Hubei Province) was ordered to be demolished by local government officials. They also confiscated Bibles and ordered the church's elder to tear down the signboards and Christian couplets. The elder was also ordered to study 'traditional Chinese culture, CCP's regulations and state laws'. The cross of the church was also torn down and thrown to the ground.

On 9 June 2019, government officials stormed into a Three-self church in Shangqiu, Henan province, taking away the church operation license and prohibiting any future church activities, claiming that they saw two children playing outside the church. They warned the church runners that everything in the church would be confisticated if they discovered anyone taking children to the church.
On 11 June 2019, a church in Huli district (Xiamen, Fujian) was shut down by the police without any government document.

Arrests: On 13 June 2019, more than 10 police officers stormed into a Protestant house church in Xiamen, Fujian province and took away more than 30 believers and the pastor. This is part of an ongoing campaign to crackdown on house churches in China.

On 14 June 2019, a temple in Fucheng District (Mianying City, Sichuan Province) was torn down by government officials. It was reported that the officials also confiscated RMB 20,000 of offerings prior to the demolition. This was part of a broader campaign launched by the CCP to demolish temples and statues across China.

Around 15 June 2019 (month of), local authorities removed traditional Tibetan windows in a Tibetan Buddhist palace in an ancient temple in Shijiazhuang prefecture (Hebei). The rectified many other Tibetan structures and symbols, and added new Chinese features traditional to the Ming and Qing dynasties. Statues and towers were either demolished or covered.

Around 15 June 2019 (middle of month), a 29-meter-tall Shakyamuni Buddha statue in Fengman District in Jilin City (Jilin Province) was destroyed with explosives because local authorities claimed that it was 'too tall'. The demolition was carried out with government officials present on site. The act was taken according to the CCP's policy to remove outdoor religious statues nationwide.

Around 15 June 2019 (month of), a group of people were seen destroying and burning things at the Daoist Wuliang Temple in Taibai county (Baoji, Shaanxi). All statues and other items were smashed, and ornaments on the walls were painted over. It was reported that many Buddhist, Daoist and folk religion temples were demolished or shutdown in Shaanxi province during the year.

Around 15 June 2019 (month of), an outdoor Buddhist statue in the Phoenix Mountain Scenic Area in Baiqi town (Shulan county-level city, Jilin City, Jilin Province) was demolished by the authorities to advance the CCP's nationwide campaign to eliminate all open-air religious symbols.

In June 2019, more than 120 members of the Church of Almighty God were arrested in cities across Shandong province, including Jinan, Binzhou, and Heze as part of a special arrest operation of CAG members. On 15 June alone, 52 people were arrested in Heze. This is part of a nationwide campaign to 'clean up gang crime and eliminate evil' that targets religious goups.

In June 2019, all religious items were taken away from unregistered Catholic churches in Taihe Village, Yi County and Dongzhao Village, Dingzhou in Baoding City, Hebei. This was part of a broader campaign to crack down on Catholic churches that refused to join the Chinese Patriotic Catholic Association.

Around 15 June 2019 (month of), the local government in Yichun prefecture-level city, Heilongjiang Province, demolished three large Buddhist statues in the Huilongwan National Forest Park, claiming that 'relevant procedures had not been completed and non-religious venues are not allowed to have outdoor Buddhist statues'. The act was taken to advance the CCP's nationwide campaign to eliminate all open-air religious symbols.

In June 2019, a Catholic church in Anguo City (Baoding City, Hebei Province) was forcibly sealed off by the government. This was part of a broader campaign to crack down on Catholic churches that refused to join the Chinese Patriotic Catholic Association.

In June 2019, over 90 statues and some building of a Buddhist temple in Yongsheng County (Lijiang City, Yunnan Province) was demolished by the county's Ethnic and Religious Affairs Bureau, on the grounds that they were illegal. This was part of a broader campaign undertaken by the CCP to crack down on religious activities.
In June 2019, government officials demolished an open-air Nanhai Guanyin statue in Shangpan (Linhai City, Zhejiang Province). The reasons for its demolition were not known.

In June 2019, the crosses from at least 37 Three-Self Churches in Guanyun County (Lianyungang City, Jiangsu Province) were demolished by the authorities. This was part of a broader campaign to remove religious symbols and elements from churches.

In June 2019, the cross of a Three-Self church venue in Huangpi District (Wuhan City, Hubei Province) was dismantled. A poster on the new Regulations on Religious Affairs was also hung on the church, and the pastor was ordered to 'study the Party's spirit'.

In June 2019, the government remodelled the Mochuan Great Mosque, located in Hanji town of Linxia county (Linxia Hui Autonomous Prefecture, Gansu Province) and ordered that its dome and four minarets were also demolished as a part of a national campaign to 'sinicize' the Muslim faith and replace it with the CCP's ideology. It was reported that numerous mosques in Linxia had been remodelled by 2019 to look 'more Chinese' with their traditional Islamic-style elements removed and replaced with the ones reflecting traditional Chinese architecture, including the old mosque in Tuanju village.

Around 15 June 2019 (month of), three Buddhist statues -- a 9-meter-tall dripping-water Guanyin statue and a boy-girl duo symbolising good fortune -- were demolished at Puti (Bodhi) Temple in Mile county (Honghe Hani and Yi Autonomous, Yunnan) on orders of the local Religious Affairs Bureau, which stated that the temple was not registered as a religious activity venue. The temple was closed down (at an unspecified date) after its director refused to convert it into an elderly activities centre.

Around 15 June 2019 (month of), the Younan Three-Self Church (with a congregation size of 400) in Guannan county (Lianyungang, Jiangsu) was forced to merge with a smaller church on orders of the government. The government threatened to demolish the church unless they moved out within three days. It was reported that the venue was later converted to a cultural auditorium.

Around 15 June 2019 (middle of month), the cross of a Three-Self Church in Ceshan Town (Linyi City, Shandong Province) was forcibly demolished by local authorities, on the grounds that it was 'too high'. It was reported that officials from the district and town governments were threatened to be dismissed if the cross was not demolished.

ACTOR1: Government of China (2017-) Hong Kong Special Administrative Region
NOTES: On 15 June 2019, the Chief Executive of Hong Kong announced the suspension of the controversial extradition bill that had sparked days of protests in the city. However, she said she was not going to withdraw the bill altogether.

In June 2019, an outdoor Guanyin statue in Yufeng Mount Scenic Area, Yubei District, Chongqing City was demolished. Police were present on the day of demolition to cordone off the main intersections leading to the mountain.

On 16 June 2019, a Buddhist temple in Xing'an County (Guilin City, Guangxi Province) had all its Buddha statues removed by about 70 law enforcement officers. This was after the authorities issued an order on 4 June 2019 for the temple to be shut down and all religious activities, signboards and recognition plaques to be removed by 15 June 2019.

On 16 June 2019, over 100 house members of the Cornerstone Church (Fangjiaoshi Church), located in the Dingtaifenghua residential area in Taiyuan, Shanxi [location coded at Xinghualing] were escorted by police to public security sub-bureaus for interrogation. In order to be released, their relatives had to pick them up and the adherents were forced to sign a 'statement of guarantee' and a 'statement of repentance' promising to break off ties with the church.

On 16 June 2019, a Christian house church in Xiang'an (Xiamen, Fujian) was forcibly shut down by police and the sign of the church was destroyed. Police also took away the phones of the church-goers. This is part of a crackdown of house churches in China.

On 17 June 2019, several buddhist temples in the scenic area of Cangu in Yi County (Hebei Province) were demolished by more than 100 government officials, on the grounds that they were 'illegal constructions'.
On 18 June 2019, a Three-Self church at Renzhuang village of Guandi township, Hongqi District (Xinxiang City, Henan Province) was demolished by about 200 police officers sent by local authorities.

On 19 June 2019, officials from the local Religious Affairs Bureau and police officers sealed off the Fule Church, a place of worship that was not part of the state-run Three-Self Church, in Jiamusi City, Heilongjiang Province. They broke into the church when a dozen members were listening to an audio sermon by a South Korean pastor. They confiscated 80,000 RMB (about $ 11,200) of donation money, some valuables, and more than 200 copies of religious literature, including the Bible because the church was not allowed to receive foreign donations according to Chinese law and the believers disobeyed the authority by refusing to join the Three-Self Church. The believers were taken to the local police station to sign statements promising not to attend worship services in the future.

On 20 June 2019, two gathering places of a church in Haicang District (Xiamen, Fujian) were shut down by the police, citing illegal gatherings and disturbance to the public. The pastor as well as many members were taken away by police for investigation. This was part of an ongoing campaign to crack down on churches in China.

Security measures: On 20 June 2019, government-backed people used container homes to create roadblocks at the North, West and East Gates of Liulin village in Jinshui district (Zhengzhou, Henan) as part of a months-long operation to cut off economic support and force villagers to evict. Over twenty hired individuals stayed behind to guard the roadblocks. The hired-individuals later also set up checkpoints to intercept villagers and vehicles, welded shut the gates, and used containers to enhance the roadblocks. The roadblocks remained in place at least until 26 August.

On 26 June 2019, two Protestant churches belonging to the Zhaozhai Church in Zhoukou City, Henan Province were demolished by the local authorities to advance the CCP's policy to reduce the number of Three-Self Churches nationwide. These two churches had been changed to an activity centre for elderly and stopped all religious activities in 2018 according to the government's order.
On 26 June 2019, a three-self church in Yunyang, Shiyan, Hubei province was raided by local police to combat religious gatherings. 37 people were arrested and released on the same day.
Property destruction: On 28 June 2019, the Buddhist Bailong Temple in Jiujiang prefecture (Jiangxi) [coded to Xunyang district] was demolished by the local government.

Around 30 June 2019 (end of month), a Sola Fide meeting venue in Wuhan City (Hubei Province) was shut down by the authorities, and its preacher was arrested. This is reportedly because the church refused to join the state-sanctioned Three-Self Church.

On 30 June 2019, a house church meeting venue in Nanchang's Wanli district was closed because it was unregistered, and the person in charge was taken away for questioning. Three other meeting venues in Nanchang were also shut down.

Around 1 July 2019 (beginning of month), a Sola Fide house church in Jiujiang (Jiangxi) was raided by the local government. More than 20 officials stormed in, confiscated over 300 Bibles and other spiritual books on the grounds that the church's gatherings were illegal because it refuses to join the Three-Self Church. Six church members, including the pastor, were arrested and taken away for interrogation. The meeting venue has been shut down.

Around 1 July 2019 (in recent days), Chinese authorities expelled 3,600 monks and nuns from the Yachen Gar Tibetan Buddhist centre in Palyul (Baiyu) county (Kardze (Ganzi) prefecture, Sichuan province). The monks and nuns were sent back to their home counties (monstly in Qinghai province) for political re-education. Since May, around 7,100 monks and nuns were forced to leave Yachen Gar, which until recent years had housed an estimated 10,000 monks, nuns, and lay practitioners devoted to scriptural study and meditation. The expulsions in May mainly involved those from Chamdo City, Tibet.

Around 5 July 2019 (shortly after), a house church in Shandong Province was shut down, on the grounds that it was 'disturbing people'. It was reported that a pastor from Taiwan had been engaged in activities at the church, and was summoned by the local Religious Affairs Bureau on 5 July 2019 as a result. She was threatened to be deported if she was found engaging in religious activities again. This was part of an intensified campaign to crack down on churches with foreign ties.

On 6 July 2019, 4 government officials stormed into a church in Lushan, Lianxi district, Jiujiang city in Jiangxi province where 37 youngsters were participating in a summer camp. They took pictures of every youngster on the site and dismissed the camp. This is believed to be part of a crackdown on church influence on young people.

On 7 July 2019, a Catholic church in Boye County, Baoding City (Hebei Province) was raided by over 30 police officers. Police emptied the church, took away the priest, and subsequently closed down the church. The priest was sent back to his hometown the next day.

On 7 July 2019, about 200 government personnel in Fugong county (Nujiang Lisu Autonomous Prefecture, Yunnan Province) demolished at least 4 Protestant house churches in several villages within the county that refused to join the state controlled Three-Self Churches. Some churches were burned down to the ground.

On 14 July 2019, five police officers from Xiantao City, Hubei Province, barged into a church and arrested an Irish and a Chinese priest. The authorities claimed that foreigners are not allowed to preach and the Irish priest was forced to leave China the next day. It was further reported that several plainclothes police officers had been visiting the church daily three days prior to the arrest.
In July 2019, a Catholic meeting venue in Suileng County (Suihua City, Heilongjiang Province) was shut down by officials, for refusing to join the Chinese Patriotic Catholic Association.

In July 2019, a statue of Lao-Tzu outside the Daoist Xuandu Temple in the Dagushan Scenic Area in Gushan town (Donggang City, Liaoning Province) were altered to look like a writer of one of the essential classical novels of Chinese literature as required by the city's Religious Affairs Bureau. The Bureau had sealed off the temple earlier in September 2018 in an attempt to demolish it, but only allowed to the temple to remain on the condition that Lao-Tzu statue would be altered.

On 15 July 2019, dozens of police stormed into a Three-self church in Foshan city, Guangdong province where more than 80 children were participating in a summer camp. Police recorded personal information of every child and took away the priest and 6 church workers. All were released on the same day. This is believed to be part of a crackdown on church influence on young people.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Muslim Group (China); Hui Ethnic Group (China); Students (China); Teachers (China)
NOTES: In July 2019, some teachers and students from a private school teaching in Arabic in Jinfeng City, Ningxi Hui Autonomous were arrested and taken away for questioning by government officials for storing and distributing the Qurans. It was reported that about 100,000 Qurans were confiscated and burned. In November 2019, students from the school were ordered to go on a holiday by the city government, while teachers were dismissed and sent home.

Around 15 July 2019 (month of), a Daoist temple in the New District of Yan'an City, Shaanxi Province was taken over by the authorities and repurposed into an activity centre. All religious statues were removed from the temple in the next month. It was reported that religious statues were also removed from at least two other Daoist temples in Yan'an City. This was part of the broader campaign to crack down and repurpose Daoist temples.

Around 15 July 2019 (month of), the local authorities began a construction to conceal a 40-metre-tall Shakyamuni Buddha statue located at the top of Lianhua Mountain in Baotou City, Inner Mongolia, by building a specially-constructed artificial mountain to hide the statue. This was part of a nationwide drive to conceal outdoor Buddhist statutes across China.

In July 2019, a True Jesus Church (Protestant) venue in Jianyang City (Chengdu City, Sichuan Province) was shut down by government officials, on the grounds that it was 'illegal'. The government officials also arranged for workers to saw off the cross and block the door of the venue.

In July 2019, the cross from a Three-Self Church in Jiamusi City, Heilongjiang Province was removed by the city government. This was part of the broader campaign to 'sinicize' Christianity in the province.

Around 15 July 2019 (month of), a large 'kang' (a kind of heated adobe or brick bed popular in northeastern China for gatherings) which could accommodate about 200 people, in a Charismatic (Protestant) house church venue in Zumin Township (Liaoyuan City, Jilin Province) was destroyed by local government officials. This was part of a broader campaign to crack down on unregistered Protestant venues across China.

In July 2019, Islamic symbols such as domes and star-and-crescent symbols were removed from about a dozen mosques in Xingyang City (Zhengzhou City, Henan Province) by the authorities. This was part of a broader campaign launched by the CCP to 'sinicize' Islam across China.

In July 2019, an outdoor Maitreya statue in a forest park of Dongguan City (Guangdong Province) was demolished, on the grounds that it was 'too visible'. This was part of a greater campaign by the CCP to remove all outdoor Buddhist statues.

In July 2019, a government-approved Three-Self Church in Yuanyang County (Xinxiang City, Henan Province) was shut down by the local government, prohibiting believers from gathering. It was reported that the government had been persecuting the church since the start of 2019 because the pastor at the church refused to remove the cross and raise the Chinese national flag in the church, as part of the religious 'sinicization' campaign by the CCP. The government subsequently took over the management of the church on 15 November 2019.

In July 2019, an outdoor Maitreya statue in Zhaoqing City, Guangdong Province was demolished, with officials claiming that 'scenic areas are not allowed to have religious statues.' In its place, a slogan promoting core socialist values was displayed after the demolition of the statue. This was part of a greater campaign by the CCP to remove all outdoor Buddhist statues.

Around 16 July 2019 (middle of month), more than 30 officials stormed into a Catholic Church in Linzhang County (Handan City, Hebei Province) and ordered the removal of the cross and statue of the Virgin Mary. The statue of Virgin Mary was demolished and the church subsequently closed down. This was part of the crackdown on churches that refused to join the Chinese Patriotic Catholic Association.

Around 16 July 2019 (middle of month), one Protestant house church in Sili town, Guixi city (Yingtan City, Jiangxi Province) was raided by the government, with the venue emptied and around 7,600 RMB (about $ 1,060) worth of property confiscated by the authorities because the church did not join state-controlled religious organisations. The person in charge of the church was threatened to be arrested if he continued holding religious meetings.

Property destruction: Around 16 July 2019 (month of), a Three-Self church in Suqian prefecture (Jiangsu) (coded to Sucheng) was demolished by authorities, and its congregation was merged with another venue.

Security measures: Around 16 July 2019 (month of), a Protestant church in Siyang county (Suqian, Jiangsu) was merged with other churches under orders of the authorities. A government official revealed that 40% of churches in Suqian had been ordered to be shut down or merged to achieve a steady decline of churches and believers.

Land seizure: Around 16 July 2019 (month of), at least four Three-Self venues in Lianyungang prefecture (Jiangsu) (coded to Xinpu) were merged with other churches. Some were later rented out, while others were converted into a library and cultural auditorium.

Around 16 July 2019 (month of), a 17-meter-tall Guanyin statue on Nanzhao Customs Island in Dali (Yunnan) was demolished by the authorities for being too tall. Government authorities threatened to close the tourist attraction if the statue was not demolished. The demolition process took four months.

On 17 July 2019, a 10-meter-tall statue of Shakyamuni Buddha outside Longxing Temple in Mengjin county (Luoyang City, Henan Province) was demolished by government-hired workers. The complete demolition of the statue took two days. The act was taken according to the CCP's policy to remove outdoor religious statues nationwide.

On 18 July 2019, more than 10 police officers stormed into a house church in Wanzai county, Yichun, Jiangxi province and damaged the door lock and electric facilities, throwing all chairs and tables to the yard and demolished the church the day after, citing that gatherings in this venue were not permitted.
