As reported on 18 July 2019, 3,600 more monks and nuns have been evicted from the Yachen Gar Tibetan Buddhist centre. This is a continuation of the expulsion since May 2019.

On 20 July 2019, a Catholic church in Wenquan town (Fuzhou City, Jiangxi Province) was raided and shut down by the government because the church refused to join the state-controlled Chinese Patriotic Catholic Association. On the day, nearly 30 officials stormed into the church and smashed the statues of Jesus and the Virgin Mary, together with other properties in the church. The statue of the Virgin Mary was burned.

On 22 July 2019, the police raided and shut down a house church meeting venue in Fuxing town (Arun banner, Hulunbuir region, Inner Mongolia) because it refused to join the state-controlled Three-Self Church. Six believers were arrested and fined. Two of them were detained for 10 days.

On 24 July 2019, a Buddhist temple in Xinqiao Town (Taizhou City, Zhejiang Province) was demolished by the local government. It was reported that the town government officials had locked the entrance to the temple in February 2019, banning all religious activities and chasing away all monks, on the grounds of 'substandard fire control measures and lack of the national flag'. The temple was undergoing renovations when the demolition took place.

On 26 July 2019, a True Jesus Church in Caidu Town, Shangcai county (Zhumadian City, Henan Province) was demolished by nearly 1,000 people sent by the local government. During the demolition, intersections leading to the church were cordoned off, and two believers guarding the church were injured while being dragged out by police. One of them had to be hospitalised due to a spike in her blood pressure. Police also took away valuables from inside the church, including electronics and believers' belongings. The demolition of the church took three days to finish. On 22 June 2019, 60 officials had broken into the church during a gathering and ordered it to shut down so that it could be turned into a nursing home, but believers refused to obey the order.

On 27 July 2019, 26 Falun Gong petitioners were arrested by the police at a residential house in Zhuyang Residential District, Dazhu County (Dazhou, Sichuan), while studying Falun Gong. Six people of the group were charged with involving cult and detained at custody facilities.

At the end of July 2019, local authorities demolished two Buddhist statutes in the towns of Changsha and Dade, both located in Kaizhou District (Chongqing Municipality). The acts were taken in the middle of a nationwide crackdown on outdoor religious statues initiated by Chinese central government.

On 29 July 2019, a Buddhist temple in Meishan City, Sichuan Province was demolished by the government, on the grounds that it was an 'unlicensed' place of worship. The demolition followed after about 500 local Buddhists tried to petition to the government to save the temple. This was part of a broader campaign launched by the CCP to demolish temples and statues across China.

On 30 July 2019, a Three-Self church in Yancheng City, Jiangsu Province was sealed off by the local authorities, after the church had been merged with another church a month ago. It was reported that the Yancheng government had been instructed by the central government to reduce the number of places of worship, reportedly in order for the central government to exercise greater control over the churches.

On 31 July 2019, a 32-meter-tall bronze four-faced Guanyin statue in Pumen Temple, located in Nanguan District (Changchun City, Jilin Province) was demolished on the grounds that it was 'too tall'. The act was taken as part of the CCP's campaign to eliminate all large open-air religious symbols.

Around 31 July 2019 (end of month), local authorities painted over a memorial stone at the Dafo Temple at Baijia town (Dianjiang county, Chongqing) which read 'Heaven-Sent Buddha Mountain'. The name of the temple at its entrance was also smeared over with cement. The act was taken in the context of a nationwide crackdown on outdoor religious statues initiated by Chinese central government.

Around 31 July 2019 (end of month), a Catholic church in Zhaozhou county, Daqing City (Heilongjiang Province) was shut down because it refused to join the Chinese Patriotic Catholic Association (CPCA). The official reason given by the government was that the church was 'unlicensed'.

On 4 August 2019, a Catholic church in Cangshan District, Fuzhou City (Fujian Province) was shut down because it refused to join the Chinese Patriotic Catholic Association (CPCA). The official reason given by the government was that it violated fire safety regulations.

On 5 August 2019, a Three-Self church in Hangkou town, Xiushui county (Jiujiang City, Jiangxi Province) was demolished by the local government on claims the land on which it stood was planned to be used for a new road. The order was issued on July 27, and the people in charge of the church tried to persuade the government to save the church. After that, they were held in the town hall and forced to sign an agreement to accept the demolition and relocation of the church. It was part of a broader campaign launched by the CCP to reduce the number of Three-Self Churches nationwide.

On 5 August 2019, dozens of bodhisattva statues in a temple in Fucheng District (Mianyang City, Sichuan Province) were destroyed by the government. The temple was also subsequently demolished, as the government claimed that the temple was standing on land promised to investors. This was part of a broader campaign launched by the CCP to demolish temples and statues across China.

On 6 August 2019, a house church meeting venue in Jiujiang, Jiangxi, was shut down by the local government, and the church's pastor was arrested and interrogated. They were asked about the number of believers in the congregation, where the donation money was kept and if the church had contacts with foreigners. They police attempted to force the pastor to disclose the whereabouts of a pastor from another church, but he refused to say anything. The pastor was released later the same day, but he has been placed under tight surveillance and prohibited from leaving the city.

On 11 August 2019, a house church in Dali (Yunnan Province) built with funding from Hong Kong was raided by around 30 officials from the Public Security Bureau and the Ethnic and Religious Affairs Bureau, and all of the church's Bibles and hymnbooks were confiscated. The act was taken in the middle of the CCP's intensified efforts to shut down house churches in mainland China with Hong Kong ties under the pretext of 'preventing riots'. Two of the persons-in-charge of the church are missionaries from Hong Kong, and Hongkongers often attended gatherings at the church.

In August 2019, a house church meeting venue in Dachang Hui Autonomous County (Langfang City, Hebei Province) was shut down by the authorities, because it was not a member of the state-controlled Three-Self Churches. This was part of a broader campaign to force house churches to join the state-controlled Three-Self churches.

In August 2019, a Guanyin statue was enclosed in a cuboid structure on orders from the local government in Jinan City, Shandong Province, with statutes of the eight Buddhist protectors of zodiac signs demolished. The local government claimed they were acting on orders from the central government.

In August 2019, a Guanyin temple in Hejiawan village of Yanchuan County (Yan'an City, Shaanxi Province) was demolished by workers hired by the government. This was part of a broader campaign to crack down on places of worship across China.

In August 2019, 40 Buddhist temples in Liuhe Town (Huanggang City, Hubei Province) were sealed off within a few days in August 2019. The people guarding the temples were also evicted. This was part of the ramped up efforts to crackdown on religious venues across Hubei Province ahead of the announcement of the central government's return inspections.

Around 15 August 2019 (month of), a Buddhist temple in Qianxi County (Tangshan City, Hebei Province) was razed to the ground by more than 20 officials from the local government acting on orders from the central government.

In August 2019, a two-storey annex with over 30 rooms of a state-run Catholic Church in Linyi City, Shandong Province, was torn down by local authorities. It was reported that the authorities also ordered for the demolition of the church building in June 2019, but the building had been spared and would instead be converted into a service centre for CCP members. This was part of a broader campaign undertaken by the CCP to crack down on religious activities.

In August 2019, three Catholic churches in Dongxiang District, Fuzhou City (Jiangxi Province) were shut down by the authorities, claiming that places of worship that are not part of the state-controlled Chinese Patriotic Catholic Association are illegal.

In the month of August 2019, five to six thousand dormitories were demolished at the Yachen Gar Tibetan Buddhist center in Baiyu/Palyul County (Garze Tibetan Autonomous, Sichuan Province) following a similar number of monks and nuns removed from the residents in May. Around 600 military personnel were deployed to monitor the inhabitants during the demolition. The demolition was said to be 'an unfolding political strategy' aimed at controlling the influence and growth of Tibetan Buddhist study and practice and dated back to early 2001.

In August 2019, a church in Mishan City (Jixi City, Heilongjiang Province) was shut down by authorities, on the grounds that it was 'too close to a school'. This was part of an ongoing campaign by the government to crack down on places of worship.

Around 15 August 2019 (month of), many Taoist symbols were removed from a temple in Xinchang County (Shaoxing City, Zhejiang Province) by the authorities and 'hardly looks like a temple now'. Surveillance cameras were installed, and the national flag was raised in the temple. This was part of the broader campaign to crack down and repurpose Daoist temples.

In August 2019, a Protestant house church in Xiangtun subdistrict, Dexing City (Shangrao City, Jiangxi Province) was shut down by the government, on the grounds that it was 'unlicensed'. It was reported that the church had refused to run the state-controlled religious organisations.

In August 2019, two churches in Pingdingshan City, Henan Province were shut down by government officials for holding 'illegal gatherings'. At one of the churches, the piano, tables and chairs were also confiscated.

In August 2019, a Sola Fide meeting venue in Jiujiang City (Jiangxi Province) was shut down by the government, on the grounds that it was 'unlicensed'. It was reported that the church had refused to run the state-controlled religious organisations.

In August 2019, Arabic characters were removed from the signboards of at least 250 Muslim shops in Xinxiang City, Henan Province, on the grounds of 'unifying Chinese characters'. Shops were also required to remove the halal signs from food packaging. It was part of a broader five-year plan to 'sinicize' Islam in China.

On 16 August 2019, a folk religion temple in Huangjiakou Town (Jingzhou City, Hubei Province) was demolished by local government officials, police officers and the town's CCP secretary. It was reported that the demolition was part of the intensified crackdowns on places of worship by Hubei Province authorities, in preparation in preparation for the Military World Games and the central government's religious work inspection.

Around 16 August 2019 (middle of month), a Buddhist temple in Xisaishan District (Huangshi City, Hubei Province) was sealed off with bricks on government orders. This was part of the ramped up efforts by local authorities to demolish outdoor Buddhist religious statues and temples.

Around 16 August 2019 (month of), armed police with guns and handcuffs and front loaders sent by the local government demolished the Buddhist Pujing Temple in Gaopo village of Baota district (Yan'an, Shaanxi). It was reported that many Buddhist, Daoist and folk religion temples were demolished or shutdown in Shaanxi province during the year, with at least 50 temples destroyed in Yan'an county within a one-month period.
Property destruction: Around 16 August 2019 (month of), the Zhazuo town government cut a three-faced Guanyin statue into pieces in Zhazuo town (Guiyang, Guizhou) for being too tall.
Property destruction: Around 16 August 2019 (month of), four Three-Self churches (including one located in Zhangjiaxu town) were demolished in Siyang county (Suqian, Jiangsu).

Property destruction: Around 16 August 2019 (month of), a Three-Self church in Siyang county (Suqian, Jiangsu) was demolished by urban management and police officers overnight after being merged with another venue.

Around 16 August 2019 (month of), the Zunhua Municipal Government painted nine white stupas in a Tibetan Buddhist temple in Zunhua County (Tangshan City, Hebei Province) yellow and removed their golden peaks, as part of an effort to ''sinicize'' the temple, to remove its distinctive Tibetan Buddhist elements and make it more representative of Chinese Buddhism. This was reportedly part of a purge of Tibetan Buddhism by city officials ahead of the upcoming visit by the central religious work inspection team in the province.

Property destruction: Around 16 August 2019 (month of), the Songyuan city government demolished the Sanyuan venue for Taoist rites and rituals in Songyuan prefecture (Jilin) [coded to Ningjiang district] on the grounds of being ''illegally constructed.''

Property destruction: Around 16 August 2019 (month of), the government demolished a two-story building used for accommodating visiting worshippers at a Taoist temple in Ji'an county (Tonghua, Jilin). It had suffered harassment from local officials since 2018 - namely those from the United Front Work Department and Religious Affairs Bureau. It had been forced to turn over donation money, with its religious statues taken away in Sep 2018, and incense burner and signboard removed in Nov 2018.

On 19 August 2019, some Chengguang officials accompanied by the local police intruded into a local church in Xiamen, Fujian undergoing renovation. They did not present their credentials and they broke the phones of some Christians. This is part of Xiamen authorities' crackdown on house churches in the region.

On 23 August 2019, a Taoist temple in Yongnian District (Handan City, Hebei Province) was demolished by the local government. More than 400 people government officials blocked the road to the temple on the day, and forcibly removed believers from the premises.

In the second half of August 2019, 40 out of 79 temples in Liuhe town, Qichun county (Huanggang City, Hubei Province) were sealed off following an order from the central government to crack down on Buddhist and folk religion places of worship. People guarding these temples were evicted, and some of them were transferred to nursing homes. These closed temples included Buddhist Kaishan Temple, Ciyundong Temple, Caogong Temple, and the Fulin Temple in Liuhe town's Zhonglu village.

On 26 August 2019, a Catholic orphanage in Xiliulin village, Xiaodian District (Taiyuan, Shanxi) was forcibly shut down by over 40 personnel from the Civil Affairs Bureau and other government institutions. More than 20 orphans with disabilities as well as some elderly people were taken away. It was reported that the orphans were taken to a local state-run welfare house. The local government had previously ordered to shut down the orphanage because 'the state did not authorise it'.

On 27 August 2019, the Buddhist Foguang Temple at Yanwo Town (Jingzhou City, Hubei Province) was destroyed according to an order issued on 22 August by the town government to demolish all the temples in town. The Taoist Qitian Temple in the town was also forcibly destroyed at an unspecified time as a result of the government order, although believers tried to seal it off and protect it.

On 28 August 2019, a South Korea-based Good News Mission church in Hebei Province was raided by six police officers while over 80 believers were having a gathering. All future gatherings and meetings at the church must stop because they are considered 'illegal gatherings' due to their ties with South Korea. Four local pastors were detained for five days because they 'engaged in the infiltration of foreign organisations'. The ban of meetings appear indefinite based on the report. The authority's act was taken among CCP's effort to inspect churches with foreign ties.

On 29 August 2019, a gold-plated Bodhisattva statue in a Buddhist temple in Daye City (Huangshi City, Hubei Province) was demolished by government officials. The word 'Buddha' above the temple door was also painted over. This was part of the ramped up efforts by local authorities to demolish outdoor Buddhist religious statues and temples.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of China (2017-) Hong Kong Police Force
ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Five Demands Movement; Government of China (2017-) Hong Kong Special Administrative Region
NOTES: On 30 August 2019, at least nine high-profile activists, including three pan-democratic Legislative Councillors pan-democratic Jeremy Tam, Au Nok-hin and Cheng Chung-tai, were arrested for their participation in anti-ELAB protests. This happened one day before the 31 August protest commemorating the incident five years ago when the National People's Congress Standing Committee handed down the '831 [August 31] framework' that effectively allowed the central government to screen candidates in the local elections for the chief executive. Arrestees believe that the arrests were to create white terror. Police denied such accusation.
Around 31 August 2019 (end of month), a house church in Honghe Prefecture, Yunnan Province, was seized by officials from the religious bureau and police. All items at the venue were confiscated.

Around 31 August 2019 (end of month), five Christian churches in Nanyang City and Zhengzhou City, both in Henan Province, were demolished or partially destroyed by the authorities as part of the CCP's campaign to combine and limit the size of the Three-Self churches and confiscate their lands.

Around 31 August 2019 (end of month), the cross of a Three-Self church in Ruihong Town (Shangrao City, Jiangxi Province) was demolished by the authorities. The pinnacle of the church was also destroyed later at an unreported date, on the grounds that it was 'in a foreign style and had to be changed to Chinese'. This was part of a broader campaign to remove religious symbols from churches and other structures.

Around 31 August 2019 (end of month), the government of Linfen City ordered for the cross and Chinese characters for 'Christian church' at a local Three-Self church in Linfen City, Shanxi Province to be demolished. The cross was removed soon after the order was issued. This was part of a broader campaign launched by the central government to remove crosses from churches across China.

Around 1 September 2019 (beginning of month), the meeting venue of New Life Church in Hegang City (Heilongjiang Province) was shut down by the authorities, because it was not a member of the state-controlled Three-Self Churches. This was part of a broader campaign to force house churches to join the state-controlled Three-Self churches.

Around 1 September 2019 (beginning of month), the meeting venue of a house church in Dongping County (Tai'an City, Shandong Province) was forced to shut down by government officials. This is part of the government's effort to crackdown on religious groups, which it considers to be 'criminal'.

On 3 September 2019, a few hundred Catholics gathered at Cangnan county, Wenzhou, Zhejiang at the grave of a priest who died two years ago but were intercepted and dispersed by more than 100 local police officers. More than 100 police officers blocked the entrances to the graveyard with police cars. Before his death, the priest refused to join the Chinese Patriotic Catholic Association and was persecuted by the CCP for a long time.

On 3 September 2019, the Buddhist Xianfeng Ancient Temple in the Datong Lake management area in Honghu City (Jingzhou City, Hubei Province) was demolished by the authorities. Over the past few months, multiple Buddhist and Taoist temples had been forcibly demolished or shut down in Hubei Province.

On 3 September 2019, a family church at Taiyuan (Shanxi Province) was shut down by the police and the Xinghualing Religious Affairs office while it was hosting a gathering of around 200 people. It was reported that the closing down of the church was related to the upcoming National Day on 1 October. Meanwhile, events of church destructions had been reported in the past year across several provinces including Shandong, Henan, Anhui and Jiangxi.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of China (2017-) Hong Kong Police Force
NOTES: On 3 September 2019, the chairman of local political party Demosisto, Ivan Lam, was taken away by the police at the Hong Kong International Airport on charges that he had 'incited others to participate in unauthorised assemblies' and 'participated in an unauthorised assembly'. This is in relation to the mass protest that took place near police headquarters on June 21.

ACTOR1: Government of China (2017-) Hong Kong Special Administrative Region
SOURCE: South China Morning Post; Radio Free Asia
NOTES: On 4 September 2019, the Chief Executive of Hong Kong announced that the anti-extradition bill that had sparked mass demonstrations in Hong Kong for the last three months would be officially withdrawn. She promised to set up an investigative platform to look into the fundamental causes of the social unrest and suggest solutions for the way forward - though stopping short of turning it into a full-fledged commission of inquiry as demanded by protesters. Protester said they did not accept this arrangement and said they would keep protesting until the government responded actively to the Five Demands.

On 6 September 2019, the Tianfu Temple in Xintan Town (Honghu City, Hubei Province) was demolished by government officials referring to the CCP's policy of banning all religions. The believers and the guards at the temple attempted to stop the demolition but were forcibly removed.

On 6 September 2019, a Guanyin temple in Xintan Town (Jingzhou City, Hubei Province) was razed to the ground on orders of the local government officials. It was reported that the demolition was part of the intensified crackdowns on places of worship by Hubei Province authorities, in preparation in preparation for the Military World Games and the central government's religious work inspection.

On 7 September 2019, an arrested monk at Tengdro monastery committed suicide while in detention in Dranak village, Tingri county (Xigaze, Tibet) (code as Shelkar) as a protest against the authorities' treatment of his family and community. He was arrested for three days among about 20 people on suspicion of having exchanged messages with other Tibetans abroad, having contributed to the earthquake relief sent to Tibetans at the sister monastery in Nepal, or having possessed photographs or literature related to the Dalai Lama.

On 8 September 2019, a house church meeting venue in a village in Zhangwang Township (Zaozhuang City, Shandong Province) was raided by government officials. All future gatherings were banned for indefinite period due to the on-going 'riots' in Hong Kong. The officials threatened to dismiss the village's Party secretary and the village head if there was to be any future gatherings.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of China (2017-) Hong Kong Police Force
NOTES: On 8 September 2019, Hong Kong activist Joshua Wong, also the secretary-general of Demosisto, was arrested at the Hong Kong International Airport in Chek Lap Kok when he was on his way to Berlin, for breaching his bail conditions. Wong believed this was a mistake as the court had approved his trip.

On 8 September 2019, an unregistered Catholic Church in Sonid Right Banner (Xilingol League, Inner Mongolia) was emptied by the local government, which dispatched over 40 personnel to seize all of the church's assets (including religious paintings, books and over 60 benches). This followed the order issued on 26 July 2019 to shut down the church on the grounds of 'lacking religious venue registration certificate' and 'substandard fire control measures'. The incident was part of a broader campaign to persecute congregations and churches that declined to join the Chinese Patriotic Catholic Association.

On 9 September 2019, over a dozen police officers stormed into the house of members of the Church of Almighty God in Shanxi Province, and searched the house without presenting a warrant. They found and confiscated 50,000 RMB. The couple argued that the money was a compensation for the death of their son from a workplace accident, but the police took away the money, insisting that it belonged to the Church. The couple was also detained.

Around 9 September 2019 (from 9 to 10 September 2019), the police in the prefecture-level city Yuncheng in Shanxi Province carried out a unified arrest operation against the Church of Almighty God (CAG) in the counties of Wenxi, Jishan, and Wanrong, as well as other localities. At least 135 CAG members were arrested during the two-day operation, and 330,000 RMB (about $ 47,000) of Church and personal money were confiscated.

On 10 September 2019, two Three-Self churches in Liangcuo village, Cangshan District (Fuzhou City, Fujian Province) were demolished by the authorities, on the grounds that they were 'unlicensed and illegally constructed'. It was reported that these places of worship under CCP's control were increasingly deemed ideological enemies and faced suppressions.

On 10 September 2019, statues of a Buddhist temple in Neijiang High-tech Zone (coded at Neijiang City, Sichuan Province) were demolished by people sent by the local government, after police officers had summoned the Buddhist monk who lived in the temple to the police station, under the pretext of 'clarifying formalities for the temple's religious activity registration certificate'. The temple was subsequently demolished a week later.

On 11 September 2019, the cross of a church in Zixi County (Fuzhou City, Jiangxi Province) was demolished on orders by the local government. According to accounts from eyewitnesses, more than 100 people including officials from the county and town governments and local police officers, cordoned off the intersections leading to the church during the demolition. The mobile phones of believers were confiscated when they attempted to take photos and videos during the demolition. This was part of a broader campaign to remove religious symbols from churches and other structures.

On 14 September 2019, a 21-meter-tall dripping-water Guanyin statue outside the Guanyin Temple in Wuhai city (Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region) was forcibly demolished by the local government on the account that 'the statue was too tall'. About 100 police officers were sent to guard the temple during the demolition, while more than a dozen Buddhists tried to prevent it. One of them was arrested.

In September 2019, an Earth God temple in Guanyingtan Town, Weiyuan County (Neijiang City, Sichuan) was dismantled by government personnel, on the grounds that it was not 'approved by the state'. The congregation was told that 'any religious group that is not officially approved is deemed a 'xie jiao' (the Chinese word for 'cult'), and is prevented from holding religious activities'. It was reported that this was part of a broader campaign launched by the government of Neijiang City to shut down Buddhist and Taoist temples on a large scale since March 2019.

In September 2019, a Guanyin statue at a Buddhist temple in Yanshan County (Cangzhou City, Hebei Province) was demolished. Government officials were on site to supervise the demolition, and police officers threatened to arrest those who attempted to stop the demolition. This was part of a greater campaign by the CCP to remove all outdoor Buddhist statues.
Property destruction: Around 15 September 2019 (month of), a Guanyin statue in Duqiao town of Linhai county (Taizhou, Zhejiang) was removed by authorities claiming that it had distracted drivers.

In September 2019, an ancient Buddhist temple in Jingzhou City, Hubei Province was demolished by the local public security and urban management departments, on the grounds that its registration certificate was false.

On 15 September 2019, more than 20 government officials raided and shut down a house church venue in Hebi City, Henan Province. This was part of a broader campaign to pressure house churches to join the state-run churches.

Around 15 September 2019 (month of), a Catholic meeting venue in Poyang county (Shangrao City, Jiangxi Province) was ordered to cease religious activities because it was not part of the state-controlled Chinese Patriotic Catholic Association. Local officials threatened to revoke retirement pensions of elderly congregation members if another meeting were to be held. The church's cross, a painting of the Virgin Mary, and religious couplets were removed, and replaced with portraits of Xi Jinping and Mao Zedong.

In September 2019, at least 13 Buddhist and Taoist temples in Chibi City (Xianning City, Hubei Province) were shut down. This was part of the ramped up efforts to crackdown on religious venues across Hubei Province ahead of the announcement of the central government's return inspections.

In September 2019, the local government shut down a Buddhist temple in Chuangwang Town, Tongshan County (Xianning City, Hubei Province), after ordering the temple to hand over its permits for renewal. This was part of the ramped up efforts to crackdown on religious venues across Hubei Province ahead of the announcement of the central government's return inspections.

Around 15 September 2019 (month of), a 16-meter-high Guanyin statue in Putian City, Fujian Province, was concealed on directives from local authority to advance the CCP's nationwide campaign to eliminate all open-air religious symbols.

In September 2019, 800 Arhat statues in the Taoyuan Holy Scenic Area in Xifeng County (Dalian City, Liaoning Province) were covered with green cloths by the county government. The largest Buddha statue of the temple was later concealed with a structure that resembles a lotus flower in December 2019. This was part of a broader campaign to crack down on places of worship and outdoor worship areas across China, and destroy statues of deities and religious symbols.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of China (2012-) People's Armed Police
NOTES: In September 2019, a church school in a cathedral in Cangzhou City, Hebei Province was raided by officials from provincial, municipal, county governments, and the armed police. They ordered the bishop to close the school, and threatened to demolish the church if he continued recruiting students. The students were subsequently dismissed and all classes were halted.

In September 2019, a Three-Self Chengmen Christian Church's meeting venue on Hudi Lane in Chengmen town (Fuzhou City, Fujian Province) was demolished by the authorities. The Chengmen Christian Church had a congregation of about 2,000 members and 20 meeting venues in more than ten villages in Chengmen town. It was reported that the church's extensive membership and rapid growth had caused the CCP's crackdown.

On 15 September 2019, authorities repurposed the Hu ancestral hall (places associated with China's folk religions) in Tongcheng county (Xianning City, Hubei Province) into a 'cultural auditorium'. This was part of a coordinated crackdown against folk religions and family clans by repurposing these family shrines which were built to honour ancestors. In this campaign, it was reported that 24 ancestral clan halls in the Tongcheng county were converted into cultural auditoriums.

On 17 September 2019, local authorities removed the domes and the crescent moon and star symbols from a Hui cemetery in Weihui City (Xinxiang City, Henan Province), due to a provincial campaign to expel Saudi and Arabic influence. This was part of a broader campaign to 'sinicize' Islam in China, where all traditional Islamic symbols and characters are prohibited from being publicly displayed.

On 20 September 2019, a Sola Fide (Protestant) meeting venue in Chengdu City, Sichuan Province was shut down after a raid by police officers and officials from the Religious Affairs Bureau. They took down the ID information of all believers present, and threatened to detain and fine anyone who continued to gather.

On 25 September 2019, a Three-Self church meeting venue in Gaohu village (Fuzhou City, Fujian Province) was demolished by the local authorities, under the pretext that it was needed for the construction of a canal. The act was taken in the context of allegedly increasing suppressions on state-controlled worship places.

On 26 September 2019, a Buddhist temple in Dawu County (Xiaogan City, Hubei Province) was razed to the ground by the local Religious Affairs Bureau. This was part of the ramped up efforts to crackdown on religious venues across Hubei Province ahead of the announcement of the central government's return inspections.

On 27 September 2019, 21 Arhat statues of a Buddhist Temple in Mianyang City, Sichuan Province were demolished on orders by the local Religious Affairs Bureau. This was part of a broader campaign launched by the CCP to demolish temples and statues across China.

On 29 September 2019, a Protestant house church venue in Longjing City (Yanbian, Jilin Province) was raided by officials from the local bureaus of public security, religious, and civil affairs. The police confiscated RMB 3,000 worth of donation money and about 50 Bibles from the church, and registered personal information of over 30 congregation members at the scene. The church director and the owner of the venue were also taken away for interrogation.

On 30 September 2019, one 21.8-metre-tall, two-faced Guanyin statue at the Guiyuan Temple in Wuhan prefecture (Hubei) was covered up by the authorities. This was part of a large-scale campaign to rectify Buddhist and Taoist venues across Hubei province.

On 30 September 2019, the dome at the Baotou Hui Secondary School in Baotou prefecture (Inner Mongolia) was removed by the authorities. Afterwards, a crescent-shaped stone monument (often used to symbolize Islam) in the school courtyard was replaced with a stone tablet with core socialist values. Other structures or objects with Arabic or Islamic symbols (streetlamps, slogans, student and staff meal and key cards) were either eliminated or replaced.

Around 30 September 2019 (end of month), a house church meeting place in Yuanmou County, Chuxiong Prefecture (Yunnan Province) was broken into by eight government officials. The officials forcibly seized more than a hundred religious books and believers were warned not to congregate at the meeting place.

Around 30 September 2019 (end of month), the statue of the Virgin Mary in a Catholic sanctuary in Tianjiajing Village, Linzhou City (Anyang City, Henan Province) was demolished on orders by the United Front Work Department and the Religious Affairs Bureau of Linzhou City. Its altar was also buried in a pit. This was part of the government's crackdown on Catholic pilgrimage sites against clergy members and congregations that refused to join the Chinese Patriotic Catholic Association.

Around 30 September 2019 (end of month), the local government demolished crosses and religious signs in 22 churches and meeting venues in Linhe District (Bayannur City, Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region). The operation was carried out by the local government ahead of a visit by the central government inspection team.

Around 30 September 2019 (end of month), local officials ordered the True Origin Catholic Church in Ji'an Prefecture-level City, Jiangxi Province to paint over the church's name with slogans 'Follow the Party, Obey the Party, and Be Grateful to the Party', display the national flag at the entrance of the church, and put up a portrait of president Xi Jinping in the centre of the main wall where the Virgin Mary with the Christ Child used to be located. A few days later, officials confiscated the keys to the church and locked all its doors and windows.

Around 30 September 2019 (end of month), government personnel went to a Catholic church in Tianjiajing, Linzhou (Henan). They removed and buried the Our Lady's Altar in the church forcibly. A church-goer tried to stop them from advancing but was dragged away.

Around 30 September 2019 (end of month), a Bodhisattva Temple in Gaojiawan village of Yanchuan County (Yan'an City, Shaanxi Province) was dismantled by the authorities. It was reported that stone cattle statues, and guardians of fortunes and health outside the temple were also removed. This was part of a broader campaign to crack down places of worship across China.

Around 30 September 2019 (end of month), two house church meeting venues in Jixi City (Heilongjiang Province) were shut down by the authorities because they were not members of the state-controlled Three-Self Churches. This was part of a broader campaign to force house churches to join the state-controlled Three-Self churches.

Between late September and early October 2019, two meeting places of Guangming House Church in Jixi City, Heilongjiang Province were seized, on the grounds that the church did not have a registration certificate.

On 8 October 2019, the local Religious Affairs Bureau in Huinan county (Tonghua City, Jilin Province) shut down a house church meeting venue because it was not a member of the state-controlled Three-Self Churches. This was part of a broader campaign to force house churches to join the state-controlled Three-Self churches.

On 8 October 2019, the cross and sculpture of Joseph holding Jesus from the pavilion of a nursing home founded by a state-run Catholic church in Xian County (Cangzhou City, Hebei Province) were removed by government-hired workers. The officials also ordered to have the rest of the religious sculptures covered or removed. They also told the nursing home that they were not allowed to have religious symbols, or allow residents to practise their faith. This was part of a broader campaign to force Catholic churches to join the state-run Chinese Patriotic Catholic Association.

On 10 October 2019, a Taoist temple in Xuchang City, Henan Province was demolished on orders from the local government. This was part of a broader campaign to crackdown on places of worship under the ongoing religious persecution strategy by the central government.

On 13 October 2019, a house church in Jinan City, Shandong Province was shut down by the Ethnic and Religious Affirs Bureau, with its crosses and other religious symbols in the venue destroyed by the authorities. The host was forced to sign an statement to 'stop gatherings involuntarily', with the congregation receiving threats not to gather in the future.

On 15 October 2019, a Sola Fide house church in Jinan City was raided by officials from the Ethnic and Religious Affairs Bureau. The host was forced to sign a statement to 'stop gatherings involuntarily'.

In October 2019, all Arabic words were removed from a signboard of a Hui-run restaurant in Chaoyang City, Liaoning Province, after the owner was ordered to do so by over ten officers from the United Front Work Department and the Ethnic and Religious Affairs Bureau following a raid. This was part of the CCP's policy to 'sinicize' Hui Muslims across China, where Arabic script and Islamic symbols were ordered to be removed from shops and restaurants.

Around 15 October 2019 (month of), all Bibles, hymnbooks, evangelism handbooks, and other religious books were confiscated from a Three-Self church in Hukou County (Jiujiang City, Jiangxi Province) by four officials from the Culture Broadcasting Bureau, on the grounds that 'they were not produced by approved publishers'. This was part of a broader campaign to crack down on faith-related materials not approved by the state, in order to advance the CCP's 'sinicization' policy.

In October 2019, the Arabic script was removed from Muslim shops in Chifeng City, Inner Mongolia, following an order from the authorities in Inner Mongolia. It was reported that more than 250 shops were affected across the city in October and November 2019. This was part of the CCP's policy to 'sinicize' Islamic culture in China, where Arabic script and Islamic symbols were ordered to be removed from shops and restaurants.

Around 15 October 2019 (month of), a red-copper statue of Earth Store Bodhisattva in a Buddhist temple in Zhangzhou City, Fujian Province was concealed with iron sheets on orders from the local Religious Affairs Bureau . A slogan 'Do not forget your initial intention. Love your country, love your religion' was attached to the cover. This was part of a nationwide drive to conceal outdoor Buddhist statutes across China.

In October 2019, officials from various government institutions (including the Religious Affairs Bureau) raided a Buddhist hall in Linzhou (Anyang City, Henan Province) and confiscated all the Buddhist books, ordering for them to be buried. They claimed that these books are 'illegal', 'indoctrinating believers', and 'affecting China's mainstream ideology'. They also claimed that reading these books, which were published in Hong Kong and Taiwan, alluded to 'colluding with foreign forces'. This was part of a broader effort to confiscate books by a prominent Buddhist monk, whose teachings have been banned by the CCP.

In October 2018, a 26-meter-tall three-faced Guanyin statue at the Xiaonanhai Golden Turtle Villa in Anyang City, Henan Province was disassembled into 49 pieces on the grounds that it 'was too tall and affected aesthetics'. It was part of a campaign by the CCP to remove all outdoor Buddhist statues.

In October 2019, a Protestant church venue in Jin'an District (Fuzhou City, Fujian Province) was closed down by officials from the Religious Affairs Bureau, on the grounds of being 'unlicensed'. This was part of a crackdown to curb growth of the Christianity, by reducing the number of places of worship.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of China (2012-) People's Armed Police
NOTES: In October 2019, a Buddhist temple and its seven-storey pagoda in Huailai County (Zhangjiakou City, Hebei Province) were demolished by the local government, on the grounds that 'it was built without approval'. Armed police officers were present to cordon off an intersection to prevent villagers from protesting against the demolition.
In October 2019, a three-faced Bodhisattva statue outside a Buddhist temple in Tianheng town, Jimo District (Qingdao City, Shandong Province) was demolished by the local government.

In October 2019, a temple in Yudan village (Baoji City, Shaanxi Province) was repurposed into an activity centre by the government, where chess and mahjong tables, and other entertainment items, were brought into the temples. Religious statues were also replaced with portraits of Xi Jinping, and slogans promoting the core socialist values. This was part of a broader campaign to crack down places of worship across China.

In October 2019, a house church meeting venue in Wuyuan County (Shangrao City, Jiangxi Province) was shut down by the authorities because it was not a member of the state-controlled Three-Self Churches. This was part of a broader campaign to force house churches to join the state-controlled Three-Self churches.
In October 2019, the local government forcibly demolished a Bodhisattva statue outside Huangshan Temple in Tianheng town, Jimo (Qingdao, Shandong).

In October 2019, crosses were removed from two Three-Self churches in Xipao Village (Dalian City, Liaoning Province). The local government officials warned the congregation that church crosses should not be more important than the national flag.

In October 2019, workers hired by the government were rushing to complete the project to conceal a 99-meter-tall Buddha statue at the Lingyun Mountain in Gaoping District, (Nanchong City, Sichuan Province) by the end of the month. The Lingyun Mountain is a national 4A-level scenic area and a Buddhists and Taoists pilgrimage site. Many religious symbols has been removed or covered according to an order issued in September 2018 stating that all religious elements should be purged from the scenic area.

In October 2019, a house church in Shuangyashan City, Heilongjiang Province had its cross and the signboard indicating that it was a Christian church removed. Later in the month, officials erased all remaining indications that it was a church to make the venue look like a regular private house.

Around 15 October 2019 (month of), the police carried out an operation under the unified command of the Ministry of Public Security and arrested 329 members of the Association of Disciples in Qinghai Province. They also confiscated RMB 860,500 and loads of valuables.

Around 15 October 2019 (month of), a Guanyin statue in a temple in Geli Island, Zhuanghe City (Dalian City, Liaoning Province) was covered up by the authorities. Slogans calling to protect natural resources were also added to the cover. This was part of a nationwide drive to conceal outdoor Buddhist statutes across China.

In October 2019, police conducted an operation in Qinghai Province, arresting 329 members of the Association of Disciples, and confiscated 860,500 yuan and other valuables. This was part of an ongoing nationwide operation on the Disciples discreetly launched in September 2019.

Around 15 October 2019 (month of), the house of a member of Church of Almighty God in Henan Province was raided by the police, who confiscated all of their savings worth over RMB 200,000. The believer and her partner were also arrested by the police.
Security measures: Around 16 October 2019 (month of), authorities shut down a Sola Vide house church venue in Heyuan prefecture (Guangdong) (coded to Yuancheng).

Property destruction: Around 16 October 2019 (month of), a 14-meter-tall white Guanyin statue outside a Buddhist temple in Xiangshan town in Daying county (Suining, Sichuan), was demolished by about 20 local officials and police officers. Another Guanyin statue at a separate temple in the same county was destroyed by authorities in the same month.

Around 16 October 2019 (month of), a Three-Self church venue was shut down in Shuyang county (Suqian, Jiangsu) by government officials. The church director was ordered to renew its documentation with the local Religious Affairs Bureau, but officials explained that 'only one church [was] allowed in the sub-district.' Twenty three other churches in the area were also closed, repurposed or demolished. It was reported that at least 45 Protestant churches (state-run Three-Self churches or unregistered house churches) were shut down in Suqian prefecture in the second half of 2019, as part of a six-month crackdown campaign in Jiangsu province.

Around 16 October 2019 (middle of month), the building housing a hall used by Tibetan Buddhists to worship in Beihai City, Guangxi Province was demolished by over 300 personnel from the Public Security Bureau and other departments dispatched by the county government, on the grounds that it was 'illegal'. During the demolition, some believers were inside the building, attempting to stop the demolition, while others tried to reason with the officials. Pepper spray was also reportedly used against believers who tried to stop the demolition, while those who refused to leave were carried out by the government personnel. This was part of a broader campaign to prevent the spread of Tibetan Buddhism among Han Chinese.

On 16 October 2019, police officers raided churches in Jiaozhou (Qingdao, Shandong) and arrested at least 23 Christians. The next day, 10 more Christians were arrested from churches in Licang during police raids. On 17 October 2019, police officers raided churches in Licang (Qingdao, Shandong) and arrested 10 Christians.

Around 16 October 2019 (month of), government authorities seized a Christian church in Beizhouzhuang village of Funing county (Yancheng, Jiangsu) and repurposed it into a cultural centre on the grounds that it had not been registered with the Religious Affairs Department.

Around 16 October 2019 (middle of month), a central government inspection team took down a Jesus blessing statue and two angel statues from the roof of a church in Linjiazhuang village (Jinan City, Shandong Province).

Around 16 October 2019 (middle of month), two Three-Self churches in Jinpu New Area in Jinzhou District (Dalian City, Liaoning Province) were sealed off by the authorities. One of the churches reported that they had submitted all the required documents to obtain the religious activity venue certificate several years ago, but was never issued a certificate. This was part of a broader campaign to reduce the number of places of worship, reportedly in order for the central government to exercise greater control over the churches.

Around 16 October 2019 (middle of month), an outdoor Earth Store Bodhisattva statue of a Buddhist temple in Weichang County (Chengde City, Hebei Province) was dismembered and later removed by the authorities. It was reported that the government had repeatedly forced the temple's person-in-charge to remove the statue, claiming that this was part of a national campaign.

Around 16 October 2019 (month of), government authorities demolished an outdoor Buddha statue (Maitreya statue) at Yongfu temple in Ningyuan county (Yongzhou, Hunan). The rebuilding and fundraising of the temple was approved more than a decade ago, but the government then decided that the statue was too eye-catching.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of China (2012-) People's Armed Police
NOTES: On 18 October 2019, a Buddhist temple in Mianyang Hi-tech District of Fucheng District (Mianyang District, Sichuan Province) was demolished by over 20 people, including government employees and the special police. During the demolition, four elderly believers who attempted to save the temple were forcibly dragged out of the temple by the government personnel. Fifty bodhisattva statues and all of the believers' belongings were buried in the rubble. This was part of a broader campaign launched by the CCP to demolish temples and statues across China.

SOURCE: China Aid; Radio Free Asia; Weiquanwang
NOTES: On 18 October 2019, a Christian church in Funan County (Fuyang City, Anhui Province) was demolished by the local authorities, as part of a nationwide effort to 'sinicize' religion in China. All property was destroyed. Some Christians who knelt before the police were sent to the hospital after fainting. The persons in charge of the church were also arrested on the next day.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of China (2017-) Hong Kong Police Force
NOTES: On 20 October 2019, during the height of the anti-ELAB demonstrations, police forces intercepted a taxi driver at the junction of Lo Fai Rd and Ting Kok Rd near the University of Education, Tai Po district (Hong Kong) (coded to Hong Kong - Tai Po) and confiscated an unsealed cardboard box from his trunk. It was later made known that the box contained 40 petrol bombs, 3 petrol liquid bottles and two gasoline igniters, and that the driver had received a university student's request to transport a box of 'medical resources' to Kowloon.

On 20 October 2019, a Three-Self church in Tengzhou County (Zaozhuang City, Shandong Province) was sealed off by local officials. The officials also threatened to demolish the church should the congregation continue to gather. It was reported that the cross and plague with the church name were also removed.

On 21 October 2019, more than 30 local government and Public Security Bureau employees stormed into an orphanage in Yongnian county (Handan City, Hebei Province) funded by a Catholic Church and looted all equipment and furniture. They also cut the electricity and locked the front door, prohibiting anyone from entering. They claimed that the orphanage was shut down according to a provincial government order. It was reported that the orphanage was shut down mainly because the priest in charge of the church was unwilling to join the state controlled Chinese Patriotic Catholic Association (CPCA).

Around 22 October 2019 (a month before 22 November 2019), a three-faced Guanyin statue at a Buddhist temple in Huairen (Shuozhou City, Shanxi Province) was demolished, on the grounds that it was 'too tall'. This was part of a greater campaign by the CCP to remove all outdoor Buddhist statues.

On 23 October 2019, a house church in Weidong District (Pingdingshan City, Henan Province) was shut down by officers from the Ethnic and Religious Affairs Bureau, Public Security Bureau, and community committee, on the grounds that it was 'unlicensed'. The church was also issued a fine, and had dozens of its hymn books and 37 chairs confiscated. The next day, law enforcement officers sealed off the venue and posted a closure notice at its entrance.

Around 23 October 2019 (in the week after 19 October), a Seventh-day Adventist house church in Neijiang City, Sichuan Province was raided by more than 100 officials and police officers. They confiscated tables and chairs, audio equipment, and other properties of the church. They also threw copies of the Bible into a trash can outside the church. They subsequently welded the entrance to the church. Members of the church also recevied calls from government officials, threatening to withhold the salaries of their children and grandchildren if they did not renounce their faith.

On 26 October 2019, a Buddhist temple in Jicheng Town (Zhengdong City, Henan Province) was demolished by government officials, on the grounds that it was 'illegally occupying the land'. It was reported that ten days prior to the demolition, the temple manager was taken to the local police station by government personnel where the manager was threatened to sign a statement to pledge his unconditional cooperation for the government's demolition of the temple.

On 26 October 2019, a Catholic pilgrimage site at the top of a mountain in Dong'ergou Parish, Jinyuan District (Taiyuan City, Shanxi Province) was 'rectified' by the town government, with its statues and top two floors removed, and the building transformed into a more Chinese-style building. This is part of a broader campaign by the Chinese government to 'sinicize' religion.

On 27 October 2019, a Shouters' venue in Taizhou City, Zhejiang Province was shut down by over 50 police officers. The police also confiscated more than 100 Bibles and hymn books, and over RMB 1,000 of donations. More than 50 church members were taken to the local police station.
On 27 October 2019, a Tibetan monk self-immolated in protest on a street near Meruma township (Ngawa Tibetan and Qiang Autonomous, Sichuan) and died.

On 29 October 2019, a Three-Self Church in Wuning County (Jiujiang City, Jiangxi Province) was raided by personnel from the Religious Affairs Bureau. They removed the words 'Christian Church' from the wall, and took away all religious symbols. They also destroyed the cross on the roof and replaced it with the Chinese national flag. It was claimed that these measures were taken because 'Christians were involved in the anti-extradition bill protests in Hong Kong'.

On 29 October 2019, five police officers stormed into a house church meeting venue in Lushan County (Pingdingshan City, Henan Province) and told the congregation that 'Jesus is a God of Western countries' and to 'believe in the God of China'. They confiscated Bibles, dismantled the cross, and also took photos of all nearly 70 believers. This was part of a broader campaign to pressure house churches to join the state-run churches.

Around 30 October 2019 (30-31 October), eight Protestant church venues were shut down by government officials in Donghai county (Lianyungang, Jiangsu) for 'being unlicensed or dilapidated.' It was reported that at least 142 Protestant churches (state-run Three-Self churches or unregistered house churches) were shut down in Lianyungang prefecture in the second half of 2019, as part of a six-month crackdown campaign in Jiangsu province.

On 30 October 2019, around 300 police officers demolished a Catholic church in Guantao (Handan, Hebei), citing that the church was built illegally on farmland. A few hundreds of church-goers and priests prayed outside the church to demand them to stop but failed.

Around 31 October 2019 (end of month), a house church venue in Weidong District (Pingdingshan City, Henan Province) was raided by officials who smashed down its door. They confiscated religious books and other items, and shut down the venue. The person in charge was told that these gatherings are 'illegal' as they were not approved by the government. This was part of a broader campaign to pressure house churches to join the state-run churches.

Around 31 October 2019 (end of month), a residence for Catholic nuns in Fu'an City (Ningde City, Fujian Province) was dismantled by the government, on the grounds that it was an 'illegal construction'. The building's roof was torn down, windows and floors broken, and its power and water supply were cut off. This was part of a broader campaign to crack down on Catholic churches that refused to join the Chinese Patriotic Catholic Association.

On 31 October 2019, a Catholic church was demolished on orders from government officials in Guantao County (Handan City, Hebei Province). Two Catholics protested against the demolition, but were forcibly dragged out of the church.

Within ten days at the end of October 2019, four Catholic churches in Baochang Town (Xilingol League, Inner Mongolia) were shut down by the local authorities, because they refused to be governed by the state. Law enforcement officers also ordered the people in charge to stop all activities at their venues and remove religious symbols and signs.

Around 31 October 2019 (end of month), a notice was posted on the door of a Three-Self Church in Kongtian Township, Anyuan County (Ganzhou City, Jiangxi Province), announcing that their registration certificate had been suspended. Three other churches across the county in Tianxin Town, Fengshan Town, and Chetou Town also reportedly had their registration certificates suspended around the same time.
Around 31 October 2019 (end of month), an underground Catholic church in Chengtou Town, Fuqing was closed, and had cameras installed at the church door by government officials.

Around 31 October 2019 (end of month), a Buddhist temple in Shishou City (Jingzhou City, Hubei Province) was shut down by the Ethnic and Religious Affairs Bureau officials. This was part of the ramped up efforts to crackdown on religious venues across Hubei Province ahead of the announcement of the central government's return inspections.

Around 31 October 2019 (end of month), three officially-approved Protestant meeting venues in Dabin Township, Yuanyang County (Xinxiang City, Henan Province) were demolished. It was reported that one of the venues was first repurposed into a senior citizen's activity centre by the government sometime in 2019, before being demolished.

Around 1 November 2019 (beginning of month), an outdoor Guanyin statue in a Buddhist temple located in Shuangqiao Town (Shangqiu City, Henan Province) was removed because officials claimed it was 'too high'. This was part of a broader campaign undertaken by the CCP to crack down on religious activities.

Security measures: Around 1 November 2019 (beginning of month), the county government closed a Taoist temple in the Jiazi Cultural Park in Qingzhou county (Weifang, Shandong) for not having the religious activity registration certificate, and assigned personnel to patrol it.

On 1 November 2019, a Catholic church in Wugaozhuang in Guantao district (Handan, Hebei) was forcibly demolished by the police. The ceiling and the cross of the church were demolished. Police played songs celebrating the CCP. Believers also sang hymns on the demolition site. That was part of an ongoing campaign to crack down on churches in China.

Around 1 November 2019 (beginning of month), the Bodhisattva statue at Tianqi Temple in Anqiu, Weifang (Shandong) was destroyed by personnel sent by the local government, with the remains of the statue thrown into a river nearby.

Around 1 November 2019 (beginning of month), the meeting venue of a house church in Taierzhuang District (Zaozhuang City, Shandong Province) was raided by six police officers. The officers forcibly tore down religious paintings, removed furniture and other church valuables, which were taken away in a truck for burning. This was part of a broader campaign to pressure house churches to join the state-run churches.

Around 1 November 2019 (beginning of month), a newly-built dormitory for monks and a hall for chanting in a Buddhist temple in Xingyang City (Zhengzhou City, Henan Province) was demolished on orders of the local government. The temple manager was also ordered to burn all the books by a prominent Venerable Master (which are banned by the CCP). 16 Buddhists living on the temple's premises were expelled.

Around 1 November 2019 (beginning of month), five meeting venues of the old Local Church in Zhengqiao Town, Leping City (Jingdezhen City, Jiangxi Province) were shut down by the authorities. All furniture, crosses, and other religious symbols were removed. This was part of a broader campaign launched by the town government to shut down all unlicensed church under the town's jurisdiction.

On 1 November 2019, a crackdown operation was launched in Qingdao City, Shandong Province against members of the Church of Almighty God. During the operation, 38 members were arrested and more than 340,000 RMB were confiscted. This was part of an ongoing campaign to crack down on the members of the Church of Almighty God.
On 1 November 2019, more than 200 police officers raided 24 churches in Pingdu (Qingdao, Shandong). They arrested 38 Christians and looted 340,000 RMB worth of donations from the churches.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of China (2017-) Hong Kong Police Force
NOTES: Weapons seizure: On 2 November 2019, police officers broke into a unit on the 4th floor of Top View Mansion, 10 Canal Rd W in Wan Chai district (Hong Kong) (coded as Hong Kong - Wan Chai) and confiscated 59 bottles of petrol bombs, 79 glass bottles each containing white waste cotton, and 50 empty glass bottles. They confiscated an estimated 4.6 liters of light yellow diesel-containing liquid, 1 liter of colorless liquid containing isopropyl alcohol, and 4.9 liters of green liquid containing gasoline. This petrol bomb bust was reported on 19 Apr 2021 to be the largest of its kind in connection with 2019-20 anti-ELAB demonstrations. Five people (incl. students) were arrested for 'conspiracy to commit arson' and 'possessing anything with intent to destroy or damage property.'

On 2 November 2019, officials from the local government in Rencheng District, Jining City hired a construction team to remove religious signs and symbols from a women's mosque. The dome was also demolished, and the Chinese national flag was placed at the entrance.

On 2 November 2019, a Catholic church meeting place in Fuqing was closed after a power outage. It was reported that this was part of the measures to shut down churches of priests whom refused to join the Patriotic Association.

On 5 November 2019, officials from Sui County stormed into a Buddhist temple in Xiaoguo Village in Sui county (Shangqiu City, Henan Province), and demolished the signboard, incense burner and the Earth Store Bodhisattva statue. They also confiscated Buddhist books and recordings as 'materials propagating beliefs of cults'. This was part of a broader campaign to crack down on places of worship and outdoor worship areas across China, and destroy statues of deities and religious symbols.

Around 6 November 2019 (in the week after 2 November), a Catholic church in Beilin Village, Yangxia Town was closed. It was reported that this was part of the measures to shut down churches of priests whom refused to join the Patriotic Association.

On 6 November 2019, police officers raided the house of an elderly Protestant believer in Malantun Town (Zaozhuang City, Shandong Province) and tore off religious paintings from the wall. The officers also threatened the believer that future generations of his family would not be able to join the army, enter university, or find a job. This was part of a broader campaign to crack down on non-state-approved house churches and their believers.

On 6 November 2019, a private Islamic school in Heze City, Shandong Province was forced to shut down by authorities. The crescent moon symbols atop the three pillars of the school were also removed or painted over.

On 7 November 2019, a Protestant house church venue in Nigou Town, Tai'erzhuang District (Zaozhuang City, Shandong Province) was shut down by the police, on the grounds of 'disrupting social order'. It was reported that all of the property of the church were confiscated. This was part of a broader campaign to crack down on non-state-approved house churches.
On 8 November 2019, a Buddhist temple in Langqi Town (Fuzhou City, Fujian Province) was demolished by the local government, on the grounds that it was an 'illegal construction'.

On 8 November 2019, the town mayor and CPC Secretary of Dongju village, Yangping town of Chencang district (Baoji, Shaanxi) broke into a local Buddhist temple (San'guan Hall) and removed all its religious statues overnight. The statues were found smashed and loaded on a garbage truck the next day. It was reported that many Buddhist, Daoist and folk religion temples were demolished or shutdown in Shaanxi province during the year, with at least 100 temples closed in Baoji city within a ten-month period.

On 8 November 2019, a Three-Self church in Sanshu Town, Huaiyin District (Huai'an City, Jiangsu Province) was merged with two other Three-Self churches on orders of the government. The licence to hold religious activity at the venue had been cancelled by the authorities, and the believers were forced to congregate at a new venue that is six times smaller than the old venue. This was part of a broader campaign to reduce the number of churches.

On 8 November 2019, government officials removed the cross from a Three-Self church in Gushi County (Xinyang City, Henan Province). It was reported that some elderly believers tried to stop the officials from removing the cross, and one believer fainted on the ground during the commotion. This was part of a broader campaign launched by the central government to remove crosses from churches across China.

On 8 November 2019, 16-meter-tall Maitreya statue in Zaohang Park located in Jimo District (Qingdao City, Shandong Province) was concealed by building an artificial mountain around it, on orders from the district government.

On 10 November 2019, 7 house churches in Longyou County (Quzhou City, Zhejiang Province) were shut down by authorities, on the grounds that congregations 'meet illegally' at these 'unlicensed' venues. This was part of a broader crackdown on congregations that refused to join the state-controlled Three-Self Church.

On 10 November 2019, local government officials demolished the bell tower, a Jesus statue and other religious structures at a registered Catholic church in Tancheng county (Linyi, Shandong), rectifying its outer appearance to resemble 'a regular residential building.' It was reported that even registered Catholic churches across China (those sanctioned by the government-run Chinese Patriotic Catholic Association) were not exempt from persecutions and harassment.

Around 10 November 2019 (a few days after), a Three-Self church in Sheyang County (Yancheng City, Jiangsu Province) was shut down by over 100 villages' officials, personnel from the Religious Affairs Bureau and United Front Work Department. It was reported that congregation members had been guarding the venue over the last few days.

On 11 November 2019, law enforcement officers raided a Buddhist temple in Liangyuan District (Shangqiu City, Henan Province), and confiscated four pickup trucks worth of religious books. This was part of a broader effort to confiscate books by a prominent Buddhist monk, whose teachings have been banned by the CCP.

On 12 November 2019, a statue of Guanyin in a Buddhist temple in Wuhan City, Hubei Province was demolished. The incident followed the newly-launched 'retification' campaigns on religious venues on 1 November 2019 by the Wuhan Municipal Ethnic and Religious Committee.

On 13 November 2019, the cross and Chinese characters for 'True Jesus Church' were removed from a True Jesus Church in Laoguan Town (Pingxiang City, Jiangxi Province) by the authorities. This was part of a broader campaign to remove religious symbols from churches and other structures.
On 14 November 2019, the Zunhua Muncipal Government took away an abbot from a Tibetan Buddhist temple in Zunhua, Hebei Province. His residence in the temple, and the temple hall were also sealed off.

In November 2019, a Protestant church venue in Putian City, Fujian Province was closed down by government officials, under the pretext that it was 'unlicensed'. The preacher attempted to apply for a new permit but the application was not approved. This was part of a crackdown to curb the growth of Christianity, by reducing the number of places of worship.

In November 2019, an Arabic language school in Zhongshahai Hui Village, Dingtao District (Heze City, Shandong Province) was shut down by the local government. All teachers, students and imams were sent home following the shut down of the school. The school was also ordered to remove its signboard, and the crescent moon and star symbols on the three columns outside the building. It was reported that the school was shut down to prevent Islam from spreading, and to bar people from studying Arabic and the Quran. Earlier during the spring of 2019, the school was raided by the local police under the pretext of searching for 'rioters and terrorists from Xinjiang'.

In November 2019, the dome of a Hui Muslim mosque in Baiyin City, Gansu Province, was removed by local authorities. This was part of a broader campaign to 'sinicize' Muslims in China, through the removal of Islamic symbols, rectifying 'Arabic-style' architectural features of buildings, and the indoctrination of Muslims.

Around 15 November 2019 (month of), the minarets of a mosque in Jinshui District (Zhengzhou City, Henan Province) was remodelled by the government. The star-and-crescent-symbols were also removed from the mosque. This was part of the five-year plan to 'sinicize' Muslims outside of Xinjiang.

In November 2019, a Buddhist hall in Linzhou (Anyang City, Henan Province) was deemed to be an 'illegal construction' and 'unlawfully occupying arable land' by the local government. Its windows and doors were boarded up, and water and electricity supply were cut off. The person-in-charge of the hall was also driven out of the area. This was part of a nationwide crackdown on places of worship in China, which are deemed to be illegal.

In November 2019, a Three-Self church venue in Jiehe Town, Tengzhou City (Zaozhuang City, Shandong Province) was shut down by local officials, under the pretext that 'gatherings are forbidden due to the riots in Hong Kong'. The congregation was threatened with fines of 20,000 RMB if they were to hold gatherings again.

In November 2019, mosques in Linqing City (Liaocheng City, Shandong Province) were ordered to demolish their loudspeakers by local government officials, on the grounds that the sound of adhan (the Islamic call to prayer) was 'disturbing people'. This was part of a broader campaign to 'sinicize' Islam outside of Xinjiang, by prohibiting mosques from playing the adhan.

In November 2019, Arabic phrases on the signboards of at least 200 Hui shops in Dezhou City, Shandong Province were painted over, on orders from the local government. The local government stated that all non-Chinese characters, including Mongolian, Tibetan, and other languages of ethnic minorities, must be removed. This was part of the CCP's policy to 'sinicize' Hui Muslims across China, where Arabic script and Islamic symbols were ordered to be removed from shops and restaurants.

Around 15 November 2019 (middle of month), the domes and star-and-crescent symbols were removed from a mosque in Qinghua Town (Jiaozuo City, Henan Province) by the authorities. Propaganda slogans were subsequently added at the entrance of the mosque. This was part of a broader campaign launched by the CCP to 'sinicize' Islam across China.

In November 2019, the Arabic script was removed from at least 200 Hui restaurants across Liaoning Province, on orders of the Ethnic and Religious Affairs Bureau. It was reported that according to a document issued by the Ethnic and Religious Affairs Bureau in Shenyang City (Liaoning Province), all Islam-related symbols and items, including the star and crescent, prayer rugs, and alike, should be removed from public places like hotels. This was part of the CCP's policy to 'sinicize' Hui Muslims across China, where Arabic script and Islamic symbols were ordered to be removed from shops and restaurants.

Around 15 November 2019 (month of), the Meishan People's Government demolished a 42-meter-tall Amitabha statue in Huazang Temple, a thousand-year-old Buddhist site in Meishan prefecture (Sichuan). More than 200 officers and officials surrounded the venue on the day, and set up checkpoints along roads leading to the site.

Around 15 November 2019 (month of), two Guanyin statues in Xianning city (Hubei) were concealed by government officials, including a thousand-hand Guanyin statue at Guanyin Temple in Guihua town and an eight-meter-tall statue in the Guanyin Pavilion. This was part of a large-scale campaign to rectify Buddhist and Taoist venues across Hubei province.

Land seizure: Around 15 November 2019 (month of), the local government took over and converted a Taoist temple in Qicun town of Shizhong district (Zaozhuang, Shandong) and converted it into a tourist centre. The temple's signboard and statues were destroyed.

Around 15 November 2019 (month of), local authorities destroyed the Tibetan-style Buddhist Tushita Palace in an ancient temple in Shijiazhuang prefecture (Hebei). The temple was modeled after the Potala Palace in Tibet, and was destroyed despite months of rectification and being an approved religious activity venue. The move was reported as part of an intensified nationwide suppression of Tibetan Buddhism during Xi's presidency.

Around 15 November 2019 (middle of month), 34 bodhisattva statues in a Buddhist temple in Songjia Town, Zizhong County (Neijiang City, Sichuan Province) were demolished by the authorities. The authorities also sealed off an 8-metre-tall Buddha statue. It was reported that this was part of a broader campaign launched by the government of Neijiang City to shut down Buddhist and Taoist temples on a large scale since March 2019.

Around 15 November 2019 (middle of month), a Tibetan Buddhist temple in Yangqu County (Taiyuan City, Shanxi Province) was raided by government personnel. The government personnel confiscated Tibetan Buddhist scriptures and ceremonial scarfs during the raid. This was part of a broader campaign to prevent the spread of Tibetan Buddhism among Han Chinese.

Around 15 November 2019 (month of), an outdoor Guanyin statue in Baixiang Temple in Xingwen county (Yibin, Sichuan) was forcibly demolished by the Ethnic and Religious Affairs Bureau, and over 30 Bodhisattva figures in the temple were smashed the same day.

Around 15 November 2019 (month of), government authorities repurposed a Catholic church in Pingding township of Yujiang district (Yingtan, Jiangxi) into an entertainment centre for mahjong and cards or dance. It was reported that officials demanded the congregation to join the CPCA prior to this, and between March and April, officials visited local believers' homes to replace religious images with those of Chairman Mao Zedong.

In November 2019, the cross and religious paintings were removed from a Protestant house church venue in Baishan (Boshan) Village, Qichun Town (Zaozhuang City, Shandong Province) by the authorities. Two people in charge of the church were also arrested later in the same month. This was part of a broader campaign to crack down on non-state-approved house churches.
In November 2019, a Catholic church in Wenquan town, Linchuan (Fuzhou City, Jiangxi Province) was repurposed by the government into an elderly activity centre.

In November 2019, a Catholic Church in Futang Village, Bixi Town (Ji'an City, Jiangxi Province) was repurposed into a cultural activity centre. The incident was part of a broader campaign to persecute congregations and churches that declined to join the Chinese Patriotic Catholic Association.

Around 15 November 2019 (month of), an unregistered Catholic church in the Diocese of Mindong in Fujian Province was forcibly closed down by the authorities, because its priest refused to join the state-controlled Chinese Patriotic Catholic Association (CPCA).

On 15 November 2019, more than 40 government personnel forcibly entered a Sola Fide house church in Quanzhou City, Fujian Province, and confiscated two laptops and 45 Bibles. They also ordered the congregation to stop gathering.

On 15 November 2019, government officials raided a Three-Self Church meeting venue in Shan County (Heze City, Shandong Province) and replaced a religious painting and embroidery of the cross with a portrait of Xi Jinping. Religious paintings were thrown away and all chairs and tables were moved out into the courtyard.

In November 2019, two temples in Lexing Town, Anzhou District (Mianyang City, Sichuan) were destroyed by the authorities. This was part of a broader campaign launched by the CCP to demolish temples and statues across China.

In November 2019, 32 venues subordinated to two Three-Self churches in Qinghe and Yinzhou districts of Tieling City were shut down by government officials. All religious symbols were also ordered to be removed from them. The authorities also demanded that the venues hand over all their donations to the two state-controlled Three-Self churches. This was part of a broader campaign to reduce the number of places of worship, reportedly in order for the central government to exercise greater control over the churches.

In November 2019, a cross of a Catholic church in Dengta City (Liaoyang City, Liaoning Province) was sawn off by workers hired by the county's Religious Affairs Bureau. The congregation was also prohibited from gathering at the church.

Around 15 November 2019 (month of), a 27-meter-tall Amitabha Buddha statue outside a temple in Longhai City (Zhangzhou City, Fujian Province) was concealed on orders of the city's United Front Work Department and Religious Affairs Bureau. This was part of a nationwide drive to conceal outdoor Buddhist statutes across China.

LOCATION: Minhe Hui and Tu Autonomous County
NOTES: In November 2019, an Islamic school in a mosque in Minhe Hui and Tu Autonomous County (Haidong City, Qinghai Province) was shut down by local authorities, as part of a broader campaign by the Chinese government to crack down on religious freedom.
