In November 2019, Liaoning City's Religious Affairs Bureau ordered the removal of three Buddha statues from Huagong Temple in Dalian City, Liaoning. Three outdoor icons of over 10 metres tall and an incense burner were destroyed.

In November 2019, the religious activity venue registration certificate of a Protestant church venue in Jin'an District (Fuzhou City, Fujian Province) was confiscated by officials from the Religious Affairs Bureau, on the grounds that the venue was located in a different district than the church it was affiliated to. This rendered the church venue illegal, since it no longer had a registration certificate, and the venue had to stop its activities in January 2020. This was part of a crackdown to curb the growth of Christianity, by reducing the number of places of worship.

In November 2019, over 40 meeting venues subordinated to a Three-Self church in Hunnan District (Shenyang City, Liaoning Province) were forced to disband by the authorities. This was part of a broader campaign to reduce the number of places of worship, reportedly in order for the central government to exercise greater control over the churches.

In November 2019, 13 prayer wheels in a Buddhist temple in Huairen City (Shuozhou City, Shanxi Province) were demolished on orders of the authorities. This was part of a broader campaign to crack down on Chinese Buddhist temples which were allegedly bearing architectural symbols and elements related to Tibetan Buddhism.

In November 2019, eight Three-Self Church venues were forcibly shut down by the Lanshan District government (Linyi, Shandong). Crosses and other Christian symbols were also removed from the venues. One of the venues was also repurposed into a warehouse.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of China (2012-) People's Armed Police
NOTES: On 16 November 2019, the Public Security Bureau, SWAT police, fire department, and other government institutions removed the statue of Ksitigarbha Bodhisattva from Wanhe Temple in Gaizhou (Yingkou, Liaoning). The local authorities claimed that the statue was 'too tall and could cause a fire if struck by lightning'.

On 17 November 2019, the Zunhua Muncipal Government forcibly demolished nine stupas in a Tibetan Buddhist temple in Zunhua County (Tangshan City, Hebei Province). This followed the previous incident on 14 November 2019 when the abbot of the temple was expelled, and parts of the temple were shut down.

On 18 November 2019, the cross base of a Three-Self Church in Tancheng County (Linyi City, Shandong Province) was removed on orders of the county government, on the grounds that the church was 'too close to the national highway' and 'too tall'. The Western-style windows of the church were also covered with iron sheets.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Buddhist Group (China); Daoist Group (China); Labour Group (China)
NOTES: On 18 November 2019, 20 Fengqing Road Sub-District Office officials carried away all Buddhist and Guanyin statues and other religious symbols from shops that sold Buddhist and Taoist merchandise at Yuanrong Tea City in Jinshui district (Zhengzhou, Henan). They banned the owners from burning incense and conducting other religious activities, and removed signboards that alluded to religion and other 'feudal superstitions.' It was reported to be a part of an government effort to 'build a civilised city.'

On 20 November 2019, local authorities destroyed the minarets of the Northern Mosque in Chuanying District (Jilin City, Jilin Province), claiming that the structures were too high and incompatible with the overall image of the city.

On 20 November 2019, more than 1000 police, government personnel and groups of unknown individuals surrounded a Mosque in Chuxiong City, Yunnan to demolish the mosque, without having agreed with the mosque management. They dragged Muslims who were praying outside of the mosque. In an hour, at least 35 Muslims brusquely entered the mosque and went to the top of the Islamic academic building. They threatened to jump off the building if the government demolish it. By that time, the kitchen and the walls of the mosque had already been demolished.

On 22 November 2019, a 17-metre three-faced Guanyin statue in a Buddhist temple in Pianguan County (Xinzhou City, Shanxi Province) was dismantled by the local authorities, on the grounds that 'it had been consecrated according to Tibetan Buddhism traditions'. It was reported that police officers prevented local villagers from attempting to stop the demolition, and a woman in her 60s fainted after being pushed to the ground. This was part of a broader campaign to crack down on Chinese Buddhist temples which were allegedly bearing architectural symbols and elements related to Tibetan Buddhism.

On 22 November 2019, a white marble statue of Guanyin on Tianzhu Mountain, Jingle County (Xinzhou City, Shanxi Province) was demolished by officials from several government institutions, on the grounds that it was 'too tall'. This was part of a greater campaign by the CCP to remove all outdoor Buddhist statues.

Property destruction: On 22 November 2019, over 50 government-dispatched personnel destroyed all 77 statues at a Buddhist Temple in Miyi county (Panzhihua, Sichuan) on the grounds of ''being unlicensed.'' They blocked the roads leading to the venue, and subdued residents living at the temple to prevent protests, communications and photography. It was reported as one of the government's efforts to conceal or destroy outdoor icons and statues at Buddhist temples across the province.

Property destruction: On 22 November 2019, over 50 government-dispatched personnel shut down a Buddhist temple in Miyi county (Panzhihua, Sichuan), and destroyed statues and an incense burner. It was reported as one of the government's efforts to conceal or destroy outdoor icons and statues at Buddhist temples across the province.

On 22 November 2019, a meeting venue of a church in Weishi County (Kaifeng City, Henan Province) was demolished by the town government. This followed a raid conducted by police officers five days before, where two preachers were taken away and signed a statement declaring that they would not hold worship services at the venue again.

On 25 November 2019, a Three-Self Church in Chengdu City, Sichuan Province was raided and shut down by the police. The signboard of the church and paintings with Bible verses were also removed. It was further reported that the police guarded the entrance of the church for more than 20 days after it was closed down, to prevent believers from returning.

On 26 November 2019, about 200 police officers and officials from the Religious Affairs Bureau blocked all the roads to folk religion Jade Emperor Hall in Dongpo district (Meishan, Sichuan) and blew up the temple with all its statues inside. It was reported that from Oct 2019 to May 2020, at least 160 folk religion venues were demolished or shut down in four prefectures - Suining, Mianyang, Nanchong and Meishan - of Sichuan province.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of China (2012-) People's Armed Police
NOTES: On 26 November 2019, the house of a farmer in Pingtan County (Fuzhou City, Fujian Province) was forcibly demolished by more than 500 personnel dispatched by the anti-riot brigade. This was one of the series of measures undertaken by the authorities after the farmer applied for compensation after the town government sold his orchard without his approval.

On 26 November 2019, the police stormed into a hotel in Yancheng City, Jiangsu Province and arrested over 40 Christians. The believers were attending a two-day meeting led by a South Korean pastor. It was reported that the church had been under surveillance for a long time on the grounds of 'religious infiltration'. 6 of the arrested were detained for up to 14 days.

SOURCE: Hong Kong Government News; South China Morning Post
NOTES: On 27 November 2019, the police conducted a two-day operation to remove dangerous goods at the Polytechnic University campus in Hung Hom, Kowloon City district (Hong Kong) after anti-ELAB pro-democracy rioters, mainly students, occupied the campus as a base for the demonstrations. They seized about 3989 petrol bombs, 1339 pieces of explosives, 601 bottles of corrosive liquids and 573 other items classified as weapons (including hammers, air guns, 12 giant catapults used to fire bricks, 28 bows and about 200 arrows.)

Around 30 November 2019 (end of month), a Three-Self church venue in Fuzhou City, Fujian Province was shut down by the authorities, on the grounds that it was 'unlicensed' and that its gatherings 'disturbed people'. In the following month, the venue director attempted to apply to be managed by another Three-Self church but the application was rejected by the government. This was part of a crackdown to curb the growth of Christianity, by reducing the number of places of worship.

Around 30 November 2019 (end of month), multiple Catholic churches adminstered by the Diocese of Mindong in Ningde City, Fujian Province were shut down due to 'inadequate fire control measures'. It was reported that officials shut down these churches because their priest refused to join the Chinese Patriotic Catholic Association.

Property destruction: Around 30 November 2019 (end of month), the township government shut down and destroyed statues at a Buddhist temple in Geliping township of Xi district (Panzhihua, Sichuan). It was reported as one of the government's efforts to conceal or destroy outdoor icons and statues at Buddhist temples across the province.
Around 30 November 2019 (end of month), the meeting venue of a Local Church in Sizhou town (Dexing City, Jiangxi Province) was sealed off and closed, after they refused to join the Three-Self Church.

Around 30 November 2019 (end of month), a Three-Self Church venue in Litan Village, Cisheng Town (Zhecheng County, Henan Province) was demolished on orders by the local government. It was reported that police officers threw out all the items stored in the church, and took away remains such as windows and bricks from the church to be sold for their own gains.

Around 30 November 2019 (end of month), a large open-air Buddha statue at a temple in Xiaonan District (Xiaogan City, Hubei Province) was demolished on orders by Hubei Province's religious affairs administration. This was part of the ramped up efforts by local authorities to demolish outdoor Buddhist religious statues and temples.

Around 30 November 2019 (end of month), a Buddhist temple in Suizhou City, Hubei Province was demolished by government officials. It was reported that the temple's person-in-charge was held in a government building for four days and forced to sign a statement agreeing to the demolition of the temple. Government officials threatened to dismiss her son from public office if she refused to sign the statement. This was part of a broader campaign to crackdown on places of worship under the ongoing religious persecution strategy by the central government.

On 1 December 2019, a house church in Nanchang City, Jiangxi Province was raided by the police, claiming that it was 'holding illegal meetings and disturbing public order'. The police damaged the church's blackboard, seized Bibles and hymnbooks, and took away more than 800RMB of donation money.

On 2 December 2019, dozens of government personnel (from the Religious Affairs Bureau, State Land Bureau and Urban Construction Bureau) demolished a Guanyin statue outside a Buddhist temple (Sanshui Palace) in Meizhou prefecture (Guangdong) on the grounds that it was too tall and built illegally.

On 2 December 2019, the Buddha statue in a temple located in Haizhai Village (Shangqiu City, Henan Province) was demolished by local government officials. The incense burner and donor recognition plaques were also destroyed. This was part of a broader campaign to crack down on places of worship and outdoor worship areas across China, and destroy statues of deities and religious symbols.

Property destruction: On 2 December 2019, the Religious Affairs Bureau leveled down two Protestant True Jesus Church venues in Duigougang town of Guannan county (Lianyungan, Jiangsu) on the grounds of being dilapidated. The Bureau claimed that two-thirds of Three-Self churches in the town would be shut down on a range of pretexts, which would be rented, sold or demolished afterwards.
On 3 December 2019, a church in Xining, Qinghai Province was forced to shut down on the grounds that it 'did not meet the fire safety measures'.

On 5 December 2019, the Urban Management and Law Enforcement Bureau dispatched more than 100 personnel and two excavators to demolish a Three-Self Church in Weidong District (Pingdingshan City, Henan Province), on the grounds that it was an 'illegal construction'. It was reported that the government had confiscated most of the church's possessions from the demolition.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of China (2012-) People's Armed Police
NOTES: On 6 December 2019, a government-approved Three-Self Church in Yuanyang County (Xinxiang City, Henan Province) was demolished. On the day of demolition, the area was cordoned off, with more than 300 officers (including special and anti-riot police, urban management personnel) guarding and preventing people from entering the area. It was reported that the demolition was ordered because the pastor at the church refused to remove the cross and raise the Chinese national flag in the church, as part of the religious 'sinicization' campaign by the CCP.

On 6 December 2019, 500 outdoor Arhat statues in a Buddhist temple in Yongcheng City (Shangqiu City, Henan Province) were ordered to be demolished to make way for a park and a stadium, despite receiving approval from the government to be built at the site over 30 years ago. The statues were then demolished on an unspecified date. This was part of a broader campaign undertaken by the CCP to crack down on religious activities.

On 7 December 2019, a house church meeting venue in Lichuan County (Fuzhou City, Jiangxi Province) was raided by the police for 'unlicensed religious materials' (religious materials not approved by the government). They confiscated several boxes of Bibles, hymn books and other religious literature, and also took down the personal details of all congregation members present during the raid, threatening to arrest them if they were to congregate again. It was reported that the government personnel continued to visit the church regularly, to ensure that members did not resume assemblies. This was part of a nationwide campaign to 'eradicate pornography and illegal publications'.

Security measures: On 8 December 2019, a house church in Dancheng County (Zhoukou City, Henan Province) was raided and shut down by local officials. The officials also threatened believers that their land would be confiscated, and their social benefits would be suspended, if they did not stop attending religious gatherings.

On 9 December 2019, dozens of protesters were detained by police in Beijing as they were on their way to attend a Human Rights Day activity at the US Embassy in Beijing, including a lawyer and his wife, who was surrounded and harassed by more than 10 people after being warned by the police not to go out and attend the activity at the US Embassy.

On 11 December 2019, local government officials broke into a house church venue in Xiushui County (Jiujiang City, Jiangxi Province) and took down and burned the cross and other religious symbols. It was further reported that four other venues in the county were subjected to similar crackdowns.

On 12 December 2019, a Buddhist temple in Xing'an County (Guilin City, Guangxi Province) was razed to the ground by local authorities. This followed months of actions undertaken by the authorities to shut down its religious activities and remove all the Buddha statues.

On 13 December 2019, a Three-Self Church meeting venue and a church in Liangyuan District (Shangqiu City, Henan Province) were demolished. The owner of the Three-Self Churching meeting venue was also ordered to remove everything from the building before the demoliton.

In December 2019, a Catholic Church in Guchuan Village in Weibin District (Baoji City, Shaanxi Province) was shut down for refusing to register with the state. Prior to its closure, Chinese words for 'Catholic Church' were removed from its outer walls, and all three crosses were removed from the roof. This was part of a broader campaign undertaken by the CCP to crack down on religious activities.

In December 2019, at least 16 mosques in Pingliang City, Gansu Province had their Islamic symbols demolished by the authorities. Two of the mosques reportedly had its dome and star and crescent symbols removed in order to look more 'Chinese', and CCP's slogans were put up in one of the mosques. This was part of a broader campaign to remove Islamic elements from mosques across China, under the five-year plan to 'sinicize' Islam outside of Xinjiang.

In December 2019, a Seventh-Day Adventist Church in Lichuan County (Fuzhou City, Jiangxi Province) was raided by government personnel, with over 100 'pirated Bibles' confiscated. This was part of a nationwide campaign to 'eradicate pornography and illegal publications'.

In December 2019, the dome and the star and crescent symbols of a mosque in Ningling County (Shangqiu City, Henan Province) were removed on orders by the local government. This was part of a broader campaign to remove Islamic elements from mosques across China, under the five-year plan to 'sinicize' Islam outside of Xinjiang.

In mid-December 2019, two Arabic-style archways decorated with domes and star-and-crescent symbols were demolished in Nangeng Street, Miyun District, Beijing. The government claimed the demolition was conducted as part of 'street reconstruction'.

In December 2019, the dome and star-and-crescent symbol on a gate to a Hui village in Yuxi City, Yunnan Province, were removed by the government. This was part of a broader campaign to 'sinicize' Muslims in China, through the removal of Islamic symbols, rectifying 'Arabic-style' architectural features of buildings, and the indoctrination of Muslims.

In December 2019, a church in Lichuan County (Fuzhou City, Jiangxi Province) was broken into by government personnel, with more than a dozen Bibles and hymn books confiscated. These books were instead replaced with secular books on farming, healthcare, and other topics. Slogans promoting the core socialist values were also posted on the walls. This was part of a nationwide campaign to 'eradicate pornography and illegal publications'.

In December 2019, a local imam was forced to remove the dome and star-and-crescent symbols from his mosque in Mengzhou City (Jiaozuo City, Henan Province) by government employees, on the grounds that 'Arabic constructions are not allowed in China because this implies worship of foreign things'. Propaganda slogans and a national flag were added inside the mosque following the removal of the religious symbols. This was part of a broader campaign launched by the CCP to 'sinicize' Islam across China.

Around 15 December 2019 (month of), Islamic symbols were removed from nearly 50 mosques in Xiaoma Village, Wuling County (Jiaozuo City, Henan Province) by the authorities. This was part of the five-year plan to 'sinicize' Muslims outside of Xinjiang.

In December 2019, the crosses of two Three-Self churches in Luobei County (Hegang City, Heilongjiang Province) were removed by the county government, on the grounds that the crosses were 'too eye-catching' and would 'attract people into the churches'. This was part of a broader campaign launched by the central government to remove crosses from churches across China.

Around 15 December 2019 (month of), 176 Christian headstones with crosses were demolished in Xiapu County (Ningde City, Fujian Province) by officials from the county government. It was reported that the land on which these headstones were resting on was later sold for ten times of the original price. This was part of a broader campaign to remove religious symbols from tombstones.

In December 2019, numerous crosses were removed from a Three-Self church in Hegang City, Heilongjiang Province by the authorities. This was part of a broader campaign launched by the central government to remove crosses from churches across China.

In December 2019, at least 16 house churches were shut down in Yongkang City (Jinhua City, Zhejiang Province) by the government. Many of the landlords who rented their properties to these churches were also threatened by the government. One of the residents reported that the authorities threatened to arrest him and impose a fine on him, and he subsequently terminated the lease contract with the church.

In December 2019, the family of a deceased Three-Self Church member in Jiangxi Province was ordered by the local government officials to remove the painted cross from the believer's gravestone, and the wooden cross behind his tomb. The family obliged as the officials threatened to detroy the gravestone if they didn't. This was part of a broader campaign to remove religious symbols from churches and other structures.

In December 2019, a Protestant church venue in Ninghai County (Ningbo City, Zhejiang Province) was shut down on orders from the local government. Prior to its closure, the church leader had repeatedly been summoned by the county government to pressure the church leader to join the state-run Three-Self Patriotic Movement. After the church leader refused to join the movement, the church was repeatedly harassed and threatened before it was finally closed down.

Around 16 December 2019 (month of), Islamic symbols were removed from the signboards of halal shops in Lufeng County (Chuxiong Yi Autonomous, Yunnan Province). It was reported that between December 2019 and May 2020, Islamic symbols were removed from the signboards of 62 halal shops.

Around 16 December 2019 (month of), the dome and star-and-crescent symbols from the memorial archway entrance in Huagang Village of Yuxi City, Yunnan Province were forcibly removed by the government. According to some villagers, the government wanted to convert the archway into a Chinese-style structure. It was part of the five-year plan to 'sinicize' all Muslims outside of Xinjiang.

Land seizure: Around 16 December 2019 (month of), the government converted a clan's ancestral hall (associated with China's folk religion) in Xianghu town of Ruijin county (Ganzhou, Jiangxi) into a ''civilisation practice station,'' which would be a centre used to communicate political ideologies (''red education'').

Property destruction: Around 16 December 2019 (month of), a Protestant house church was leveled by the Yuhang district government (Hangzhou, Jiangsu) on the pretext that it was an illegal religious venue built without proper approval. The church was demolished previously to allegedly build a railway, and now to allegedly erect a new building.
Property destruction: Around 16 December 2019 (month of), authorities removed the cross from a Three-Self church in Bai village, Huangbai township of Ruijin county (Ganzhou, Jiangxi).

ACTOR1: Police Forces of China (2017-) Hong Kong Police Force
NOTES: On 19 December 2019, four people from the Spark Alliance--one of the largest crowd-funded initiatives providing financial aid to anti-ELAB protesters for things including living subsidies, medical costs, and bail--were arrested in Hong Kong on suspicion of money laundering, and were released on bail a few hours later. Officers seized over HK$130,000 in cash, HK$165,000 worth of supermarket coupons, and froze over HK$70 million in funds and insurance products.
On 20 December 2019, a Buddha statue in a temple in Longsha District (Qiqihar City, Heilongjiang Province) was destroyed by the local government, on the grounds that the statue was 'too tall'.

On 20 December 2019, a Three-Self Church in Lichuan County (Fuzhou City, Jiangxi Province) was raided by police officers. The police officers subsequently confiscated 30 Bibles found in the church. This was part of a nationwide campaign to 'eradicate pornography and illegal publications'.

On 20 December 2019, a Protestant house church venue in Tai'erzhuang District (Zaozhuang City, Shandong Province) was raided by nine local government officials. During the raid, officials tore down religious paintings from the walls and burnt the paintings. This was part of a broader campaign to crack down on non-state-approved house churches.

On 20 December 2019, a Catholic Church in Chengbei Subdistrict, Fu'an City (Ningde City, Fujian Province) was shut down with its church gates locked by government. This was part of a broader campaign to crack down on Catholic churches that refused to join the Chinese Patriotic Catholic Association.

On 22 December 2019, a Three-Self church in Xieji Town, Liangyuan District (Shangqiu City, Henan Province) was demolished after months of persecution by the government and failed attempts by the congregation to stop the demolition. It was reported that the government had ordered the demolition of the church after the congregation members continued to gather despite the local authorities ordering the shutdown of the church in August 2019. Just before Christmas 2019, a church in Chumen Town, Yuhuan City (Zhejiang Province) was converted into anti-cult centre by the local government. All the religious symbols were removed, and replaced with propaganda slogans praising the Communist Party. It was part of the enforced plan for the 'Four Requirements' campaign launched in June 2018 to 'sinicize' places of worship.

On 25 December 2019, the self-built house of a petitioner in Cangshan District (Fuzhou City, Fujian Province) was forcibly demolished by the local authorities, while the petitioner was still being detained in a detention centre for being charged with 'provoking trouble' in September 2018.

On 27 December 2019, the dome and the star and crescent symbols of a mosque in Huating County (Pingliang City, Gansu Province) were removed by the authorities. This was part of a broader campaign to remove Islamic elements from mosques across China, under the five-year plan to 'sinicize' Islam outside of Xinjiang.

On 27 December 2019, a Catholic Church in Saiqi Town, Fu'an City (Ningde City, Fujian Province) was shut down by government officials. A notice to shut down the bishop's residence was later issued on 15 January 2020. This was part of a broader campaign to crack down on Catholic churches that refused to join the Chinese Patriotic Catholic Association.

On 28 December 2019, several police officers stormed into a Sola Fide (Protestant) venue in Le'an County (Fuzhou City, Jiangxi Province) which was celebrating Christmas. Bibles, hymnbooks, audio equipment, Christmas decorations, and other valuables were confiscated by the police officers. Two church directors were also escorted to the local police station for questioning, and forced to write statements stating that they would not hold private meetings anymore.

Around 30 December 2019 (between 29 and 31 December 2019), a Catholic Church in Luojiazhuang Village of Qishan County (Baoji City, Shaanxi Province) was demolished by the Religious Affairs Bureau of Qishan County. It was reported that the church refused to be registered with the state and was subsequently demolished for 'lacking proper permits'. This was part of a broader campaign undertaken by the CCP to crack down on religious activities.

On 30 December 2019, a Buddhist temple in Xingyang City (Zhengzhou City, Henan Province) was demolished by government officials, on the grounds that it was an 'illegal construction'. On the day of the demolition, over 70 employees were sent by the Xingyang city government, with checkpoints set up along the road to prevent worshippers from hindering the demolition process. The entire temple, together with many Buddha statues and other valuable religious items, was turned into ruins. This was the second time that the same temple had been demolished, after it was first demolished during the Cultural Revolution.

On 1 January 2020, the statue of Virgin Mary was removed from a Catholic Church in Linchuan District (Fuzhou City, Jiangxi Province) on orders by the local government. This followed the removal of the church's crucifix on Christmas Day in 2019. The church had since been emptied, with chairs and tables removed. The incident was part of a broader campaign to persecute congregations and churches that declined to join the Chinese Patriotic Catholic Association.

On 1 January 2020, a nursing home operated by Catholic conscientious objectors in Fuzhou City, Jiangxi Province was raided by six local government officials and police officers. They confiscated 30 religious publications, a cross and other religious symbols and paintings. They also pressured the church's priest to sign an application to join the state-run Chinese Patriotic Catholic Association.

Property destruction: On 2 January 2020, local officials removed the cross of a Three-Self church in Hefei prefecture (Anhui) (coded to Shushan). On 2 January 2020, government-hired workers destroyed 24 statues at a Taoist venue in Dayu town (Suining, Sichuan). It was reported that from Oct 2019 to May 2020, at least 160 folk religion venues were demolished or shut down in four prefectures - Suining, Mianyang, Nanchong and Meishan - of Sichuan province, of which 116 temples were in Suining alone.

On 3 January 2020, a Buddhist temple in Qitang Town (Chongqing Municipality) was destroyed by the local authorities. This was part of the continued efforts to crack down on Buddhist temples across China.

On 5 January 2020, a Protestant house church venue in Nancheng County (Fuzhou City, Jiangxi Province) was closed down by local government officials. The preacher was also escorted to the county's Public Security Bureau for questioning. He was detained for five days for refusing to join the Three-Self Patriotic Movement. This was part of a broader campaign to pressure unregistered Protestant churches to join the state-run Three-Self Church.

On 5 January 2020, a house church in Jianggan District (Hangzhou City, Zhejiang Province) was shut down by local officials, on the grounds that they were acting upon the orders from the central government to shut down all house churches. This was part of a broader campaign to crack down on house churches which refused to be brought under the control of the central government.

On 8 January 2020, the cross of a Three-Self Church in Lanshan District (Linyi City, Shandong Province) on orders of the provincial government, on the grounds that it was 'too eye-catching'. The Chinese characters for 'love' and 'Christian Church' were also removed from the outer wall.

On 10 January 2020, a Protestant house church venue in Dexing City (Shangrao City, Jiangxi Province) was cleared out and shut down by the local government. The officials also threatened to demolish the venue if the director held meetings there again.

On 11 January 2020, a 'yellow shop' (businesses that support the pro-democracy movements) in Yuen Long (Hong Kong) was attacked by 3 unidentified masked men. One of them kicked a bench and destroyed it with a mallet. No injuries reported.

On 12 January 2020, a Catholic nursing home in Saiqi Town (Fu'an City, Fujian Province) was raided by nearly 50 government officials and police officers. The government personnel cut off the water and electricity supply to the nursing house and then forcibly shut it down, on the grounds of 'substandard fire control measures'. It was reported that the government personnel stated that the nursing home had to close down to pressure the parish's priests to join the state-run Chinese Patriotic Catholic Association.

Property destruction: On 12 January 2020, the county government destroyed all small statues and removed the large statues at a Buddhist Temple in Miyi county (Panzhihua, Sichuan), affecting over 50 statues in total. On 13 January 2020, a Catholic Church in Xiabaishi Town (Ningde City, Fujian Province) was shut down by local government officials. In November 2019, the officials also ordered for the Chinese characters referencing 'The Sanctuary of Our Lady of Lourdes' to be replaced by a CCP slogan. This was part of a broader campaign to crack down on Catholic churches that refused to join the Chinese Patriotic Catholic Association.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of China (2017-) Hong Kong Police Force
NOTES: On 14 January 2020, a water pipe soil-made bomb was seized by the police in Mong Kok, Yau Tsim Mong District (Hong Kong) and was defused at the scene. 6 people were arrested on 14 January 2020, and 4 more people were arrested on 15 January 2020. In January 2020, a house church venue in Guangfeng District (Shangrao City, Jiangxi Province) was shut down by government officials. This followed after a series of harassment by government officials, where the government hired two people in December 2019 to guard the entrance to the church every day to prevent believers from gathering. This was part of a broader campaign to crack down on house churches which refused to be brought under the control of the central government.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of China (2017-) Hong Kong Police Force
NOTES: On 15 January 2020, police found and destroyed a bomb-making laboratory in a village house in Sheng Shui, North District (Hong Kong). Laboratory supplies including chemical powders, gas canisters were seized, and a man was arrested. It was in relation to the water pipe bomb found in Mong Kok the day before.

In January 2020, the domes and star-and-crescent symbols were removed from at least 10 mosques in Pingdingshan City, Henan Province. This was part of a broader campaign launched by the CCP to 'sinicize' Islam across China.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of China (2017-) Hong Kong Police Force
NOTES: On 16 January 2020, police discovered more homemade explosives buried underground in a village house in Sheng Shui, North District (Hong Kong). 3 women living in the house were arrested for handling and possessing explosives. This was in relation to the seizure of a water pipe bomb in Mong Kok on 14 January 2020, and the seizure and demolition of a bomb-making laboratory in the same village house in Sheng Shui.
Property destruction: Around 16 January 2020 (month of), a Guanyin statue outside a Buddhist temple in Linhai county (Taizhou, Zhejiang) was demolished by authorities.

On 16 January 2020, the Chinese government forced the closure of a Catholic church in Fu'an County (Ningde City, Fujian Province) by cutting off its electricity and water supply. It also issued a deportation order for the bishop to leave the bishop's office. Several other clerics who worked with the bishop were also forced to leave the church. It is widely believed that the church was shut down because the bishop refused to join the Chinese Patriotic Catholic Association set up by the government.

ACTOR2: Police Forces of China (2017-) Hong Kong Police Force
NOTES: On 19 January 2020, an unidentified person threw four petrol bombs into the reporting room and parking area of Tai Po Police Station (Tai Po District, Hong Kong). No injuries were reported.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of China (2017-) Hong Kong Police Force
NOTES: On 21 January 2020, authorities removed an altar and part of a 'Lennon Wall' dedicated to two youths who passed away during the anti-extradition bill protests last year. During the operation, about 50 armed riot police were at the site on alert.

ACTOR2: Police Forces of China (2017-) Hong Kong Police Force
NOTES: On 22 January 2020, unidentified persons threw petrol bombs at Tuen Mun Police Station (Tuen Mun, Hong Kong). Brakes on the cars at the station were also found to have been burnt. Police officers arrested 2 suspects nearby, who were found to be in possession of gloves, lighter, petrol bombs and laser pen.

On 1 February 2020, the State Administration for Religious Affairs of China implemented the 'Administrative Measures for Religious Groups', which in addition to the new Regulations on Religious Affairs issued in 2018, was reported to further govern the organization of religious groups. The provisions contain six chapters and 41 articles, which stipulated regulations around the organization of religious groups, their functions, and their supervision and management.
Property destruction: On 2 February 2020, the prefecture government demolished a house church venue in Heyuan prefecture (Guangdong) (coded to Yuancheng).

ACTOR2: Police Forces of China (2017-) Hong Kong Police Force
NOTES: On 2 February 2020, two homemade bombs were found in a train cabin at Lo Wu MTR Station (North District, Hong Kong). One of the bombs exploded after the police and explosive disposal section arrived at the scene. No casualties or arrests reported. This was the fourth case of crude homemade bombs placed in different locations across Hong Kong since 27 January 2020, in response to the Hong Kong government's decision not to fully close the border with Mainland China during the coronavirus outbreak. A channel on Telegram named 'Stick 92' had claimed responsibility for the incident and threatened to 'bomb' people 'spreading disease' by travelling from mainland China to Hong Kong.

On 3 February 2020, the cross of a Three-Self church in Hexi Village, Lanling County (Linyi City, Shandong Province) was removed by workers hired by a representative of the Zhuangwu town government, on the grounds that the representative 'could be dismissed from office' if his superiors saw the cross. This was part of a broader campaign launched by the central government to remove crosses from churches across China.

On 7 February 2020, local officials smashed properties in the venue of a Protestant house church in Xuzhuang Town (Zhengzhou City, Henan Province) during an inspection to check if lockdown measures were being implemented at the venue. This was part of an ongoing crackdown on religious activities and places of worship across China.

Property destruction: On 10 February 2020, the town government demolished a 200-square-metre Protestant house church in Tushan town of Pizhou county (Xuzhou, Jiangsu). The government also trucked away church belongings worth about 25,000 RMB two days before the demolition.

On 12 February 2020, a family of four were playing mahjong at home in Hubei when two police officers barged into their house, holding batons and hammers. During an argument, the police officer smashed the mahjong table with a hammer and almost hit one of the men with a baton, but was stopped by the other police officer. This was one of several reports of abuse by law enforcement officers while performing their duties for the prevention of the coronavirus outbreak.

On 12 February 2020, a house church venue in Liyuan Town, Heping County (Heyuan City, Guangdong Province) was demolished by the authorities. A female believer was arrested by the police and detained for five days for opposing the demolition. It was reported that the local officers had been pressuring the congregation to move out as 'the government plans to develop the locale into a tourism area'. This was part of a broader campaign to crack down on unregistered house churches across China.

On 14 February 2020, between 20 and 30 people were arrested by epidemic prevention personnel in Hubei Province for not wearing masks. They were tied together on a long string, with all of their hands tied to their back. It was reported that they were paraded on the streets as a form of punishment. This was one of several reports of abuse by law enforcement officers while performing their duties for the prevention of the coronavirus outbreak.

Property destruction: Around 15 February 2020 (month of), the Tengzhou city government demolished a three-faced Guanyin statue in the Longshan Scenic Area in Tengzhou county (Zaozhuang, Shandong) over 20 days.
Property destruction: Around 15 February 2020 (month of), the town government demolished a Seventh-day Adventist house church venue in Xinglou town of Pizhou county (Xuzhou, Jiangsu).

Property destruction: Around 15 February 2020 (month of), the town government smashed glazed tiles and removed the cross, religious couplets and other signs from a Three-Self venue in Gangshang town in Pizhou county (Xuzhou, Jiangsu) before shutting it down. 111 official and house church venues were shut down between Jan and Mar 2020 on the pretext of ''coronavirus prevention.''

Around 15 February 2020 (month of), government officials demolished a 108-room nursing home in Fuzhou prefecture (Fujian) that was run by a state-approved Buddhist temple, causing most residents to leave. They also went back on their promise not to obstruct the building of a new nursing home, threatening to arrest the temple's director if he attempted to open a new centre.

Around 15 February 2020 (month of), the dome and star-and-crescent symbols were removed from a Hui Muslim mosque in Zhongtou town of Jia county (Pingdingshan, Henan), then changed to a Chinese-style structure in May 2020.

Around 18 February 2020 (between 17 to 19 February 2020), hundreds of residents in Xiaogan City and Huanggang City (Hubei Province) were arrested and detained by epidemic prevention personnel. They were detained in stadiums or vacant school buildings to 'learn' the new policy issued by the Hubei Provincial Government, which prohibits urban residents from going out, and rural residents from gathering or going out. It was reported that the detainees were forced to run around the playground, chanting epidemic prevention slogans from time to time.

On 19 February 2020, a 3-metre-tall Buddha statue and pavilion in a Buddhist temple located in a town in Kaizhou District (Chongqing) was demolished by a local CCP secretary, after being pressured by local officials. It was reported that the CCP secretary had attempted to demolish the statue the day before but was stopped by the temple's manager, who was then taken away by the police.

On 20 February 2020, a Buddhist temple in Huanghua Town (formerly known as Chengjiao Township) (Anyang City, Henan Province) was repurposed into an activity centre on orders from the local government, on the grounds that it was 'not harmonious with the surrounding environment and negatively affected the town's image'. All Buddhist statues in the temple were smashed, and slogans promoting the core socialist values were hung outside the temple. The signboard of the temple was replaced with the name of a new cultural activity centre.

On 23 February 2020, the dome and other parts of a mosque in Lushan County (Pingdingshan City, Henan Province) were demolished by the local government. It was reported that the demolition took place while Hui villagers were away from the village for 22 consecutive days, providing free lunch for frontline medical and sanitation workers, and urban management personnel who were fighting against the coronavirus outbreak. It was part of a broader five-year plan to 'sinicize' Islam in China.

Property destruction: Around 25 February 2020 (between 22 - 29 February), the city government demolished a shed that was used for Christian worship gatherings in Heyuan prefecture (Guangdong) (coded to Yuancheng).

Around 1 March 2020 (beginning of month), the roof cross of a Christian church in Huaishang District (Bengbu City, Anhui Province) was removed by the head of United Front Work Department of the village, village officials, and a few guards they led.

On 1 March 2020, the 'Regulations on Ecological Governance of Network Information Content' issued by the Chinese Internet Network Information Center, an administrative body under the Ministry of Industry and Information Technology, came into effect. The new regulation prohibits the publication of inappropriate content by 'internet information content producers and users', and the use of internet and other technologies to carry out insults, defamation, threats, spread rumours, violate the privacy of others. It was believed that the new regulations would have a significant impact on the freedom of expression.

On 6 March 2020, a Buddhist temple in Hanshan District (Handan City, Henan Province) was destroyed on orders from the local government, on the grounds that it 'lacked a religious activity venue registration certificate'. 36 officials from the district government, Religious Affairs Bureau, Public Security Bureau, Criminal Investigation Brigade, and other law enforcement departments were mobilised for the demolition. During the demolition, an elderly resident was forcibly dragged away by government employees when attempting to stop the demolition.

Property destruction: On 7 March 2020, over 100 county government-dispatched personnel and police officers blocked the roads to a Buddhist temple in Miyi county (Panzhihua, Sichuan) and destroyed more than 20 statues. They also confiscated donation boxes, and welded steel bars to the temple door to prevent anyone from entering. It was reported as one of the government's efforts to conceal or destroy outdoor icons and statues at Buddhist temples across the province.

As reported on 8 March 2020, the cross from a church in Huaishang District (Bengbu City, Anhui Province) was dismantled by the local authorities. This was part of a broader campaign initiated by the Ethnic and Religious Affairs Bureau of Anhui Province for public security units to continue cracking down on 'illegal evangelism'.

ACTOR2: Police Forces of China (2017-) Hong Kong Police Force
NOTES: Property destruction: On 8 March 2020, unidentified persons hurled petrol bombs at a police quarters in Sheung Shui, North District (Hong Kong) (coded as Hong Kong - North). A flower trough at the site caught fire, and the windows of a parked car were damaged. The police subsequently conducted an on-site investigation and seized four petrol bombs. No arrest reported.

On 9 March 2020, an 11-metre-mall Guanyin statue of a Buddhist temple in Fuzhou City, Fujian Province was demolished by government officials, on the grounds that it was 'too tall'. The officials had threatened the abbot that they would demolish the temple if the Guanyin statue was not removed.

On 11 March 2020, a mosque in Yinchuan City, Ningxia Region was 'sinicized' by the government. During the rectification process, local Muslims were prohibited from interfering, or sharing information or discussing the rectification.

On 11 March 2020, a Christian church in Yixing City (Wuxi City, Jiangsu Province) was forcibly demolished on orders from the government. It was reported that videos showed that the building, which originally took up about 200 square metres, was torn down with bricks all over the ground and the roof was completely gone.

On 13 March 2020, the cross from a church in Woyang County (Bozhou City, Anhui Province) was dismantled by the local authorities. This was part of a broader campaign initiated by the Ethnic and Religious Affairs Bureau of Anhui Province for public security units to continue cracking down on 'illegal evangelism'.

On 14 March 2020, a Three-Self church in Huoqiu County (Lu'an City, Anhui Province) was shut down by the county government. It was reported that the officials had initially ordered the church director to remove the cross, on the grounds that the cross would fall and injure people. They then forced the church to shut down after the church director refused to remove the cross.

Around 15 March 2020 (month of), eight Buddhist temples in Yongchuan District (Chongqing Municipality) were closed on orders of the local government. Some temple managers were told to close down the temples, under the pretext of 'epidemic prevention measure'. The officials had threatened to demolish the temples if they were not closed down.

Around 15 March 2020 (month of), the cross of a Sola Fide church in Ceshan Town (Linyi City, Shandong Province) was removed by the town authorities. This was part of a broader campaign to crack down on unregistered house churches across China.

Around 16 March 2020 (month of), the authorities began painting over or covering Islamic symbols and writings in Arabic on signboards of Hui-run businesses located in Chuxiong City (Chuxiong Yi Autonomous, Yunnan Province). It was reported that between March and May 2020, signboards of 70 Hui-run businesses were painted over or covered.

Around 16 March 2020 (month of), over 200 government-dispatched personnel demolished a local Buddhist temple in Mamiao town of Huaining county (Anqing, Anhui) as part of the national policy. To avoid public protests, the government did not inform the temple's director and villagers beforehand.

Property destruction: Around 16 March 2020 (month of), local authorities demolished Three-Self church housed in a makeshift structure in Yutai county (Jining, Shandong) on the pretext that it was an ''illegal construction.'' They tore up all Bibles, images of Jesus, then bulldozed the church with furniture in it. The original church had been demolished before in the same year.

Around 16 March 2020 (month of), a Three-Self church in Yutai county (Jining, Shandong) was demolished by the county government. They broke in during a gathering, tore up Bibles and religious images, then demolished the building with furniture and electrical appliances buried underneath.

Around 16 March 2020 (month of), a state-sanctioned Catholic church in Tongjia Town (Yingtan City, Jiangxi Province) was shut down and repurposed into an entertainment venue by the town government. The local government officials stated that 'Catholics should be suppressed because they are linked to the US and support the Hong Kong riots'.

Around 16 March 2020 (month of), the dome and crescent atop a mosque in Liangjia town, Yucheng City (Dezhou, Shandong) were removed on orders of the town government. Its exterior walls were also painted white and slogans were added to the mosque's front door. Two warning signs were also added to the main door encouraging people to report 'illegal religious activities' and warning CPC members against 'entering religious venues and attending religious activities'.
Property destruction: Around 16 March 2020 (month of), two Taoist temples in Lingxi town of Cangnan county (Wenzhou, Jiangxi) were demolished.

On 18 March 2020, a mosque in the Economic Development Zone of Zhengzhou City, Henan Province was remodelled by government-hired workers to make the mosque appear 'more Chinese'. It was reported that the star-and-crescent symbols had previously been removed in November 2019. This was part of the five-year plan to 'sinicize' Muslims outside of Xinjiang.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of China (2017-) Hong Kong Police Force
NOTES: On 26 March 2020, the police seized 800 shells, 200 bullet heads, suspected gunpowder and a press machine in an abandoned pre-war military structure near the Leaping Dragon Walk hiking trail in Eastern District (Hong Kong). Ten rounds of rifle bullets, a haul of arrows and knives, and chemicals which could be used to produce explosives, were also found at the site. 4 men were arrested in Hong Kong 12 hours after the site was uncovered. At a press conference held on 27 March 2020, the police stated that the bullets and explosives were made to supply violent protests. They added that while the bullets were homemade and might have less power than commercial products, they were capable of causing harm to a degree.

On 29 March 2020, the halls of a Buddhist temple in Beiguan Village, Kaiyuan District (Linzhou City, Anyang City, Henan Province) were converted by the authorities into reading and activity rooms, where books and Chinese chessboards were assembled. The signboard of the temple was also painted over.

Around 31 March 2020 (end of month), the domes and stars-and-crescent symbols were removed from 17 mosques in Kongtong District (Pingliang City, Gansu Province) on orders from the local government. It was reported that ahead of the removal of these religious elements (at an unreported date), imams and in-charges of the mosques were sent for indoctrination by the authorities, where they were forced to study 'de-Arabization and de-Saudization policies, as well as the promotion of religion 'sinicization'. This was part of a broader campaign launched by the CCP to 'sinicize' Islam across China.

Around 31 March 2020 (end of month), the domes and star-and-crescent symbols of a men-only mosque in Xiaoma Village, Wuzhi County (Jiaozuo City, Henan Province) were removed on orders of the government. This was part of the five-year plan to 'sinicize' Muslims outside of Xinjiang.

Around 1 April 2020 (beginning of month), the domes and star-and-crescent symbols of two mosques in Dali City (Dali Bai Autonomous, Yunnan Province) were demolished by the government. Slogans promoting the core socialist values and posters promoting the 'sinicization' of Islam were also put up inside the mosques. This was part of the state's five-year plan to 'sinicize' all Muslims outside Xinjiang.

Around 1 April 2020 (beginning of month), the cross of a Three-Self church in Duyang County (Jiujiang City, Jiangxi Province) was removed on orders of a local government official ahead of an inspection by higher-ups. The official claimed that the church was 'too eye-catching' due to its proximity to a highway.

On 1 April 2020, a Buddhist temple in Dangtu County (Ma'anshan City, Anhui Province) was forcibly demolished by the local government. During the demolition, nearly 100 law enforcement personnel surrounded the temple to prevent people from approaching. Some elderly people were reportedly pushed to the ground, and a resident filming the demolition was threatened to be arrested. It was reported that the temple had previously been sealed off by the government in May 2019 for the 'lack of religious activity venue registration certificate'.

Around 1 April 2020 (beginning of month), a Charismatic house church venue and two Sola Fide venues in Ceshan Town (Linyi City, Shandong Province) were shut down by the local government. This was part of a broader campaign to crack down on unregistered house churches across China.

On 2 April 2020, a Vietnamese fishing boat reportedly crashed into a Chinese coastguard vessel in the disputed region near Chinese-controlled Paracel Islands. According to the Chinese coastguard in an online statement issued on 3 April 2020, the fishing boat had been illegally fishing in the waters near the Paracel Islands and had refused to leave despite repeated warnings from the Chinese coastguard. The fishing boat later allegedly rammed into the coastguard vessel, and all eight fishermen were rescued by the Chinese coastguard and returned to the Vietnamese authorities. The Vietnamese foreign ministry had refuted this claim and lodged a protest against the Chinese government, stating that the fishing boat had been rammed and sunk deliberately by the coastguard. This marked the second incident in less than a year where a Vietnamese fishing vessel was reportedly sunk near Paracel Islands, in a disputed region claimed by Vietnam, China, and Taiwan.

On 2 April 2020, the cross of a Protestant church in Fuyang City, Anhui Province was removed by ten officials from the city's Religious Affairs Bureau, Public Security Bureau, and other government departments. It was reported that the government officials had been dispatched to oversee the removal of the church the day before, but were blocked by over 100 congregation members. The cross was removed in the early morning of 2 April 2020 after hours of pressuring the church's director.

On 3 April 2020, the cross on top of a Christian church in Duchang County (Jiujiang City, Jiangxi Province) was removed on orders of a government official. Church members argued with the official, but eventually took it down themselves.

On 4 April 2020, the domes and star-and-crescent symbols were removed from a government-approved mosque in Jiumen village (Shijiazhuang City, Hebei Province) by the authorities. This was part of a broader campaign to 'sinicize' mosques to make them look 'more Chinese'.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of China (2012-) People's Armed Police
NOTES: On 8 April 2020, more than 1,000 special police officers, and an unreported number of government officials from the municipal offices and district office were mobilised to demolish a Qing Dynasty-era ancestral house of a human rights activist in Yaodu District (Linfen City, Shanxi Province). The demolition followed the arrest of the activist and his third sister the day before. It was reported that the authorities had attempted to suppress the family for many years through the departments of land planning, public security, fire protection, among many others. The activist had been a target of government suppression for his activism on mainstream media for vulnerable communities in Linfen City.
On 10 April 2020, a folk religion temple in Zhengzhou prefecture (Henan) was leveled to the ground by the authorities at night and without warning.

On 10 April 2020, the cross of a Protestant church in Shucheng County (Lu'an City, Anhui Province) was removed by workers hired by the government. It was reported that crosses were removed from at least 250 Three-Self churches in many cities across Anhui Province between January and April 2020.

On 10 April 2020, a Three-Self church in Fuzhou City, Jiangxi Province was destroyed on orders of the township government and local Religious Affairs Bureau. This was part of an intensified campaign to demolish Three-Self churches across China.

On 11 April 2020, the crosses and all other religious elements were removed from two Three-Self churches in Qiu County (Handan City, Hebei Province) by the authorities. This was part of the broader campaign to 'sinicize' religion, by removing religious elements from places of worship across China.

On 11 April 2020, over 70 government personnel demolished a one-storey building in the courtyard of a nursing home in Gushan town (Fuzhou, Fujian) without warning. The nursing home was run by a Three-Self church, and previously approved by the local Religious Affairs Bureau.

On 12 April 2020, a Three-Self church located on Shengli Road, Chengxi District (Xining City, Qinghai Province) was demolished by around 10 officials from the municipal government, on the grounds that it was an 'illegal building' with 'building safety hazards'. It was reported that the majority of believers in the church was female.

On 13 April 2020, an old church in Xiaxu Village (Shangrao City, Jiangxi Province) (coded at Shangrao City) was forcibly cleared out under the orders of the local officials, and the church was demolished by more than a dozen urban management personnel. This was part of a broader campaign to crack down on unregistered house churches across China.

On 13 April 2020, the cross of a Three-Self church in Dashu Township, Duchang County (Jiujiang City, Jiangxi Province) was removed on orders of the county government. The official also threatened to demolish the church if the church director did not remove the cross.
On 14 April 2020, a folk religion temple in Dengfeng county (Zhengzhou, Henan) was demolished by the authorities.

Around 15 April 2020 (middle of month), the crosses of all 33 Three-Self churches in Hanshan County (Ma'anshan City, Anhui Province) were removed by officials from the county's United Front Work Department and other government institutions. It was reported that the city authorities had been publicly criticised by the provincial government for not removing crosses quickly enough.

Around 15 April 2020 (middle of month), the cross of a Three-Self church was demolished by the local government. A local believer reported that the government is planning to convert to church into an elderly activity centre. It was reported that Protestants in the county had been targeted likely due to their considerably large number of believers.

Around 15 April 2020 (middle of month), the cross and other religious symbols of a local church venue in Fenglingtou Town, Guangxin District (Shangrao City, Jiangxi Province) was forcibly removed by the local officials. It was reported that the officials also looted the church's donation money. This was part of the broader campaign aimed at forcing house churches to join the state-run churches.
Around 15 April 2020 (month of), the domes and crescent symbols of two Hui Muslim mosques in Yuzhou county (Xuchang, Henan) were demolished.

Around 15 April 2020 (month of), local authorities removed crosses from a Three-Self church in Zhangzhuang town of Yi'nan county (Linyi, Shandong). Crosses were removed from churches across Shandong ahead of provincial government inspections.

Around 15 April 2020 (month of), local authorities removed crosses from a Three-Self Church in Rizhao city (Shandong) and another Three-Self church on Danyang Road, Donggang district (Rizhao, Shandong). Crosses were removed from churches across Shandong ahead of provincial government inspections.

Around 15 April 2020 (month of), local authorities tore down religious images and symbols at a Catholic house of prayer in Changpojiao village of Jianshui county (Honghe, Yunnan), then destroyed its Hall of the Virgin Mary before repurposing the venue. A centre for weddings and funerals was built in its place two months later.

On 15 April 2020, a Three-Self church in Fuxing district (Handan, Hebei) was destroyed on the grounds of being 'an illegal building.' Officials had reportedly planned its demolition over a year ago, but the congregation attempted to postpone it.

Around 15 April 2020 (month of), the crosses of two Three-Self churches in Yangbu County (Shangrao City, Jiangxi Province) were removed by the authorities. The churches were also converted into activity centres. This was part of an intensified crackdown on churches in Jiangxi Province, where crosses from at least six churches were removed within a week in April 2020.

Around 15 April 2020 (month of), the cross and other religious symbols of a Three-Self church in Xinyuan Village, Yugan County (Shangrao City, Jiangxi Province) were removed by government officials using kitchen knives. The congregation was told that they were not allowed to worship God in the church, or the church would be demolished. This was part of an intensified crackdown on churches in Jiangxi Province, where crosses from at least six churches were removed within a week in April 2020.

On 15 April 2020, two folk religion temples in Baizhuang Village, Cizhou Town (Handan City, Hebei Province) were demolished by over 30 officials. This was part of a broader campaign launched across three provinces in April 2020, where nearly 100 folk religion sites were suppressed during the month.

Around 15 April 2020 (month of), five mosques in Minquan County (Shangqiu City, Henan Province) were forcibly rectified on orders from the central government to 'sinicize' over 1,000 mosques across the province. Domes with star-and-crescent symbols were removed from the mosques to make them look 'more Chinese'.

Around 15 April 2020 (month of), all poplar trees planted by farmers in Zuojiagou village, Shilai town of Xintai county (Tai'an, Shandong) were cut down overnight by the authorities without consent of the farmers, after the county government mandated all its villages to plant food crops (including grains) instead of trees in the next five years. Similar policies were enacted in Guangxi, Guangdong and Zhejiang provinces. Around the same time, President Xi had also called for a nationwide reduction of food waste, raising alleged speculations that China was facing 'imminent' food shortages due to the global pandemic, natural floods and trade uncertainties.

Around 15 April 2020 (month of), the local government ordered the closure of a nursing home in Putian prefecture (Fujian) that was established by a state-run Protestant church, on the grounds that 'the building's fire control measures were substandard'. This was part of a broader campaign to crack down on nursing homes run by religious groups in order to block any promotion of religions.

Around 15 April 2020 (month of), a mosque in Chengguan District (Lanzhou City, Gansu Province) had its Islamic symbols demolished by the local government. This was part of a broader campaign to 'sinicize' mosques across Gansu Province.

Around 15 April 2020 (month of), a Buddhist temple in Jinzhou District (Dalian City, Liaoning Province) was demolished by the authorities, on the grounds that it was an 'illegal construction'. Nearly 100 police officers were dispatched to prevent believers from approaching the temple during the demolition. All Buddhist statues were also removed from the temple before it was razed to the ground.

Around 15 April 2020 (month of), a Three-Self church in Qingshui Township, Guangxin District (Shangrao City, Jiangxi Province) was shut down by the local government, on the grounds of being 'unlicensed and too eye-catching'. Officials also reportedly destroyed religious symbols inside the church. The church was later converted into an elderly activity centre in early May 2020.

Around 15 April 2020 (month of), a mosque in Qilihe District (Lanzhou City, Gansu Province) had its Islamic symbols demolished by the local government. This was part of a broader campaign to 'sinicize' mosques across Gansu Province.

Around 15 April 2020 (month of), the domes and star-and-crescent symbols of a mosque in Jian'an District (Xuchang City, Henan Province) were converted into a Chinese-style hexagonal pavilion by workers hired by the Religious Affairs Bureau. This was part of a broader campaign to 'sinicize' mosques across the province, such that the mosques were recitified to look 'more Chinese'.

Around 15 April 2020 (month of), a mosque in Zhuanglang County (Pingliang City, Gansu Province) had all of its three domes removed by the authorities. This was part of a broader campaign to 'sinicize' mosques across Gansu Province.

Around 15 April 2020 (month of), the dome and minarets were removed from a mosque in Baiyin City, Gansu Province by the authorities. This was part of a broader campaign launched by the CCP to 'sinicize' Islam.

Around 15 April 2020 (month of), a mosque in Yinchuan City, Ningxia Region was 'sinicized' on orders from the government, with its dome and minarets removed. This was part of a broader campaign to 'sinicize' mosques, such that they were rectified to make them look 'more Chinese'.
Property destruction: Around 15 April 2020 (month of), authorities demolished some buildings at a Taoist Temple in Liaoyang county (Liaoyang, Liaoning). It was shut down last year.

Property destruction: Around 15 April 2020 (month of), authorities destroyed a Bodhisattva statue outside a Buddhist temple in Dongshagou village, Wujinshan town of Yuci district (Jinzhong, Shanxi) on orders to destroy all statues taller than ten metres.

Property destruction: Around 15 April 2020 (month of), some halls of a Buddhist temple on the Guangfu Mountain in Cangshan district (Fuzhou, Fujian) were demolished by the local government due to plans to build a new road.

On 15 April 2020, the cross on the roof of a Three-Self church in Sanhe Town, Feixi County (Hefei City, Anhui Province) was taken down by about a dozen police and other personnel on orders from the local government.
Property destruction: Around 15 April 2020 (month of), the town government removed the crosses and the signboard from a local Catholic venue in Simencun town of Botou county (Cangzhou, Hebei).

Around 15 April 2020 (month of), local authorities demolished the state-run Three-Self Tianfeng Church in Luoyang prefecture (Henan) on the pretext of 'expanding a railway line.' Although the government initially agreed to build a new church nearby, the Religious Affairs Bureau director, urban management officers and workers again destroyed 12 pillars at the church's new ongoing construction site on 30 July 2020.

On 16 April 2020, government-hired personnel destroyed all statues in a folk religion temple in a village administered by Hejian town of Linzhou county (Anyang, Henan) and demolished several temple buildings. A signboard on the remaining structure indicated the temple was being repurposed into a volunteer service station or 'civilisation practice station'.

On 16 April 2020, the cross of a Three-Self church in Xishan Town, Xinjian District (Nanchang City, Jiangxi Province) was removed on orders of two local government officials. The church was also asked to erect a flagpole for the Chinese national flag.

Security measures: Around 17 April 2020, it was observed through satellite imagery that government workers with cranes and heavy machinery had started small-scale dredging in a bay at Woody Island (Yongxing Island) of the Paracel Islands (Sansha, Hainan) and building a web of land bridges, interpreted as a foundation to expand the island through land reclamation, and make way for new settlements and military outposts, such as the China Coast Guard and Navy of the People's Liberation Army. The satellite imagery was taken between April 17 and June 25. Newer satellite imagery showed that construction for land reclamation and coastal erosion protection continued into late 2020.

Around 17 April 2020 (between 14 to 19 April 2020), a hall and two residential buildings of a folk religion temple in Wenling City (Taizhou City, Zhejiang Province) were demolished by the county government. According to a Taizhou city government employee, village officials had been summoned by higher authorities to intensify their crackdowns on folk religions venues as 'illegal structures'. This was part of a broader campaign launched across three provinces in April 2020, where nearly 100 folk religion sites were suppressed during the month.

On 18 April 2020, a Buddhist temple in Dongjie Village, Linzhou City (Anyang City, Henan Province) was repurposed into an activity room for the elderly by over 20 Linzhou city government personnel. It was reported that prior to the conversion of the temple, government labourers had forcibly smashed Buddhist statues and looted all valuables, on the grounds that 'no Buddhist temples or statues are allowed within 30 meters from the road'.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of China (2017-) Hong Kong Police Force
ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Government of China (2017-) Hong Kong Special Administrative Region; Former Government of China (2017-) Hong Kong Special Administrative Region; DP: Democratic Party (Hong Kong); Hong Kong Labour Party; CP: Civic Party (Hong Kong); LSD: League of Social Democrats; CHRF: Civil Human Rights Front; Lawyers (China)
SOURCE: Hong Kong Government News; HKFP; South China Morning Post
NOTES: Arrests: On 18 April 2020, the police launched an operation in Hong Kong and arrested 15 prominent figures, including current and former lawmakers from the pro-democracy camp, for their involvement and participation in the anti-ELAB demonstrations on 18 August 2019 and 1 October 2019. The arrestees included former chairs of the Democratic Party (including a barrister dubbed as the 'father of Hong Kong democracy'), lawmakers from the Democratic Party, Labour Party, Civic Party, League of Social Democrats, and the vice-convenor of the CHRF. Opposition lawmakers accused the police of launching the operation after repeated criticisms of the pro-democracy camp from the Beijing's Liaison Office over the past week for 'blocking and disrupting legislative proceedings', while the Security Bureau issued a statement noting that the arrests were made based on evidence from investigations and strictly according to the laws in force.

On 18 April 2020, China declared two new administrative districts in the contested region in the South China Sea, and released a new map naming all the islands and reefs it claims. The new districts were Nansha District (based at Fiery Cross Reef), which will oversee Spratly Islands, and Xisha District (based on Woody Island), which will oversee the Paracel Islands - both groups of islands claimed by Vietnam. The declaration was announced despite unresolved territorial disputes over the region between China and a number of Southeast Asian countries, including Vietnam, Malaysia, and the Philippines. The Vietnamese government had since issued a statement on 19 April 2020 condemning the move by China, calling it a serious violation of its sovereignty.

On 18 April 2020, the cross of a Catholic church in Ma'anshan City, Anhui Province was demolished by the community chairperson and several youths. They were informed by the county's United Front Work Department five days ago that the crosses from Christian and Catholic churches had to be demolished.
On 19 April 2020, the cross of a Catholic church in Yongqiao District (Suzhou City, Anhui Province) was demolished by the authorities.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of China (2017-) Hong Kong Police Force
NOTES: On 20 April 2020, the Wan Chai Police Headquarters in Wan Chai District (Hong Kong) received a mail package containing a home-made bomb addressed to the Commissioner of Police. The Explosive Ordnance Disposal Unit was called to the scene after the package started emitting suspicious smell. The bomb was safely defused with no injuries reported. Following examination of the bomb, the Explosive Ordnance Disposal Unit reported that the bomb was a targeted device, which would explode at close range when the recipient opened the package, commonly used by 'terrorists' around the world in recent years. No arrests had yet been made in relation to this incident.

On 20 April 2020, a Three-Self church in Shangrao County (former name of Guangxin District - location coded as Guangxin) (Shangrao City, Jiangxi Province) was demolished by the county government, on the grounds that it was 'unlicensed and dilapidated'. It was reported that the local officials told the congregation that the order came from their higher-ups because 'the government doesn't allow belief in Jesus'.

On 20 April 2020, a Buddhist temple in Yi County (Baoding City, Hebei Province) was demolished by over 200 personnel dispatched by the county government and Public Security Bureau, on the grounds that it was an 'illegal construction'.

On 21 April 2020, the cross of a Three-Self church in Jiangjia Village (Yugan County, Shangrao City, Jiangxi Province) was removed by the authorities. It was reported that the church director and believers were previously advised by a village official that higher-level government demanded to have crosses removed from all churches, and have worship services banned in all Protestant places of worship. Three days later, four village officials shut down the church and removed all chairs and religious symbols from the church.

On 21 April 2020, the cross of a Three-Self church in Gaojia Village (Shangrao City, Jiangxi Province) was removed by government-hired workers. It was reported that the congregation was told to sell the church. Three days later, four village officials tore down all religious symbols, painted over the cross on the podium, and removed all chairs in the church. The church was also shut down.

On 22 April 2020, 18 statues in two folk religion temples located in Heshun Town, Linzhou City (Anyang City, Henan Province) were demolished by over 20 government personnel and police officers. One of the temples was converted into a cultural activity centre three days later, while the other became an entertainment centre. This was part of a broader campaign launched across three provinces in April 2020, where nearly 100 folk religion sites were suppressed during the month.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of China (2017-) Hong Kong Police Force
NOTES: On 23 April 2020, more than 30 white-clad unidentified persons and riot police demolished an altar dedicated to two youths located in Sheung Tak Parking Garage, Sai Kung District (Hong Kong). The altar was first constructed by anti-ELAB demonstrators last year, for the two youths who lost their lives during the anti-ELAB demonstrations.

On 24 April 2020, a Three-Self church in Weifang City, Shandong Province was demolished by the authorities, on the grounds that it was an 'illegal construction'. It was reported that police officers were guarding the site during the demolition to prevent believers from protesting. This was part of an intensified campaign to demolish Three-Self churches across China.

On 25 April 2020, the last remaining cross and religious couplets of a Three-Self church in Xinjian District (Nanchang City, Jiangxi Province) were removed by a government-hired welder. It was reported that the authorities had previously removed six of seven of the church's crosses in the second half of 2018. This was part of an intensified crackdown on churches in Jiangxi Province, where crosses from at least six churches were removed within a week in April 2020.
On 27 April 2020, the cross of a Christian church located on Suzhou Road in Luyang District (Hefei City, Anhui Province) was demolished by the authorities.

On 27 April 2020, crosses were removed from at least three Three-Self churches in Hedong district (Linyi, Henan) on orders of the local authorities after they had conducted a 'health inspection for epidemic prevention.' Other churches in the area were banned from reopening for reasons unrelated to hygiene or coronavirus prevention.

On 27 April 2020, an old Local Church venue in Guangxin District (Shangrao City, Jiangxi Province) was demolished by local government officials, who warned the congregation that 'believing in Jesus is believing in a foreign god' which meant 'going against the Party'. This was part of a broader campaign launched by the municipal government to demolish unregistered places of worship and 'sinicize' state-run venues.

On 27 April 2020, a house church in Guangxin District (Shangrao City, Jiangxi Province) was demolished by over 30 personnel from the local government, on the grounds that it had to be demolished because 'it was privately owned and unapproved by the government'. This was part of the broader campaign aimed at forcing house churches to join the state-run churches.

On 28 April 2020, the United Front Work Department and workers removed the cross from the state-run Protestant Hancheng Church in Hanshan county (Ma'anshan, Anhui). It was reported that all crosses taller than government buildings had to be removed in order not to overshadow state institutions. Churches had to be 'Sinicised' and had to look like enterprises.
Property destruction: On 28 April 2020, authorities removed crosses, religious images, and the podium from an unregistered Catholic church in Xingdi village in Jize county (Handan, Hebei).

On 28 April 2020, six or seven officials removed a cross and painted over religious couplets at a Three-Self church in Yuncheng county (Heze, Shandong). Three days after the cross was removed, they also destroyed crosses and other religious symbols found at the church director's home. Crosses were removed from churches across Shandong ahead of provincial government inspections.

On 29 April 2020, 176 tombstones with crosses were demolished in a cemetery in Xiapu County (Ningde City, Fujian Province) by over 60 personnel from the Songgang subdistrict police station, the Civil Affairs Bureau, the Land Bureau, urban management, and other government departments. It was reported that families of the deceased were not informed nor received any notice before the demolition. More than 60 tombstones were also marked with serial numbers in May 2020, and will likely be demolished soon after.

On 29 April 2020, a 30-metre-tall Guanyin statue was demolished by more than 100 government personnel and an excavator at Guanghan Temple in Shehong county (Suining, Sichuan).
