The Central Committee ordered the destruction, and threatened to demote officials of every level in Shehong county should they refuse.
Around 29 April 2020, a 6-metre-tall outdoor Guanyin statue and 14 indoor Bodhisattva statues were demolished at Jiuchong Temple in Tuopai township (Suining City, Sichuan Province).

On 29 April 2020, local authorities removed a cross from a Three-Self church from Shanghe county (Dezhou, Shandong). Crosses were removed from churches across Shandong ahead of provincial government inspections.

Around 30 April 2020 (end of month), an old Local Church meeting venue in Shatian Town, Guangfeng District (Shangrao City, Jiangxi Province) had its cross, the Ten Commandments, and other religious symbols removed by government officials. This was part of a broader campaign launched by the municipal government to demolish unregistered places of worship and 'sinicize' state-run venues.

Around 30 April 2020 (end of month), local government authorities demolished a 13-meter-tall Guanyin statue at Longyun Temple in Zhangzhou prefecture (Fujian) on the grounds of it being 'too tall.' Officials from the United Front Department supervised the demolition, and threatened to arrest anyone who resisted or continued to worship at the venue. There had been four past instances where monks at the Temple were ordered to cover up the statue.

On 30 April 2020, the cross of a Three-Self church venue in Fenghuo Village, Dashu Township (Jiujiang City, Jiangxi Province) was removed by the Religious Affairs Bureau and township government officials, on the grounds that 'it was higher than the national flag'.

Around 30 April 2020 (end of month), crosses and other religious symbols in the homes of several believers in Cao County (Heze City, Shandong Province) were destroyed by local officials. It was reported that the state representatives claimed that 'no poverty alleviation resources should be given to the people who have religious symbols at home'.

Around 30 April 2020 (end of month), a local Three-Self church in Shegeng Town (Shangrao City, Jiangxi Province) was emptied by government personnel led by the town mayor. The government personnel removed the church's podium, cross, and all other religious symbols. It was reported that Protestants in the county had been targeted likely due to the considerably large number of believers.

Around 30 April 2020 (end of month), a nine-metres-tall outdoor Buddha statue at a local flower farm in Cenxi county (Wuzhou, Guangxi) was forcibly demolished by the county's United Front Work Department, armed police officers and hired workers for being 'unapproved and illegal, too tall and too large.'

Around 30 April 2020 (end of month), the folk religion Longxing Temple and Yuanjue Temple in Qingzhou county (Weifang, Henan) was guarded by guards preventing believers from entering. It was claimed that the Religious Affairs Bureau had banned all religious activities, and temples were under camera surveillance.

Around 1 May 2020 (beginning of month), the cross and religious calendar in the home of a Three-Self church preacher in Jiangxi Province were destroyed by village officials, on the grounds that people receiving social benefits from the government 'should not hold any religious beliefs'.

Around 1 May 2020 (beginning of month), all fruit-bearing trees and plants in fruit farms managed by local farmers in a village in Guangzhou prefecture (Guangdong) were destroyed within 17 days under orders of the authorities after the prefecture-level government issued a notice demanding all agricultural fields to plant staple food crops (like rice grains) instead of trees. Similar policies were enacted in Guangxi, Shandong and Zhejiang provinces. Villagers had to ensure their farmlands were productive to prevent management rights from being withdrawn. Around the same time, President Xi had also called for a nationwide reduction of food waste, raising alleged speculations that China was facing 'imminent' food shortages due to the global pandemic, natural floods and trade uncertainties.

Around 1 May 2020 (beginning of month), four folk religion temples at a village in Hanshan district (Handan, Hebei) were either completely leveled to the ground with an excavator by local officials and had deity statues destroyed, or had their entrances blocked and icons removed. It was reported that the government of Hebei had been cracking down on folk religion temples in rural communities since April of the same year. By the end of July, 104 temples were destroyed and 110 temples shut down or repurposed in the prefecture-level city of Handan.

On 2 May 2020, the police found 4kg of ammonium nitrate and fuel oil, 10kg of dangerous chemical products, and an improvised bomb in an abandoned school building on Choi Hing Road, Kwun Tong District (Hong Kong). After further investigation, it was reported that some of the chemicals appeared to be from the batch reportedly stolen from The Hong Kong Polytechnic University after anti-ELAB demonstrators broke into the laboratory in November 2019. This was the 11th case involving explosives and improvised bombs handled by the police since anti-ELAB demonstrations broke out in Hong Kong in June 2019. No arrests had yet been made in relation to this case.

On 3 May 2020, two folk religion temples in Heshan town (Chengdu, Sichuan) were demolished by the government on the grounds of 'illegal construction'. More than 50 statues were destroyed, as well as personal belongings as the temples were not notified beforehand. It was reported that from Oct 2019 to May 2020, at least 160 folk religion venues were demolished or shut down in four prefectures - Suining, Mianyang, Nanchong and Meishan - of Sichuan province.
On 6 May 2020, the cross on the roof of a Christian church in Panji District (Huainan City, Anhui Province) was taken down on orders from the local government.

Around 7 May 2020, local authorities demolished a local church in Guangxin district and a Seventh-day Adventist Church in Huanggu town of Guangxin district (Shangrao, Jiangxi). The local church was reportedly demolished because the congregation refused to let government officials manage their donations or sing the national anthem in worship. The demolitions were two of at least 400 Three-Self and house church venues that were demolished, closed or repurposed in Shangrao in the spring of 2020.

On 8 May 2020, the cross of a Three-Self church in Fengtian Village, Dashu Township (Jiujiang City, Jiangxi Province) was removed by government officials, on the grounds that 'the cross would fall and harm people'.

On 8 May 2020, a Catholic meeting venue in Gaocheng District (Shijiazhuang City, Hebei Province) was emptied by officials. The electricity supply to the venue was cut. The officials also ordered the venue's director to remove all religious symbols and threatened to confiscate the venue's land if the congregation continued to gather.

On 9 May 2020, the Buddhist Xiabao Temple in Taizi town (Huangshi, Hubei) was destroyed by Taizi town officials and over ten urban management officers, who made a hole in the temple's back wall before demolishing the rest of the building.

On 9 May 2020, the cross of a Three-Self church in Wangdun Township (Jiujiang City, Jiangxi Province) was removed by the local government, who warned that any objections would result in the demolition of the church.

On 12 May 2020, in the middle of the night, government officials dispatched three cranes and hundreds of police officers to remove crosses from the state-run Protestant Lingyunshan Christian Church in Dangtu county (Ma'anshan, Anhui).

On 12 May 2020, an old Local Church venue in Yugan County (Shangrao City, Jiangxi Province) was repurposed into an activity centre for the elderly by government officials. The cross and signboard of the church were also removed by government-hired workers. This was part of a broader campaign launched by the municipal government to demolish unregistered places of worship and 'sinicize' state-run venues.

On 12 May 2020, a Three-Self church in Diaoling village (Zhoukou, Henan) was forced to demolish its cross by the government, as a pre-condition to reopening after coronavirus prevention measures were lifted. Other churches in the area were banned from reopening for reasons unrelated to hygiene or coronavirus prevention.

On 14 May 2020, a Three-Self church in Dasha Town (Jiujiang City, Jiangxi Province) was raided by around eight village officials. They tore down all religious symbols, including the cross and shut down the church, under the pretext that 'the church was too close to the village committee office'.

On 15 May 2020, the Buddhist Taishan Temple in Shiyan prefecture (Hubei) was demolished by 200 government personnel. During the demolition, they blocked all the roads leading to the temple, and confiscated mobile phones from anyone working on the site.
Around 16 May 2020 (month of), a folk religion temple was destroyed by authorities in Dengfeng county (Zhengzhou, Henan) on the pretext of widening a road.

Around 16 May 2020 (month of), three folk religion temples in Gongyi county (Zhengzhou, Henan) were demolished by the authorities. Another folk religion temple was converted into a Chinese Civil War memorial hall.

Around 16 May 2020 (month of), many folk religion temples were repurposed by authorities to be used as storehouses and other use in Ci county (Handan, Hebei). One temple was converted into an activity centre.

Around 16 May 2020 (month of), the dome of Dongjiao Grand Mosque (Hui Muslim) in Kongtong district (Pingliang, Gansu) was removed by government authorities after a year of pressure due to claims that it had been built in a foreign style. Islamic symbols were removed from 17 mosques this late March in Kongtong district alone, and domes from at least 8 mosques were removed amidst the pandemic. It was reportedly part of a national policy to 'sinicise' Islam, and of a provincial effort to target domes and star-and-crescent symbols.

Around 16 May 2020 (month of), three domes and star-and-crescent symbols were removed from the worship hall in a mosque located in Dali City, Dali Bai Autonomous, Yunnan Province), on the grounds that 'they represent infiltration of a foreign culture'. This was part of the state's five-year plan to 'sinicize' all Muslims outside Xinjiang.

Around 16 May 2020 (month of), government authorities cleared a Buddhist library in Jilin province of books published abroad (including Hong Kong and Taiwan) or by well-known Buddhist masters in relation to 'social unrest in Hong Kong' and to remove its association with Buddhism. The library had to remove its original signboard display, and show books by Confucian philosophers and posters with Xi's presidential speeches instead.

Around 16 May 2020 (month of), a clan ancestral temple (associated with China's folk religion) in Shiyan prefecture (Hubei) was converted into a cultural auditorium by government authorities. Ancestral statues were demolished, and 'CCP propaganda books' were placed on its bookshelves.

Around 16 May 2020 (month of), the signboards of 176 Hui businesses in Songming County (Kunming City, Yunnan Province) were 'sinicized'. It was reported that the campaign to 'sinicize' signboards in the county started six months ago.

Security measures: Around 16 May 2020 (month of), a Catholic venue in Shijiazhuang prefecture (Hebei) was shut down because it did not have the religious activity venue registration certificate. It was reported that local officials had pressured the church's priest to join the Chinese Patriotic Catholic Association (CPCA) (location coded as Chang'an, municipal seat of Shijiazhuang).

Land seizure: Around 16 May 2020 (month of), county authorities converted a folk religion temple in Donggang county (Dandong, Liaoning) into a folk customs exhibition hall. It had been shut down as ''an illegal construction'' since Aug 2018, when authorities destroyed all its statues and seized the temple.
Property destruction: Around 16 May 2020 (month of), authorities demolished a house church venue in Heyuan prefecture (Guangdong) (coded to Yuancheng).

Around 16 May 2020 (middle of month), officials from the United Front Work Department, the National Security Brigade and police officers removed five crosses and an entrance signage from a state-sanctioned Catholic church in Julu county (Xingtai, Hebei). It was reported that even registered Catholic churches across China (those sanctioned by the government-run Chinese Patriotic Catholic Association) were not exempt from persecutions and harassment.

Around 16 May 2020 (month of), the town government took ownership of 10 clan ancestral halls (associated with China's folk religion) in Maochen town (Xiaogan, Hubei) and converted them for public use, and informed the heads of local clans that clan activities had been banned.

Around 16 May 2020 (month of), a folk religion temple in a village of Donggang town, Linzhou county (Anyang, Henan) was demolished by the authorities as it was located in front of the village committee office.

Land seizure: Around 16 May 2020 (month of), the county government shut down at least 50 Three-Self Churches in Poyang county (Shangrao, Jiangxi), merging their congregations with other state-approved Protestant venues in the area and repurposing the left-over churches for other use. Churches that acquired all necessary documents before being constructed were forced to hand their permits and certificates over upon officials' requests. The operation aimed to reduce the overall number of religious venues so that they do not outnumber village committees.
Property destruction: Around 16 May 2020 (month of), authorities removed the cross from a Three-Self church in Yinan county (Linyi, Shandong).

On 16 May 2020, in the middle of the night, three folk religion temples in Pingfangzhuang village, as well as two folk religion temples Xiquan and Tumen villages in Caisang town, Zhenlin district of Linzhou county (Anyang, Henan) were demolished by local government officials. Over 20 temples from eight neighbouring were demolished within the same day. It was reported that every villages administered under Linzhou county received orders from the Religious Affairs Bureau after the COVID-19 lockdown has been eased to demolish and repurpose folk religious temples by the end of May.

Around 16 May 2020 (middle of month), three folk religion temples (including the Guanye Temple) were demolished with an excavator by government officials of Xiaoxibao township, Yongnian district (Handan, Hebei). Other temple owners in the region converted the temples into public activity or fitness centres to evade demolitions. It was reported that the government of Hebei had been cracking down on folk religion temples in rural communities since April of the same year. By the end of July, 104 temples were destroyed and 110 temples shut down or repurposed in the prefecture-level city of Handan.

Around 16 May 2020 (month of), a Buddhist temple in Julu county (Xingtai, Hebei) was converted into a Mao Zedong Memorial Hall under a rectification operation supervised by government-assigned personnel. Publications about Mao had to be displayed, and Buddhist statues were removed.

Around 16 May 2020 (month of), two crosses were removed from a Three-Self church in Tancheng county (Linyi, Shandong) on orders of government officials in order to avoid being shut down or having all its facilities destroyed and taken away. Crosses were removed from churches across Shandong ahead of provincial government inspections.

On 17 May 2020, representatives of the Religious Affairs Bureau in Yongzhou prefecture (Hunan) shut down a local house church for 'holding illegal gatherings without permits,' and confiscated electronic devices and Bible copies.

On 17 May 2020, municipal-level government authorities tore down an 8-metre-tall Guanyin statue in Xin'an Temple in Pingdu City (Qingdao, Shandong) on the grounds of 'illegal construction.' A few days afterwards, all doors and windows of the temple were cemented.

On 17 May 2020, the roof cross of a local Three-Self religious venue in Hedong district (Linyi, Shandong) was removed by the district government on the grounds that it was higher than the 'red flag.' Officials threatened congregation members with arrest to prevent them from speaking about the situation. Crosses were removed from churches across Shandong ahead of provincial government inspections.

On 17 May 2020, local officials raided an old Local Church in Taqian Town (Jingdezhen City, Jiangxi Province). They tore down Biblical verses and religious symbols from the walls and burned and smashed the church's donation box. A congregation member stated that local government had pressured the church to register with the state, but the congregation refused. This was part of a broader campaign launched by the municipal government to demolish unregistered places of worship and 'sinicize' state-run venues.

On 19 May 2020, the roof cross and a statue of the Virgin Mary were forcibly removed from a Catholic church in a village of Lanling county (Linyi, Shandong) by local officials on the grounds that the cross was taller than the village committee building. Crosses were removed from churches across Shandong ahead of provincial government inspections.
Property destruction: On 19 May 2020, a folk religion temple in Tangchi town of Shucheng county (Lu'an, Anhui) (location coded as Shucheng) was demolished by authorities for ''being unlicensed.''

On 19 May 2020, local officials removed the cross and Virgin Mary statue from Wuqiu Village Catholic Church in Wuqiu village, Jinling town of Lanling county (Linyi, Shandong) (coded at Lanling county) on the grounds that they were positioned higher than the village committee building. It was reported that even registered Catholic churches across China (those sanctioned by the government-run Chinese Patriotic Catholic Association) were not exempt from persecutions and harassment.

On 20 May 2020, more than ten local government officials, including the heads of the United Front Work Department and Religious Affairs Bureau, removed a cross from Three-Self church in Lanling county (Linyi, Shandong). The cross was removed for being 'too eye-catching.' Crosses were removed from churches across Shandong ahead of provincial government inspections.

On 22 May 2020, an old Local Church in Hengshen Town, Guangfeng District (Shangrao City, Jiangxi Province) was cleared out on orders from the local government, with the chairs and tables in the church confiscated. The officials also removed the cross of the church later in the afternoon. This was part of a broader campaign launched by the municipal government to demolish unregistered places of worship and 'sinicize' state-run venues.

On 25 May 2020, a house church in Jiaotan Town (Jingdezhen City, Jiangxi Province) was raided and ordered to be shut down by the police and officials from the county's Religious Affairs Bureau, on the grounds that the place was not registered with the government and is therefore 'illegal'. The police and government personnel removed a religious sign, and other banners and slogans in the church. All the chairs and properties in the church were also removed.

On 28 May 2020, a Three-Self church venue in Xubu Town, Duchang County (Jiujiang City, Jiangxi Province) was shut down by the town government, on the grounds that it was 'too close to the village committee'. The venue's cross was also demolished, while Bibles and hymnbooks were confiscated. The venue was converted into a 'Party Members' Activity Center' five days later, with national flags raised and propaganda posters displayed inside it.
On 28 May 2020, a Three-Self church in Jianxi District (Luoyang City, Henan Province) was demolished by government personnel, under the pretext of 'road construction'.

On 28 May 2020, local authorities removed all items from an unregistered Catholic church in a village in Shijiazhuang prefecture (Hebei) in order for the village to qualify under the 'civilised cities and villages' campaign, which incentivises local governments to shut down places of worship, remove religious symbols and reduce the number of people of faith.

On 28 May 2020, the National People's Congress (NPC) passed the resolution to legislate a national security law in Hong Kong. The legislation would ban acts of treason, secession, sedition, subversion, and also intends to prohibit foreign political organisations from conducting political activities in Hong Kong, or establishing ties with political organisations. Reports stated that the legislation has been used in Mainland China to accuse journalists of spying, or punish critics of the central government. The CCP had stated that the law is necessary due to 'national security risks' following months of anti-ELAB demonstrations in Hong Kong. The NPC standing committee will now formulate the legislation, which will be added to Annex III of the Basic Law without going through Hong Kong's own legislature. Commentators have stated that the legislation will mark an end to the city's autonomy under the 'One Country, Two Systems'. The announcement of the proposed national security law had since sparked demonstrations across Hong Kong since it was first announced on 21 May 2020.

On 28 May 2020, government-hired workers razed the folk religion Qinglong Mountain Temple to the ground in Dayu town (Suining, Sichuan) after tearing down statues of deities since January of the same year. It was reported that from Oct 2019 to May 2020, at least 160 folk religion venues were demolished or shut down in four prefectures - Suining, Mianyang, Nanchong and Meishan - of Sichuan province, of which 116 temples were in Suining alone.

On 30 May 2020, government-hired workers smashed all statues in the folk religion Jinhai Temple in Dayu town (Suining, Sichuan) and leveled the temple to the ground the next day. It was reported that from Oct 2019 to May 2020, at least 160 folk religion venues were demolished or shut down in four prefectures - Suining, Mianyang, Nanchong and Meishan - of Sichuan province, of which 116 temples were in Suining alone.
Security measures: On 31 May 2020, the township government shut down an unregistered Catholic church in Jiehedian township, Yongnian district (Handan, Hebei).

Around 31 May 2020 (end of month), a folk religion temple in a village in Dongyao town of Linzhou county (Anyang, Henan) was repurposed into an activity centre by local authorities, and its 23 deity statues were demolished.

On 31 May 2020, a Three-Self church in Jianxi District (Luoyang City, Henan Province) was demolished by government personnel, on the grounds that it was an 'illegal construction'. Over 100 people were involved in the demolition, with the government personnel removing all items from the church and barricading the area around the church off before the demolition. Congregation members attempted to stop or film the demolition but were intercepted by the police and government officials. The church director and two congregation members were reportedly taken to the police station.

Around 1 June 2020 (beginning of month), the dome of a Hui mosque in the Kuancheng district (Changchun, Jilin) was demolished by the Religious Affairs Bureau and replaced with a Chinese-style hexagonal pavilion.
On 1 June 2020, the town government sent about 30 workers to demolish statues in the Guanyin Hall (a folk religion venue) at Xianzhang village, Chadian town of Linzhou county (Anyang, Henan).

On 2 June 2020, town officials shut down and destroyed the Roman-style pillars and removed all religious symbols (including the altar, podium, benches, images of 14 stations of the Way of the Cross) at a Western-style Catholic church in Zhangmengtun village, Dingzhou city (Baoding, Hebei). They painted over ceramic tiles with cross symbols.

ACTOR1: Government of China (2017-) Hong Kong Special Administrative Region
NOTES: On 4 June 2020, the Hong Kong legislature passed the controversial national anthem bill criminalising insults of the Chinese national anthem, where offenders who are found guilty could be fined up to HKD 50,000 or face three years in prison. The bill had sparked several protests across Hong Kong since it was first added into Annex III of Hong Kong's Basic Law by the central government in 2017. During the meeting, pro-democracy legislators made a last-minute demonstration in bid to stall proceedings, holding placards and dropping a container of foul-smelling liquid in the Legislative Council. Firefighters and police officers sent in to investigate said dead insects were found in the liquid, but no poisonous gas was detected. The legislators who dropped the liquid were forcibly removed from the hall by security guards. Most pro-democracy legislators refused to take part in the ballot.

On 6 June 2020, government officials of Linyi county removed all crosses, other religious symbols, and benches from the Wangdangjia village church in Wangdangjia village of Linyi county (Dezhou, Shandong). Another church affiliated with the Chinese Patriotic Catholic Association (CPCA) on Cuijia Lane, Linyi County was shut down soon after. They claimed that the church gatherings were not well-attended. It was reported that even registered Catholic churches across China (those sanctioned by the government-run CPCA) were not exempt from persecutions and harassment.

On 8 June 2020, more than 100 officials from the Nanguan District's Religious Affairs Bureau, Public Security Bureau, and Land and Resources Bureau demolished a Three-Self church in Nanguan District (Changchun City, Jilin Province). Nearly 100 believers were guarding the church to prevent its demolition, and a large number of police officers were on guard with shields at the scene. A wheelchair-bound believer was reportedly pushed to the ground by a demolition staff.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of China (2012-) People's Armed Police
NOTES: On 10 June 2020, a China coast guard vessel reportedly gave chase to and crashed a Vietnamese fishing boat in the waters of a disupted region off the Chinese-controlled Paracel Islands, as announced by the Vietnam's Ministry of Foreign Affairs on 14 June 2020. 16 fishermen on board abandoned the boat and escaped. The China coast guard later rescued some of the fishermen, and the captain of the fishing boat reported that the coast guard forced him to sign a document and removed some facilities on the boat.

On 11 June 2020, a Christian believer's home in Jimei District (Xiamen City, Fujian Province) was forcibly demolished by police from the city's Public Security Bureau, Urban Management Bureau, and Religious Affairs Bureau. Furniture were also forcibly taken away. The police also physically stopped people from filming the incident. This followed a raid on a house church by the police on 3 May 2020, where some believers were injured and some were arrested.

On 11 June 2020, a church in Jimei District (Xiamen City, Fujian Province) was forcibly demolished by hundreds of police from the city's Public Security Bureau, Urban Management Bureau, firefighters and Religious Affairs Bureau. This followed a raid on the church by the police on 3 May 2020, where believers were arrested. Some believers reported that the church had been harassed by the authorities for refusing to join the state-run Three-Self church.
On 13 June 2020, two folk religion temples in Rencun town of Linzhou county (Anyang, Henan) were demolished by the authorities.
Around 15 June 2020 (month of), a four-faced Guanyin statue atop the Qingfeng Mountain in Ezhou prefecture (Hubei) was forcibly demolished by the Liangzihu district government.

Around 15 June 2020 (month of), local authorities removed crosses from a Three-Self church and several house churches in Gaoqing county (Zibo, Shandong). Crosses were removed from churches across Shandong ahead of provincial government inspections.

Around 15 June 2020 (month of), numerous Buddhist statues were demolished in Ezhou prefecture (Hubei) by the authorities, and some temples were repurposed into agro-tourism sites or elderly activity centers. The operation took place within a week of a meeting between the Ezhou and Huangshi prefecture governments to discuss the rectification of Buddhist and Taoist venues.

Around 15 June 2020 (month of), the government covered up a Tibetan Buddhist white stupa (a shrine housing sacred relics) on Xiaolong Mountain, Jimo district (Qingdao, Shandong), claiming that the icon distracted drivers and affected traffic along a nearby highway.

Around 15 June 2020 (month of), 97 temples (Buddhist and Daoist) were shut down or repurposed in Huangshi prefecture (Hubei) by the authorities, and their statues were removed. The operation took place after a meeting between the Ezhou and Huangshi prefecture governments to discuss the rectification of Buddhist and Taoist venues.

Around 15 June 2020 (month of), the government-registered Buddhist temple in Shaanxi province was demolished by local authorities. The congregation was merged with another temple, despite promises to rebuild the existing temple.
Around 15 June 2020 (month of), a folk religion temple in Fuzhou prefecture (Fujian) was demolished by over 100 personnel sent by the authorities.
Around 15 June 2020 (month of), authorities closed down a folk religion temple in Ci county (Handan, Hebei).

Around 15 June 2020 (month of), the town government rectified ten clan ancestral halls (associated with China's folk religion) in Maochen town (Xiaogan, Hubei), one of which was converted into a cultural activity centre for the elderly. Slogans promoting 'destroying the Four Olds' (a popular motto during the Cultural Revolution) were displayed in some of the halls.

Around 15 June 2020 (month of), the Manichaean Cao'an Temple at Huabian Mountain in Quanzhou prefecture (Fujian) remained closed under the surveillance of police officers even when other local religious venues reopened in the same month as the pandemic was eased. The temple attracted visitors, scholars and journalists from abroad for being only intact Manichaean building, and was reportedly kept closed 'to prevent foreign infiltration.' Previous efforts to sinicise the Cao'an temple including ordering it to erect the national flag and post slogans about socialist values and traditional Chinese culture.

Around 15 June 2020 (month of), three temples (including two Buddhist and one Daoist temples) in Jianli county (Jingzhou, Hubei) were closed down by government authorities, on the pretext of 'being unlicensed.'

Security measures: Around 15 June 2020 (month of), the United Front Work Department merged and shut down all venues subordinate to the Three-Self churches in Jinan prefecture (Shandong) (location coded at Lixia, seat of Jinan), ahead of each inspection visit by high-level CPC officials. Six out of 30 subordinate sites of a church remained open, with the rest shut down after having their activity certificates revoked. Three out of 36 licensed Three-Self venues in Tianqiao district were allowed to remain open.

Property destruction: Around 15 June 2020 (month of), officials destroyed all statues at two Buddhist temples in Renhe district (Panzhihua, Sichuan). It was reported as one of the government's efforts to conceal or destroy outdoor icons and statues at Buddhist temples across the province.

Property destruction: Around 15 June 2020 (month of), the Lingxi town government sent about 100 workers to demolish two buildings in a Taoist Temple in Lingxi town of Cangnan county (Wenzhou, Zhejiang). The demolition of the accommodation facilities made it impossible to host pilgrims and worshippers visiting the temple.

Property destruction: Around 15 June 2020 (month of), local officials destroyed a Buddhist temple in Danyang town of Bowang district (Ma'anshan prefecture, Anhui) under the orders of the prefecture government.
Property destruction: Around 15 June 2020 (month of), the government destroyed a Three-Self Church in Hangzhou prefecture (Jiangsu) (coded to Jianggan) on the pretext of being illegally constructed.
Property destruction: Around 15 June 2020 (month of), authorities removed the cross from a Three-Self church in Yichun prefecture (Jiangxi) (coded to Yuanzhou).

On 19 June 2020, district government authorities dispatched 200 personnel and excavators to destroy a Three-Self church in the Yingdong district (Fuyang, Anhui), and placed three church members under 'strict surveillance' at a local hospital.
On 19 June 2020, government authorities demolished a Three-Self Church venue that had been closed down in Songyao village of Dengfeng county (Zhengzhou, Henan).

On 21 June 2020, a dozen Ethnic and Religious Affairs Bureau personnel and police officers raided a local house church venue in Daying county (Suining, Sichuan), confiscating 21 religious texts and removing a cross from one of the walls before shutting down the venue. They accused five members of illegal gathering, and detained the church director for a couple hours.

SOURCE: Radio Free Asia; South China Morning Post
NOTES: On 23 June 2020, China's Ministry of Natural Resources published a list of Chinese names for 50 new underwater features (including canyons, sea knolls and terraces) in the East China Sea near Senkakus Islands or Diaoyudao Islands, which had been at the centre of a long-running territorial dispute between China and Japan. This followed the announcement made by the Japanese government the day before, to rename the administrative area including the disputed islands from Tonoshiro to Tonoshiro Senkaku, which had been seen by China and Taiwan as a move to assert Japan's claim over the islands.

On 24 June 2020, over 70 police officers and 25 employees of a local welfare institution forcibly took away 25 children under the custody of a Catholic orphanage in Jinzhou county (Shijiazhuang, Hebei). The bishop was asked to hand over all remaining children at the orphanage less than two weeks later. It was reported that the bishop had been harassed by the authorities for months to shut down the orphanage, and transfer the children to a state-run orphanage. The bishop-in charge had been arrested and imprisoned several times since 1981 for refusing to join the CPCA.

SOURCE: Tibet Watch; Free Tibet; Asian News International
NOTES: On 24 June 2020, government authorities forcefully relocated about 60 Tibetans from 13 households from Dolying village of Payul county (Tibet) to a new settlement within Palyul county. The houses in the new settlement flew Chinese flags on their roofs and hung portraits of Communist Party leaders within the homes. Between 2018 and 2019, around 400 Tibetan families were reportedly involved in a mass forced relocation from Tibetan-majority locations to government-built settlements.

Around 24 June 2020 (as reported), China began building taxiways, aprons, hangars for military aircraft at the Tibet Linzhi Milin Airport in Mainling County (Nyingchi City, Tibet), close to the border with India. This followed the deadly clash between Indian and Chinese soldiers at the Line of Actual Control in Galwan Valley on 15 June 2020. According to the latest satellite images released, air defence missile positions were also built near the airport.

On 24 June 2020, about 300 government-dispatched workers demolished a folk religion temple in Fuzhou prefecture (Fujian). Two believers were pressed and pushed to the ground for asking to see a demolition order and to relocate statues of deities from the temple.

On 25 June 2020, the Three-Self True Jesus Church in Daqing Residential District, Hualong district (Puyang, Henan) was demolished by the authorities despite prior approval by the Religious Affairs Bureau. An excavator demolished the main entrance, then the entire building was bulldozed ten days later. In October 2019, local authorities also forced the church to take down its cross and raise the national flag.

Around 26 June 2020, over 30 personnel from the Public Security Bureau and other state institutions demolished a Catholic house of prayer in Dingtou village, Xiabaishi town of Fu'an county (Ningde, Fujian) on the grounds that the venue was 'illegally constructed.' It was reportedly one of several suppressions in the Diocese of Mindong in Fujian province, because priests refused to join the CPCA.

Property destruction: On 27 June 2020, authorities demolished a Buddhist temple to the ground in Cangshan district (Fuzhou, Fujian) on the pretext of building an expressway. Another Buddhist temple on Longyan Mountain was also destroyed in the same month.

On 28 June 2020, the deputy secretary of a town administered by Leiyang county (Hengyang, Hunan) and three subordinates raided a house church, confiscated the church's donation box and destroyed Bible verses posted on the walls. They claimed that they acted as a result of the church's 'disobedience,' and that it was 'illegal to hold religious gatherings without a permit or joining the Three-Self Church.'

Property destruction: On 28 June 2020, a Buddhist temple (also listed as a county-level protected cultural heritage) in Handan prefecture (Hebei) was demolished, with government institutions stating that ''the [cultural heritage] certificate was useless'' (location coded at Congtai, municipal seat of Handan).

On 28 June 2020, over 20 local police and government officials broke into a Christian house church in Mashuang town in Nankang District (Ganzhou City, Jiangxi Province) and confiscated Bibles, hymn books, and chairs from the church. They said that the gathering was illegal, and took away some people for questioning.

On 30 June 2020, the founding members of Demosisto (Joshua Wong, Agnes Chow, Nathan Law) announced their resignations from the pro-democracy political group, shortly after the National People's Congress approved the legislation of the national security law in Hong Kong. Following their resignations, the group announced that it would cease operations in Hong Kong, stating that its current operations were 'unsustainable' given the current political climate. In addition, several pro-independence groups including Studentlocalism, Hong Kong Independence Union, Students Independence Union and the Hong Kong National Front announced that they had disbanded. The founder of Studentlocalism also announced that he would withdraw from political activism, while the convenor of Hong Kong Independence Union announced on the same day that he had left Hong Kong. On 3 July 2020, Nathan Law from Demosisto announced to the press that he had left Hong Kong, but did not reveal his whereabouts and situation.
Property destruction: On 30 June 2020, a Taoist temple in Gushan town of Jin'an district (Fuzhou, Fujian) was demolished as local authorities requisitioned the land on which it stood.
Around 30 June 2020 (end of month), in the middle of the night, three folk religion temples in Longhu village of Tangyin county (Anyang, Henan) were demolished by the government.

Around 1 July 2020 (beginning of month), the dome of a Hui Muslim mosque in Baicheng city (Jilin) was demolished, and its indoor Arabic-style windows were in the process of being changed to a more traditional Chinese style. The converted mosque was said to resemble more of an office building.

Property destruction: Around 1 July 2020 (beginning of month), the district government demolished a three-faced Guanyin statue outside a Buddhist temple on Zhongnan Mountain, Chang'an district (Xi'an, Shaanxi) with claims that its construction was not approved. Over 300 public security and special police officers guarded the site and blocked all roads leading to the temple. One demolition worker was detained for posting photos of the demolition.

On 1 July 2020, Beijing's controversial national security law for Hong Kong came into effect, which criminalises acts of secession, subversion, terrorism or collusion with foreign forces, carrying a minimum term of 10 years and a maximum of life imprisonment for serious cases. The law was passed by the National People's Congress Standing Committee the day before, with its details only revealed hours after it had been passed. Under the new law, arson and vandalising public transport with an intent to intimidate the Hong Kong or Chinese government for political purposes will constitute acts of terrorism. The Chinese central government would also set up an office in Hong Kong for safeguarding national security, with personnel dispatched from relevant Chinese security agencies, and Hong Kong will have no jurisdiction over these new offices. Further measures will be taken to strengthen the management of international groups, foreign NGOs and news agencies that operate in the city.

Property destruction: On 2 July 2020, the county government demolished a Three-Self Church venue in one of the villages in Lanling county (Linyi, Shandong) due to its proximity to a village committee office.

On 2 July 2020, over 100 police officers demolished a folk religion temple in one of the villages of Dangtu county (Ma'anshan, Anhui). Eight elderly believers who were protecting the temple were dragged out. A week before the demolition, over 60 villagers organized to take turns protecting the temple 24 hours a day while village officers repeatedly harassed them.

On 2 July 2020, government personnel demolished a five-storey building in Gushan town (Fuzhou, Fujian) that operated as a nursing home, congregation venue and elderly care centre run by a Three-Self church. The nursing home was previously approved by the local Religious Affairs Bureau.
On 6 July 2020, the local government demolished a Three-Self Church in Jianzhuang township (Handan, Hebei) on the grounds of being 'illegally constructed.'

ACTOR1: Government of China (2017-) Hong Kong Special Administrative Region
SOURCE: Ming Pao; Hong Kong Government News; Bitter Winter
NOTES: On 7 July 2020, Implementation Rules for Article 43 of the National Security Law took effect in Hong Kong. Article 43 stipulates a range of law enforcement measures that may be taken in handling 'urgent situations' pertaining to national security. According to the Rules, police officers would be authorised to conduct searches at private properties without a warrant, and demand those suspected of endangering national security to surrender travel documents. The Police Commissioner is given powers to require internet service providers to remove information that may lead to national security crimes.

On 7 July 2020, a folk religion temple in Guangzong county (Xingtai, Hebei) was demolished by authorities along with the religious statues left inside. People later built a small temple on the original foundation, but the government soon destroyed it as well.
On 7 July 2020, crosses were removed from two Three-Self churches in Yongjia county (Wenzhou, Zhejiang). Wenzhou was known as 'China's Jerusalem' for its large Christian population.

On 8 July 2020, the Committee for Safeguarding National Security converted the Metropark Hotel in Causeway Bay, Wanchai District (Hong Kong) into its temporary office headquarters, which was officially launched after the emblem of the PRC was placed on the building, and a flag-raising opening ceremony was held. This marked the establishment of the fourth Liaison Office of Beijing in Hong Kong.

Property destruction: On 8 July 2020, over 30 town government officials and urban management personnel removed all religious statues, and destroyed a Buddhist temple in Da'a town of Xinfeng county (Ganzhou, Jiangxi).
Property destruction: On 10 July 2020, police officers removed the cross of a Three-Self church in Panji district (Huainan, Anhui).
Property destruction: On 15 July 2020, the county government removed crosses from the Three-Self church in Qifu village of Ci county (Handan, Hebei).
Security measures: Around 16 July 2020 (month of), the police raided and shut down a Sola Fide meeting venue in Wucheng district (Jinhua, Zhejiang).
Around 16 July 2020 (month of), a folk religion temple in Shiguan village (now known as Wu village), Nanle county (Puyang, Henan) was demolished by the authorities.

Around 16 July 2020 (month of), a Three-Self church in Lusigang township, Yugan county (Shangrao, Jiangxi) was demolished by the township government on the pretext of 'building a high-speed highway.' While the church was demolished, the public restroom next to it was not.

Around 16 July 2020 (month of), 16.5 acres of trees in a dozen villages planted by farmers in Xintai county (Tai'an, Shandong) were destroyed overnight without the farmers' consent by government-hired thugs, who were seen holding long wooden sticks while carrying out the mandatory tree-cutting policy, likely referring to a county-government mandate (as early as Apr 2020) for all its villages to plant food crops (including grains) instead of trees in the next five years. Similar policies were enacted in Guangxi, Guangdong and Zhejiang provinces. Around the same time, President Xi had also called for a nationwide reduction of food waste, raising alleged speculations that China was facing 'imminent' food shortages due to the global pandemic, natural floods and trade uncertainties.

Around 16 July 2020 (month of), Protestant worship venues (affiliated with five Three-Self Churches) in the rural areas of Xinyu prefecture (Jiangxi) were closed by local authorities under the pretext of 'low attendance', where 30 believers was set as the benchmark. It was reported that these venue closures would affect elderly believers with limited mobility the most.
Around 16 July 2020 (month of), a folk religion mausoleum in Nanle county (Puyang, Henan) was demolished by authorities on the pretext of 'giving way to the construction of a commercial street.'

Property destruction: Around 16 July 2020 (month of), the United Front Work Department locked up a state-run Catholic church in Hedong district (Linyi, Shandong) after removing its cross and signage that said ''Catholic Church'' and ''Creator of All Things'' at its entrance.
Land seizure: Around 16 July 2020 (month of), authorities converted a Taoist Temple in Donggang county (Dandong, Liaoning) into a nursing home. It had been sealed off since Sep 2018.

Around 16 July 2020 (month of), government officials removed a cross and installed a surveillance camera at a Catholic church in Hebei province, despite the fact that the church had joined the Chinese Patriotic Catholic Association in hopes of being able to organize worship services in peace. It was reported that even registered Catholic churches across China (those sanctioned by the government-run Chinese Patriotic Catholic Association) were not exempt from persecutions and harassment.

Around 16 July 2020 (middle of month), the dome of a mosque in Kaiping district (Tangshan, Hebei) was converted into a Chinese-style pavilion by the authorities as part of the national policy to convert Islamic domes into Chinese-style structures. From Jul to Sep, at least six mosques in Tangshan were rectified. At the time of reporting on 9 Oct, 17 more mosques were planned to be rectified with a cost of at least 10,000,000 RMB.

Around 16 July 2020 (month of), folk religion temples in Rencun town of Linzhou county (Anyang, Henan) were repurposed by the authorities and converted into storage facilities, natural gas management offices, fire stations, and other facilities.

Around 16 July 2020 (month of), the dome of a mosque in Qing county (Cangzhou, Hebei) was removed by local authorities and placed in the mosque's backyard. Two days later, authorities discovered the dome through satellite imagery and immediately ordered for it to be destroyed.

Security measures: Around 16 July 2020 (month of), the prefecture government shut down a Buddhist hall within an urban residence in Shuozhou prefecture (Shanxi) (coded to Shuocheng) because it didn't have a religious activity venue registration certificate.
Property destruction: Around 16 July 2020 (month of), officials removed the cross from a Three-Self church in Jinxiang county (Jining, Shandong) on the pretext that it was too tall.

Property destruction: Around 16 July 2020 (month of), municipal government personnel cut off the electric supply and removed the cross to an unregistered Catholic meeting venue in Shijiazhuang prefecture (Hebei) (coded to Chang'an).
Property destruction: Around 16 July 2020 (month of), authorities removed the cross from a Three-Self church in Linchuan county (Fuzhou, Jiangxi).

Property destruction: Around 16 July 2020 (month of), local officials demolished the two crosses on a Three-Self church in Xiaohe town (Xinfeng, Jiangxi). The congregation's protests delayed the demolition by a week, but orders were ultimately enforced after officials lied that the old cross would be replaced with a new one.

Property destruction: Around 16 July 2020 (month of), the county government demolished a Three-Self church in Yutai county (Jining, Shandong) after claims that the church was too close to the village committee building and that ''believing in Jesus meant going against the Communist Party.''

Looting: Around 16 July 2020 (month of), poverty alleviation officials closed down a house church venue in Zhoukou prefecture (Henan) (coded to Chuanhui) after confiscating the venue's cross and other valuables.

Security measures: Around 16 July 2020 (month of), all Three-Self churches and house church venues were closed in a town in Tancheng county (Linyi, Shandong), affecting 40 venues in total. It was reported that many Three-Self church venues were closed before the pandemic outbreak, and more were merged or shut down after restrictions had been eased.

On 22 July 2020, around 100 government officials and police officers demolished Christian Xinguang House Church in IOI Yuanbowan, Jimei district (Xiamen, Fujian) without explanation or notification. They destroyed its interior decoration and confiscated objects. The security gate of a worshipper's apartment was also removed. The church had been labeled as an illegal social organisation after it refused to join the Three-Self Church, and had undergone two other demolition operations since November of the previous year.
Security measures: On 23 July 2020, authorities shut down a house church venue in Nanzhao county (Nanyang, Henan).

ACTOR1: Police Forces of China (2017-) Hong Kong Police Force
SOURCE: Ming Pao; South China Morning Post; The Stand News
NOTES: On 23 July 2020, police officers seized explosives and hazardous materials from an education learning centre in North Point, Eastern district and an apartment in Kennedy Town, Western district (both located on Hong Kong Island, coded at GP2) suspected to be the workplace and residence of two men who set off a rubbish bin blast in Wan Chai during this year's banned 1 July demonstration march. They found materials and ingredients for manufacturing explosives, including brack oil, ammonia powder, bleach products amounting to a total of 106g of low-energy explosives. They also found cyanide hidden in children's toys. The two men were arrested.

On 25 July 2020, crosses were removed at four Three-Self Church venues in Dazhongcun town of Lanling county (Linyi, Shandong), after the town government hired workers to eliminate religious symbols and slogans from those buildings. A town official on the site stated that 'crosses must be removed from all churches because Christianity does not belong in China.' The ongoing cross removal campaign in Linyi city was launched at the beginning of 2019.

On 26 July 2020, the cross on the roof of a Christian church in Xinfeng County (Ganzhou City, Jiangxi Province) was forcibly taken down. There were no further reports on who carried out the demolition.

Around 28 July 2020 (as reported), thousands of Buddhist books were confiscated from at least 20 stores selling Buddhist merchandise in Chifeng prefecture (also Ulankhad) (Inner Mongolia). Government officials frequented the shop to conduct inspections, issuing fines to those selling banned materials. It was reported that government-organised operations to purge non-approved Buddhist books had intensified nationwide, expanding beyond temples and worship venues.
On 29 July 2020, a folk religion temple in Kaifeng prefecture (Henan) was demolished by about 200 Public Security Bureau and Urban Management Bureau officials and police officers.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of China (2017-) Hong Kong Police Force
SOURCE: Ming Pao; DW; HKFP; Radio Free Asia
NOTES: On 29 July 2020, the former convener and three former members of pro-independence group Studentlocalism were arrested by officials of the National Security Department and the police in Yuen Long, Sha Tin and Tuen Mun districts respectively. The group was arrested on suspicion of breaching Articles 20 and 21 due to social media posts promoting secession. This marked the first arrest of public political figures under the newly passed national security legislation. It was reported that on 31 Jul, four of them were released on bail with specific terms.

On 30 July 2020, a Protestant church in Xuezhuang town of Xinhua district (Pingdingshan, Henan) was converted into a school for massage therapists. It had been closed down by the district management committee since September 2018.

ACTOR1: Government of China (2017-) Hong Kong Special Administrative Region
SOURCE: Radio Free Asia; Hong Kong Government News
NOTES: On 30 July 2020, Returning Officers (electoral affairs authorities) invalidated 12 pro-democracy figures from registering as candidates in the September Legislative Council elections in Hong Kong. The candidates included five Civic Party incumbent LegCo members and district councillors, a localist community activist, a former journalist and Demosisto co-founder Joshua Wong. They stated that the nominees had not complied with requirements to uphold and support the Basic Law or pledge allegiance to Hong Kong, and instead supported Hong Kong independence, self-determination or changing the system while soliciting intervention by foreign governments and political entities in relation to domestic affairs. It was reported that their disqualification may be linked to their opposition to the national security law.

On 30 July 2020, the local government demolished a Three-Self Church in Fengfeng Mining District (Handan, Hebei) on the grounds of being 'illegally constructed' and engineering works at a nearby river.

On 31 July 2020, village officials demolished a Three-Self Church in Yinzhang village of Yichuan county (Luoyang, Henan) on the grounds that the church was occupying lands intended for a school. Since last year, the church had been a reported target of the government, which made repeated attempts to convert it into an activity centre for the elderly.

ACTOR1: Government of China (2017-) Hong Kong Special Administrative Region
SOURCE: Radio Free Asia; Hong Kong Government News
NOTES: On 31 July 2020, the Chief Executive announced the decision to postpone the 2020 Legislative Council General Elections by a year due to the severe coronavirus situation in Hong Kong, and on the basis of protecting the health of safety of the Hong Kong people. The elections were instead scheduled to take place on 5 September 2021.

Property destruction: On 2 August 2020, police officers and government officials raided a house church in Luyi county (Zhoukou, Henan), confiscating eight Bibles and destroying 60 wooden benches on the pretext that house churches ''were illegal'' as they go against the Communist Party.

On 2 August 2020, local authorities burned books from the Buddhist Ciyun Temple in Lingyuan county (Chaoyang, Liaoning). Seven pickup trucks worth of books authored by Master Chin Kung and the Dalai Lama were carried outside the temple and burnt overnight.

Around 4 August 2020 (as reported), local officials confirmed that a restricted-access 'residential area' had been established in Makit county, outside of Kashi (Kashgar) prefecture (Xinjiang) for an estimated 7000 and above Uyghur and Muslim minorities released from internment camps. The gate locked community reportedly would allow 'released' inmates to reunite with their families. The establishment of the area came amidst international attention on indications that China had been relocating inmates from internment camps to work in factories across China.

Security measures: On 5 August 2020, an unregistered Catholic church in Chang'an district (Shijiazhuang, Hebei) was sealed off and shut down by local officials ahead of provincial and municipal governments' inspections.

Land seizure: On 7 August 2020, the county government merged a state-run Three-Self church in Linquan county (Fuyang, Anhui) with another church venue for ''disobeying the government,'' ''being too close to a school,'' and ''because the building was dilapidated.'' They seized the building and took away donation money amounting to 420,000 RMB and all belongings.
Security measures: On 9 August 2020, authorities shut down a Sola Fide house church venue in Neixiang county (Nanyang, Henan).

ACTOR1: Police Forces of China (2017-) Hong Kong Police Force
SOURCE: HKFP; Hong Kong Government News; RTHK; DW; Apple Daily Hong Kong; Radio Free Asia
NOTES: On 10 August 2020, officers arrested ten prominent pro-democracy public figures in Hong Kong and conducted a court-warranted search of the newsroom Apple Daily and Next Media. The figures arrested - Next Media and Apple Daily founder Jimmy Lai, his son and five media executives (at their Tseung Kwun O newsroom), Studentlocalism ex-member Agnes Chow (in Tai Po), and 'Fight for Freedom, Stand with Hong Kong' members Andy Li and Wilson Li (also ITN journalist) - were accused breaching the national security law. Journalists were restricted from leaving the Apple Daily office for 9 hours. On the same day, the police would also search a restaurant owned by Lai's son and confiscated his computer. On 11-12 Aug, most of those arrested were released on bail after surrendering their passport, paying bonds, and having their assets frozen.
Property destruction: On 10 August 2020, in the early morning, authorities removed the cross of a state-approved Catholic church in Linhuan town of Suixi county (Huaibei, Anhui).

Property destruction: On 13 August 2020, about 300 county officials and police officers demolished a Buddhist temple in Susong county (Anqing, Anhui). The temple director was kept at home under police control until the demolition was completed.

Security measures: Around 16 August 2020 (month of), Religious Affairs Bureau officials shut down the Yinzuo International Christian Venue in Keqiao district (Shaoxing, Zhejiang) after it repeatedly refused to join the Three-Self Church and provide a list of congregation members.

Property destruction: Around 16 August 2020 (month of), the signboard and three Buddhist statues at its entrance of a Buddhist temple in Jinzhong prefecture (Shanxi) (coded to Yuci) were removed on orders of the Jinzhong Religious Affairs Bureau. On 10 September 2020, the prefecture government in the northern province of Shanxi shut down the temple, claiming that it lacked proper building certificates, and occupied arable land.

Property destruction: Around 16 August 2020 (month of), officials removed a small cross and a signboard ''Salvation Church'' from a state-run Protestant church in Ganzhou prefecture (Jiangxi) (coded to Zhanggong) for being too eye-catching.

Property destruction: Around 16 August 2020 (month of), local officials toppled the crosses on a Catholic church in Puyang county (Puyang prefecture, Henan). A local official explained that if the crosses were not removed, he would be dismissed, and the church would be shut down.
Property destruction: Around 16 August 2020 (month of), authorities removed the cross from a Three-Self church in Tancheng county (Linyi, Shandong).
Property destruction: Around 16 August 2020 (month of), authorities removed the cross from a Three-Self church in Jixi prefecture (Heilongjiang) (coded to Jiguan).

Property destruction: Around 16 August 2020 (month of), authorities demolished a Three-Self church in Pingyu county (Zhumadian, Henan) on the pretext of needing the land to build water conservancy facilities. It was reported that apart from the church, no other buildings were demolished.
Security measures: Around 16 August 2020 (month of), authorities shut down numerous house churches in Wenzhou city, Zhejiang Province (coded as Lucheng).

Around 16 August 2020 (month of), a Buddhist temple in Qipan township of Jianli county (Jingzhou, Hubei) was converted by authorities into an elderly activity center, since it did not have the registration certificate. The converted building was covered with CPC-endorsed political slogans.

Around 16 August 2020 (month of), over 660 lawyers in Hunan province had their professional licenses 'voluntarily' revoked on the grounds of 'illegally' having side jobs, signing labour contracts with non-law firms or holding overseas passports. It was alleged that the lawyers were coerced. It was reported that over 1200 lawyers in Hunan faced similar circumstances across the last four months.

Property destruction: On 18 August 2020, the city government demolished a Catholic church in a village of Yongnian district (Handan, Hebei) for ''being unlicensed,'' claiming that the valid religious activity venue registration certificate it had was ''merely a piece of paper.''

Security measures: On 19 August 2020, the local government blocked the stairs leading to outdoor Buddhist statues at the Puji temple in Nanlong town of Nanbu county (Nanchong, Sichuan), and shut the venue down. The statues were later hidden behind concrete blocks. It was reported as one of the government's efforts to conceal or destroy outdoor icons and statues at Buddhist temples across the province.

Around 20 August 2020, South Mongolian Human Rights Information Centre leaked information about an official document detailing a new language policy from the central government that had been kept secret. The new policy required all elementary and middle schools across Inner Mongolia to replace Mongolian language with Chinese language as the language of instruction starting from 1 Sep 2020, as ordered by the central government. The leaked document detailing the plan had since prompted protests across Inner Mongolia.

On 20 August 2020, county government personnel emptied a Three-Self Church venue in Longnan county (Ganzhou, Jiangxi) and confiscated more than a dozen Bible and hymnbook copies. The congregation was not informed beforehand.

On 23 August 2020, 12 police officers and government officials raided a Great Praise Church venue in Gushi county (Xinyang, Henan), and emptied the venue. Another venue was raided the same day, with officials taking away the donation box, electrical appliances, furniture and religious texts.

On 23 August 2020, government authorities in China blocked the only Mongolian-language social media platform Bainuu (first the news feed then user profiles). The ban came days ahead of the 26 Aug release of a national-level policy document, stating that Mongolian would be replaced with Mandarin Chinese as the medium of instruction for three subjects in elementary and middle schools for minority groups across the autonomous region starting immediately with this semester (similar changes applying to minority school curricula in five other regions). Changes to the language policy have sparked a wave of demonstrations in Inner Mongolia.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: DP: Democratic Party (Hong Kong); Five Demands Movement; Government of China (2017-) Hong Kong Special Administrative Region
SOURCE: RTHK; Radio Free Asia; The News Lens
NOTES: On 26 August 2020, in the early morning, two Democratic Party LegCo members (one a former investigator of the Independent Commission Against Corruption) were arrested by the police at their homes in Hong Kong for alleged participation in the '7.21 Incident' demonstration-turned-mob violence at Yuen Long MTR station and a 'Liberate Hong Kong' demonstration at Tuen Mun - both during the anti-ELAB movement in July of last year. A total of 16 arrests have been made in relation to this incident at the time of reporting, including 13 white-clad rioters from the '7.21 Incident,' and an administrator of an anti-ELAB Telegram group 'SUCK Channel' for abetting others in crime.

On 28 August 2020, over 100 government personnel and police officers demolished a house church venue in Xincheng town of Xiuzhou district (Jiaxing, Zhejiang), allegedly for the church's refusal to join the state-administered Three-Self Church. Prior to the event, they also installed surveillance cameras at the venue entrance.

Security measures: On 30 August 2020, government officials shut down two house church venues in Xingqi village and one venue in Xiyi village Keqiao district (Shaoxing, Zhejiang) after they repeatedly refused to join the Three-Self Church.

On 30 August 2020, government authorities performed a regional crackdown on stores in Inner Mongolia, confiscating all literature, texts and stationary in the Mongolian language and ordering relevant books to be taken off shelves. The operation took place following the 26 Aug release of a national-level policy document, stating that Mongolian would be replaced with Mandarin Chinese as the medium of instruction for three subjects in elementary and middle schools for minority groups across the autonomous region starting immediately with this semester (similar changes applying to minority school curricula in five other regions).

Arrests: Around 31 August 2020, over 100 ethnic Mongolian parents, teachers, herders, protest organisers, rights activists and other protest participants were arrested or placed in various forms of detention across Inner Mongolia [coded to Xincheng] since the spread of large-scale student boycotts, strikes and demonstrations against a national-level state policy to replace Mongolian with Mandarin Chinese as the medium of instruction. The first of these demonstrations started on 28 Aug. As of 7 September, a total of over 200 ethnic Mongolians had been arrested in Tongliao and Ordos prefectures.

On 31 August 2020, government authorities imposed a curfew in Lubei town of Jarud Banner (Tongliao, Inner Mongolia) in response to days of demonstrations against a new policy to replace Mongolian with Mandarin Chinese as the medium of instruction for three subjects in elementary and middle schools for minority groups across the autonomous region. Cars were not allowed to leave or enter the city.
On 3 September 2020, a folk religion temple was demolished by authorities in Dengfeng county (Zhengzhou, Henan).

Security measures: On 3 September 2020, an unregistered Catholic church in Youtong village of Luancheng district (Shijiazhuang, Hebei) was shut down by village officials for refusing to join the Patriotic Church. It was converted into a parking lot.
On 5 September 2020, a Three-Self Church venue in Longnan county (Ganzhou, Jiangxi) was shut down after a police raid.

Property destruction: On 6 September 2020, the government of Xiaokou town in Taihe county (Fuyang, Anhui) destroyed four folk religion temples on the pretext of preventing river erosion. Over 30 government personnel were sent to disperse the residents opposing the demolition, prohibiting them from photographing the scene.

NOTES: On 6 September 2020, the Vice-Chairman of People Power Tam Tak Chi was arrested by the national security department of the Hong Kong Police and held at the police station in Tai Po, North district (Hong Kong) for five charges of crimes related to 'uttering seditious words' (allegedly anti-ELAB slogans). He was supposed to be released after 48 hours, but was sent to a detention centre in Lai Chi Kok and denied bail due to a last-minute additional charge for 'creating public disorder.' His arrest sparked several demonstrations in Hong Kong.
Property destruction: On 7 September 2020, the county government demolished a Three-Self church in Changfeng county (Hefei, Anhui) for ''being unlicensed.''
Property destruction: On 7 September 2020, authorities demolished a Three-Self church in Dingyuan county (Chuzhou, Anhui) for having ''illegal gatherings.''

Around 8 September 2020 (between 8-9 September), a folk religion temple in Wenling county (Taizhou, Zhejiang) was demolished by over 100 personnel from the local Religious Affairs Bureau and police officers on the grounds that it was 'unlicensed.' Statues of deities were preserved, but now kept outdoors.

On 13 September 2020, police officers broke into a house church venue in Liangshan county (Jining, Shandong) by destroying the entrance door lock, and looted its donation box and 100 chairs. Earlier in the day, they arrived at the church during a service, and declared it an illegal gathering, dispersing the congregation and confiscating four Bible copies.

From Jul to Sep, at least six mosques in Tangshan were rectified. At the time of reporting on 9 Oct, 17 more mosques were planned to be rectified with a cost of at least 10,000,000 RMB.

Security measures: Around 15 September 2020 (month of), all unlicensed Protestant Three-Self Church venues in Zhaozhaizi town of Gaotang county (Liaocheng, Shandong) were shut down by officials. Liaocheng prefecture's CPC committee dispatched 12 teams to 36 towns and townships to inspect grassroots CPC organisations. It was reported that religious issues play a central part in these inspections, which were planned for Sep through mid-Dec 2020.

On 19 September 2020, the state-run Three-Self Holy Grace Church in Luoyang prefecture (Henan) was leveled to the ground by authorities in the name of 'expanding a flood control channel.' Officers privately revealed that it was an implementation of national policy, while the channel expansion plan did not necessitate the church's destruction.

The same secretary had also taken over grassland and wooded areas previously used by local communities. The secretary was dismissed from his position in less than half a month following the incident and was placed under investigation.

Looting: On 20 September 2020, the police and Religious Affairs Bureau officials raided a house church in Qinzhou prefecture (Guangxi) (coded to Qinbei) during a gathering with over 50 believers. The police confiscated all Bible copies, religious books, benches, a piano, and several electrical appliances.
Property destruction: On 22 September 2020, authorities removed crosses from a registered Catholic church in Huiyang district (Huizhou, Guangdong).

Security measures: Around 16 October 2020 (month of), nine old local Churches in Yushan county (Shangrao, Jiangxi) were shut down by government authorities.

They were later transferred by car to Jiujingzhuang 'black jail'. It was not reported how long they were there for.

SOURCE: Radio Free Asia; DW; Shijiazhuang Daily; Shijiazhuang Municipal People's Government; GardaWorld; Ming Pao
NOTES: Security measures: On 7 January 2021, the National Health Commission of Hebei Province announced that the provincial capital of Shijiazhuang prefecture (Hebei) (coded to Chang'an) was to enter lockdown immediately after recording 83 confirmed symptomatic and 148 asymptomatic coronavirus cases between 2 to 6 Jan, in alleged connection to a wedding- or Catholic-related community outbreak in Xiaoguozhuang village. All 11 million residents were instructed to complete mandatory testing within three days, and all nonessential movement were banned to and from Shijiazhuang. On 9 Jan, authorities ordered a 7-day mandatory home quarantine, with a suspension of bus, taxi, subway services in the city. All residents of Langfang and Xingtai cities were placed under the same quarantine order on 12 Jan and 8 Jan respectively.

Security measures: Around 11 January 2021 (as reported), infrastructure upgrades under construction were observed south of the dual-use military and civilian Xigaze (Xigatse) Heping Airport in Jiangdang township (Xigaze, Tibet), including a surface-to-air missile site, a suspected military support building, a new railway terminal and new railway line, and a possible fuel dump. A newly developed underground facility with two tunnel entrance could support the storage of missile systems. The creation of these new infrastructures was seen by experts as in line with the government's efforts to upgrade many logistical facilities in the Tibetan Plateau, and along the Line of Actual Control (LAC) between China and Tibet.

Security measures: On 13 January 2021, authorities declared a state of emergency in Heilongjiang province (coded to Songbei) due to ongoing coronavirus activity, banning large gatherings throughout the province, and calling on residents to defer all nonessential travel.

Security measures: On 20 January 2021, government authorities imposed a gathering ban for all residents of Daxing District (Beijing), in response to detection of two community cases of a variant of COVID-19 with increased transmissibility. Residents of Daxing District were not allowed to leave Beijing without permission or presenting a negative coronavirus test, and authorities banned large gatherings throughout the district.

Looting: Around 26 January 2021 (week of), officers from multiple government departments closed down house churches in Yanjiao Development Area (Langfang, Hebei), taking away belongings inside the venues, then sealing their entrances. The operation to close down churches started since last year. It was reported that Yanjiao government authorities closed at least a dozen churches between the end of Jan and Mar 2021.

Looting: Around 27 January 2021 (between 25 January - 29 January), police officers ransacked and confiscated properties from several house churches within Beijing municipality.

NOTES: Weapons seizure: On 8 February 2021, the police tactical unit's Organized Crime and Triad Investigation Division arrested two men outside Wing Fok Centre, Fanling, North district (Hong Kong), suspected of supplying explosive substances to those with 'radical and violent means' to 'achieve political ends.' Many chemicals and items were confiscated after searching their belongings, offices and residences, including 23.5 kg worth of substances used in the manufacturing of explosives. Other items include bows and arrows, gas masks, armour gear, expandable batons, telescopic sticks, electroshock weapons, communication devices and political flyers about the anti-ELAB movement. The police received intelligence in Jan 2021 about a conspiracy to detonate explosives in crowded areas before the Lunar New Year holidays, and initial investigations show that both suspects had been involved in social unrest related to the anti-ELAB demonstrations.
Arrests: On 15 February 2021, the police of Zigong city (Sichuan) (coded to Ziliujing) arrested more than 50 Church of Almighty God members after Skynet monitoring and secret tracing.

Recruitment: Around 17 February 2021 (from 14 February - 20 February), in the third week of February, People's Liberation Army (PLA) officials from Lhasa visited Rutog town of Rutog county (Ngari, Tibet) to recruit Tibetans as soldiers. The military had been holding special recruitment drives across the Tibet Autonomous Region since the beginning of the year, as reported on 17 April 2021 as a 'stepped-up effort' to recruit more Tibetans amid the dragging border standoff with India on the Line of Actual Control (LAC). Citing three separate intelligence agencies as their source, those familiar with the developments said the PLA intended to form a Special Tibetan Army Unit.
Property destruction: Around 1 March 2021 (as reported), authorities demolished a mosque in Zhaoyang district (Zhaotong, Yunnan).

The heliport consisted of an estimated 1700m apron with a 60m runway, 10 helipads, 27 hangars and an administrative area, with the capability to support military aircrafts and unmanned aerial vehicle operations. With the coordinates 24.0449, 117.8486, the facility was approximately 183 km from Penghu county and 386 km from Dongsha Islands, both administered by the Taiwan government.

As of 9 Apr 2021, the blanket movement restriction was lifted, but localities designated high- and medium-risk faced travel, movement and gathering restrictions.

Around 22 May 2021 (from 19 May - 25 May), the police of Guangdong province (coded to Guangzhou) arrested nearly 160 The Church of Almighty God (CAG) members during a unified arrest operation in Foshan, Guangzhou, Zhuhai and other cities.
