NOTES: Other: On 4 June 2021, around 200 citizens attended an evening mass at Holy Redeemer Catholic Church in Tuen Mun district (Hong Kong) (coded as Hong Kong - Tuen Mun) to commemorate the 32th anniversary of the June Fourth Tiananmen Square Massacre, and close to 200 stood outside as the church reached full capacity. They lit up their smartphones and candles, and kept walking to avoid violating coronavirus gathering guidelines. Though not explicitly advertised as political gatherings, 8pm evening masses were planned for seven Catholic churches across Hong Kong by the Justice & Peace Commission of the HK Catholic Diocese after government authorities announced that the annual vigil at Victoria Park would be banned. Attendees mostly wore black, and many wore yellow face masks. Some wore t-shirts and bags with political messages and slogans.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Catholic Christian Group (China); HKJP: Justice & Peace Commission of the HK Catholic Diocese
NOTES: Other: On 4 June 2021, citizens attended an evening mass at Saint Bonaventure Church in Tsz Wan Shan, Wong Tai Sin district (Hong Kong) (coded as Hong Kong - Wong Tai Sin) to commemorate the 32th anniversary of the June Fourth Tiananmen Square Massacre. The event was full-house, and attendees mostly wore black. Though not explicitly advertised as political gatherings, 8pm evening masses were planned for seven Catholic churches across Hong Kong by the Justice & Peace Commission of the HK Catholic Diocese after government authorities announced that the annual vigil at Victoria Park would be banned.
Other: On 4 June 2021, several Protestant organizations in Hong Kong held prayer and meditation meetings to honor those who died in the 1989 June Fourth Tiananmen Square Massacre.

On 15 June 2021, the government of Shanxi province (coded to Xinghualing) carried out a unified arrest operation of The Church of Almighty God (CAG) members, resulting in the arrest of 403 CAG members by 26 Jun 2021. There were 124 arrested in Changzhi city, 83 in Luliang city, 67 in Jinzhong city, 96 in Linfen city, and 33 in Datong city. It was alleged that the arrest operation could go on till the end of July. One Office of State Security in Shanxi was said to have issued a document ordering the maintenance of social order during the celebration of the CCP's 100th anniversary, which included 'putting real efforts to strengthen surveillance over key personnel and carry out severe crackdown on the CAG.'

Recruitment: Around 17 June 2021 (as reported), Indian sources and intelligence reports suggested that Chinese military and police recruitment drives for unemployed local youths were being conducted in Yadong county (Xigaze, Tibet) to form a 'volunteer militia' in areas across the border from Sikkim, India. The recruits would receive training with the police and People's Liberation Army, then be sent to duties at vehicle check posts, immigration, and law enforcement at 'model xiaokang (well-off) villages' built along the border.

Security measures: Around 23 June 2021 (as reported), hundreds of armed police and soldiers were deployed in Beijing municipality as the Beijing government stepped up security measures ahead of the ruling CCP's centenary celebration on 1 July 2021. More than 200 buses filled with armed People's Liberation Army soldiers arrived Bird's Nest stadium. Dozens of police officers were also deployed on Chongwenmen Street near Chaoyang district.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of China (2017-) Hong Kong Police Force
NOTES: Weapons seizure: On 29 June 2021, the Organised Crime and Triad Bureau confiscated explosives and weapons during two house raids in Lam Tin, Kwun Tong district and Tai Po, Tai Po district (Hong Kong), seizing seven 1.5-kilogram bags of potassium nitrate and sulphur powder, 580 cartridges for concrete nail guns, ammunition, and chemical substances that could be used for making explosives. Two men were arrested. They found evidence of the two 'publicly threatening to kill public figures and cause bloodshed at police stations' on social media, as well as discussing the assembly of firearms.

Security measures: Around 1 July 2021 (week of), local authorities suspended all religious activities and public events in Garze Tibetan Autonomous Prefecture (Sichuan) (coded as Kangding City), including in Shiqu County, as one of a series of monitoring and surveillance measures against Tibetan monks and students during the period of the 100th anniversary of the establishment of the ruling Communist Party. Armed personnel were deployed in the region to implement the restrictions.

Other: On 2 July 2021, people carried white flowers outside the Sogo Department Store in Causeway Bay, Wanchai district (Hong Kong) (coded as Hong Kong - Wan Chai) to mourn and pay tribute to a 50-year-old man who had stabbed a police officer before killing himself on 1 July 2021 when Hong Kong marked the 24th anniversary of its return to Chinese sovereignty. People continued to mourn for seven days, although the police stopped and searched the participants and warned that any suspected actions to pay tribute belong to inciting behavior 'supporting terrorism.'

Other: On 4 July 2021, Next Media Trade Union announced its disbandment in Hong Kong following the ceasing of operations of the company and the dismissal of most of its employees. The pro-democracy tabloid Apple Daily, which was owned by Next Media, was forced to shut down after a year of police raids and the arrests of its owner and other staff on charges of violating a Beijing-imposed national security law.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of China (2017-) Hong Kong Police Force
NOTES: Weapons seizure: On 5 July 2021, the police's national security department confiscated explosives and raw materials used to make a highly explosive chemical triacetone triperoxide (TATP) and apparatus in a home laboratory in a hostel room in Tsim Sha Tsui (Hong Kong) (coded as Hong Kong - Yau Tsim Mong). Police arrested nine members of Returning Valiant (a self-proclaimed revolutionary group), including six school students, for plotting 'terrorist' activities after uncovering an attempt to make explosives and plant bombs across the city, including transportations and public courts. The nine were suspected of violating the national security law.

Other: On 5 July 2021, three human rights and civic groups - Civil Rights Observer, Progressive Lawyers Group and Progressive Teachers' Alliance - announced cease of operations and disbandment in Hong Kong while some cited a lack of resources and the 'current climate' in the wake of the national security law imposed by Beijing last year. The Progressive Lawyers Group announced its disbandment, although the group's convenor refused to disclose more details about the reason. It was reported that at least 13 civil society and professional organizations had disbanded within the last two weeks.

ACTOR1: Government of China (2017-) Hong Kong Special Administrative Region
NOTES: Other: Around 8 July 2021 (between 7 July - 10 July), 152 pro-democracy district councilors resigned in Hong Kong as a new political vetting system, and compulsory oaths of allegiance were set to be implemented later this month. Reports suggested that disqualified district councilors may be forced to repay their salaries and allowances to the government unless they had resigned before being disqualified.

Around 30 July 2021 (as reported), police held more than 170 Uyghur Muslim prayers in custody in Aksu city, Xinjiang, to attend prayer services without permission from authorities during the Muslim Eid al-Adha holy days on 20-23 July 2021. The detainees' whereabouts were unknown, leaving the legality of the detention locations in question. It was reported that the authorities only allowed people over 50 years of age to attend worship services during Eid as a security measure to prevent unrest and preserve stability.

On 9 August 2021, 110 Tibetans were arrested in Janglam village in Nyainrong county, Tibet Autonomous Region, on suspicion of sharing online photographic evidence of the annual Nagchu Horse Racing Festival. Thirty people remained detained as of the time of reporting on 11 August 2021, while 80 people were fined and released on bail. Before the festival, the authority barred the public from attending the traditional Tibetan event over COVID-19 concerns and announced a ban on sharing photos or videos publicly.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Teachers (China); HKPTU: Hong Kong Professional Teachers' Union
SOURCE: Straits Times (Singapore); South China Morning Post; Radio Free Asia
NOTES: Other: On 10 August 2021, the Hong Kong Professional Teachers' Union (PTU) announced it was disbanding in Hong Kong, citing 'huge pressure' from a growing number of attacks from the government and the state media. Last month, Education Bureau had already cut ties with the opposition-leaning education union, accusing it of inciting -violence and anti-government sentiment in schools, while pro-Beijing newspapers described the union as a 'malignant tumor' in need of eradication. The city's largest teachers' union representing a single profession with 95,000 members was among dozens of civil society groups to disband since the ruling CCP imposed a draconian national security law on the city from 1 July 2020.

On 22 August 2021, police raided homes and the Dza Wongpo Monastery in Wenbo township (also known as Dza Wonpo township), Shiqu County (Ganzi, Sichuan), and arrested 59 Tibetans, including 19 monks, for possessing pictures of the Dalai Lama, Tibet's exiled spiritual leader. It was part of CCP's campaign against possession of the banned images in the Tibetan area.

Around 27 August 2021 (between 25 - 29 August), police arrested around 53 Tibetan monks and villagers in Wenbo township (also known as Dza Wonpo township), Shiqu County (Ganzi, Sichuan), for possessing pictures of the Dalai Lama, Tibet's exiled spiritual leader, for sharing messages and information with contacts outside Chinese-controlled areas, and for 'discussing social issues in the community.' It was the second mass arrest within a week in the village, resulting in 113 people being arrested in total.

Property destruction: Around 1 September 2021 (beginning of month), authorities demolished Lungkya monastery, an unidentified nunnery, and many Tibetan homes in Madoi County (Guoluo, Qinghai) as part of infrastructure reconstruction following the 7.4 magnitude earthquake that happened on 22 May 2021. The mass demolishment of both damaged and undamaged buildings forced monks, nuns, and Tibetan residents to temporarily take shelter in the newly built camps with steel roofs. 1,216 children were relocated to Chinese-government-run distant boarding schools due to forced relocation.

Other: On 3 September 2021, localist political party Civic Passion announced its disbandment in Hong Kong as the party faced 'no way forward in politics.' The decision came a week after the Legislative Council unseated the party's chairman as a legislator on 26 August 2021 because he did not meet the requirement of pledging loyalty to the city and vowing to uphold the Basic Law.
Other: On 12 September 2021, Wall-fare, a civil society group supporting detained pro-democracy activists, announced its disbandment in Hong Kong amid a national security crackdown on dissent.

ACTOR1: Government of China (2017-) Hong Kong Special Administrative Region
NOTES: Other: On 15 September 2021, seven elected pro-democracy district councilors, including a DP member, were disqualified in Hong Kong after the Home Affairs Bureau ruled their oaths to uphold the Basic Law and bear allegiance to the Hong Kong government were 'invalid' without further explanation. Two of the ousted councilors were currently facing trial under the national security law, and the other five offered their offices to be used as polling stations during the primary elections. They were among the first group of district councilors required to take the pledge, since a new oath-taking bill had passed in May 2021.

SOURCE: HKFP; Radio Free Asia; South China Morning Post
NOTES: Other: Around 22 September 2021 (between 21 - 24 September), the China Human Rights Lawyers Concern Group in Hong Kong announced on 21 September 2021 that it was in the process of disbanding after political denunciation and investigation by national security police amid a crackdown on public dissent and peaceful opposition in the city. The group, founded to support human rights lawyers on the mainland, had refused the data request by national security police on the deadline of data submission. On 24 September 2021, Student Politicism, a pro-democracy student group, announced its disbandment after four current and former members were arrested and charged under the national security law.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: The Alliance: Hong Kong Alliance in Support of Patriotic Democratic Movements of China
NOTES: Other: On 25 September 2021, the Hong Kong Alliance in Support of Patriotic Democratic Movements of China voted to disband in Hong Kong following -months of political pressure from the authorities and a string of arrests of its leaders under the national security law. The group stands accused of acting as the agent of a foreign power, with three leaders arrested on suspicion of 'incitement to subvert state power,' and the group's assets frozen. Established in 1989, the group routinely attracted over 100,000 people to attend the now-banned annual 4 June vigils, commemorating victims of the crackdown, fighting for accountability from Beijing, advocating the democratization of China, and seeking an end to one-party rule for more than 30 years.

ACTOR1: Government of China (2017-) Hong Kong Special Administrative Region
NOTES: Other: On 29 September 2021, ten elected pro-democracy district councilors, including the DP Vice-chair and an Umbrella Movement activist, were disqualified in Hong Kong after the Home Affairs Bureau ruled their oaths to uphold the Basic Law and bear allegiance to the Hong Kong government were 'invalid' without further explanation. One of the ousted councilors, also a barrister, was currently out on bail and facing national security charges over the democrats' informal primaries. A total of 17 district councilors had been ousted from their offices after their oaths were deemed invalid this month.

Around 1 October 2021 (week of), the authorities arrested over 170 Uyghurs, including over 40 women and 19 minors, in Hotan prefecture (Xinjiang) (coded to Hotan City), accusing them of having anti-China sentiment and a negative attitude towards National Day flag-raising activities.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: HKCTU: Hong Kong Confederation of Trade Unions; Labour Group (China)
SOURCE: Wen Wei Po (Print); Deutsche Welle; HKFP
NOTES: Other: On 3 October 2021, the Hong Kong Confederation of Trade Unions disbanded in Hong Kong as it faced an intensified government crackdown and Beijing-backed media accusing it of a 'foreign agent.' The city's largest pro-democracy labor coalition represented 145,000 members from 97 associated groups covering a broad spectrum, including aviation, construction, catering, retail and social welfare. On 3 October 2021, two new labor unions established after the 2019 anti-extradition movements, the Union of Hong Kong Occupational Therapists and the Hong Kong Early Childhood Educators' Union, also disbanded.

SOURCE: Wen Wei Po (Print); Deutsche Welle; HKFP
NOTES: Other: On 7 October 2021, the Student Union of the Chinese University of Hong Kong, founded in 1971, announced its disbandment following increasing pressure from the university since the national security police had arrested eight students and alumni over a peaceful pro-democracy rally on its campus in December 2020.

ACTOR1: Government of China (2017-) Hong Kong Special Administrative Region
NOTES: Other: On 8 October 2021, 16 district councilors, including a DP member, were disqualified in Hong Kong after the Home Affairs Bureau ruled their oaths to uphold the Basic Law and bear allegiance to the Hong Kong government were 'invalid.' A total of 33 district councilors had been ousted from their offices after their oaths were deemed invalid last month.

Property destruction: Around 15 October 2021 (week of), police began demolishing villagers' houses in Shibalidian village in Chaoyang district, Beijing (coded as Beijing - Chaoyang), threatening two independent candidates in the village not to rally for district elections commencing on 9 November 2021. The two independent candidates were also held under house arrest by the police.

ACTOR1: Government of China (2017-) Hong Kong Special Administrative Region
NOTES: Other: On 21 October 2021, 16 pro-democracy district councilors were disqualified in Hong Kong after the Home Affairs Bureau ruled their oaths to uphold the Basic Law and bear allegiance to the Hong Kong government were 'invalid.' One district councilor had resigned voluntarily before the announcement. Following the oath ceremony, 49 district councilors had been ousted, leaving 60 pro-democracy councilors left in office.

Property destruction: Around 31 October 2021 (end of month), Tibetan volunteers led by monastery officials were forced to demolish the Gaden Rabten Namgyaling school attached to Drago Monastery in Kangding City, Ganzi (Karze) Tibetan Autonomous Prefecture, Sichuan, under government order. The demolishment leaving 130 students without Tibetan school education came after Chinese authorities accused the temple of violating land-use laws, despite that the law covered only local residential buildings. The source suggested that the forced demolishment was part of wider campaigns that the authorities had sought to restrict the size and influence of Tibetan Buddhist monasteries.

On 10 May 2018, police in Bade, Taoyuan arrested 7 senior officials of the Taiwan Civil Government and shut down the organization's bureau. Police also seized 130 million yuan in cash along with a banner reading ''The United States will take over Taiwan.''

On 31 May 2018, a man dissatisfied with the performance of the Minister of Justice threw two petrol bombs at the Ministry of Justice (Taipei City-Zhongzheng). The petrol bombs did not cause any damage, and police detained the perpetrator.

Movement of forces: On 31 March 2019, two Chinese military aircraft from the People's Liberation Army crossed into Taiwan's southwestern air space and was intercepted by Taiwan air force jets. The incident triggered a ten minute standoff between the Taiwan and China warplanes (location coded at Taipei City as the capital of Taiwan at GP 3). It was for the first time in 20 years when the Chinese military had intentionally crossed the median line of the waterway.
On 12 December 2019, police destroyed a bomb planted by unidentified assailants found outside the Kuomintang headquarter in the East District (Tainan City) without causing any injuries.

On 16 October 2020, a few fishermen set fire on a patrol boat in Fishing Harbor in Magong City, Penghu to show their frustration with the local authorities. The patrol boat was owned by an environment volunteer who was appointed by the local authorities to combat illegal fishing. The boat was completely destroyed but no one was injured.

Other: On 6 February 2021, the Electoral Commission announced that a vote to recall independent Kaohsiung City Councilor failed (coded at Taipei City). The recall vote was supported by the KMT which organized numerous demonstrations to encourage people to vote for her recall. KMT will most likely now stop their campaign to try to remove the councilor.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of the United States (2017-2021)
SOURCE: Mainichi Shimbun; Asahi Shimbun; BBC News
NOTES: On 6 January 2018, a US military helicopter was forced to make an emergency landing in a suburban area on Ikei Island in Uruma city. With Anti-US sentiment already high, this could trigger protests and unrest, especially as it comes after a series of protests triggered by parts from a US helicopter falling into a the grounds of a local school last month.

On 13 January 2018, the majors of four municipalities in Okinawa (Okinawa, Ginowan, Miyakojima, and Ishigaki) announced that these cities would not participate in the prefectural referendum regarding Henoko airbase. This is likely to increase protests and unrest in relation to the US presence on the island.

On 16 January 2018, 7 unidentified men were found dead in a wooden boat which washed up in the Shimoyasuhara district of Kanazawa, Ishikawa, bearing North Korean items such as badges depicting former North Korean President Kim Il Sung. Another male was found at the same site drowning on the 10th.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of the United States (2017-2021)
SOURCE: News24 (Japan); Mainichi Shimbun; Asahi Shimbun; Japan Update
NOTES: On 23 January 2018, a US military helicopter was forced to make an emergency landing on a helipad on Tonaki Island, Okinawa. This is the third incident this month and is likely to further inflame anti-US sentiment and unrest on the island. The Mayor of Tonaki and the Governor of Okinawa were quick to denounce the incident, and Defence Minister Onodera has requested a suspension of helicopter flights.

On 4 February 2018, mayoral candidate Taketoyo Toguchi was elected to the Mayor's office in Nago, Okinawa. Mr Toguchi was supported by the ruling LDP-Komeito coalition and does not oppose Henoko airbase (which is being built within Nago city-limits). This may intensify opposition to Henoko airbase on the island.

On 5 February 2018, a JSDF helicopter crashed into a home in Kanzaki, Saga, causing a large fire. Mainichi Shimbun reports an increase in protests against the prefectural government's plan to deploy Osprey military helicopters to Saga Airport as a result of the crash. 2 JSDF personnel reported killed, and 1 civilian injured.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Chongryon: General Association of Korean Residents in Japan
NOTES: On 23 February 2018, 2 right-wing activists drove past Chongryon headquarters in Chiyoda, Tokyo, firing 5 shorts into the front gate. No casualties reported.

SOURCE: AFP; Kyodo News (Japan); Mainichi Shimbun; Channel News Asia; AP; FNN; Reuters; Tokyo Shimbun; BBC News; Nishinippon Shimbun; Asahi Shimbun; TV Asahi; Nikkei Shimbun; News24 (Japan)
NOTES: On 19 April 2018, the vice minister of finance resigned after a weekly magazine published a story accusing him of sexual harassment. This comes after a petition was submitted to the Ministry with 25000 signatures demanding that the Ministry do more to protect the rights of victims, a formal protest by TV Asahi after one of its own employees came forward directly accusing the vice minister, and even SDPJ members holding up #metoo signs during official government hearings.

On 22 December 2018, a man vandalized the Self Defense Forces Okinawa Regional Cooperation Headquarters from Maejima, Naha. He broke a window and tried to set fire to the building. The man was arrested later on.

On January 16, 2019, a man destroyed a Japan Coast Guard rubber boat used by the police to supervise the Henoko sea demonstrations (coast of Henoko, Nago). He was arrested for the second time on March 18, 2019, for vandalism. The first time, on December 22, 2018, he broke a window and tried to set fire to the Self Defense Forces Okinawa Regional Cooperation Headquarters building.

On January 24, 2019, 18 companies across Japan including pharmaceutical companies (from Tokyo and Osaka Prefecture), food companies (from Tokyo and Sapporo), and the Tokyo headquarters of The Asahi Shimbun national daily and The Mainichi Shimbun, received blackmail letters demanding money and containing cyanide, a substance that can be deadly. Some of the letters were signed with the name of former Aum Shinrikyo members, some executed in 2018. No report about people being injured.

On January 24, 2019, 18 companies across Japan including pharmaceutical companies (from Tokyo and Osaka Prefecture), food companies (from Tokyo and Sapporo), and the Tokyo headquarters of The Asahi Shimbun national daily and The Mainichi Shimbun, received blackmail letters demanding money and containing cyanide, a substance that can be deadly. Some of the letters were signed with the name of former Aum Shinrikyo members, some executed in 2018. No report about people being injured.

On January 24, 2019, 18 companies across Japan including pharmaceutical companies (from Tokyo and Osaka Prefecture), food companies (from Tokyo and Sapporo), and the Tokyo headquarters of The Asahi Shimbun national daily and The Mainichi Shimbun, received blackmail letters demanding money and containing cyanide, a substance that can be deadly. Some of the letters were signed with the name of former Aum Shinrikyo members, some executed in 2018. No report about people being injured.

SOURCE: BBC News; TV Asahi; News24 (Japan); Mainichi Shimbun
NOTES: In the prefectural referendum held on February 24, 2019, 72% of the Okinawans voted against the relocation of Futenma base to Henoko. The voter turnout was 52.48%. Okinawa Prefectural Governor urged both the central government and the US to listen to the will of the people and stop the relocation process. The result of the referendum doesn't have binding power. The Prime Minister announced that the government will push ahead with the Henoko base construction in spide of the result of the referendum.

Security measures: On 26 March 2019, the Japanese central government deployed two Ground Self-Defence Force units, one in Miyakojima Island and another one in Amami-Oshima Island. The Defence Minister declared that the deployment will help the local authorities with managing natural disasters and that future deployments are planned in Ishigaki Island. The deployments are likely to trigger the locals' indignation over the presence of military troops.

Security measures: On 26 March 2019, the Japanese central government deployed two Ground Self-Defence Force units, one in Miyako Island and another one in Amami Oshima Island. The Defence Minister declared that the deployment will help the local authorities with managing natural disasters and that future deployments are planned in Ishigaki Island. The deployments are likely to trigger the locals' indignation over the presence of military troops.
On 14th April 2019, port workers begun a 48 hours nation-wide strike after failing to reach an agreement with the Japan Harbour Transportation Association over minimum wages.

SOURCE: Kyodo News (Japan); AP; BBC News; Saga Shimbun; AFP
NOTES: On 30 Mar 2020, a collision occurred between a JMSDF escort ship and a Chinese fishing boat in the East China Sea. Both governments are investigating the cause of the collision. One injury reported (only reported by BBC - all other sources reporting no injuries).
On 31 Mar 2020, the United States formally returned a portion of the US Army Camp Zukeran (Camp Foster), located in Chatan, Okinawa, to Japan.

On 1 Apr 2020, the Okinawa Prefectural Police Forces established the 'Remote Island Border Guard' unit with the intention to increase patrols around the country's remote border islands, including the disputed Senkaku/Diaoyu Islands, and their ability to deal with illegal landings in cooperation with the Japanese Coast Guard.

SOURCE: Mainichi Shimbun; Japan Today; AP; Tokyo Shimbun; Channel News Asia; Shimbun Akahata; Nikkei Asian Review; AFP; IWJ; Saga Shimbun; Asia News International; BBC News; Straits Times (Singapore); News24 (Japan); Kyodo News (Japan); Kahoku Shimpo; DPA; Nikkei Shimbun; Fukui Shimbun; Sankei Shimbun; FNN; Xinhua; Nishinippon Shimbun; Asahi Shimbun; The Japan News; TV Asahi
NOTES: On 7 April 2020, the Government of Japan declared a state of emergency in the following 6 prefectures in response to the escalating coronavirus crisis: Tokyo, Saitama, Chiba, Kanagawa, Osaka, Hyogo, Fukuoka. On 16 April, the state of Emergency was extended nationwide until May 6. On 4 May, the state of emergency was extended until 31 May, and will be revisited on 14 May in case it can be lifted early. On 14 May, the state of emergency was lifted across 39 prefectures, leaving only the following 8 still under a state of emergency: Hokkaido, Chiba, Saitama, Tokyo, Kanagawa, Kyoto, Osaka, Hyogo. On 25 May, the state of emergency was lifted across the whole country, leaving no prefectures still under the state of emergency. The state of emergency gives those prefectures in which it is declared extra powers to control the congregation and movement of residents, and set restrictions on businesses.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of the United States (2017-2021)
SOURCE: Nishinippon Shimbun; Asahi Shimbun; Shimbun Akahata; Ryukyu Shimpo; Mainichi Shimbun; Okinawa Times; Kyodo News (Japan); Tokyo Shimbun
NOTES: On 11 April 2020, a hazardous chemical compound leaked out of Futenma airbase (Ginowan, Okinawa) into the surrounding civilian neighbourhood including one of the city's main waterways that is also a source of tap water for the city, and has reached as far as neighbouring cities including Urasoe. Emergency crews have advised citizens not to clean the substance, as it is potentially hazardous, but have not succeeded in clearing it themselves, and the military base has also dismissed calls to clear the compound, stating that the compound is easily soluble and should clear during rainfall. Citizens submitted an official protest with the city, who has also submitted an official protest with the military base and the Ministry of Defence. The Ministry of Defence has in turn lodged a complaint with the US High Command.

SOURCE: Asahi Shimbun; Tokyo Shimbun; Nikkei Shimbun; Fukui Shimbun; Kahoku Shimpo; Kyodo News (Japan); FNN; TV Asahi; Mainichi Shimbun; Ryukyu Shimpo; Saga Shimbun; News24 (Japan)
NOTES: On 14 April 2020, All Okinawa Council announced a cessation of all protest events in relation to Henoko airbase starting from 15 April until at least 6 May due to the Coronavirus outbreak. This is the first reported interruption to the long-running sit-in in front of Henoko airbase which has been held every day for the past 5 years and 9 months. On 12 June, the group announced that regular protests in front of the base would resume from 15 June after the Ministry of Defense announced that work would resume on the base from 12 June. Work was temporarily halted on 17 April due to the COVID-19 pandemic. On 4 August 2020, All Okinawa Conference announced a second suspension of all protest activities in the prefecture until 18 August in response to the emergency declaration issued by the governor to curb the coronavirus pandemic. On 7 September 2020, the sit-in in front of Henoko airbase restarted due to the lifting of the emergency declaration in Okinawa. Coded as Nago since the group mainly operates in this area.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of the United States (2017-2021)
SOURCE: FNN; Kyodo News (Japan); Mainichi Shimbun; Ryukyu Shimpo
NOTES: On 8 May 2020, 5 US military helicopters flew in formation directly over the nursery school in Ginowan, Okinawa, where helicopter parts were dropped by US military helicopters in December 2017. Just 4 days later on 12 May, two US soldiers were arrested in Chatan, Okinawa, for alleged attempted robbery. Both incidents have fuelled renewed opposition from residents over the safety of residents and the necessity of military bases in Okinawa.

SOURCE: DPA; Mainichi Shimbun; IWJ; News24 (Japan); AP; BBC News; Japan Today; Okinawa Times; Tokyo Shimbun; Channel News Asia; AFP; Kyodo News (Japan); FNN; Sankei Shimbun; Nikkei Shimbun; Shimbun Akahata; Asahi Shimbun; Saga Shimbun; Fukui Shimbun; Hokkaido Shimbun; TV Asahi; Kahoku Shimpo; Nishinippon Shimbun; Ryukyu Shimpo
NOTES: On 8 May 2020, the Abe Administration opened parliamentary deliberations on revisions to the public prosecutor retirement age in the National Public Service Act, resulting in huge public backlash. Due to ongoing COVID-19 countermeasures, protesters have taken to social media, voicing opposition to the revision in a series of twitter campaigns amassing over 4 Million tweets in 2 days. In addition, numerous prominent Japanese celebrities have openly voiced opposition; formal protest statements were submitted from the Japan Federation of Bar Associations and 38 other regional Bar Associations; former cabinet ministers and legislators have held public talks on Zoom opposing the revision; and opposition parties have banded together to block the legislation, arguing that the revision will undermine the independence of the public prosecutors office. The government initially declined to comment on the sustained public outcry, but later decided to hold a Q&A. Following a defeat of the legislation in parliament during the previous week, the Prime minister decided on the 18th to postpone further discussion on the bill until he could 'win the trust of the public'. On the 21st, the Public Prosecutor resigned after it came to light that he broke COVID-19 lockdown measures on several occasions.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of the United States (2017-2021)
SOURCE: Shimbun Akahata; Kyodo News (Japan); Mainichi Shimbun; Ryukyu Shimpo
NOTES: On 24 June 2020, highly hazardous chlorine gas seeped out of Kadena airbase in Kadena, Okinawa, following a fire at the facility on June 22, affecting an area 300 meters around the base. US Authorities announced about 100 people including Japanese have experienced complaints due to the gas, but that the gas has not impacted the surrounding municipalities. However, some reports voice concerns that the gas may have leaked into the water supply of the surrounding municipalities. Okinawa Defence Bureau and local government officials have formally protested the base authorities.

On 31 July 2020, the Governor of Okinawa issued a prefecture-wide a state of emergency declaration from August 1 to 15 in response to the soaring coronavirus infection rate in the prefecture. July 31 marked a new record for reported infections in a single day (71) for Okinawa, and there is a widespread belief that this is being driven partly by the military bases in the prefecture which are perceived to be handling the crisis ineffectively. On 14 August 2020, The Governor extended the energy declaration until 29 August.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of the United States (2017-2021)
NOTES: On 4 August 2020, parts fell from a US military F-15 fighter while on a routine flight out of Kadena airbase. There are no reports of injury to civilians, but the prefectural government has submitted a formal protest to the Ministry of Defence, the US military command in Okinawa, and the Kadena defence bureau. This event is likely to increase protest activity in the area.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: LDP: Liberal Democratic Party (Japan); Government of Japan (2012-); Former Government of Japan (2012-)
NOTES: On 4 August 2020, members of LDP including the former Minister of Defense proposed a plan of capabilities to intercept missiles even in the territory of an opponent to Prime Minister Abe. This action is likely to cause unrest; those who are concerned claim the possibility of the capability leading to a war in the future. This plan has been suggested to the Abe cabinet twice already by members of LDP.
On 6 August 2020, the Governor of Aichi issued a prefecture-wide a state of emergency declaration from August 6 to 24 in response to the soaring coronavirus infection rate in the prefecture.

SOURCE: TV Asahi; FNN; Mainichi Shimbun; Tokyo Shimbun
NOTES: On 1 October 2020, Prime Minister Suga rejected appointment of 6 candidates out of 105 for the Science Council of Japan. There is no precedent for this. Some of the rejected scholars were against the Security Bill and the Conspiracy Law, and this led to controversy and disagreements among people about Suga's intent. Protesters including professors have taken to social media, voicing opposition to the government's intervention in academic fields in a series of twitter campaigns, amassing over 250,000 tweets in 2 days. This decision may continue to raise unrest in Japan.

On 16 October 2020, the Government of Japan has made the decision to release contaminated water from Fukushima Nuclear Power Plant into the ocean despite opposition from local fishermen and environmental groups. This decision is likely to spark further unrest amongst these groups, and raise further concerns in neighboring countries who are keeping an eye on how the situation is managed in Japan. On 23 October 2020, a government spokesperson backtracked on the decision saying that the Government had no plans to make a final decision anytime soon following strong opposition from fishermen and environmental groups over the original announcement.

Other: On 24 December 2020, Tokyo Public Prosecutors decided not to indict former Prime Minister Shinzo Abe for allegations that his office inappropriately paid for annual government cherry blossom viewing events with political funds. The prosecutors instead indicted his secretary for violation of the Political Funds Control Law, seeking a fine against him as they allege he failed to keep proper financial records surrounding the events. Over 200,000 tweets on December 24th voiced opposition to the prosecutors' decision. The decision is likely to cause some unrest among people in Japan (coded at Tokyo).

ACTOR1: Military Forces of the United States (2017-2021)
NOTES: Other: On 12 August 2021, parts fell from a US MV-22 Osprey aircraft into the ocean near Okinawa. The aircraft was traveling from Camp Hansen to Futenma Air Base. There were no reports of injury to civilians, but the event is likely to increase protest activity in the area. Demonstrations opposing military bases is one of the major protest trends in Japan. Reasons behind the opposition include safety concerns and anti-war sentiment. Location coded at Tokyo.

ACTOR1: Military Forces of the United States (2021-)
NOTES: Other: On 27 August 2021, it was reported that U.S. Marines finished the process of releasing treated contaminated water containing organic fluorine compounds such as PFOS into the sewer at Futenma U.S. military air base in Ginowan, Okinawa on 26 August. The release has been opposed by the Japanese government, the Okinawa prefectural government, and Ginowan city. This development may affect protest activity surrounding U.S. military bases. Demonstrations opposing the presence of the US military bases in Japan make up one of the main protest trends in the country. Event coded at the capital, Tokyo.

Other: On 9 January 2018, North and South Korea began official talks in Panmunjom (Joint Security Area, Kaesong City) for the first time in two years, leading to the reestablishment of a military hotline, a agreement for North Korea to participate in the PyeongChang Winter Olympics, and military talks.

SOURCE: AFP; Asia News Network; YNA; AP; Tongil News
NOTES: Other: On 8 February 2018, about 50,000 people, including 13,000 soldiers, attended a military parade in Kim Il-sung Square in Pyongyang for the 70th anniversary of the founding of the Korean People's Army (KPA). The parade showcased the ICBMs Hwasong-14 and Hwasong-15 (which Pyongyang claimed was an intercontinental ballistic missile capable of striking the US mainland), as well as other ballistic missiles, artillery, tanks, and armored vehicles. At this time, Kim Jong-gak replaced Hwang Byung-seo as the director of the General Political Bureau.

Change to armed group: Around 14 February 2018 (month of), it was reported that a Senior Colonel in the Ministry of State Security defected while in Heping, Shenyang. The colonel, who headed the North-Eastern China division of the Overseas Anti-Espionage Department, played a key role in North Korea's nuclear program and had significant access to state secrets. In response to his defection, Kim Jong Un sent out assassination orders, according to several anonymous sources within North Korea. The location of the colonel is unknown (event coded at Pyongyang)

Other: On 6 March 2018, North Korean leader Kim Jong Un met 10 South Korean officials including Chung Eui-Yong, the top national security advisor of Moon Jae-in in Pyongyang. They agreed to pursue denuclearization and permanent peace of the Korean Peninsular. Kim Jong Un especially expressed willingness to have the inter-Korea summit and to restart talks with the U.S.

Other: On 29 March 2018, envoys from North Korea and South Korea had a meeting in the border truce village of Panmunjom (Joint Security Area, Kaesong City) in the Demilitarized Zone. They reached the agreement on having a bilateral summit on 27 April.

Change to armed group: Around 15 April 2018 (month of), the North Korean government designated Chagang Province (capital Kanggye City) as a strategic military region, likely in an effort to conceal nuclear weapons and associated material associated with the completion of expanded underground military factories in the province.

Other: On 21 April 2018, North Korea announced that it will suspend missile and nuclear weapons testing, likely in an effort to encourage diplomatic talks with South Korea and the United States (event coded at Pyongyang).

SOURCE: Asia News International; YNA; AP; AFP; Radio Free Asia
NOTES: Other: On 27 April 2018, the leaders of North and South Korea met at the military demarcation line and held an official inter-Korean summit at Panmunjom (Joint Security Area, Kaesong City) on the North-South border. They agreed to pursue a permanent peace treaty and denuclearization of the peninsula. This was the first inter-Korean summit held in a decade, and marked the first time a North Korean leader had set foot in South Korea since the end of the 1950-1953 Korean War. This meeting set the stage for future talks between North Korea and the United States. On 28 May 2018, South Korea's National Assembly rejected a resolution supporting the summit's ''Panmunjom Declaration''.

Other: Around 4 May 2018 (between 28 April - 10 May), buildings of a nuclear test site were dismantled in Punggye-ri, Kilju, North Hamgyong. This happened after North Korean leader Kim Jong Un showed his commitment to halt nuclear tests in the inter-Korea summit on 27 April.

SOURCE: Asia News International; AP; Radio Free Asia
NOTES: Other: On 10 May 2018, North Korea released into US custody three American detainees who had been arrested for alleged anti-state activities in North Korea. The release of these prisoners came prior to the June 2018 Singapore Summit between North Korean leader Kim Jong-un and US President Donald Trump (event coded at Pyongyang).

Other: Around 24 May 2018 (between 23 - 25 May), the North Korean government demolished tunnels at its nuclear test site in Punggye-ri, Kilju, North Hamgyong. The move was seen as part of a diplomatic rapprochement with South Korea. The event occurred ahead of a planned summit between US and DPRK leaders in Singapore on 12 June, which has now been cancelled by President Trump. The North Korea government invited journalists from the United States, South Korea, China, Russia and Britain to witness the dismantling process.

Other: On 25 May 2018, North Korea Vice Foreign Minister Kim Kye Gwan announced that North Korea is willing to sit for talks with the United States. This change was made after President Donald Trump called off a summit with Kim Jong Un, blaming Pyongyang's recent statements. On 24 May, North Korea issued a new threat to walk away from the planned Trump-Kim summit, scheduled for June 12 in Singapore.

Other: On 26 May 2018, North Korean leader Kim Jong Un and South Korean President Moon Jae-in met at the truce village of Panmunjom (Joint Security Area), North Korea. It was the second meeting between the two leaders. They exchanged views on how to put back on track a summit between North Korea and the US which was initially scheduled for 12 June. President Trump has previously declared that the summit might not happen.

Agreement: On 12 June 2018, North Korea leader Kim Jong Un and U.S. President Donald Trump signed a joint statement on cooperation to build peace in the Korean Peninsula during a Singapore summit at the Capella Hotel on Sentosa island in Singapore. The leaders agreed to new peaceful relations, security guarantees for North Korea, denuclearization of the Korean Peninsula, return of the remains of US soldiers killed during the Korean War (event coded at Pyongyang).

Other: On 6 July 2018, Kim Yong Chol, a senior ruling party official, met the U.S. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo at the state guest house Baek Hwa Won in Pyongyang. They discussed a specific timeline for North Korea's denuclearization and the implementation of the agreements signed during the Singapore summit. The North Korea's Foreign Ministry described the meeting as 'regrettable' claiming that the U.S. government's approach is to halt the North Korean nuclear weapons program without giving anything in return (i.e. easing sanctions on the country).

On 12 July 2018, school computers and printers were stolen from Hyesan People's Committee's supply station in Hyesan City. The suspects are believed to be soldiers. It is believed that the incident occurred due to food shortages in military units.

Other: Around 24 July 2018 (as reported), the North Korean government started dismantling Sohae Satellite Launching Station in Tongchang-ri, Cholsan County, North Pyongan Province. The station used as a missile engine test site which Kim Jong Un promised to shut down during the last summit with the U.S. on 12 June 2018.

Other: On 1 August 2018, the North Korean government handed over to the US 55 boxes containing what is believed to be the remains of American soldiers killed in the Korean War. A US military plane made a rare trip into North Korea to carry them. The US President Donald Trump expressed gratitude to North Korean leader Kim Jong Un for his reconciliatory action (event coded at Pyongyang).

Other: On 1 August 2018, military leaders from North and South Korea held talks at the truce village of Panmunjom (Joint Security Area, Kaesong City) in the demilitarized zone (DMZ). They discussed specific methods to ease border tensions, shared ideas on reducing the number of military forces and arms in the DMZ and conducting a joint excavation for the remains of soldiers that were killed in the Korean War.

Other: On 4 September 2018, North Korean leader Kim Jong Un and other officials met a five-member delegation led by South Korean President Moon's national security advisor in Pyongyang. They discussed about the next inter-Korea summit and about an end-of-war declaration.

Other: On 14 September 2018, North and South Korea opened their first liaison office at the North Korean border town of Kaesong City. The office is the first of its kind since the two Koreas were divided at the end of World War II. South and North Korean officials would station at the office and have to face to face discussions over various inter-Korean issues, and exchange messages from their governments directly.

SOURCE: YNA; NK Pro; Daily NK; Radio Free Asia; AP
NOTES: On 19 September 2018, a series of inter-Korean agreements were signed between the governments of North Korea and South Korea. According to the agreements, the North Korea will close the Tongchang-ri engine test ground and missile test pad with the observance of experts from concerned countries, and also dismantle Yongbyon nuclear facilities (the latter depending on the relations with U.S). The sides also agreed to refrain from any action to infiltrate, attack or occupy each other's area of jurisdiction by any means or method, suspending army training exercises and all artillery drills 5km near the inter-Korean border and withdraw all guard posts in the demilitarized zone (DMZ).

Other: On 1 October 2018, the governments of North Korea and South Korea began joint demining activities in the Joint Security Area (JSA) as per the inter-Korean military agreement signed on September 19.

Other: On 26 October 2018, the governments of North Korea and South Korea began demolishing of total 22 Guard posts (11 from each side) in the demilitarized zone (DMZ) as per the objective set by the inter-Korean military agreement signed on September 19. Coded at the Joint Security Area.

Other: Around 15 November 2018 (month of), according to South Korea's National Intelligence Service, North Korea's former acting ambassador to Italy and his wife defected and hid in Italy. On 1 August 2019, a South Korean lawmaker said the diplomat transitioned to be protected in a third country. On 7 October 2020, the intelligence committee of South Korea's National Assembly confirmed that the diplomat had been living in South Korea since July 2019 (event coded at Pyongyang).

ACTOR1: Police Forces of North Korea (2011-) State Security Department
NOTES: Around 14 March 2019 (month of), it was reported that a high-level official from the Ministry of State Security defected from Pyongyang, prompting North Korean authorities to send an arrest team into China.

Around 29 March 2019 (as reported), according to South Korean intelligence agencies, North Korea almost completed restoring a part of the Dongchang-ri nuclear missile launch site (Tongchang-ri missile engine test site in Cholsan County, North Pyongan Province, also known as the Sohae Satellite Launching Station) although it partially dismantled last year as part of disarmament steps.
Around 4 April 2019 (as reported), according to a South Korean military spokesman, North Korea is building a new 3,000-tonne submarine capable of launching ballistic missiles in Sinpho City.

On 17 April 2019, North Korea tested a new tactical weapon with President Kim Jong-Un's supervision. According to a U.S. think tank, activity had been detected around Nyongbyon. It marked the first weapon test after a summit between Kim and US President Trump.

Change to armed group: On 4 May 2019, North Korea fired 10-20 short-range projectiles, including Multiple Rocket Launcher and New-type Tactical Guided Missiles, from a base in Hodo peninsula located in the north of Wonsan, Kangwon. The projectiles flew about 70-230 km and landed in the sea between North Korea and Japan (coded at Sea of Japan).

SOURCE: AP; JoongAng Ilbo; Chosun Ilbo; YTN
NOTES: Change to armed group: On 9 May 2019, North Korea fired two short-range ballistic missiles from a base in Sino-Ri Kusong, North Pyongan province to waters off north-eastern coast of Hamgyong province, North Korea (coded at Coast of North Hamgyong). The projectiles flew about 420 kilometers (260 miles) to 270 kilometers (167 miles) and landed in the sea between North Korea and Japan.

On 30 June 2019, DPRK leader Kim Jong Un and US President Donald Trump met for the third time in Panmunjom inside DMZ (Joint Security Area). Trump became the first sitting US President to set foot on North Korean soil by crossing the military demarcation line in to the North. Trump, Kim, and South Korean President Moon then entered the South Korean side for talks. The DPRK leader and the US President agreed that the denuclearization talks would resume within weeks after their meeting on that day.

On 6 July 2019, the son of the former South Korean Foreign Minister defected and arrived in Pyongyang from South Korea. His parents defected to North Korea in 1986. His father was previously South Korea's ambassador in West Germany before defection and an official of the North Korean government after defection. His mother also took high positions in the North Korean government.

SOURCE: BBC News; KBS; JoongAng Ilbo; VOA
NOTES: Change to armed group: On 25 July 2019, North Korea fired 2 short-range ballistic missiles (SRBM) from a based in Wonsan, Kangwon. The projectiles flew about 430-690 km and landed in the sea between North Korea and Japan (coded at Sea of Japan).
Change to armed group: On 31 July 2019, North Korean military forces fired 2 short-range ballistic missiles from Hodo peninsula near the east coast town of Wonsan (coded at Coast of Kangwon).

Change to armed group: On 2 August 2019, North Korea fired two short-range ballistic missiles (SRBM) from the Yeongheung area, South Hamgyeong Province. The projectiles flew about 220 km towards the sea between North Korea and Japan (coded at Sea of Japan).

Change to armed group: On 6 August 2019, North Korea fired two short-range ballistic missiles (SRBM) from a base located in Kwail-gun, South Hwanghae. The projectiles flew about 450 km and landed in the sea between North Korea and Japan (coded at Sea of Japan).

Change to armed group: On 10 August 2019, North Korea fired two short-range ballistic missiles (SRBM) from a location near Hamhung-si, South Hamgyong Province. The projectiles flew about 400 km and landed in the sea between North Korea and Japan (coded at Sea of Japan).

Change to armed group: On 16 August 2019, North Korea fired two short-range ballistic missiles (SRBM) from a base located near Tongchon-gun, Kangwon Province. The projectiles flew about 230 km and landed in the sea between North Korea and Japan (coded at Sea of Japan).

Change to armed group: On 24 August 2019, North Korea fired two short-range ballistic missiles (SRBM) from the Sondok area of South Hamgyong province. The projectiles flew about 380 km and landed in the sea between North Korea and Japan (coded at Sea of Japan).

Change to armed group: On 10 September 2019, North Korea fired two short-range ballistic missiles (SRBM) from the Kaechon city area of South Pyongan province. The projectiles flew about 330 km and landed in the sea between North Korea and Japan (coded at Sea of Japan).

Other: Around 15 September 2019 (month of), it was reported that North Korea's former acting ambassador to Kuwait defected from North Korea (coded as Pyongyang) with his wife and child and entered South Korea. The South Korean government has not officially acknowledged his defection.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of Russia (2000-) Federal Security Service
NOTES: On 27 September 2019, over 260 North Korean fishermen were arrested by Russia's Federal Security Service (FSB) in the Sea of Japan for alleged illegal fishing.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of Russia (2000-) Federal Security Service
NOTES: Around 29 September 2019 (from 28 - 30 September), 87 North Korean fishermen were arrested by Russia's Federal Security Service (FSB) in the Sea of Japan for alleged illegal fishing. FSB claimed that another 174 North Korean sailors were saved by Russian border guards and would soon be returned home.

On 30 September 2019, 28 North Korean defectors in South Korea were reportedly returned to North Korea, after a report came out on the same day claiming that 12 North Koreans were brought to South Korea against their will.

Change to armed group: On 2 October 2019, North Korea fired two submarine-launched ballistic missiles (SLBM), presumed to be a Pukguksong-type, from the sea northeast of Wonsan, Gangwon province. The projectiles flew about 450 km towards the sea between North Korea and Japan (coded at Sea of Japan).

On 7 October 2019, a patrol vessel of a Japanese Fisheries Agency collided with a North Korean fishing boat allegedly fishing illegally in Japan's exclusive economic zone. Before the collision, the Japanese vessel had warned the North Korean boat, according to the Japanese Fisheries Agency. The collision happened at about 350 kilometres northwest of the Noto Peninsula (Sea of Japan). 20-60 North Korean fishermen fell overboard and were then rescued by Japanese authorities.

Change to armed group: On 31 October 2019, Military Forces of North Korea launched two missiles from a location a base near Sunchon city in South Pyongan province as part of the testing of its Multiple Launch Rocket System (MLRS). The projectiles flew about 370 km towards the sea between North Korea and Japan (coded at Sea of Japan).

On November 23, 2019, Military Forces of North Korea launched artillery fires from Changrin Island during Kim's visit, which landed in an unknown location. South Korea claimed the shelling violated the military agreement.

Change to armed group: On 28 November 2019, according to South Korean officials North Korean military forces fired 2 short-range missiles from the launcher near Yeanpo village (Ryonpho-Ri) in Hamju county of South Hamgyeong province into the East Sea (coded at Sea of Japan).

Change to armed group: On 7 December 2019, the North Korean government conducted a missile engine test at the Sohae Satellite Launching Station in Tongchang-ri, Cholsan. Observers estimated that the test was related to long-range ballistic missile technology. North Korea had boycotted nuclear talks for months and recently threatened to resume missile tests. Scholars believed that denuclearization was already off the negotiating table.

On 7 December 2019, according to South Korean officials North Korean military forces conducted a burn test of a rocket engine at the Sohae Satellite Launching Station in in Tongch'ang-ri, Pyeongbuk-do. North Korea had last conducted such a test in March 2017.
On 13 December 2019, North Korean military forces conducted an ICBM engine test at the Sohae Satellite Launching Station in Tongch'ang-ri, Pyeongbuk-do.

Change to armed group: On 14 December 2019, the North Korean government conducted a missile engine test at the Sohae Satellite Launching Station in Tongchang-ri, Cholsan. North Korea described it as ''crucial'', and experts worried that it could be a prelude to the possible launch of an intercontinental ballistic missile in the coming days. North Korea threatened to deliver a ''Christmas gift'' to the US in early December.
Around 29 December (between 28 - 31 December), North Korean declared that it would no longer be abiding by its self-imposed moratorium on nuclear and ICBM testing, which it had held to since 2018.

On 22 January 2020, the Government of North Korea introduced a series of measures to curb the spread of coronavirus, banning the entry of inbound visitors as well as foreign residents in the country to leave the country via China. On January 27, 2020, the Government of North Korea introduced a one-month quarantine program to be imposed on people arriving in the country from Chinese ports in a bid to curb the spread of coronavirus. The Sino-DPRK border city of Dandong lifted restrictions on April 9, signalling a resumption of the border city's economy. Quarantine measures in place around the Nampo-Dalian water route, North Korea's busiest trade route, appeared to have been lifted or scaled down around April 23-25 but were again implemented in late July.

On 24 January 2020, North Korea cancelled multiple flights between Pyongyang and Chinese cities in a bid to curb the spread of coronavirus. On January 31, North Korea shut down its land, sea, and air borders and asked Chinese authorities to temporarily stop sending North Korean defectors back into the country. North Korea also suspended all events, ceremonial visits, and meetings' in the country at least until the end of February.

SOURCE: AP; Rodong Sinmun; YNA; NK Pro
NOTES: Other: On 30 January 2020, the North Korean government announced a national emergency quarantine due to the risk that the new coronavirus pandemic could potentially pose (coded at Pyongyang). The two Koreas agreed to close down their liaison office in Kaesong, North Korea, due to the outbreak. As of April 3, 2020, Rodong Sinmun announced that there were no infected people in the country, although around 500 people are kept under quarantine.

Around 15 February 2020 (month of), North Korea extended its coronavirus-related suspension of all rail, air and sea routes in and out of the country until at least the end of the month, allowing only outbound movements of people via land crossings with China, closing the inter-Korean land crossings until further notice, banning all movements of foreign residents outside their residence except for an emergency visit to the hospital by ambulance, closing public amenities, tightening the internal travel within the country, and redoubling border inspections and medical surveillance on out-of-country returnees. The travel restrictions on foreign residents living in Pyongyang had been lifted on April 2. The Ministry of Foreign Affairs announced that lifting the restrictions prove how efficient the measures against the coronavirus are.

SOURCE: NK Pro; Kyodo News; AP; YNA
NOTES: Change to armed group: On 2 March 2020, according to South Korean officials North Korean military forces fired 2 short-range ballistic missiles from the launcher near Wonsan city into the East Sea (coded at Sea of Japan).

Change to armed group: On 9 March 2020, according to South Korean officials North Korean military forces fired at least 3 unidentified missiles from the launcher near Sondok city in South Hamgyong province into the East Sea (coded at Sea of Japan).

SOURCE: YNA; AFP; JoongAng Ilbo; AP; Korea Economic Daily; Kangwon Ilbo; Metro Seoul; Asia News International; News1; Kyunghyang Shinmun; Segye Ilbo
NOTES: Change to armed group: On 21 March 2020, North Korea fired two short-range ballistic missiles at Sonchon, North Pyongan to waters off the eastern coast of Hamgyong province, North Korea (coded at Coast of North Hamgyong). This has been recorded as the third missile test by North Korea in the year of 2020. (For the 1st and 2nd tests, 2 and 9 March 2020 respectively.)

SOURCE: Seoul Shinmun; DPA; Kyunghyang Shinmun; NEWSIS; AFP; AP; News1; YNA; JoongAng Ilbo
NOTES: Change to armed group: On 29 March 2020, North Korea fired two ballistic missiles from Wonsan, Kangwon to waters off the eastern coast of Hanmgyong province, North Korea (coded at Coast of North Hamgyong). The projectiles flew about 230 kilometres (143 miles) at a maximum altitude of 30 kilometres (19 miles). This has been recorded as the forth missile test by North Korea in the year of 2020. (2, 9, 21 and 29 March 2020 respectively.) This missile fire has faced international pushback from South Korea, Japan and U.S. among others for continuing military provocations amid COVID-19 (coronavirus) crisis.

SOURCE: AFP; YTN; Dong-a Ilbo; Kyongbuk Ilbo; Gyeongnam Ilbo; News1; Asia News International; Munhwa Ilbo; Segye Ilbo; Kukmin Ilbo; Seoul Shinmun; AP; NEWSIS; Kangwon Domin Ilbo; Korea Economic Daily; JoongAng Ilbo; YNA; Chosun Ilbo
NOTES: Change to armed group: On 14 April 2020, North Korea fired several cruise missiles from Munchon, Kangwon to waters off the eastern coast of Kangwon province, North Korea (coded at Coast of Kangwon). This cruise missile launch was recorded as the first time since June 2017. The projectiles flew about 150 kilometres (93 miles). Later the same day, North Korea launched several Sukhoi-class fighter jets from Wonsan, Kangwon, that fired an unspecified number of air-to-surface missiles toward the North Korea's eastern waters. Those launches came a day before North Korea marks the 108th birthday of North Korea's late founder, known as the Day of the Sun. They also came a day ahead of the South Korean national election.

SOURCE: AFP; AP; Daily NK; Channel News Asia; Radio Free Asia; NK Pro
NOTES: Security measures: On 24 July 2020, North Korea placed Kaesong City, North Hwanghae under lockdown, claiming that a redefector from the South had crossed the DMZ and was suspected of having coronavirus. South Korean officials confirmed the redefection, but stated it was unlikely the individual had contracted coronavirus in South Korea. Sources within North Korea have claimed that the lockdown measures on the borders and some ports has been followed by increased nationwide restrictions on movement. WHO placed the total number of people in quarantine in North Korea at 4,380. The lockdown of Kaesong City was lifted on 13 August 2020.

Other: Around 1 August 2020 (beginning of month), according to an anonymous source, an active-duty North Korean soldier working as an overseas labourer in Moscow defected. The defection was presumably for economic reasons, as the coronavirus has left North Korean overseas labourers in Russia with little work. It is reported that several such North Korea labourers have escaped from Vladivostok, Khasan, and Ussuriysk in Russia for similar reasons. On 5 September 2020, anonymous sources in North Korea reported that a soldier deserted his unit in Pyongyang during training for an upcoming military parade scheduled for October 2020. The desertion which occurred on 5 September is reportedly being considered by military authorities to be a major ''mistake'', as the soldier's unit is participating in an important national event.

On 2 August 2020, North Korea deployed 1,500 troopers from its 11th Corps - a special anti-terrorism unit - to the Chinese border in Ryanggang Province to strengthen enforcement along the border due to coronavirus concerns. Sources within North Korea increased the estimate to 3,000 troopers in both Ryanggang and North Hamgyong Provinces by 13 August 2020.

On 10 August 2020, military authorities in North Korea quarantined a company of soldiers from the 25th border guard brigade stationed along the Sino-Korean border in Ryanggang Province after one soldier came into contact with a Chinese national. The quarantine is planned to last two months, after which the soldiers will be inspected for any symptoms of coronavirus.

Around 15 August 2020 (month of), North Korea ordered all military units to focus on rebuilding areas damaged by flooding from typhoons instead of participating in summer training exercises. Anonymous sources within North Korea report that soldiers deployed to Unpha County in North Hwanghae Province for recovery efforts are stealing from locals, pawning off construction materials and more in exchange for bread, alcohol, and other basics.

On 20 August 2020, two North Korean women living in China were caught crossing into North Korea near Samjiyon in Ryanggang Province. As a result, the border cities of Samjiyon and Hyesan were locked down due to fears that the women may test positive for coronavirus.

On 20 August 2020, two North Korean women living in China were caught crossing into North Korea near Samjiyon in Ryanggang Province. As a result, the border cities of Samjiyon and Hyesan were locked down due to fears that the women may test positive for coronavirus.

On 25 August 2020, North Korean authorities ordered the suspension of all trade across the Sino-North Korean border in an effort to ensure that a military parade and mass rally celebrating the 75th anniversary of the founding of the communist party to be held on October 10 be unaffected by coronavirus fears. Although the border had already been officially shut down in January 2020, state-sponsored smuggling activities were still ongoing. In addition, on 27 August, local military and police units put into effect an order from the Ministry of State Security to shoot on sight anyone within one kilometre of the Sino-Korean border. This emergency declaration will reportedly be in effect until the pandemic ends.

On 25 August 2020, according to anonymous sources in North Korea, the Reconnaissance General Bureau (RGB) deployed around 500 troops to Pyongyang in an effort to protect secret RGB military facilities from damage during Typhoon Bavi. Other critical facilities in Pyongyang were protected by the Pyongyang Defense Command, Artillery Guidance Bureau, and other military units. In addition, soldiers from the West Naval Fleet and the army's Thirds Corps were deployed to Nampo Port to protect critical infrastructure from the typhoon.

Explosive remnants of war: On 7 September 2020, a massive explosive device went off at a typhoon recovery site in Kumgang county in Kangwon Province, according to an anonymous source. The device was a Korean War-era bomb that had been unearthed by heavy rains from Typhoons Maysak and Haishen, and resulted in the deaths of 2 government officials and 2 bomb squad technicians when they attempted to disarm it.

On 10 October 2020, North Korea held a military parade in Pyongyang to celebrate the 75th anniversary of the founding of the Workers' Party of Korea. The parade included a new ICBM, said by analysts to likely be the largest road-mobile ICBM to have ever been built and possibly capable of holding multiple warheads with multiple re-entry vehicle capability; North Korea has not yet publicly tested this ICBM. Also on display was North Korea's previous largest missile capable of carrying a nuclear warhead, the Hwasong-15, as well as a new SLBM dubbed the Pukguksong-4. Other signs of modernization in North Korea's conventional forces were evident. The country did not display any nuclear-capable missiles during its last military parade in September 2019 during peace negotiations with South Korea and the United States.

Detonation: Around 15 October 2020 (month of), an anonymous source reported that several soldiers of the 27th border guard brigade were injured in an explosion while laying landmines along the northern border in North Hamgyong Province in an attempt to stop border crossings during the coronavirus pandemic. The soldiers were reportedly untrained. The event is coded at Hoeryong City, the largest city on the Sino-North Korean border in North Hamgyong Province.

Detonation: Around 15 October 2020 (month of), an anonymous source reported that soldiers of the 25th border guard brigade and Special Forces were injured in an explosion while laying landmines along the northern border in Ryanggang Province (coded as Hyesan City) in an attempt to stop border crossings during the coronavirus pandemic. In mid-October 2020, one Special Forces soldier died and three more were injured in a similar project along Ryanggang Province border due to insufficient field training.

Security measures: On 27 October 2020, an anonymous source reported that counties along the Chinese border in North Hamgyong Province (coded as Undok, seat of Kyonghung County), were put under lockdown to prevent coronavirus and deter citizens and soldiers from attempting to flee to China during the coronavirus pandemic.

Security measures: On 27 October 2020, an anonymous source reported that counties along the Chinese border in North Hamgyong Province (coded at Onsong, seat of Onsong County), were put under lockdown to prevent coronavirus and deter citizens and soldiers from attempting to flee to China during the coronavirus pandemic.

Security measures: On 27 October 2020, an anonymous source reported that counties along the Chinese border in North Hamgyong Province (coded at Kyongwon, seat of Kyongwon County), were put under lockdown to prevent coronavirus and deter citizens and soldiers from attempting to flee to China during the coronavirus pandemic.

Security measures: On 27 October 2020, an anonymous source reported that counties along the Chinese border in North Hamgyong Province (coded at Musan, seat of Musan County), were put under lockdown to prevent coronavirus and deter citizens and soldiers from attempting to flee to China during the coronavirus pandemic.

Security measures: On 27 October 2020, an anonymous source reported that counties along the Chinese border in North Hamgyong Province, including Hoeryong City (coded as Hoeryong City), were put under lockdown to prevent coronavirus and deter citizens and soldiers from attempting to flee to China during the coronavirus pandemic.

Security measures: Around 1 November 2020 (beginning of month), anonymous sources reported that Hyesan City on the northern border of Ryanggang Province was put under a 20-day blockade after a smuggling incident, followed by the quarantining of more than 40 residents who were suspected of having coronavirus.

Detonation: On 8 November 2020, an anonymous source reported that one North Korean officer was killed and another soldier maimed in an explosion while inspecting landmines along the northern border in Ryanggang Province (coded as Hyesan City) in an attempt to stop border crossings during the coronavirus pandemic.

Security measures: Around 15 November 2020 (month of), anonymous sources reported that anti-aircraft artillery battalions under the 9th Corps were forward deployed to the norther border in Ryanggang Province (coded as Hyesan City) to deter citizens from attempting to flee to China during the coronavirus pandemic.

Security measures: Around 15 November 2020 (month of), anonymous sources reported that anti-aircraft artillery battalions under the 9th Corps were forward deployed to the border city of Hoeryong (Hoeryong City) in North Hamgyong Province to deter citizens from attempting to flee to China during the coronavirus pandemic.

Security measures: Around 15 November 2020 (month of), anonymous sources reported that anti-aircraft artillery battalions under the 9th Corps were forward deployed to the border county of Onsong in North Hamgyong Province to deter citizens from attempting to flee to China during the coronavirus pandemic.

Security measures: Around 15 November 2020 (month of), anonymous sources reported that anti-aircraft artillery battalions under the 9th Corps were forward deployed to the border county of Musan in North Hamgyong Province to deter citizens from attempting to flee to China during the coronavirus pandemic.

Security measures: On 21 November 2020, an anonymous source reported that all of Chagang Province (coded at Kanggye City) was put under a coronavirus lockdown after a breach in the quarantine of Wiwon County, which had been instituted on 16 November. In Wiwon County along the Chinese border, entire military and border patrol units were placed under quarantine after 5 members of the ''Storm Corps'' special forces and the border patrol units died of coronavirus-like symptoms.

Other: On 2 December 2020, around 40 foreign diplomats and humanitarian workers left North Korea (coded as Pyongyang) after the government signaled that coronavirus prevention measures would stay in place, leaving only 3 foreign humanitarian workers in the country. The workers left as they were unable to perform their duties under continuing coronavirus prevention measures. As of 19 November 2020, North Korea has reported 8,594 ''suspected'' cases of coronavirus in the county since the beginning of the outbreak, although the government continues to claim zero cases.

Change to armed group: Around 15 December 2020 (month of), an anonymous source reported that about 600 people working as administrative staff at Correctional Labor Camp Number 6 (Songgan County), including the head of the camp, were replaced due to constant controversies on human rights abuses at the camp. The move is seen as a way to soothe public indignation over this matter.
