NOTES: Other: Around 15 December 2020 (month of), 10 state security officials and border security command soldiers were executed due to the gold smuggling. Dozens of their families were sent to the political prison camps. Location coded at Pyongyang.

Other: Around 15 December 2020 (month of), a North Korean soldier stationed on the Sino-North Korean border to discourage border-crossings defected from Kimjongsuk County, Ryanggang Province after a superior officer harassed the soldier and pressed him for bribes.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Former Military Forces of North Korea (2011-)
NOTES: Other: On 25 December 2020, an anonymous source reported that an unidentified person who tried to cross the border to North Korea was shot and killed by a North Korean soldier stationed on the Sino-North Korean border (Kimjongsuk county, Ryanggang Province) in an attempt to stop border crossings during the coronavirus pandemic. The identity of a person who was killed is not confirmed, but it is assumed that he is the former North Korean soldier who had recently defected to China after a superior officer constantly harassed and pressed him for bribes.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of North Korea (2011-) State Security Department
NOTES: Arrests: On 5 January 2021, an anonymous source reported that about 20 key personnel who were part of North Korea's nuclear weapons and missiles development, including the head of the Second Research Center of the Central Committee's Bureau, were arrested by the State Security authorities for possessing videos of South Korean TV shows (location coded as Pyongyang).

Other: Around 8 January 2021 (between 5 - 12 January), three people were killed and two were injured by North Korean military and border patrol units stationed on the Sino-North Korean border in North Pyongan Province (coded as Sinuiju City) as they tried to defect or smuggle goods. Sources reported that on August 2020 North Korea has ordered military units and police to shoot on sight anyone in the country who goes within one kilometre of the Sino-Korean border.

SOURCE: BBC News; NK News; VOA; Daily NK
NOTES: Security measures: On 14 January 2021, North Korea held a military parade in Kim Il Sung Square, Pyongyang, to celebrate the end of the Workers' Party's Eighth Congress. Some previously unseen weapons, including submarine-launched ballistic missile (SLBM) and short-range ballistic missiles (SRBMs) were displayed during the parade. This is seen by many as a show of force to demonstrate their nuclear weapon capabilities, especially as it came just days before the inauguration of U.S. President-elect Joe Biden. It also worries the U.S and neighboring countries as the SLBMs are harder to detect in advance. However, the actual capabilities of these weapons have not yet been revealed or publicly tested.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of North Korea (2011-) Ministry of People's Security
NOTES: Change to armed group: Around 15 January 2021 (week of), North Korean authorities created a new guard unit, named the 41st Battalion, to put down demonstrations. The unit comprises about 900 top combat troops, commanders, and shooters from the Supreme Guard Command (coded at Pyongyang).

Other: On 18 January 2021, 3 family members were arrested near Hyesan City by North Korean military and border patrol units stationed on the Sino-North Korean border as they attempted to defect through Kimhyongjik County. As reported by Asia Press from a source inside North Korea, the man took opium as they were caught and was rendered unconscious.

Other: On 28 January 2021, 2 people were arrested by North Korean military and border patrol units stationed on the Sino-North Korean border in Ryanggang Province (coded as Hyesan City) as they tried to defect. As reported by Daily NK from a source inside North Korea, the arrested defectors were regarded as espionage agents and subjected to harsh torture. Sources reported that on August 2020 North Korea has ordered military units and police to shoot on sight anyone in the country who goes within one kilometre of the Sino-Korean border.

Security measures: On 29 January 2021, North Korean authorities imposed a lockdown in North Hamgyong province (coded as Chongjin City) to prevent the spread of coronavirus pandemic. The intensified social distancing measure restricted residents from leaving their homes. The government reinstated the action after the previous lockdown was lifted on 20 January.

Security measures: On 29 January 2021, North Korean authorities ordered a 30-day lockdown of Hyesan city in Ryanggang province to prevent the spread of the coronavirus pandemic. This 'confinement order' was placed to avoid the border residents smuggling Chinese products into North Korea after a smuggling incident. The lockdown mandates the residents to stay at home and not commute for work. All roads are blocked, and vehicle use is prohibited. The authorities put the first lockdown in Hyesan city in November 2020. The lockdown was lifted earlier than planned on 15 February due to unknown number of deaths owing to sickness and starvation.

Security measures: On 29 January 2021, North Korean authorities ordered a 30-day lockdown of Samjiyon city in Ryanggang province to prevent the spread of the coronavirus pandemic. This 'confinement order' was placed to avoid the border residents smuggling Chinese products into North Korea after a smuggling incident. The lockdown mandates the residents to stay at home and not commute for work. All roads are blocked, and vehicle use is prohibited. The lockdown was lifted earlier than planned on 15 February due to unknown number of deaths owing to sickness and starvation.

Other: On 31 January 2021, a man was shot and killed by the North Korean military and border patrol units stationed on the Sino-North Korean border near Musan County in North Hamgyong Province as he attempted to defect. Sources reported that on August 2020 North Korea has ordered military units and police to shoot on sight anyone in the country who goes within one kilometre of the Sino-Korean border.

Security measures: On 1 February 2021, the government enforced additional security measures in North Hamgyong (coded as Chongjin City) to close all bridges in the province, except the bridge in Saebyul Country which remains open for emergencies. The new measures were imposed to prevent the spread of the coronavirus pandemic.

Other: Around 1 February 2021 (beginning of month), a man chasing a goat was shot and killed by a North Korean border guard in North Pyongan Province (coded as Sinuiju City). The guard shot the person as he entered a buffer zone near the border lockdown line. North Korea maintains 'shoot-on-sight' orders at the borders to prevent the spread of coronavirus.

Other: On 2 February 2021, 2 defectors were shot by the North Korean military and border patrol units stationed on the Sino-North Korean border in Chagang Province (coded as Kanggye City) as they attempted to cross the border and pass across the river into China. As reported by Daily NK from a source inside North Korea, they were killed on the spot. One of the defectors was a border patrol soldier. Sources reported that on August 2020 North Korea has ordered military units and police to shoot on sight anyone in the country who goes within one kilometre of the Sino-Korean border.

Security measures: On 3 February 2021, North Korean authorities imposed a month-long lockdown in Chasong County (coded at Chasong) in Chagang province to prevent the spread of the coronavirus pandemic. The authorities placed this lockdown order after the incidents of smuggling and defections earlier this year. The lockdown was lifted earlier than planned on 17 February due to about 100 deaths owing to starvation.

Security measures: On 3 February 2021, North Korean authorities imposed a month-long lockdown in Manpho City in Chagang province to prevent the spread of the coronavirus pandemic. The authorities placed this lockdown order after the incidents of smuggling and defections earlier this year. The lockdown was lifted earlier than planned on 17 February due to about 100 deaths owing to starvation.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of North Korea (2011-) State Security Department
NOTES: Other: Around 15 February 2021 (month of), as a student living in Huichon City (Huichon) watching and distributing South Korean videos, his family members were confiscated all assets and sent to a political prison camp by the State Security Police due to guilt by association.

Security measures: On 2 March 2021, North Korean authorities ordered a 30-day lockdown of Sakju-gun in North Pyongan province. The reason for this lockdown is not yet confirmed, but it is assumed that the authorities placed this order to strengthen the border control after they found an individual who is on the missing person list smuggled himself into the country. The lockdown mandates the residents to stay at home and not commute for work. On 14 March 2021, North Korean authorities downgraded their previous 30-day lockdown order of Sakju County. This was to soothe public indignation over the death of a prematurely born baby, which mainly happened due to the lockdown. The new restrictions have eased the level of movement, including allowing people to leave their houses, but still prohibiting people moving in and out of the county. On 23 March 2021, the previous lockdown order of Sakju County was lifted. This was due to the worsened situations within the county, including the deaths of people from starvation.

Security measures: On 3 March 2021, North Korean authorities ordered a 30-day lockdown of Hyesan city in Ryanggang province. The reason for this lockdown is not yet confirmed, but it is assumed that the authorities placed this lockdown order to strengthen the border control after an illegal border crossing incident in early February. The lockdown mandates the residents to stay at home and not commute for work. All roads are blocked, and vehicle use is prohibited. On 4 March 2021, North Korean authorities downgraded their previous 30-day lockdown order of Hyesan city in Ryanggang province, which was imposed on 3 March 2021. This was due to the strong opposition of the local residents. The new restrictions have eased the level of movement, including allowing people to leave their houses from 6 pm and commute to work.

Security measures: On 3 March 2021, North Korean authorities ordered a lockdown of Samjiyon city in Ryanggang province to prevent the spread of coronavirus pandemic after catching an illegal border crossing. The authorities did not announce a specific period of the lockdown order and told the residents to stay at home and not commute for work.

Change to armed group: Around 15 March 2021 (week of), North Korean authorities commanded the Ministry of Social Security to form a new helicopter unit. The unit's role is to protect lives and safety during disasters and accidents, but it would also be utilized to track down defectors and criminals. The unit is based in Chunghwa County, North Hwanghae (coded at Chunghwa).

Change to armed group: On 17 March 2021, the Central Committee issued a directive to transfer the Oct. 3 Factory, a shipyard under control of the Navy's East Sea Fleet Command, to the Munitions Industry Department (MID). The authorities also promoted the status of the Oct. 3 Factory to a 'special status facility' and a special joint enterprise. According to a source, this change will presumably accelerate its production and development of submarines and submarine-launched ballistic missiles (SLBMs). Location coded at Pyongyang.

Change to armed group: On 21 March 2021, North Korea fired two short-range cruise missiles from Onchon (South Pyongan) to the Yellow Sea. This has been recorded as the first missile test by North Korea in 2021, and it has been 11 months since the last missile test.

SOURCE: VOA; NK News; Channel News Asia; AP
NOTES: Change to armed group: On 25 March 2021, North Korea fired two short-range ballistic missiles, which are considered to be a new type of 'tactical guided projectile', from Hamju (South Hamgyong) into the East Sea (also known as the Sea of Japan). The projectiles flew about 450 kilometers (280 miles) with an altitude of 60 kilometers (37 miles). This was the first ballistic missile launch since March 2020.

Security measures: On 1 April 2021, North Korean authorities deployed soldiers from Construction Bureau 8 as a construction troop to Uiju in North Pyongan Province, on the border between North Korea and China. The authorities plan to install barriers and high-voltage wires along the entire border to increase border security and deter people from smuggling goods over the border. About a total of 1000 soldiers were deployed in the North Pyongan Province border area.

Security measures: On 1 April 2021, North Korean authorities deployed soldiers from Construction Bureau 8 as a construction troop to Yongchon in North Pyongan Province, near the border between North Korea and China. The authorities plan to install barriers and high-voltage wires along the entire border to increase border security and deter people from smuggling goods over the border. About a total of 1000 soldiers were deployed in the North Pyongan Province border area.

Security measures: On 1 April 2021, anti-aircraft machinegun troops stationed near the borderline at Ryanggang Province (coded at Hyesan City) have begun to withdraw from their military bases. The troops were forward deployed in early November of 2020 to block people's illegal activities, such as defection and robbery, during the coronavirus pandemic. The withdrawal of forces is likely due to other troops' forward deployment for installing high-voltage wires and barriers at the border.

Other: Around 5 April 2021 (between 23 March - 19 April), over the four weeks, the North Korean authorities mounted a cylindrical object in the central position on its submersible missile test stand barge at the Nampo Navy Shipyard (coded at Nampo), indicating that the authorities could have been preparing to test a submarine-launched ballistic missile (SLBM).

Security measures: On 12 April 2021, a 'special security week' was enforced by the North Korean authorities to raise the level of security in the country before the Day of the Sun (Kim Il Sung's birthday on 15 April). According to a military authorities source, the armed soldiers near the DMZ were provided with rounds of live ammunition to be fully equipped and prepared for any incidents near the border areas, such as the defection of a North Korean man to South Korea by swimming on 16 February. Location coded at Pyongyang.

Security measures: On 28 April 2021, the North Korean government ordered citizens to stay indoors over a yellow dust storm coming from China. Especially, Pyongyang citizens were banned from outdoor activities from midnight until 10:00 am on April 28 (location coded as Pyongyang). This appears to be preventive measures against the coronavirus as the North Korean authorities previously claimed that yellow dust could carry coronavirus into the country.

Other: On 3 May 2021, families of two Organization and Guidance Department (OGD) officials were deported to South Hwanghae province (coded as Haeju City) by the North Korean authorities. It was due to the officials' alleged corruption and acceptance of bribes.

Security measures: On 10 May 2021, a 'special security week' was enforced by the North Korean authorities to raise the level of security for the next fifteen days. According to a military authorities source, this order was given due to the upcoming ROK-U.S. summit scheduled on 21 May. Additionally, on 15 May 2021, the North Korean military authorities started to conduct fifteen days of military drills that train soldiers to attack the enemy from behind. According to a military authorities source, this order was also given due to the upcoming ROK-U.S. summit scheduled on 21 May. Location coded at Pyongyang.

Detonation: On 13 May 2021, two soldiers who secretly went to Tumen River to take water to wash their clothes, died after stepping on a minefield. The two soldiers were working on building electric wire fences and concrete walls on the Sino-North Korean border near Hoeryong City, North Hamgyong Province.

Around 15 May 2021 (month of), ten commanders of construction units, such as the Seventh General Bureau and Eighth General Bureau, were arrested by the Military Security Command for allegedly engaging in corrupt construction practices. Most likely the arrests took place in Pyongyang (Pyongyang).

Looting: On 15 May 2021, four North Korean soldiers blocked a military vehicle and looted gasoline in exchange for bread, cigarettes, and other basics. They were deployed to Kangwon Province for military drills and plundered the car at the Kosung-Chorwon Road in Kangwon Province (coded as Wonsan). They were arrested after they arrived at their training spot.

Other: On 15 May 2021, a 52-year-old major general on the Seventh General Bureau's political committee was publicly executed near the riverbank of the market area of Pyongyang's Hyongjesan District (Pyongyang) for engaging in corrupt construction practices while handling national construction projects.

Choe Sang Gon, has been arrested and sent to a political prison camp in North Hamgyong province for negligence in activities focused on child education (coded at Pyongyang). He was arrested during the enlarged meeting of the Second Politburo of the Eighth Central Committee.

Security measures: On 30 June 2021, a 'special security week' was enforced across the country by the North Korean authorities to raise the level of security for the next nine days. According to a military source, this order was given to tighten the military discipline and to prevent unexpected disturbances due to the demotion of some top military officials. Location coded at Pyongyang.

NOTES: Other: Around 1 July 2021 (beginning of month), as a woman living in Hoeryong (Hoeryong City, North Hamgyong) was caught for using a Chinese-made mobile phone, her family members were deported to a rural area by the State Security Police. She was sent to a political prison camp on charges of espionage.

Change to armed group: On 11 July 2021, the North Hamgyong Provincial branch of the Workers' Party of Korea (WPK) ordered the establishment of 'autonomous internal disciplinary units' composed mainly of provincial Socialist Women's Union of Korea organizations and their members (coded as Chongjin City of North Hamgyong Province). As reported by Daily NK from a source inside North Korea, the unit was recently established to eradicate 'anti-socialist and non -socialist behavior.'

Looting: Around 15 July 2021 (week of), a group of soldiers threatened a resident on the road at Pyongsan county and stole his belongings. As reported by RFA from a source inside North Korea, the military is robbing and assaulting citizens on the streets to secure materials, such as cigarettes, cash, food, and other things. These robbing incidents are done to fulfill the items needed to celebrate the national holiday called the 'Day of Victory in the Great Fatherland Liberation War (27 July).'

Looting: Around 15 July 2021 (month of), soldiers of a military unit in Panjuk-dong were involved in five robbery incidents at the residential areas in Chongjin City, stealing food and money for the upcoming national holiday on 27 July. As reported by RFA from a source inside North Korea, the military is robbing and assaulting citizens on the streets to secure materials, such as cigarettes, cash, food, and other things, needed to celebrate the national holiday called the 'Day of Victory in the Great Fatherland Liberation War (27 July).'

Other: On 18 July 2021, two people were shot by the North Korean military and border patrol units stationed on the Sino-North Korean border in Hyesan City as they attempted to defect to China. As reported by Daily NK from a source inside North Korea, they were killed on the spot. Sources reported that in August 2020 North Korea has ordered military units and police to shoot on sight anyone in the country who goes within 1~2 kilometer of the Sino-Korean border.

Other: Around 27 July 2021 (from 24 - 27 July), the North Korean government held a workshop of military commanders and political officers to discuss ways to enhance the North's military strength (coded at Pyongyang). It was the first such meeting since North Korea's military was founded. According to the official Korean Central News Agency, the North Korean leader Kim Jong Un ordered the workshop attendees to put more significant efforts into boosting their units' combat efficiency.

Other: Around 31 July 2021 (end of month), North Korean soldiers killed three Chinese fishermen who had drifted to an island in Cholsan County, North Pyongan Province, due to a typhoon. As reported by Daily NK from a source inside China, a Chinese fishing boat left the port of Zhanghe in Liaoning Province around 25 July to catch crabs near North Pyongan Province. The killing might have been triggered by a shoot on sight order enforced ever since August 2020 to contain the spread of the coronavirus pandemic.

Looting: Around 1 August 2021 (beginning of month), three soldiers from the Storm Corps (11th Corps) broke into the local warehouse of the Ministry of State Security (Hoeryong City) and robbed the food allegedly due to poor food supplies. They were caught at the scene by the patrol and discharged from the military. Also, their battalion commander, political guidance officer, and security guidance officer were deposed from their position.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of North Korea (2011-) Border Guard
NOTES: Other: On 11 August 2021, a man in his 20s was shot to death by the North Korean border guards near the Yalu River in Hyesan City as he was discovered entering the riverside. Sources reported that in August 2020, North Korea had ordered military units and police to 'unconditionally' shoot on sight anyone or animals that enter the established buffer zone 1 to 2 kilometers from the Sino-Korean border closure line.

Security measures: Around 15 August 2021 (week of), North Korean authorities deployed military officers to counties in Ryanggang Province to build makeshift structures to prevent border crossings and defections in border regions between North Korea and China (coded at Hyesan City of Ryanggang Province).

ACTOR1: Police Forces of North Korea (2011-) State Security Department
NOTES: Other: On 4 September 2021, as a Ministry of Social Security officer working at Hyesan Station (Hyesan City) was sent to a political prison camp for helping defectors, his family members were deported to a rural area by the State Security Police due to the guilt by association.

SOURCE: Radio Free Asia; VOA; KBS; AP
NOTES: Change to armed group: On 11 September 2021, North Korea launched new long-range cruise missiles, its first low-flying missiles capable of hitting targets in Japan. The missiles traveled for about two hours above the territorial land and waters of North Korea, hit targets 1,500 kilometers away, and fell into the country's territorial land. This was the fourth ballistic missile launch of the year 2021. The launch and landing exact locations are unknown. Event coded at Pyongyang.

SOURCE: KBS; Radio Free Asia; VOA; AP
NOTES: Change to armed group: On 12 September 2021, for the second consecutive day, North Korea launched new long-range cruise missiles in the air above the territorial land and waters of North Korea. The missiles fell into the country's territorial waters. The launch and landing exact locations are unknown. Event coded at Pyongyang.

SOURCE: VOA; AP; KBS; Radio Free Asia
NOTES: Change to armed group: On 15 September 2021, North Korea conducted two short-range ballistic missile tests from Yangdok that traveled 800 kilometers and reached a maximum altitude of 60 kilometers. The missiles landed in waters east of the Korean peninsula (coded at Sea of Japan). The missiles fell into waters within Japan's exclusive economic zone. This was the fifth ballistic missile launch of the year 2021.

SOURCE: BBC News; AFP; Asian News International; Daily NK; VOA; DPA; Radio Free Asia; AP; KBS
NOTES: Change to armed group: On 28 September 2021, North Korea's Academy of Defence Science test-fired its newly developed hypersonic missile 'Hwasong-8' in Toyang-ri, Ryongrim County of Chagang Province. The missile is reportedly fired to waters east of the Korean peninsula (coded at the Sea of Japan). The state-run Korean Central News Agency (KCNA) reported that the new hypersonic missile could deliver a nuclear payload. The latest missile launch was overseen by recently re-promoted Pak Jong-chon, a North Korean Marshal and a member of the Presidium of the Politburo of the Workers' Party, instead of the North Korean leader Kim Jong-un. The missile test was its third round of weapons firings in September 2021.

SOURCE: DPA; AP; VOA; Radio Free Asia; Xinhua; AFP; Asian News International; BBC News; Daily NK; KBS
NOTES: Change to armed group: On 30 September 2021, North Korea's Academy of Defence Science test-fired a new type of anti-aircraft missile, a defensive weapon system designed to destroy aircraft with a relatively short range. The launch and landing locations are unknown (coded at Pyongyang). As reported by the North's state-run Korean Central News Agency (KCNA), the test was conducted to confirm the practicality of operation of the launcher, radar, and comprehensive battle command vehicle, and the all-around combat performance of the missile. The missile test was reportedly watched by Pak Jong-chon, a member of the Presidium of the Politburo of the Workers' Party, and other defense and science officials. The missile test was its fourth round of weapons firings in September 2021.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of North Korea (2011-) Border Guard
NOTES: Other: On 30 September 2021, a man in his 50s was shot to death by the North Korean border guards near the Sino-North Korean border in Hoeryong City as he was discovered returning from China. Under the state's coronavirus emergency quarantine system, it is strictly prohibited to go to China. As reported by Daily NK from a source inside North Korea, the Ministry of State Security had known he had gone missing since mid-September.

SOURCE: AFP; AP; Asian News International; BBC News; VOA; DPA; Xinhua
NOTES: Other: On 4 October 2021, North Korea restored communication lines with South Korea 55 days after it cut a cross-border hotline. According to South Korea's unification ministry, officials from both Koreas exchanged their first phone call (coded at Pyongyang).

Around 7 October 2021 (from 1 - 15 October), the authorities, presumably police, arrested about 60 residents, mostly street vendors, in Hoeryong City and sent them to forced labor brigades for violating the nighttime curfew along the Sino-North Korean border. Beginning on 1 October, the authorities have strengthened the border security by extending the hours of its nighttime curfew from 6 PM to 7 AM. According to the report, the number of locals subjected to forced labor for breaking curfew has more than quadrupled from the same period last year in Hoeryong as of 15 October.

Other: On 11 October 2021, North Korea held a Self-Defence-2021 weapons exhibition in Pyongyang to celebrate the 76th anniversary of the founding of the Workers' Party of Korea. The exhibition featured an array of newly developed weapons, including intercontinental ballistic missiles (ICBM) North Korea has already test-launched or displayed during military parades in recent years. Other weapons on display were ballistic missiles fired from submarines or trains, solid-fueled, short-range missiles, and a developmental hypersonic missile that had its first test-flight in September 2021. North Korean authorities said it would continue developing weapons for self-defense.

SOURCE: DPA; Radio Free Asia; Daily NK; BBC News; KBS; VOA; AFP; AP
NOTES: Change to armed group: On 19 October 2021, North Korea test-fired a new submarine-launched ballistic missile (SLBM) from the '8.24 Yongung' submarine. The missile was launched eastward from a site in the vicinity of Sinpho City in North Korea's South Hamgyong province into the East Sea (coded at the Sea of Japan). As reported by the North's state-run Korean Central News Agency (KCNA), the missile traveled a distance of up to 450 kilometers at a maximum altitude of 60 kilometers. The test was the fifth missile launch since September 2021 and the eighth in 2021.

Change to armed group: On 22 October 2021, the North Korean military ordered military training camps in all branches to shift to 'No. 1 Combat Readiness,' in which units can immediately shift to wartime footing whenever a war breaks out. The order called on training camps to hold underground command exercises for 15 days from 23 October to 6 November and conduct 'mock attack drills.' According to the source, the order seems to respond to the South Korean military's 'Hoguk Exercise 2021' from 25 October to 5 November. Location coded at Pyongyang.

Looting: On 25 October 2021, as reported by Daily NK from a source inside North Korea, soldiers from the 12th Corps dispatched to Kapsan County (Ryanggang) robbed rice and livestock from the local civilians.

Security measures: On 19 November 2021, North Korean authorities ordered a two-week lockdown of Kimhyongjik County, Ryanggang Province, until 4 December. The order suspended travel permits for the county, banned vehicles and persons from entering the town, and closed markets. The reason for this lockdown is assumed to strengthen Sino-Korean border security after a man was arrested for returning from China while violating coronavirus quarantine rules.

Other: On 2 December 2021, North Korea's border guard soldiers shot three residents trying to flee across the Yalu River into China in the northern region of Ryanggang Province, Kimjongsuk County. One person was hit in the head and died instantly, while two others were arrested at the scene. The information of the three people and their motives for crossing the border is unknown. Under the state's coronavirus emergency quarantine system, anyone approaching the border river without permission would be shot without warning.

Other: On 25 February 2018, Kim Yong-chul, Vice Chairman of the Central Committee of the Workers' Party of Korea for South Korean affairs, visited South Korea leading the North Korea's Olympic delegation for the closing ceremony of the 2018 Winter Olympics in Pyeongchang, South Korea (coded as Ha). They had a series of talks with South Korean President Moon Jae-in, and other high-level officials. They shared faith in a peaceful relationship of the Korean peninsula.

ACTOR1: Police Forces of South Korea (2017-) Coast Guard
NOTES: On 19 May 2018, two North Koreans were spotted by the South Korean Coast Guard on a boat near Baengnyeong Island in South Korea's western sea. After expressing their desire to defect, the two men were handed over to South Korean intelligence services.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Labour Group (South Korea); KCTU: Korean Confederation of Trade Unions
SOURCE: Kyunghyang Shinmun; JoongAng Ilbo; Dong-a Ilbo; Jeonbuk JoongAng Ilbo
NOTES: On 26 January 2019, Jeonju Deputy Mayor and Taxi Branch Manager of the Korean Public Service and Transport Workers' Union (KPTU) under the KCTU reached an agreement at the meeting at Jeonju City Hall (Jeonju), on the management of full-scale monthly payment system. By signing the agreement, a 510 days of high altitude sit-in protest has ended.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: KCTU: Korean Confederation of Trade Unions; Labour Group (South Korea)
SOURCE: Chosun Ilbo; YTN; Hankyoreh; YNA; Dong-a Ilbo; JoongAng Ilbo
NOTES: On 21 June 2019, the chairperson of the Korean Confederation of Trade Unions (KCTU) was arrested in Seoul, under charges of illegal activity during KCTU rallies in opposition to the expansion of unit periods in the flexible working hour system.

Other: On 26 September 2019, South Korea's military fired warning shots at a North Korean patrol boat with 4 crewmembers affiliated with North Korean army, because the boat allegedly crossed the southern border of North Korea and entered South Korean waters near the western border island of Yeonpyeong (coded at Coast of Yeonpyeong, Ongjin, Incheon). The North Koreans said the vessel drifted because of engine failure, so South Korea sent a mechanic onboard to fix the vessel. This was the first time South Korea fired warning shots towards a North Korean vessel since the current administration took office in 2017.

Other: On 27 November 2019, South Korea's military fired warning shots to a North Korean civilian vessel at the waters near the southern border island of Socheong (event coded at Coast of Socheong, Ongjin, Incheon), claiming that the vessel crossed South Korea western sea boundary. The South Korean authorities believed, however, that the vessel did not cross the boundary intentionally. This was the second time South Korea fired warning shots towards a North Korean vessel since the current administration took office in 2017. The first time was in September 2019.

On 7 January 2020, it was reported that South Korea had moved a Patriot missile unit to Bukaksan Mountain in Gangbuk-gu, central Seoul from North Gyeongsang to better defend key facilities from North Korea. The Patriot missile is designed to intercept incoming aircraft and missiles at altitudes of around 20-40 kilometres.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Protestant Christian Group (South Korea); CCK: Christian Council of Korea
SOURCE: Dong-a Ilbo; Hankyoreh; Hankook Ilbo; JoongAng Ilbo; Chosun Ilbo
NOTES: On 24 February 2020, the chief of the Christian Council of Korea was arrested in Seoul, on charges of violating the Public Official Election Act for appealing for support for a particular political party at rallies in Gwanghwamun.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: KCTU: Korean Confederation of Trade Unions; FKTU: Federation of Korean Trade Unions; Labour Group (South Korea)
SOURCE: Korea Economic Daily; Seoul Shinmun; Chosun Ilbo; Hankyoreh; EDaily; Hankook Ilbo
NOTES: On 18 March 2020, as per government's request to restrain public gatherings during the COVID-19 (coronavirus) crisis, representatives from 'Federation of Korean Trade Unions (FKTU)' and 'Korean Confederation of Trade Unions (KCTU)' reached an agreement with government at the meeting at Blue House, Jongno, Seoul, announcing that the labour groups will stop public demonstrations, and expressing their resolves to cooperate with government to break though the current crisis.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Military Forces of the United States (2017-2021)
NOTES: Around 22 April 2020 (from 20 April - 24 April), military forces of South Korea and the United States carried out a five-day joint air exercise in South Korea, which has been suspended since 2018. This resumption came with North Korea's recent missile launches this year. North Korea immediately condemned the South Korean government for conducting the South Korea-U.S. joint military exercise.

SOURCE: Busan Ilbo; Hankook Ilbo; JoongAng Ilbo; YTN; Dong-a Ilbo; Chosun Ilbo; Segye Ilbo; Seoul Shinmun; Kyunghyang Shinmun
NOTES: On 28 September 2020, the former chief of the Korea Freedom Federation and the representative of Ilpa Manpa Patriots' Confederation in Seoul were arrested on charges of violating the Assembly and Demonstration Act and the Infectious Disease Control and Prevention Act. They were charged for organizing a rally in downtown Seoul in violation of the government's quarantine guidelines amidst of the coronavirus outbreak. [size=no report]

Other: On 8 January 2021, the Seoul Central District Court ordered Japan's government to pay reparations to 12 South Korean comfort women. The Japanese Prime Minister rejected the court's ruling. This might spark further protests on this issue in South Korea (coded at Seoul City).

Other: On 14 January 2021, the Supreme Court of South Korea has upheld former President Park Geun-hye's 20-year prison sentence on corruption and bribery charges. It was a final ruling, which ended the political scandal that led to the impeachment of the president in 2017. This might spark further protests on this issue in South Korea (coded at Seoul City).

Other: On 1 March 2021, President Moon Jae-in called for improved bilateral cooperation with Japan during his speech for the 102nd anniversary of the March 1 Independence Movement day ceremony. As addressed, the South Korean government is 'ready to sit down and have talks' with the Japanese government to resolve the past (historical) issues while maintaining a forward-looking partnership (coded at Seoul City). His speech, seen by some as a diplomatic turning point, is perceived as a departure from the usual harsh condemnation of Japan's atrocities during the colonial period.

SOURCE: AFP; AP; YNA; BBC News; News1
NOTES: Elections/referendum: On 7 April 2021, the 2021 South Korean by-elections for 21 electoral districts, including 2 metropolitan mayors for Seoul and Busan, 2 municipal mayors, 8 metropolitan council constituencies, and 9 municipal council constituencies, were held in South Korea. The main opposition People Power Party (PPP) won both Seoul and Busan mayoral elections (coded at Seoul City).

SOURCE: AFP; Dong-a Ilbo; News1; AP; Xinhua
NOTES: Other: On 21 April 2021, the Seoul Central District Court dismissed a lawsuit filed by a group of 'comfort women' who were forced to work in Japanese wartime brothels. The court upheld Japan's right to 'sovereign immunity' from overseas lawsuits, contradicting the ruling on 8 January that ordered Japan's government to pay reparations to the victims (coded at Seoul City).

SOURCE: YNA; Jeonnam Ilbo; Hankyoreh; NEWSIS; News1
NOTES: Other: On 7 June 2021, the Seoul Central District Court dismissed a lawsuit filed by 85 Korean victims of wartime forced labor and their families against 16 Japanese companies. The court said wartime forced laborers cannot claim individual legal rights to damages from Japan (coded as Seoul City). This development might bring further protests on the issue of 'comfort women'.

Other: On 29 June 2021, South Korea's National Assembly adopted a resolution condemning Japan's plan to dump radioactively contaminated water from its destroyed Fukushima nuclear plant into the sea (coded as Seoul City). The lawmakers urged the Japanese government to withdraw the release plan immediately.

Other: On 27 July 2021, the South Korean government announced that the two Koreas restored direct cross-border communication lines that North Korea severed in June 2020 to protest anti-North Korea propaganda leaflets flying in from South Korea. This development is regarded as part of two Korea's efforts to improve inter-Korean relations (coded as Seoul City).

Other: On 15 September 2021, South Korea tested a new submarine-launched ballistic missile following North Korea's short range ballistic missile test-launch on the same day. It is the first underwater-launched ballistic missile test conducted by South Korea. Event coded at Seoul City.

On 1 April 2018, former Finance Minister, Head of Cabinet Secretariat and member of the parliament of Mongolia was arrested by the Independent Authority Against Corruption of Mongolia in Ulaanbaatar together with three other officials, including former Director of General Intelligence Authority. The former Finance Minister, Head of Cabinet Secretariat and member of the parliament of Mongolia was accused of a corruption case related to the ''Oyu Tolgoi'' Investment Agreement.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: DP: Democratic Party (Mongolia); MPP: Mongolian People's Party
NOTES: On 10 April 2018, two former Prime Ministers of Mongolia were arrested by the Independent Authority Against Corruption, Mongolia in Ulaanbaatar on the same day. One ex-Prime Minister, who was accused of misusing the authority during the establishment of ''Oyu Tolgoi'' Investment Agreement, is currently a member of Mongolian People's Party, while the other, who was accused of making damage to the state as establishing ''Dubai'' Investment Agreement, is a member of Democratic Party.

ASSOC_ACTOR_1: Teachers (Mongolia); CMTU: Confederation of Mongolian Trade Unions
NOTES: Strikes: Around 10 September 2018 (as reported), over 100 educational organizations of Mongolia joined a teachers' strike at the national level which was launched by the Mongolian Education and Science Trade Union (affiliated with CMTU) from 3 September 2018 for an undetermined period. The teachers demanded a salary increase up to 50 per cent by the end of 2018.

On 29 December 2018, a special operation was conducted by police, intelligence and military forces of Mongolia in accordance with the direction given by the Prime Minister of Mongolia. It took place in Gurvan saikhan soum, Dundgovi province and terminated mining licenses of JPF LLC, a 100% Chinese invested company, for mining of Zuun (East) and Salkhit deposits from 2043 to 2047, and accusing the company for hiding of 930 million togrogs taxation.

On January 8, 2019, former Minister for Justice and Home Affairs of Mongolia D. Dorligjav and his younger brother were detained in the Detention Center No. 461 of the General Authority of Court Decision Execution. D. Dorligjav was arrested for a case that he allegedly took bribes of 4 million U.S. dollars from a mining company in his capacity as prosecutor general between 2012 and 2014. His case is indirectly connected to the political demonstration against MANAN (translated as Fog) injustice regime which was organised on December 27, 2018 and January 10, 2019, respectively.

On January 16, 2019, the Government of Mongolia made a decision to transfer a license of 'Asgat' silver deposit, which is located in Nogoon Nuur soum, Bayan-Ulgii province, Mongolia, to the State Owned Company 'Erdenes Mongol' LLC. Asgat is one of sixteen strategically important mining deposits of Mongolia.

SOURCE: Mongol News; AFP; Channel News Asia
NOTES: On January 29, 2019, M. Enkhbold, the Parliament Speaker was ousted from his post by the secret votes of the Parliament Members following several weeks of demonstrations demanded his resignation over a grant corruption scandal including a scheme to sell government posts for 60 billion tugrik.

On 23 April 2019, the former director of Mongolia's General Intelligence Agency was arrested. He was accused of breaching the laws on intelligence procedures by using torture to obtain confessions from defendants who were accused of the murder of a politician and pro-democracy leader.

On May 2, the State Great Khural (the Parliament) issued a decision to resign and appoint a new Head of the IAAC. A few days ago, civil society representatives demanded the resignation of the Head of IAAC during demonstrations.

On June 20, M. Enkhsaikhan, the former Prime Minister and former Deputy Prime Minister of Mongolia was arrested by the Independent Authority Against Corruption (IAAC) of Mongolia right after the investigation interview at the IAAC. He was accused of providing preferential treatment to others during the development of the Investment Agreement of Tavan Tolgoi mining.

On 14 August 2019, the Government of Mongolia approved a resolution about taking a total of 896.5 thousand hectares of land under Tost and Toson Bumba Nature Reserve which is located in Gurvantes soum of South Gobi (Omnogovi) province after termination of the license for mining granted to the 'South Gobi Coal Trans' company on a specially protected zone of Tost and Toson Bumba Nature Reserve. Prior to this resolution, local people and civil society groups protested for protection of this Nature Reserve.
On 25 September 2019, the leader of the 'Bosoo Khokh Mongol' non-government organisation was arrested in Uvs Province, Mongolia. He was accused of violating the rights of transgender citizens.

At the night between 29-30 October, police and intelligence agency of Mongolia detained around 800 Chinese citizens and seized approximately 1,000 high capacity computers and 10,000 mobile phone SIM cards of the Mongolian mobile operators. They were accused of money laundering and detained in several hotels in Ulaanbaatar where they were staying and working. The main organisers, including 4 Chinese and 1 Mongolian men were also arrested. Majority of them entered into Mongolia through tourist visas while some of them entered through business visas with a validity of 30 days.

Security measures: On 26 February 2020, the governor and the mayor of Ulaanbaatar issued a ban restricting entertainment, sports, cultural, and religious activities in Ulaanbaatar following a government resolution (no. 62, dated 12 February 2020) on the national heightened state of readiness for disaster protection. The new ban is intended to prevent the spread of the coronavirus pandemic. Public events, protests and demonstrations are prohibited. The ban was lifted on 11 November 2020.

On 28 March 2020, the head of 'Irgediin Shudarga Shuukh (Citizens Fair Court)' NGO, an influential figure in the Mongolian society, was detained for 30 days by the decision of the First Instance Court for Criminal Cases of Chingeltei District, Ulaanbaatar. He is accused of threatening and taking MNT 50 million from the former member of the Parliament. Outside the court, his supporters created a minor disorder trying to stop the vehicle carrying him to the detention centre.

SOURCE: Udriin Sonin; Montsame Agency; Unuudur; News.mn
NOTES: Arrests: On 11 April 2020, the head of ''Zov Amidrakh Ukhaan (Right Life Skills)'' a controversial human rights NGO was arrested in Ulaanbaatar-Bayanzu'rx for obstruction of law enforcement action and sexual assault. On 17 November 2020, the court sentenced him for 6 years and his wife for 1 year in jail for sexual assault, domestic violence and obstruction of law enforcement. Some claim that the arrests are politically motivated.

On 23 April 2020, a former Minister for Mongolia and 20th Prime Minister of Mongolia was kept in a custody until the next court hearing on 5th May 2020 by the decision of the Primary Criminal Court of Bayanzurkh, Sukhbaatar and Chingeltei Districts, Ulaanbaatar during the trial about accusing him in political sabotage and misuse of power during tenure as the Minister for Mongolia over an 'unsigned' agreement regarding the 'Tavan Tolgoi' coal mine project (one of the strategic priority deposits of Mongolia). The court considered that his too active engagement on the social media network is an attempt to influence the others related to the case. He was arrested on this case on 20 June 2019.

On 28 May 2020, a former MP, who was registered as an independent candidate by the General Election Commission to run in the upcoming Parliamentary Election in June 2020, was detained by the decision of First Instance Court for Criminal Cases of Chingeltei District, Ulaanbaatar during the court preliminary hearing of a case related to the former MP. The court decision justification was he breached Criminal Procedure Law as oppressing an investigator as calling to the investigator. The former MP and his lawyer deemed the court decision breached the Law on General Election and was made with pure political purposes.

On 13 June 2020, an MP and election candidate from the Mongolian People's Party (the ruling party), who runs in the forthcoming parliamentary election, was detained in the Detention Centre 461, located in Bayangol District, Ulaanbaatar, by the decision of First Instance Court for Criminal Cases of Bayanzurkh, Sukhbaatar and Chingeltei Districts, Ulaanbaatar as deemed he didn't come to the court hearing physically as well as didn't lodge 1 billion togrogs' bail. The MP has been accused of a criminal case about misusing of the power during his tenure as Prime Minister of Mongolia.

On 18 June 2020, three candidates, including former Finance Minister of Mongolia, who run in the forthcoming parliamentary election from Democratic Party were detained in Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia at the end of the trial with a justification that they didn't pay the cash bail since the last trial. They have been accused of a case about abusing of power during the negotiations for the Oyu Tolgoi agreements, namely the Investment Agreement between the Government of Mongolia and Ivanhoe Mines Mongolia Inc LLC and Ivanhoe Mines Ltd and Rio Tinto International Holdings Limited, signed on October 6, 2009, and the Oyu Tolgoi Underground Mine Development and Financing Plan, signed on 18 May 2015.
On 24 June 2020, the rulling party, Mongolian People's Party, secured a victory in the parlamentary elections.

Security measures: On 11 November 2020, the government decided to enforce a national emergency curfew (coded at Ulaanbaatar) starting from 12 November due to the first locally transmitted case of coronavirus. The heightened state of readiness for disaster protection was changed to public state of readiness for disaster protection. Public state of readiness was eased twice on 14-23 December 2020 and 11 January to 10 February 2021, respectively. During the curfew public events, protests and demonstrations are prohibited.

Non-violent activity: On 21 January 2021, the State Great Khural (Parliament) approved the request of the Prime Minister to voluntary step down with his entire cabinet following a massive protest held the previous day in Ulaanbaatar. During the protest, the demonstrators demanded the resignation of the State Emergency Commission. Two cabinet officials were members of this commission.

SOURCE: Udriin Sonin; MNB; Montsame Agency; News.mn
NOTES: Other: On 25 January 2021, a Member of Parliament from MPRP began a hunger strike at the Sukhbaatar Square (Ulaanbaatar-Su'xbaatar) demanding the Government take the matter of the Oyu Tolgoi project (a strategic copper and gold deposit) Investment Agreement to the international court by 31 January 2021. The MP claims that the Investment Agreement concluded in 2009 between the Government of Mongolia and Rio Tinto is not beneficial to Mongolia. His hunger strike led to protests and public outrage. He stopped the hunger strike on 29 January when the Government took legal action to the New York court.

Non-violent activity: On 27 January 2021, a new Prime Minister, member of the MPP, was appointed by the State Great Khural (the Parliament) to replace the former Prime Minister who resigned with his entire cabinet the previous week due to a mass protest (event coded at Ulaanbaatar). A new cabinet was formed on 29 January. Eight Ministers are from the recently dismissed cabinet, while eight Ministers are newly appointed. All are members of MPP.

Security measures: On 10 February 2021, the government issued a decree to enforce 'public state of readiness for disaster protection' starting from 11 February to limit the spread of coronavirus. Severe restrictions of movement were enforced in Ulaanbaatar. Consequently, 90 percent of public movement was prohibited in the capital. The 'public state of readiness for disaster protection' state ended on 23 February. Some restrictions were lifted and the ' heightened state of readiness for disaster protection' was implemented.

SOURCE: Sonin.mn; Montsame Agency; Udriin Sonin; Shuud.mn
NOTES: Security measures: On 15 March 2021, level 3 (orange level) of the 'heightened state of readiness for disaster protection' was implemented in Ulaanbaatar. The new restrictions ban public gatherings and demonstrations for 14 days to limit the spread of coronavirus. The level 3 was ended on 9 April 2021.

SOURCE: Shuud.mn; Udriin Sonin; Shuurhai; Newspress.mn; Itoim.mn
NOTES: Other: On 25 March 2021, a brother of a female prisoner (one of two prisoners who confessed to murdering a prominent Mongolian politician) began a hunger strike at the central square of the capital (Ulaanbaatar-Su'xbaatar) demanding the state's leaders to release his sister. He stated that his sister is innocent and her confession to the murder was obtained by means of torture. He accuses the ex-chief of the intelligence agency for torture acts conducted to his sister since 2013 for several years. This case is under a high level of public attention, thus might lead to further protests.

Around 2 April 2021 (week of), an activist and a member of Xan-Uul District council were arrested in Ulaanbaatar. They were arrested for staging a sit-in during the coronavirus restriction which bans gatherings and demonstrations. During the sit-in the activist demanded the government to provide citizens transparent information regarding the newly introduced 3% interest loan and equally allocate loans to each citizen.

SOURCE: Medee.mn; News.mn; Udriin Sonin; Itoim.mn; Montsame Agency; Ikon.mn
NOTES: Security measures: On 10 April 2021, level 4 (Red Level) of the 'public state of readiness for disaster protection' was implemented nationwide including in Ulaanbaatar. The new restrictions continue to ban public gatherings and demonstrations to contain the spread of the coronavirus. On 8 May 2021, level 4 (Red Level) was ended.

SOURCE: Ulsturch.mn; News.mn; Polit.mn; Ikon.mn; Itoim.mn; Montsame Agency
NOTES: Other: On 19 April 2021, the President of Mongolia issued a decree to dissolve the ruling party, Mongolian People's Party (MPP). He accused the MPP of violating the Constitutional Law and the Law on Political Parties. The decree mentioned that the MPP 'has unlawfully transferred the constitutionally proclaimed state-oriented governance to party-oriented governance and attempted to take over the state power by unconstitutional means and militarize the Party's local offices and local governors'. This development might trigger protests or political instability in the country. Event coded at Ulaanbaatar.

Other: On 29 April 2021, the Mongolian parliament adopted an amendment to the Presidential Election Law, accepting a constitutional court decision from 16 April which states that the current president cannot run for re-election. The amendment is seen as highly controversial as any amendments to this law within one years before the elections are considered illegal under the current legal framework. Event coded at Ulaanbaatar. On 6 May 2021, the President of Mongolia vetoed the Presidential Election Law which was adopted by the Parliament on 29 April, looking for a legal option that would allow him to run for re-election. The President (DP member) claims that the ruling party (MPP) aims to establish a one-party dictatorship in the country and the changes made to the law by the MPP MPs violate the Constitutional Law.

SOURCE: Montsame Agency; Shuud.mn; Udriin Sonin; News.mn; Ikon.mn
NOTES: Elections/referendum: On 9 June 2021, former Prime Minister and chairman of the ruling Mongolian People's Party (MPP), Ukhnaa Khurelsukh, won the presidential elections. Khurelsukh's victory is expected to further consolidate the power of the ruling MPP. Event coded at Ulaanbaatar.

On 5 July 2021, a brigadier general of the police forces was arrested by Mongolia's General Intelligence Agency in Ulaanbaatar. He is accused of disclosing state secrets, espionage and illicit enrichment.

ASSOC_ACTOR_2: Police Forces of Mongolia (2016-); Military Forces of Mongolia (2016-); Government of Mongolia (2016-)
SOURCE: Itoim.mn; News.mn; Shuurhai; Ubmedee.mn; Polit.mn; Zarig.mn; Unuudur; Ulsturch.mn
NOTES: On 6 July 2021, six government officials of Zamyn U'ud soum were arrested in Zamyn-Uud, Dornogovi. They were all accused of corruption and abuse of power. The soum governor, a frontier military platoon leader and a traffic police senior officer were among them.

SOURCE: Zarig.mn; Unuudur; Ikon.mn; News.mn; Zuunii Medee; Polit.mn
NOTES: On 3 August 2021, the former general prosecutor of the capital city prosecution office was arrested by the Independent Authority Against Corruption in Ulaanbaatar. He was accused of abuse of power and money laundering. According to informal sources, a large amount of money and confidential documents related to politicians were found from his home.

On 4 August 2021, a whistleblower was arrested by the police in Ulaanbaatar before a press conference. He planned to hold a press conference to disclose information related to his father's death who died under mysterious circumstances after he accused the ruling party of using vote-counting machines during the recent presidential election. The whistleblower was previously arrested because he claimed that the ruling party cheated to win the elections and used vote-counting machines.
